chat_gpt_summary: Queensland-based company, Transportable Shade Sheds, has gone bankrupt, leaving many of its customers and workers out of pocket. The company, which was founded in 2002, owed over $1.3 million to 160 creditors and trade suppliers. The liquidator will not continue the company's operations. The company's director, Robert Salomon, is under investigation, and the company's assets are being sold to pay its debts. Customers have vented their frustration on social media, and some have joined a Facebook group to seek help. The liquidator has advised creditors to submit a Proof of Debt form to register their claim.
article:
A shed supplier on the Sunshine Coast has become the latest casualty to join a spate of companies in the sector which have gone bankrupt in recent months.
Mooloolaba-based business Transportable Shade Sheds has left dozens of Australians out-of-pocket and have failed to pay their workersâ leave entitlements after going into liquidation on April 3.
The failed company is now under external administration and owes more than $1.3 million to about 160 trade suppliers and creditors.
Bill Cotter of Robson Cotter Insolvency Group was appointed liquidator of the company following its collapse.
There are an additional five other companies set up as a group of related entities which have also ceased trading including Vanquish Holdings Pty Ltd, Bend Tube Designs Pty Ltd, Sable Labour Hire Pty Ltd, Tochlo Pty Ltd and TSS Dealers Pty Ltd. 
âThe businesses had ceased to trade shortly prior to the date of liquidation,â a statement from the liquidators read on its website. 
âThe Liquidator will not be trading-on the business operations of the companies during the liquidation process.â
An investigation into the cause of the companies failures is now underway, with the insolvency group currently âsecuring and realisingâ the assets.
Robson Cotter from the independent boutique advisory firm told the Courier Mail there were dozens of customers who had received partial or fully incomplete orders at the time the company went broke.
âThe amount potentially owing to customers with partially or fully incomplete orders delivered is currently unquantified,â he said.
Mr Cotter added several staff from the company were owed money for leave entitlements and superannuation.
Robert Salomon is understood to be the company director of Transportable Shade Sheds which was founded just over two decades ago in 2002.
Mr Salomon built the ânationally recognised company with international aspirationsâ alongside his partner Kylie, which offered a number of easy installation sheds, quickshades and canvacons.
âWe supply our Shade Sheds as a pre-engineered kit that has been designed for anyone to erect. So, no welding or technical knowledge is required,â the company explained on its website.
âWe swage the frames for you and with our slip fit connection system, it is just a matter of simply joining them together!â
The companyâs website remains active despite its insolvency with customers still able to make inquiries to order products.
As for its social media pages, there were little signs to show the company was struggling, with the last post made to the Transportable Shade Sheds (TSS) Instagram and Facebook accounts asking customers to send a picture of their installed purchase.
âHappy Friday! Check out this awesome shot from one of our customers! Have you got any photos of Your Shade Shed? Weâd love to see them,â the post is captioned.
âWe hope you all have a nice weekend!â
Customers who have been impacted by the companyâs closure have resorted to a Facebook group to vent their frustrations about the lack of notice they were given to suggest the company had gone bust. 
One loyal customer who has purchased seven sheds from the company said she ordered two sheds in June last year and paid the deposit only to never receive the products.
âIâm devastated, angry and canât wait for karma and the legal system to catch up with them so they can pay with what they have done to us and other families, including staff,â she wrote.
âThey chased us in the last two weeks for the balance of $15,000 and we refused to pay till the sheds were delivered to our premises in good order first. 
âIâm so glad we never paid them the extra money and now we have to see how we get our deposit back as we worked extremely hard for the money just like everyone else that got scammed by TSS.â 
Meanwhile one Victorian customer was left with the framework and anchors of a shed after he failed to receive its panels.
âI was told when the original framework was out for shipping, that the suppliers of the panels (are) state specific. Wondering if they are laying at a factory or depot somewhere in Victoria,â he said. 
âI really feel for those who have spent the money with zero to show for.â
A third person who claims they were a dealer and reseller for the company said he now has to find $90,000 to refund customer deposits for sheds âthey are not going to getâ. 
âItâs going to put me close to the edge, but I should hopefully just be able to keep my head above water after I have refunded my customers,â he said.
âAt least my customers will get every cent back whereas there must be hundreds, if not thousands of people around Australia that bought directly through them and will not get a penny back, I feel for them.â
The insolvency group recommends affected customers and creditors to submit a Proof of Debt form to register their claim via its email â admin@rcinsol.com.au. 
News.com.au has contacted both Robson Cotter Insolvency group and Transportable Shade Sheds for comment.
headline: Transportable Shade Sheds collapse: Customer furious after learning Sunshine Coast company owes $1.3 million

chat_gpt_summary: Sydney-based fashion brand Babyboo, founded by Argylica Conditsis when she was 17, is now worth $60m, with customers in almost 150 countries and a team of 40 employees. Conditsis started the business by investing $1,000 she saved from her part-time job at Pizza Hut. She initially sold bedazzled shoes before expanding to clothing. Babyboo pivoted to loungewear during Covid lockdowns, which saw sales boom. The company now plans to expand internationally further, launch new collections and move into a new office and warehouse.
article:
At just 17 years old, fashion-loving Argylica Conditsis took $1000 she had saved from her part-time Pizza Hut job and invested it in her âhobbyâ.
The Sydney teen had a âcrazy ideaâ to sell statement shoes, and began listing them online after embellishing and bedazzling them herself back in 2011.
They were an instant hit â and just 12 years later, her Babyboo Fashion brand has gone from a gamble that began in her bedroom to a growing fashion empire valued at a staggering $60 million.
Itâs not a bad achievement for a young woman who is yet to see her 30th birthday.
âIt has been a bit of a roller coaster after starting when I was really young â I had just finished high school and was on holidays between school and uni when we started,â she told news.com.au.
âI had been working late night and weekend shifts at Pizza Hut during school and making something like $6 an hour, so saving $1000 was a lot for me back then, and I put it all into stock.
âIt was definitely not supposed to be a business â it was just a hobby, but when we first put the shoes online they went viral. I popped them on a Facebook page and it kind of evolved naturally over time.â
Ms Conditsisâ brother William has been with her every step of the way, and she eventually âstole himâ out of uni to work on the business full time, after also dropping out of her own Visual Communications degree to focus on building up the brand. 
Within three years of launching the online business, the pair decided to expand into clothing, and after initially running Babyboo out of Ms Conditsisâ bedroom and taking over âevery inchâ of her parentsâ Baulkham Hills home, it was soon time to expand into a proper warehouse and office.
Today, Babyboo has customers in almost 150 countries around the globe, a team of more than 40 employees and 1.1 million Instagram followers.
Ms Conditsis said one of her secrets to success was really understanding her customers from day one.
âI started bedazzling shoes myself because there were just no products like them out there â¦ I always liked to be the one that stood out with outfits and I realised weâd have to start (making them) ourselves as there was a gap in the market,â she explained.
âIf youâd told me back then weâd be as big as we are today I would have laughed at you â thereâs no way I would have believed it and it is now so much bigger than I ever imagined.
âWe never had a business plan or goal and each year that the business would double would come as a surprise.
âNow itâs more of a structured business with processes and strategies but in the early days it was all trial and error and learning from our mistakes quickly.â
The now-29-year-old said it was a blessing to work so closely with her brother.
âIt has been great to join forces with him â weâre so alike, but have our own strengths and weaknesses that work well together,â she said.
âWill is really good at understanding operations and processes and is very creative as well, and I focus more on the product, brand and social side of things.â
She said the biggest achievement for her personally was building a business from âabsolutely nothingâ with no financial backing to one now valued at $60 million, which has also allowed her to build up a team and community of women who âshare the same passionâ.
âWe empower a lot of women around the world by making them feel good, weâre with hundreds of thousands of women worldwide for all their special occasions,â she said.
âDressing them and making them feel empowered is what gets me up every morning â itâs not just a business, it actually serves a purpose.â
However, it hasnât all been smooth sailing.
Like most retailers, Babyboo took a hit during the Covid pandemic, but was able to quickly pivot and expand into loungewear, which was soon snapped up by those living through brutal lockdowns.
The move saw sales boom â and now, the next step for the thriving business is continuing its international expansion, settling into a new office and warehouse and launching new collections to increase the offering for customers. 
When it comes to advice for other budding young entrepreneurs, Ms Conditsis said it was simple.
âI always say never compare your chapter one to someone elseâs chapter six â eventually, youâll get there, after going through a process of evolving and learning,â she said.
âWhen I was young, there were a lot of people who didnât take me seriously and I got a lot of nos, but I think most of the businesses that will rise in the coming years will be from young people, who are very in tune with social media and have a lot to offer.â
headline: How Argylica Conditsis turned Babyboo Fashion into $60m empire

chat_gpt_summary:
The Royal Automobile Club of Queensland (RACQ) released a weekly quiz on its Facebook page, asking Australian motorists when they should indicate when using a roundabout. The quiz provided four options, and the correct answer is option B, which is to indicate right on approach and driving in the roundabout and indicate left when leaving.

While the majority of the respondents answered correctly, many commented that most drivers don't indicate correctly or at all. Some drivers even indicate right to go straight ahead, which is incorrect.

article:
A basic Aussie road rule about roundabouts has been stumping drivers across the country. 
The Royal Automobile Club of Queensland (RACQ) released its weekly quiz, this time asking Australian motorists when they should indicate when using a roundabout.
Four options were provided in the quiz: 
A) No indicator on approach and driving in the roundabout, right indicator when leaving. 
B) Right indicator on approach and driving in the roundabout, left indicator when leaving. 
C) Right indicator on approach and driving in the roundabout, no indicator when leaving.
D) No indicator on approach, right indicator when in the roundabout and left when leaving.
The correct answer is, of course, B. 
The post on Facebook has generated over 1200 comments.
And while the majority who answered were correct, many lamented the inability of road users to get it right.
One person wrote that âmost people in real life donât do itâ.
Another woman wrote: âNo indicator at all seems to be the rule where I live.â
Meanwhile another complained about âthe amount of people I see indicating right to go straight ahead on a roundaboutâ.
One person noted that 95 per cent of responses had the correct answer but still ânobody indicates correctly when they are at the roundabout in their carâ. 
âThey either donât indicate or indicate incorrectly,â they said.
The RACQ runs the weekly quiz on its Facebook page in a bid to educate motorists so they can become safer road users.
headline: Easy roundabout question stumping Australians in RACQ driving quiz

article:

article:

Visible in the footage but unbeknown to the two dogs, a large crocodile quickly ascends, snatching the smaller of the two dogs in its mouth before hurtling it in the air and disappearing from view.

article:
Terrifying dashcam footage has captured the moment a driver slams on the brakes as a young girl darts in front of his car on a Melbourne street.
âLuckily this driver was alert or this could have ended in tragedy,â wrote the Dash Cam Owners Australia Facebook page.
The video, which was filmed last Thursday afternoon, shows a young girl in pink pants dashing out from behind a parked car into the middle of the narrow street.
A man, presumably her father, has his back turned and appears to be doing some work on the house, which has a ladder propped up against the fence.
The driver slams on the brakes and the car screeches to a halt but still collides with the girl, bowling her to the ground as she tumbles over.
The man yells angrily and smashes his fist on the carâs bonnet before running to pick up the screaming girl, continuing to hurl abuse at the driver.
âSheâs alright? Sheâs alright?â the driver asks.
Victoria Police has been contacted for comment.
On Facebook, many users said the dad was in the wrong. 
âParent doing a parental reaction â¦ but FFS it wasnât the driverâs fault. Have better control of your kid around roads!â one person wrote.

One woman said the dad had âaudacityâ to hit the car after his child ran onto the road, while another man added âI hope the driver is sending the father a bill for a new bonnetâ.

Kids can be unpredictable. Thank goodness this ended the way it did for all involved â it could easily have been a tragedy,â one man said.
Another user suggested both sides bore âa bit of responsibilityâ.

chat_gpt_summary: Locals in Southern Tasmania witnessed a spectacular Aurora Australis, or Southern Lights, display, with colorful beams visible to the naked eye. Photographers and aurora chasers flooded social media with stunning images of the event, which is caused by energetic charged particles colliding with gases in the upper atmosphere. The lights are most visible in Australia and New Zealand's southern areas during this time of year, but they can occur at any time. Another aurora is expected in Australia's far south early Tuesday morning.
article:
Southern Tasmanian locals have flooded social media today with what has been described as the best Aurora Australis (aka Southern Lights) display âeverâ. 
Experts say youâll be able to see the lights from Tasmania and coastal parts of Victoria tonight, but it looks to be weaker.
Tassie is no stranger to the light event though they are usually faint and hard to spot without the aid of a long exposure photograph.
But this morning around 5.15am the display put on a show, with colourful beams reportedly visible to the naked eye. 
Toby Schrapel, a freelance photographer from The Huon Valley, 40 minutes south of Hobart, described the moment he and his son saw the rare event. 
âWe could see full colour to the naked eye â not quite like what the camera sees, but it was the most colour (Iâve) ever seen,â he said. 
He had been camping with his son in the valley when it happened, and they were both blown away by the southern lights. 
âHarlan then told me âThis is so special to see the magic sky colours with you daddyâ â So Iâm never forgetting this one,â he said. 
âMay have started another aurora chaser.â
A Tasmanian Facebook group dedicated to snapping and forecasting the event when it comes around was bombarded today by incredible pictures and accounts. 
âIt was amazing to see beams and movement last night visible to the naked eye,â one aurora chaser wrote. 
âAbsolutely insane show tonight,â another wrote. 
Auroras, also known as the Northern and Southern Lights, occur when energetic charged particles travelling along the Earthâs magnetic field lines collide with gases in the upper atmosphere, emitting light. 
Astonishingly, there are some reports of the lights even being visible in Victoria and New South Wales. 
Some amazing photos being posted to various Aurora groups on Facebook. Visible in NSW, images taken from #Kiama and #Dubbo at 5am. Severe G4 KP8 Geomagnetic Storm event.#aurora#southernlights#AuroraAustralis#spaceweather#kp8#geomagneticpic.twitter.com/fwaHjwzC8P
#AuroraAustralis on #Gunditjmara country western Victoria, Australia at 5am this morning pic.twitter.com/8vzn3cX5vI
Aurora Borealis is the term used to describe the phenomenon in the northern hemisphere, while Aurora Australis is used in the south. 
These lights are most visible in Australia and New Zealandâs southern areas during this time of year, although they can occur at any time. 
According to the Australian Space Weather Forecasting Centre, auroras are most likely to appear in March and September due to the Earthâs orientation relative to the sun and the likelihood of solar storms. 
The atmosphereâs composition determines the shades of an aurora, with more oxygen-producing greens and yellows and more nitrogen resulting in dark red or blue.
Bureau of Meteorology says another aurora is likely for Australiaâs far south early Tuesday morning.
headline: Aurora Australis: Strong naked eye Southern lights up Hobart Tasmanian skies

chat_gpt_summary: Around 18,000 cows died in a Texas barn fire following an explosion on Monday. It is thought that machinery in the facility may have ignited methane gas, leading to the deadliest barn fire for cattle in the history of Texas. article:
About 18,000 cows have been killed in a âhorrificâ explosion and fire at a dairy farm in the southern US state of Texas.
One agricultural worker was also injured, authorities said on Thursday.
Itâs thought that machinery in the facility may have ignited methane gas.
âThis was the deadliest barn fire for cattle in Texas history and the investigation and clean-up may take some time,â Texas Agriculture Commissioner Sid Miller said in a statement.
The explosion and fire ripped through the Southfork Dairy Farms near the town of Dimmitt in the Texas Panhandle on Monday night.
A photo showed an enormous plume of smoke rising into the sky following the incident. 
Many of the cattle died because a fire spread to an area where the cows were being held before being taken to a milking area and then into a holding pen, the BBC reports. 
âThereâs some that survived,â Sheriff Sal Rivera told local news outlet KFDA.
âThereâs some that are probably injured to the point where theyâll have to be destroyed.â
Firefighters and police rushed to the scene and âdetermined that one person was trapped inside,â the Castro County Sheriffâs Office said on Facebook. The person was rescued and flown to a hospital in Lubbock, it said.
The cause of the explosion and fire were not immediately clear, said Miller, who described it as a âhorrific event.â
âOnce we know the cause and the facts surrounding this tragedy, we will make sure the public is fully informed â so tragedies like this can be avoided in the future,â he said.
Castro County Sheriff Sal Rivera told the CBS affiliate in Amarillo that a system to remove manure from the barns may have gotten âoverheated.â He said methane may have âignited and then spread out with the explosion and the fire,â adding that a probe would have to determine the precise cause.
âFarms must do more to protect animals by adopting commonsense fire safety measures,â tweeted the Animal Welfare Institute, one of the oldest animal welfare charities in the United States, referring to the Texas tragedy.
- with AFP
headline: 18,000 cows die in âhorrificâ explosion

article:
Disturbing dashcam footage has captured the moment a woman appears to leap in front of a car south of Brisbane before the driver speeds away, suspecting an âinsurance fraud incidentâ â or worse.
The video, posted by the Dash Cam Owners Australia Facebook page, was taken in the early hours of Tuesday morning in Browns Plains, south of Brisbane.
A woman with dark hair wearing jeans and a light hoodie is seen suddenly running from the left hand side of the road in front of the moving vehicle.
She appears to brace herself and jump up towards the bonnet as the driver brakes, knocking her to the ground.
The driver reverses back as a man runs from the other side of the road to the womanâs side, yelling at the driver to stop â but the person behind the wheel drives around the couple.
âDashcam footage of alleged insurance fraud incident,â the page wrote. 
âThere were several people approaching from behind the vehicle instantly after the incident, driver fled due to risk of carjacking/suspecting a fraudulent claim at 3am in Browns Plains.â
A Queensland Police spokeswoman said police were âaware of a video circulating on social media where a female walks out in front of a vehicle and is struck on Browns Plains Road at Browns Plains on May 2â.
âThe driver reported the incident to police shortly after the incident,â she said.
âPolice attended the location but were unable to locate those involved. No formal complaint has been made to police at this time however investigations are ongoing into the circumstances surrounding the incident.â
The video has been viewed more than 70,000 times with nearly 1000 comments.
âI had one of them,â one man wrote.
âI drove off as there was a group of them hiding in the bushes. They called the police and reported a hit [and] run. Police came and watched my dashcam with front and rear cameras. 
âNo action was taken as the girl did the exact same thing. Ran out and I stopped. Then she bumped into my car. Itâs a scam and an attempt at carjacking. This is very common in Europe and becoming common here. Mine occurred down the Gold Coast.â
âThat must have hurt â¦ hopefully!â a woman said.
âSo he gets his missus to take the hit, what a kind and considerate guy he is,â another man added.
âFinally natural selection is coming back â¦ but to help the selection process donât hit brakes,â a fourth person wrote.
One woman sparked disbelief with her take on the video.
âThey are kidding arenât they?â she wrote. âThey knocked her down and drove away. If they were scared they could [have] backed off and locked their doors, call an ambulance.â
One person replied, âYouâve lived a sheltered life havenât you.â
Another said, âYouâre the kind of person who gets carjacked.â
A third woman explained, âIf this happened to me, and a group of people were surrounding my car and approaching on all angles, Iâd be getting the hell out of there as well. 
âA locked door means little when the window is smashed and youâre dragged out of it. That and itâs clearly a fake accident. 
âShe threw herself into the bonnet when she realised the car was stopping short.â
frank.chung@news.com.au
headline: Dashcam shows woman jump in front of car

article: First Nations people in central Queensland say the state government is inflaming local tensions by pushing ahead with plans to meet with the former leader of a far-right âpatriotsâ group, who was booted off Facebook after leading a mob to surround the Rockhampton home of an Indigenous teenager. Guardian Australia on Tuesday revealed that the ringleader of the group, Torin OâBrien, is the former president of a group that regularly posted offensive anti-Islam content online. OâBrien referred to himself online as part of the âInfidel Legionâ and made comments calling Muslim people âknuckle draggersâ. Last week, he posted the names and photographs of two Aboriginal young people, believed to be teenagers, on Facebook and accused them of criminal activity. OâBrien then corralled locals to attend their home on Sunday. On Tuesday, Facebook deleted OâBrienâs profile for breaching the platformâs community standards, while Labor MPs defended the decision to meet with him. The former One Nation candidate, who was portrayed as an âanti-crime crusaderâ in some media reports, was invited to sit down âwith police and other stakeholdersâ, as community tensions related to youth crime escalate. Alwyn Doolan, a Gooreng Gooreng and Wakka Wakka man from the Aboriginal community of Woorabinda, west of Rockhampton, said the government had legitimised a âmobâ. âThe community is very wary,â Doolan said. Sign up for Guardian Australiaâs free morning and afternoonemail newsletters for your daily news roundup âThis fella shouldnât have any dealings with government and I donât understand why Annastacia Palaszcuk is not out clearly condemning this as well.â Doolan said Aboriginal people in the community were âlooking over their shoulderâ and worried about the potential of being misidentified or subject to violence. OâBrien has been contacted for comment. The Facebook group he created â to organise community members to go to the homes of people he accused of being criminals â remains online. Posts in the group use racist slurs to refer to Indigenous people. One post, about a ârace warâ, said: âbring it on that would mean we could legally go and get these dogsâ. Guardian Australia has also seen posts by far-right groups that appear designed to fan racial tensions in Queensland and promote vigilante actions. The MP for Rockhampton, Barry OâRourke, confirmed he invited OâBrien to attend a meeting âwith police and other stakeholdersâ. âThere is no place for mob action. I completely agree with the police commissioner that this kind of behaviour is extremely dangerous and unhelpful. Weâve seen this kind of behaviour lead to innocent people being harmed or killed in the past and thatâs what we desperately want to avoid in Rockhampton,â OâRourke said. âThe contempt we saw for police on the weekend was especially worrying. âThat is why I have invited Mr OâBrien to attend a meeting with police and other stakeholders â itâs an opportunity for him to air his views the right way, and also an opportunity for police to emphasise the risks to himself and others from these actions. No one wants to see this escalate.â The Queensland police commissioner, Katarina Carroll, told reporters on Monday that information posted online was not correct and urged Queenslanders not to take the law into their own hands. Asked on Tuesday why police were meeting with OâBrien, Carroll said itâs âincredibly important to meet with everyoneâ. She said police were still investigating whether charges should be laid. âItâs incredibly important that, irrespective of what your background is, to give those people perspective, and to actually tell them what theyâre doing is not quite correct,â she said. The police minister, Mark Ryan, said it was âgood representationâ for local MPs to meet with members of their community. Asked whether this included those who espouse anti-Islam beliefs, Ryan said âjust because you meet with someone doesnât mean you agree with themâ. âYou can be appalled by someoneâs views but nonetheless your role is to listen to people,â he said. Members of Rockhamptonâs Indigenous community are planning to meet this week, to discuss issues of youth crime, âvigilante groupsâ and childrenâs safety in the city.
headline: Facebook blocks Rockhampton mob leader as Queensland MP prepares to meet with him

chat_gpt_summary: Mark Zuckerberg, the founder of Facebook and Meta, surprised the martial arts community by winning gold and silver medals at his first Brazilian jiu-jitsu tournament in Redwood City, California. The 38-year-old tech billionaire revealed that he took up the sport during the pandemic and posted about his win on Instagram. Zuckerberg received support from high-profile athletes, including former UFC champion Conor McGregor. Other celebrities, such as actor Ashton Kutcher, comedian Russell Brand, and actor Jason Statham, have also taken up Brazilian jiu-jitsu. Even Tom Hardy, known for his roles in Peaky Blinders and Venom, competes in the sport in the UK.
article: Mark Zuckerberg is adding one more title to his rÃ©sumÃ©: medal-winning martial artist. The Facebook and Meta founder won gold and silver medals at his very first Brazilian jiu-jitsu tournament in Redwood City, California, to the shock of many in the martial arts community and probably more widely. The 38-year-old tech billionaire said he took up an interest in the sport early on in the pandemic and he posted his win on Instagram, saying: âCompeted in my first jiu-jitsu tournament and won some medals for the Guerrilla Jiu Jitsu team.â One of his coaches, Khai âthe Shadowâ Wu, congratulated his student: âYesterday getting to see Zuck compete was pretty epic. No match was easy and everything was earned. It was an honor to be able to help coach and offer any advice I could.â Zuckerberg received support for his new hobby from several high-profile athletes. Former UFC champion and student of anger management Conor McGregor commented on the post: âYo!!! F***ing awesome Mark.â Brazilian Bernardo Faria, the five-time world jiu-jitsu champion, said of Zuckerbergâs win: âAmazing!!! Half guard, arm-bars, triangle! Super cool!ââ Other celebrities also congratulated the tech nerd-turned-athlete on his success. US TV host and former teen heartthrob Mario Lopez commented with three fire emojis. Other famous people have also taken up the sport. Actor Ashton Kutcher, who took up jiu-jitsu more than a decade ago, has a brown belt in the sport. Actor Jason Statham and comedian Russell Brand have purple belts. The Peaky Blinders and Venom star Tom Hardy also competes in the UK, and has won competitions in Wolverhampton and Milton Keynes.
headline: Facebook founder Mark Zuckerberg wins medals on jiu-jitsu debut

chat_gpt_summary: UK bank TSB has called on Meta, the parent company of Facebook, Instagram, and WhatsApp, to do more to protect customers from scams originating on its platforms. TSB's research found that 80% of its three largest fraud categories (impersonation, purchase, and investment) came from Meta-owned sites and apps. Impersonation scams on Meta's platforms accounted for 86% of cases in that category recorded by TSB, with two-thirds of those incidents on WhatsApp. TSB also warned of a 300% rise in "family and friends" fraud on WhatsApp. Meanwhile, 80% of purchase fraud cases started on Facebook Marketplace, with TSB refunding 2,100 cases from that platform.
article: Meta has been urged to take action to protect customers from fraud, after TSB said scams via the social media companyâs platforms Facebook, WhatsApp and Instagram have soared. The UK bank said there had been a huge jump in the number of scams originating from Meta-owned sites and apps, releasing research that shows they now account for 80% of cases within TSBâs three largest fraud categories: impersonation, purchase and investment. Its findings follow the announcement on Tuesday of a government crackdown on scammers in response to the massive growth of web-based fraud, including a ban on technology that allows mass texting of numerous phones. Paul Davis, the director of fraud prevention at TSB, said: âSocial media companies must urgently clean up their platforms to protect the countless innocent people who use their services every day. âIn the meantime, we are urging the public to remain cautious to potential scam content â and to spread the word to help protect those around you. âItâs high time that social media and telephone companies took financial liability for the rising levels of fraud taking place on their platforms.â Impersonation scams originating on Metaâs platforms accounted for 86% of cases in that category recorded by TSB between 2021 and 2022, with two-thirds of those incidents coming from WhatsApp. âFamily and friendsâ fraud cases via the mobile messaging platform rocketed by 300% in a year, according to TSB analysis of its fraud data, and the bank refunded more than 550 victims. The scam involves a con artist posing as a friend or relative of the victim. They get in touch via WhatsApp or another messaging platform and gain the targetâs trust before asking for money. TSB warned consumers to be vigilant to any unexpected messages purporting to be from family or friends, and advised contacting the individual directly before sending a payment. Meanwhile, the bank found that 80% of purchase fraud cases â where someone is tricked into buying a product or service that does not exist â began via Metaâs platforms. Most of these originated through Facebook Marketplace, where incidents of fraud almost doubled in one year. TSB refunded 2,100 cases from this platform under the bankâs fraud refund guarantee. The research also found that scams taking place through Meta account for almost 87% of all investment fraud cases at TSB, and they predominantly begin on Instagram and Facebook. TSB fraud experts urged consumers to stick to recognised investment platforms and to avoid social media âget rich quickâ schemes. A Meta spokesperson said: âThis is an industry-wide issue and scammers are using increasingly sophisticated methods to defraud people in a range of ways including email, SMS and offline. âWe donât want anyone to fall victim to these criminals which is why our platforms have systems to block scams, financial services advertisers now have to be FCA authorised and we run consumer awareness campaigns on how to spot fraudulent behaviour. âPeople can also report this content in a few simple clicks and we work with the police to support their investigations.â
headline: Facebook and WhatsApp owner urged by UK bank to act on fraud as scams soar

chat_gpt_summary: The US Federal Trade Commission (FTC) is accusing Facebook, now Meta, of deceiving parents about protections for children on the Messenger Kids app and breaching a 2019 agreement on privacy. The FTC is proposing to tighten the existing agreement on privacy to include a ban on profiting from minors' data and expanded limitations on using facial recognition technology. Meta's parent company, Facebook, is also facing criticism over revelations that it steered young users towards damaging content that could have severe mental health impacts. The FTC's move has been applauded by consumer rights groups as a positive step towards creating more robust protections for children online. Meta has 30 days to respond to the proposed changes.
article: The US Federal Trade Commission (FTC) is accusing Facebook of misleading parents about protections for children and is proposing to tighten an existing agreement on privacy to include a ban on profiting from minorsâ data. The FTC said on Wednesday that Facebook misled parents about how much control they had over who their children had contact with in the Messenger Kids app and was deceptive about how much access app developers had to usersâ private data, breaching a 2019 agreement on privacy. The FTCâs proposed changes include barring Facebook from making money off data collected on users under age 18, including in its virtual reality business. It would also face expanded limitations on using facial recognition technology. Shares of Meta, Facebookâs parent company, fell as much as 2% after the news. A Meta spokesperson, Andy Stone, said on Twitter that the move was a âpolitical stuntâ. âWe will vigorously fight this action and expect to prevail,â he wrote. The FTCâs action on Wednesday is the first step in the process of changing the 2019 agreement. Facebook will have 30 days to answer. The company can appeal any commission decision to an appeals court. âFacebook has repeatedly violated its privacy promises,â said Samuel Levine, director of the FTCâs Bureau of Consumer Protection. âThe companyâs recklessness has put young users at risk, and Facebook needs to answer for its failures.â The FTC has twice before settled with Facebook over privacy violations. The first time was in 2012. Facebook agreed in 2019 to pay a record $5bn fine to resolve allegations it had violated a 2012 consent order by misleading users about how much control they had over their personal data. That order was finalized in 2020. Meta is one of several social media giants to face scrutiny in recent years over potential harms its products pose to children. Meta leaders testified in front of Congress after revelations from whistleblower Frances Haugen that the company knew it steered young users towards damaging content that could have severe mental health impacts. Other social media firms have also faced increasing pressure surrounding the inability to control misinformation and hate speech on their platforms, an issue that was the subject of multiple congressional hearings in recent years. Still, little concrete action has been taken by Washington to address the concerns. As national legislation stalls, consumer rights groups applauded the FTCâs move, describing it as a positive step towards creating more robust protections for children online. âKids should never have been used as an engine of profit for Meta, and itâs great that the FTC is continuing to act aggressively,â said Lisa Gilbert, executive vice-president of the progressive non-profit Public Citizen. âUntil Congress acts on its promise to ensure privacy for kids and adults online, itâs critical that the agency boldly enforces the law.â
headline: US regulators may ban Facebook from monetizing data from children

chat_gpt_summary: Reach, the publisher of the Mirror, Express and Daily Star newspapers, has reported a fall in group revenue of almost 6% for the four months to 23 April, with changes to the way Facebook displays news content blamed for the decline. Reach also said that digital revenues had slumped by almost 15% since January, with a slowdown in the number of page views from online readers. However, the company said print revenue remained strong, with revenue from print circulation rising by 2% over the period as it benefited from higher prices for newspapers. Print advertising was also slightly ahead of expectations. Reach has previously announced plans to slash hundreds of jobs as part of a £30m cost-cutting drive.
article: The publisher of the Mirror, Express and Daily Star newspapers has blamed changes in the way Facebook displays news content for a slide in its digital revenues. Reach, which also owns hundreds of regional newspapers including the Birmingham Mail, Liverpool Echo and Manchester Evening News, reported a fall in group revenue of almost 6% for the four months to 23 April. It has previously announced plans to slash hundreds more jobs amid a Â£30m cost-cutting drive as it battles higher costs resulting from inflation and disappointing advertising sales. The newspaper group, which owns a network of regionally focused news websites including Glasgow Live and Hampshire Live, said it had experienced a slowdown in the number of page views from online readers, with changes to the presentation of news by Facebook reducing traffic to its sites. Reachâs digital revenues have slumped by almost 15% since January and it warned of a challenging environment for digital advertising. However, it said its print revenue remained strong, and it had continued to sell ârobustâ quantities of newspapers. The company said revenue from print circulation rose by 2% over the period, as it benefited from higher prices it is charging for its newspapers that were introduced last year. Print advertising was slightly ahead of expectations. Jim Mullen, Reachâs chief executive, said: âExternal factors continue to impact digital revenue, delivery of the customer value strategy is driving a higher quality mix, underpinned by the strength of print. âOur focus on data, means customers are receiving and responding more often to relevant content and a more engaging user experience.â Reach, which is holding its annual shareholder meeting on Wednesday, said it was continuing with its plans to cut its operating costs by 5-6% this year, adding that its actions to do so were âwell advancedâ. The publisher warned in March that up to 420 staff could face redundancy as part of its cost-cutting plans, including 192 journalists, only weeks after announcing it would cut 200 jobs. Reach added it was continuing its investment in a digital operation to tap the US market, and had almost 100 full-time staff in place before its launch of US websites for the Mirror and the Express in the coming months.
headline: Mirror publisher blames revenue decline on Facebook changes
