chat_gpt_summary: Jorja Brown, a vintage interiors curator, found herself obsessing over a 2x1.5m weaving made of pure alpaca wool and depicting a trio of musicians on Facebook Marketplace, but missed the deal. Weeks later, she found the same weaving on eBay and arranged to meet the seller, who gifted her several motivational books and suggested she start her own interiors business. Brown now runs a vintage furniture and home decor business from her home, and the weaving often appears in the background of photos of her furnishings and homewares.
article: When Jorja Brown moved into a Melbourne rental, owning only a bookshelf and a bed just as the Covid pandemic took hold, she knew furnishing her new home would be a challenge. In her search for essential items, such as a couch, the vintage interiors curator took to the treasure-filled quagmire of Facebook Marketplace, and soon found herself obsessing over a 2 x 1.5m weaving made of pure alpaca wool and depicting a trio of musicians. Unfortunately, sheâd missed the deal. With the piece still on her mind days later, Brown reached out to the seller for more details. âShe couldnât tell me much, just that sheâd bought it while travelling in South America. Sign up for the fun stuff with our rundown of must-reads, pop culture and tips for the weekend, every Saturday morning âBut I couldnât stop thinking about it â¦ I even reverse-image searched it [on Google], but nothing came up.â She contacted the seller again. âI asked if sheâd help put me in touch with whoever bought it, but she wouldnât. I had to tell myself: âLet it go, itâs not meant to be.ââ A few weeks later, Brown was scrolling through eBay in search of a dining table. She says her eyes âinstantly lit upâ when she noticed a floor rug in one of the thumbnail photos. Some quick inquiries revealed it was the very same weaving sheâd coveted , already back on the market. âI just love the line work. You donât know what it is at glance and that makes you look at it longer and deeper.â And more serendipity was to come. âI drove out and met [the seller], we ended up chatting for two hours about art and design â he was a curator himself.â After hearing her enthusiasm for transitioning to a new career in interiors, Brown says the seller gifted her several motivational books, and suggested she start with Now is the Time by Patrick Lindsay. âIt took me about six months to get the courage to quit my job, but that book was really the seed,â says Brown. She is now self-employed and runs a vintage furniture and home decor business from her home. As Brownâs business grows, the weaving often makes a background appearance in photos of furnishings and homewares. âPeople often ask about it, but itâs definitely not for sale.â â¢ This article was amended on 10 February 2023. The intended reference to the book recommended by the seller was Now is the Time by Patrick Lindsay, not The Power of Now by Eckhart Tolle.
headline: âI couldnât stop thinking about itâ: one womanâs hunt for Facebook Marketplace treasure

chat_gpt_summary: The UK's Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) has ordered businesses to amend or remove more than 8,500 misleading financial promotions during 2022, more than 15 times the previous year's number, as the use of social media marketing channels and "fin-fluencers" directing investment products at younger age groups increased. The FCA also published nearly 1,900 alerts to consumers about potential scammers, up over a third on 2021. Tech companies including Google, TikTok, Facebook, and Twitter have changed advertising policies to ensure that regulated firms are involved in adverts for financial products following FCA intervention. However, the FCA said more needs to be done to protect consumers.
article: More than 10,000 misleading financial promotions and scams aimed at consumers via social media sites such as Instagram, Facebook, YouTube and TikTok have been identified and targeted by the financial watchdog during the past year. The Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) said the use of social media marketing channels and the rise of so-called âfin-fluencersâ â particularly directing investment products at younger age groups â exploded last year, resulting in a record number of takedown notices and alerts. The FCA ordered businesses to amend or remove 8,582 promotions during 2022, 15 times the 573 recorded the previous year. It also published almost 1,900 alerts to consumers about potential scammers, up more than a third up on 2021. Google, which owns YouTube, Meta, which owns Instagram and Facebook, TikTok, Twitter and Microsoftâs Bing have changed advertising policies to ensure that regulated firms are involved in adverts for financial products after FCA intervention. However, the regulator said it was still monitoring whether the companies were effectively blocking illegal adverts. âMore needs to be done by tech companies to protect consumers,â the FCA said. âGiven the substantial number of illegal promotions we continue to identify, our expectation is that every social media platform improves their capability to identify and remove the illegal financial promotions on a proactive basis.â The crackdown included taking action against a company that attempted to take advantage of the cost of living crisis, targeting more than 70,000 online followers that the FCA deemed were potentially vulnerable consumers. An online retail broker with more than 1.1 million UK customers, with a primary market of millennial age investors, was ordered to halt a marketing campaign after the FCA identified âserious concernsâ that its promotions, which used social media influencers, were âtargeting vulnerable customers with significant debtâ. The FCA also sought to get an unregistered cryptocurrency exchange offering products to UK consumers to be shut down, and separately alerted 55 consumers who had been identified on a scammers list targeting consumers who had been searching for loans online. âFinancial promotions must be fair, clear and not misleading,â said Sarah Pritchard, executive director, markets, at the FCA. âThis year, we will continue to put pressure on people using social media to illegally promote investments, which put peopleâs hard-earned money at risk.â The FCA said advances in the technology it uses to identify problem firms and misleading adverts had also fuelled the increase in cases last year. It has hired more than 100 people in roles such as machine learning and data analysis to build automated tools to scan thousands of websites every day. The watchdog said it looked at about 180,000 websites last year, resulting in about 4,500 websites and social media platforms being reviewed. This resulted in 1,441 alerts being issued and 400 of the offending websites being taken down. Last year, the Advertising Standards Authority sent enforcement notices to 50 firms in the cryptocurrency sector warning them that they must clearly explain the risks for potential investors. The watchdog slapped bans on a bitcoin firm for urging that it was âtime to buyâ or miss out, and on football club Arsenalâs campaign to get fans to buy its crypto âtokensâ.
headline: Scams: FCA blocks more than 10,000 ads from Instagram, Facebook and YouTube

chat_gpt_summary: Meta has announced that former US president Donald Trump will be allowed to return to Facebook and Instagram. Meta's president of global affairs, Nick Clegg, said the risk has "sufficiently receded" in the two years since the Capitol riots on 6 January 2021 to allow the ban to be lifted. Trump responded to the news on his own social media network, Truth Social, but it is effectively behind a wall for web users because the company is not accepting new registrations. The move comes as Meta faces financial difficulties and pressures to remain relevant. The decision has been criticised by some who argue that the "guardrails" on Trump's posts are insufficient.
article: Itâs been two years since Donald Trump was banned from Meta, but now heâs back. The companyâs justification for allowing the former president to return to Facebook and Instagram â that the threat has subsided â seems to ignore that in the two years since the ban Trump hasnât changed, itâs just that his reach has reduced. Last week, Metaâs president of global affairs, Nick Clegg, announced that soon Trump will be able to post on Instagram and Facebook. The company said âthe risk has sufficiently recededâ in the two years since the Capitol riots on 6 January 2021 to allow the ban to be lifted. What you might not have been aware of â except through media reports â was Trumpâs response. That is because the former US president posted it on Truth Social, his own social media network that he retreated to after he was banned from the others. And it is effectively behind a wall for web users, because the company is not accepting new registrations. On that platform, Trump is said to have fewer than 5 million followers, compared to 34 million and almost 88 million heâd had on Facebook and Twitter respectively. Metaâs ban meant that Trump wouldnât have space on its platforms during the US midterms elections in 2022, but would anything have been different if Trump had been given a larger audience? As Dan Milmo has detailed, almost half of the posts on Trumpâs Truth Social account in the weeks after the midterms pushed election fraud claims or amplified QAnon accounts or content. But you wouldnât know it unless you were on that platform, or reading a news report about it like this one. If given a larger audience, will Trump resume his Main Character role in online discourse (a role that Twitterâs new owner, Elon Musk, has gamely taken on in the past few months)? Or has his influence diminished? This is the gamble Meta is taking. When Musk lifted Trumpâs ban on Twitter in November after a user poll won by a slim margin, it was easy to read the former presidentâs snub of the gesture as a burn on the tech CEO. But it seems increasingly likely that the Meta decision about whether to reinstate him was looming large in Trumpâs mind. Earlier this month, NBC reported that Trumpâs advisors had sent a letter to Meta pleading for the ban to be lifted, saying it âdramatically distorted and inhibited the public discourseâ. If Trump had gone back to Twitter and started reposting what he had posted on Truth Social, there would have been more pressure on Meta to keep the ban in place (leaving aside the agreement Trump has with his own social media company that keeps his posts exclusive on Truth Social for several hours). Twitter lifting the ban and Trump not tweeting at all gave Meta sufficient cover. The financials Thereâs also the possible financial reasoning. Angelo Carusone, the president of Media Matters for America, said Facebook is âa dying platformâ and restoring Trump is about clinging to relevance and revenue. For months, Trump has been posting on Truth Social about how poorly Meta is performing financially, and in part trying to link it to him no longer being on Facebook. Meta has lost more than US$80bn in market value, and last year sacked thousands of workers as the company aimed to stem a declining user base and loss of revenue after Apple made privacy changes on its software (Â£). But what of the âguardrailsâ? Metaâs justification for restoring Trumpâs account is that there are new âguardrailsâ that could result in him being banned again for the most egregious policy breaches for between one month and two years. But that is likely only going to be for the most serious of breaches â such as glorifying those committing violence. Clegg indicated that if Trump is posting QAnon-adjacent content, for example, his reach will be limited on those posts. The ban itself was a pretty sufficient reach limiter, but we will have to see what happens if Trump starts posting again. The unpublished draft document from staff on the January 6 committee, reported by the Washington Post last week, was pretty telling about Meta, and social media companies generally. It states that both Facebook and Twitter, under its former management, were sensitive to claims that conservative political speech was being suppressed. âFear of reprisal and accusations of censorship from the political right compromised policy, process, and decision-making. This was especially true at Facebook,â the document states. âIn one instance, senior leadership intervened personally to prevent rightwing publishers from having their content demoted after receiving too many strikes from independent fact-checkers. âAfter the election, they debated whether they should change their fact-checking policy on former world leaders to accommodate President Trump.â Those âguardrailsâ donât seem particularly reassuring, do they? Is AI really coming for your job? Layoffs continue to hit media and companies are looking to cut costs. So it was disheartening for new reporters in particular to learn that BuzzFeed plans to use AI such as ChatGPT âto create content instead of writersâ. (Full disclosure: I worked at BuzzFeed News prior to joining the Guardian in 2019, but itâs been long enough that I am not familiar with any of its thinking about AI.) But perhaps itâs a bit too early to despair. Anyone who has used free AI to produce writing will know itâs OK but not great, so the concern about BuzzFeed dipping its toes in those waters seems to be overstated â at least for now. In an interview with Semafor, BuzzFeed tech reporter Katie Notopoulos explained that the tools arenât intended to replace the quiz-creation work writers do now, but to create new quizzes unlike what is already around. âOn the one hand,â she said, âI want to try to explain this isnât an evil plan to replace me with AI. But on the other â¦ maybe let Wall Street believe that for a little while.â That seems to be where AI is now: not a replacement for a skilled person, just a tool. The wider TechScape This is the first really good in-depth look at the last few months of Twitter since Elon Musk took over. Social media users are posting feelgood footage of strangers to build a following, but not every subject appreciates the clickbaity attention of these so-called #kindness videos. If youâre an influencer in Australia and youâre not declaring your sponcon properly, you might be targeted as part of a review by the local regulator. Speaking of influencers, Time has a good explanation for why you might have seen people posting about mascara on TikTok in the past few days. Writer Jason Okundaye makes the case that itâs time for people to stop filming strangers in public and uploading the videos online in the hope of going viral. Nintendo rereleasing GoldenEye007 this week is a reminder of how much the N64 game shaped video games back in the day.
headline: TechScape: Why Donald Trumpâs return to Facebook could mark a rocky new age for online discourse

chat_gpt_summary: Late night talk show hosts, including Stephen Colbert, Wanda Sykes, Jimmy Kimmel and Seth Meyers have commented on former US president Donald Trump's return to Facebook after his ban. Sykes compared it to "letting Hannibal Lecter babysit your most delicious child", while Colbert argued that Meta was punishing everyone by reinstating Trump. Meyers mocked Tucker Carlson's conspiracy theory that classified documents found at former vice president Mike Pence's residence were concocted to make Trump look bad. Kimmel marked the 20th anniversary of his talk show, thanking staff and expressing surprise at the show's longevity.
article: The Daily Show Wanda Sykes, the Daily Showâs guest host for the week, tore into Metaâs decision to reinstate Donald Trump to Facebook and Instagram on Thursday evening. âI mean, letting Trump back on Facebook is crazy. Youâre just asking for trouble,â she said. âItâs like letting Hannibal Lecter babysit your most delicious child. âBut Facebook is putting him back online anyway, because they say that âthe public should be able to hear what their politicians are saying,ââ she continued, quoting the companyâs public statement on the matter. âAnd to that, let me say: phooey. âWe all know Facebook is losing a ton of money, and they want that Trump attention back,â she explained. âThey need a hit! Trump is their White Lotus. Heâs the Jennifer Coolidge of the internet.â Sykes then offered an experiment to test out Trumpâs return to Metaâs platforms. âI think for the first week, they should only allow him to post cat photos,â she said. âLetâs see how it goes. And if you see a bunch of cats storming the Capitol â although adorable, shut it down.â Stephen Colbert On the Late Show, Stephen Colbert also lamented Trumpâs return to Facebook. âThatâs a punishment for all of us,â he said. Trumpâs two-year ban on Meta platforms following January 6 has now expired, and Meta determined he could be reinstated because his ârisk to public safetyâ had âsufficiently recededâ. âThe risk has receded because heâs been gone!â Colbert exclaimed, comparing Metaâs logic to thinking, âyou know, between knife thrusts, Jack the Ripper is a pretty chill dudeâ. Upon reinstatement, Trump must follow Metaâs updated community guidelines, which prohibit violence and incitement, fraud and deception, and hate speech. âSo all the former presidentâs love languages,â Colbert quipped. In addition, Meta said since Trump already declared his candidacy for president in 2024, heâs not subject to fact-checking. âMeta! What are you thinking? You canât allow him to post conspiracy theories on Facebook!â Colbert reacted. âThatâs your momâs friendâs job â âfor the last time, Cathy, teenagers are not identifying as gerbils and demanding taxpayer-funded woodchips.ââ Seth Meyers On Late Night, Seth Meyers mocked Tucker Carlsonâs latest conspiracy theory, this time on how classified documents found at Mike Penceâs Indiana residence were concocted to make Trump look bad. âProbably the craziest reaction to the Pence news has come from Fox host Tucker Carlson,â he explained, âwho concocted an elaborate fantasy where the DoJ asked Pence to look for the documents, assuming he had none, in order to make Trump look bad by comparison, so that they could then prosecute Trump.â Meyers imitated Carlsonâs fallacy-filled delivery: âItâs possible, in fact itâs likely, they were planning on asking Mike Pence to go undercover as Donald Trump. And if that was the plan, how would they do it? Would they have arrested Donald Trump so they could perform an experimental surgery wherein they removed Donald Trumpâs face and swap it with Mike Pence just like they did to John Travolta and Nicolas Cage? âIn reality, the Biden and Pence revelations show this is a lot more commonplace than most of us realized,â Meyers concluded, âand if Trump had just given the documents back when asked, there wouldnât have been a problem.â Jimmy Kimmel Jimmy Kimmel celebrated the 20th anniversary of his show, which premiered after the Super Bowl on 26 January 2003. âWhy these people at ABC hired me, I still have no idea,â he joked in an emotional monologue. âI feel like at some point, ABC just forgot they were paying the show, like a 24-hour fitness membership, and it went on. âWhen we started, there were no iPhones, there was no YouTube, there was no Uber, no Twitter, no wifi, no Netflix, no Google,â he said. âWe had Nokias and Ask Jeeves and that was it. âWeâve been through two wars, a worldwide pandemic, four presidents, one insurrection, at least three different Kanyes,â he added, displaying a Blockbuster card for the show. âIf you told me we were going to last longer than Blockbuster, I wouldâve sooner believed Iâd be working at Blockbuster in 20 years.â Kimmel got choked up thanking his executive producers, staff, family and âeverybody at ABC who didnât fire me. âEvery day it takes a lot of people to make something this dumb,â he said. âAnd weâve covered a lot of dumb stuff over the past 20 years, from Snooki to Honey Boo Boo, Ken Bone to Sarah Palin, Sanjaya, Clay Aiken, chocolate rain, double rainbow, Stormy Daniels, William Hung, the astronaut diaper lady, Kim Kardashianâs sex tape, Hulk Hoganâs sex tape, Pam and Tommyâs sex tape. The Octomom â I think she made a sex tape. Nicki Minajâs cousinâs friendâs balls. I have been allowed to use this platform to speak out about issues that matter to me, like healthcare and sensible gun laws. âThank you for your patience,â he concluded. âI donât know what I did to deserve it, but I appreciate it. I donât take this for granted, and I appreciate that as long as I am here, youâll never have to see Matt Damonâs stupid face on this show.â
headline: Wanda Sykes on Trumpâs Facebook return: âLike letting Hannibal Lecter babysit your most delicious childâ

chat_gpt_summary: Facebook's decision to allow Donald Trump back on its platform confirms the company's hypocrisy and its inability or unwillingness to learn from past political disasters. Allowing Trump back on the platform signals that neither the past nor a perpetrator's thoughts about the past matter, and deprives citizens of vital information. The decision also reveals Facebook's business model, which optimizes for outrage, and its attempts to create less toxic politics have regularly been reversed because engagement appeared to have declined. However, Facebook's business model and social media are not the same thing, and every media revolution has created a moral panic, and innovations have also deepened democracy.
article: It was left to Nick Clegg â once a great hope for liberal politics in Britain, nowadays cutting a sad figure as global lobbyist for a company with major PR problems â to announce that Facebook was open to Donald Trumpâs nefarious business again. The decision was wrong, but it hardly spells the end of democracy, as alarmists equating Facebook with an inevitable triumph for fascism might think. What the decision does, though, is confirm the breathtaking hypocrisy of a corporation seemingly unable â or unwilling â to learn from its complicity in repeated political disasters. Hillary Clinton never stopped being pilloried for her âbasket of deplorablesâ speech in 2016. However, the fact is that Trump and plenty of his supporters have said and done things which are deplorable. The really scandalous part was her casual remark that some Americans were âirredeemableâ. But democracy is based on the notion that no one is irredeemable, that we should never give up on fellow citizens, hard as it may be. Those who have engaged in anti-democratic actions must have the chance to convince others that they have changed their ways. Just as it is wrong to deprive felons of voting rights for life, so is it misguided to exclude people from democratic politics forever. The Italian politician Silvio Berlusconi, after years of evading criminal punishment, was eventually sentenced to community service. He was subsequently able to return to politics, even making a bizarre debut on TikTok, where he tried hard to appear youthful and enthuse Italyâs ragazzi despite looking, after multiple facelifts, like a waxwork of himself. But Trump has neither paid any price for various offenses against democracy, nor ever shown the slightest repentance for his role in what Facebook, in its official announcement, gingerly calls âcivil unrestâ (as if we were talking about some general conflagration, with all sides to blame). By allowing him back on, Facebook is signaling that neither the past, nor what a perpetrator thinks about the past, matter. It pretends that, unless Trump is on the platform, citizens have no chance to find out what âthe king of social mediaâ (according to Nigel Farage) is thinking, depriving them of vital information â a patently absurd claim given that Trump remains the most public American who has ever lived. Not only that: AJ Liebling once observed that freedom of the press is guaranteed only to those who own one â if nothing else, freedom to address the public is also guaranteed to those who own a social network. True, if Facebook executives stick to the narrowest justification for restricting speech, they can argue that Trump is not causing imminent violence. But even that is debatable. A recent post by Trump on his own platform, Truth Social, targeted two African American election workers in Georgia, Ruby Freeman and her daughter Shaye Moss, whose lives had already been made hell by Trumpâs team in 2020. âWhat will the Great State of Georgia do with the Ruby Freeman MESS?â the former president asked. Facebook points to new âguardrailsâ to prevent posts inciting hatred. But the corporation must know full well that far-right politicians have created a trap when it comes to content moderation: having convinced everyone that conservatives are unfairly disadvantaged by âbig techâ, every sanction will be sold to outraged supporters as confirmation that the right is always the victim. If Trump stays on the platform, he wins; if he is removed again for breaking through guardrails, he also wins. And so does Facebook. For all its sanctimonious talk of âopen debateâ and âcommunityâ, its business model is to optimize for outrage; outrage means maximum âengagementâ and hence profit. Facebookâs attempts to create less toxic politics have regularly been reversed because âengagementâ appeared to have declined as a result. Its much-touted oversight board â an impressive body of former politicians, judges and academics â might criticize individual decisions, but cannot determine Facebookâs overall policy. Revealingly, the board distanced itself from the Trump decision immediately, stressing that it had not been involved; it also called for more transparency. But transparency is of course what platforms have always denied to both governments and researchers. On one level, Facebook may know that its business model is irredeemable, since it is bound to produce ever more scandals. The fact that we now call Facebookâs parent company âMetaâ â leaving behind the F-word, with its bad connotations â is an extraordinary PR triumph. (Google never convinced us to say âAlphabetâ, but, then again, while also engaged in comprehensive surveillance and robbing us of data, it was arguably never as evil as Facebook.) There is much generalizing about social media killing democracy. Every media revolution has created a moral panic â the printing press supposedly gave us the wars of religion; radio caused Hitler; TV enabled McCarthyism. But this technological determinism is facile; innovations have also deepened democracy. Social media and Facebookâs business model are not the same thing. The Trump decision demonstrates, though, that Facebook just cannot let go of its âincitement capitalismâ. Jan-Werner MÃ¼ller teaches at Princeton and is a Guardian US columnist. His most recent book is Democracy Rules
headline: Facebook is allowing Trump back. The platform hasnât learned its lesson | Jan-Werner MÃ¼ller

chat_gpt_summary: Facebook and Instagram's decision to allow Donald Trump to return to the platforms has been criticised by civil rights advocates and politicians, who say that it could lead to increased division and hate speech. The social media firm lifted the ban imposed on Trump following the Capitol attack on 6 January and will allow him to post again in the coming weeks. Experts have suggested that Trump's return to the platforms could result in him spreading dangerous misinformation and hate speech once again. Critics of the decision argue that it is primarily for financial benefit, as the company has lost users and value in recent months.
article: Politicians and civil rights advocates have weighed in on Metaâs decision to allow former president Donald Trump to return to Facebook and Instagram, stating that his presence on the platforms will âfan the flames of hatred and divisionâ. The social media firm has lifted a ban imposed on Trump after the January 6 Capitol attack and will allow him to post again in the coming weeks. Experts in online hate speech say there is no reason to believe Trump will not return to spreading dangerous misinformation and hate speech upon his return. âGiving Donald Trump access to his Facebook account allows him to once again use his platform as a megaphone to spread misinformation about the integrity of our elections, incite violence and stoke the flames of white supremacy,â said Mariana Ruiz Firmat, executive director of racial justice movement Kairos Action. Democratic politicians have also spoken out against the decision, with Democratic congresswoman Jan Schakowsky, of Illinois, saying that reinstating Trump âwill only fan the flames of hatred and division that led to an insurrectionâ. Trump was impeached for inciting the January 6 riot, a deadly attempt to overturn his defeat by Joe Biden in the 2020 election. The events also led to his being banned from a number of major social media platforms, including YouTube, Snapchat and Twitter. The Twitter ban was lifted in November, after the site was purchased by the Tesla owner, Elon Musk. Trump has not tweeted since, although he is active on his own social media platform and would-be Twitter rival Truth Social. Google, owner of YouTube, did not respond to a request for comment on whether Trump would be allowed to return, but some experts have suggested that the decisions from Meta and Twitter could set a precedent that leads other platforms to follow suit. In a blog post explaining Metaâs decision, its president of global affairs and former British deputy prime minister Nick Clegg said the companyâs platforms should be available for âopen, public and democratic debateâ. âThe public should be able to hear what their politicians are saying â the good, the bad and the ugly â so that they can make informed choices at the ballot box,â he said. Clegg also said that Trump would be allowed back with new âguardrailsâ preventing future violations of platform policies. He would, for example, be âpermitted to attack the results of the 2020 election without facing consequencesâ but would face action if he âwere to cast doubt on an upcoming election â like, the 2024 presidential raceâ. Many have argued that Metaâs decision is largely for financial benefit, as the company has floundered in recent months amid a declining user base and huge expenditures on its virtual reality project, the metaverse. The company lost more than $80bn in market value and laid off thousands of employees in 2022. âMeta knows the impact of bringing Trump back â the company knows he will turn Facebook and Instagram into a cesspool of hate, violence, and extremism â but it doesnât care,â said Angelo Carusone, president of Media Matters for America. âFacebook is a dying platform, and Meta will do anything to cling to relevance and revenue â even if that means endangering its users and our democracy.â Among Democrats, Adam Schiff, a former House intelligence committee chair, said Trump had âshown no remorse [or] contritionâ for January 6, and Facebook had âcaved, giving him a platform to do more harmâ. Schakowsky added: âThe reinstatement of Trumpâs accounts show that there is no low [Meta chief executive] Mark Zuckerberg will not stoop to in order to reverse Metaâs cratering revenue and stagnant consumer growth, even if it means destroying our democracy.â Eric Swalwell, like Schiff now barred from the intelligence committee by Republican leaders, said: âWe know that [Trumpâs] words have power and they inspire, and then the leaders in the Republican party, like Speaker [Kevin] McCarthy, they donât condemn them. And so when theyâre not condemned, theyâre a green light and open lane for more violence to occur.â But there was support for Meta among some civil liberties groups, who have argued that censoring him is a threat to first amendment rights. Anthony Romero, executive director of the American Civil Liberties Union, said: âLike it or not, President Trump is one of the countryâs leading political figures and the public has a strong interest in hearing his speech. âThe biggest social media companies are central actors when it comes to our collective ability to speak â and hear the speech of others â online. They should err on the side of allowing a wide range of political speech, even when it offends.â The debate over Trumpâs accounts has renewed longstanding arguments that individual corporations and executives at their helm should not have such power to moderate public speech. âMeta will always prioritize its profits over the safety of Black and other marginalized communities â which is why vital communications platforms that have monumental impact on our everyday lives should not be led by private companies,â said Ruiz Firmat of Kairos. âIf we want a digital realm that works for all of us, we must put governance of the internet in the hands of users.â Meanwhile, Trump used his own platform, Truth Social, to celebrate, writing: âFacebook, which has lost billions of dollars in value since âdeplatformingâ your favorite president, me, has just announced that they are reinstating my account. Such a thing should never again happen to a sitting president, or anybody else who is not deserving of retribution!â
headline: Trumpâs return to Facebook will âfan the flames of hatredâ, say experts and politicians

chat_gpt_summary: Former US President Donald Trump's return to Facebook and Instagram will bring pressure on the social media platforms to monitor and moderate his posts, following his history of pushing baseless election fraud claims and amplifying QAnon conspiracy theories on his Truth Social account. Nick Clegg, the former British deputy prime minister turned president of global affairs at Meta, Facebook and Instagram's parent company, who presided over Trump's reinstatement process, has outlined guidelines to prevent content that "deligitimises" an election or is related to QAnon from appearing in users' feeds. Trump risks further suspension if he violates these guidelines, but the decision to lift the ban has been criticised for "platforming bigotry and divisiveness".
article: If Donald Trumpâs activity on his Truth Social account is a reliable indicator of what his return to Facebook and Instagram will unleash, then Nick Clegg is going to be busy. The former US president has used his rightwing social media platform to push baseless claims of election fraud and amplified content related to the QAnon conspiracy multiverse. These were two issues that received a special mention from Clegg, the former British deputy prime minister turned president of global affairs at Meta, Facebook and Instagramâs parent, as he explained the decision to end Trumpâs two-year exile on Wednesday. Clegg, who presided over the Trump reinstatement process, said content that âdeligitimisesâ an upcoming election or is related to QAnon could be blocked from appearing in other peopleâs feeds or have the reshare button removed. He said such content did not violate Metaâs community standards â or content guidelines â but could increase the risk of a repeat of the Capitol riot that got Trump banned in the first place. According to US campaign group Media Matters, nearly half of the posts on Trumpâs Truth Social account in the weeks after the US midterm elections pushed election fraud claims or amplified QAnon accounts or content. If Trump continues in that vein on Facebook and Instagram, then he will immediately hit the âguardrailsâ that Clegg outlined in his post. Metaâs founder and chief executive, Mark Zuckerberg, recently described his job as a series of body blows: âItâs almost like everyday you wake up and youâre punched in the stomach.â The reappearance of Trump will almost certainly result in further pressure on his solar plexus, judging by reaction overnight. Campaign groups warned it would be inflammatory, with the Anti-Defamation League saying Meta had chosen to âplatform bigotry and divisivenessâ and that the decision âisnât a matter of free speechâ. If Zuckerberg and Clegg had kept the ban in place, anger from the right of the political spectrum would have been equally loud, of course. But Clegg was clear that free speech was at the forefront of the decision, saying the public âshould be able to hear what their politicians are sayingâ including a candidate for office such as Trump. This reflects Zuckerbergâs belief that Meta is a champion of âfree expressionâ. Clegg reiterated that in his blogpost on Wednesday, using the opening sentence to state: âSocial media is rooted in the belief that open debate and the free flow of ideas are important values.â The measures outlined by Clegg to limit the threat from content that veers towards âthe risk of real-world harmâ are largely already in place. These include a repeat offender policy that applies to public figures who have been banned but then allowed to return: if Trump posts further violating content it will be removed and he could be suspended for between one month and two years. The guidelines on restricting election falsehood and QAnon content are an update on the repeat offender policy. That balance between free speech and real-world harm, and the strength of that repeat offender policy, will be tested when Trump comes back. Although Trump has yet to tweet following his reinstatement to Twitter, he has made clear that he wants to get back on Facebook. In a letter to Meta this month his advisers said the ban âdramatically distorted and inhibited the public discourseâ and should be rescinded. That argument about distorting and inhibiting the public realm, where everyone has a right to feel safe, would be of interest to Ruby Freeman. The former Georgia election worker was subjected to a âdeluge of intimidation, harassment, and threatsâ and was forced to leave her home after Freeman and her daughter were falsely accused of involvement in falsifying ballots in the 2020 presidential election. In a Truth Social post this month, Trump wrote: âWhat will the Great State of Georgia do with the Ruby Freeman MESS? Why not just tell the TRUTH, get rid of the turmoil and guilt, and take our Country back from the evils and treachery of the Radical Left monsters who want to see America die?â Metaâs community standards on bullying and harassment prohibit âcalling for, or making statements of intent to engage in, bullying and/or harassmentâ. If Trump repeats his Truth Social posts on Facebook and Instagram, another ban â or at least pressure to impose one â looms.
headline: Donald Trumpâs Truth Social posts bode ill for his return to Facebook

chat_gpt_summary: Facebook and Instagram will lift their ban on former US President Donald Trump's accounts for the first time in two years, according to parent company Meta. However, the company has put in place new "guardrails" to prevent repeat offenses, including stronger controls for public figures during times of civil unrest. These rules include restricting their ability to post for up to two years depending on the severity of the violation, and limiting the distribution of certain content. Trump was banned from Facebook and Instagram after the US Capitol riots on 6 January 2021, but Meta has determined that the risk has "sufficiently receded" to lift the ban.
article: Former US president Donald Trump will have the ban on his Facebook and Instagram accounts lifted for the first time in two years, parent company Meta has announced. But what are the âguardrailsâ it says will deter repeat offences, what will it mean for the platform, and what would it take for him to be banned again? Why is Trump being allowed back? In short: the safety situation is not what it was on 6 January 2021, the day of the Capitol riots. Metaâs president of global affairs, Nick Clegg, said in a blog post on Wednesday that the company had determined the risk had âsufficiently recededâ, and as a result, the ban would be lifted âin the coming weeksâ. However, Clegg said there would be new âguardrailsâ in place to deter Trump or other public figures from acting in similar ways in future. What are these âguardrailsâ? Meta has updated its policy on restricting accounts that violate the guidelines on Facebook or Instagram, with special rules for public figures during times of civil unrest. Normally people can be restricted from posting for between one and 30 days, but it can be permanent if severe enough or if it comes despite repeated warnings. But public figures will have stronger controls. This includes government officials, political candidates, and people with over a million followers. The types of violations could include inciting or celebrating ongoing violence or civil unrest. The type of violation â and the public figureâs influence over the people involved in the violence â will determine the length of the restriction, which will be between one month and two years. Meta said most violations will put a public figure in a one-month time-out from posting. A serious violation that would result in a one-year ban would be activity such as sharing a link to a statement from a terrorist group after an attack. The more severe the violence or attack, the more likely the ban will be the full two years. Other action might be more mild. Clegg said if, for instance, Trump references QAnon content, the distribution of that content would be limited, and Meta would restrict his ability to advertise. Why was Trump banned from Facebook? Trump was banned from Metaâs Facebook and Instagram platforms after the US Capitol riots on 6 January 2021. Despite the escalating violence on the day, Trump persisted in posting unsubstantiated claims that the 2020 election had been stolen, and praised the violent protesters at the attempted insurrection. In a statement posted to Facebook the next day, Meta CEO Mark Zuckerberg, said it was clear at the time that Trump âintends to use his remaining time in office to undermine the peaceful and lawful transition of powerâ and the risks of allowing Trump to continue to use the service âare simply too greatâ. A block was placed on Trumpâs accounts indefinitely, but then Meta gave the final decision on whether to keep the ban in place to the Facebook Oversight board â a body designed to make final decisions on Facebookâs moderation activity at armâs length from Meta management. The board ruled that the ban should remain in place, but said the final decision on whether Trump be readmitted should be decided by Meta. The board suggested Meta should decide within six months, but Meta opted to wait two years from the original ban on 7 January 2021. Has Trump been allowed back on any other platforms? In the aftermath of 6 January 2021, Trump was also banned from Twitter, YouTube and Snapchat. So far, only Twitter has lifted its ban. Twitter lifted its ban in November 2022, after the companyâs new owner, Elon Musk, conducted a Twitter poll which elected to remove the ban by a slim majority. Trump has not tweeted since the ban was lifted. He continues to post on his own social media platform, Truth Social. Trump agreed that all posts he makes on the site will have an exclusivity period of six hours before they can be posted on other sites. But that agreement expires in June, and Rolling Stone has reported that Trump is preparing to return to Twitter as he readies his campaign for the 2024 presidential election. Trump Media and Technology Group CEO Devin Nunes has claimed, however, that Trump has âno interestâ in returning to Twitter.
headline: Why is Trump allowed back on Facebook and will Metaâs âguardrailsâ contain him?

chat_gpt_summary: Meta's decision to allow former US President Donald Trump back on Facebook and Instagram following a two-year ban has been met with outrage by civil rights and online safety groups. The groups expressed concern about Facebook's ability to prevent future attacks on democracy and quell misinformation. The company says there will be new "guardrails" in place to prevent further offending, with the former president being subject to suspension for between one month and two years depending on the severity of the violation. Several advocates say Trump should not be given a platform to spread hate and incite violence. Others, including free speech advocates, argue that candidates for political office should be heard by the public.
article: The news that Meta will allow Donald Trump back on Facebook and Instagram following a two-year ban has been met with fury and indignation among civil rights and online safety advocates. The former US president will be allowed to return to the platforms âin coming weeksâ but âwith new guardrails in place to deter repeat offencesâ, Metaâs president of global affairs, Nick Clegg, wrote in a blogpost explaining the decision on Wednesday. The Anti-Defamation League, the NAACP, Free Press, Media Matters and other groups expressed concern about Facebookâs ability to prevent any future attacks on the democratic process or quell misinformation. âMake no mistake â by allowing Donald Trump back on its platforms, Meta is refuelling Trumpâs misinformation and extremism engine,â said Angelo Carusone, president and CEO of media watchdog Media Matters for America. âWhen Trump is given a platform, it ratchets up the temperature on a landscape that is already simmering â one that will put us on a path to increased violence.â Trump was removed from Meta platforms after the Capitol riots on 6 January 2021, during which he posted unsubstantiated claims that the election had been stolen, praised increasingly violent protesters and condemned former vice-president Mike Pence even as the mob threatened his life. Democratic congresswoman Jan Schakowsky said reinstating Trumpâs accounts âwill only fan the flames of hatred and division that led to an insurrectionâ. âThe Capitol community is still picking up the pieces from the January 6th insurrection that Trump ignited, and now he is returning to the virtual scene of the crime,â she tweeted. In a statement explaining the decision to allow Trump to return, Clegg said: âThe public should be able to hear what their politicians are saying â the good, the bad and the ugly â so that they can make informed choices at the ballot box.â âIn the event that Mr Trump posts further violating content, the content will be removed and he will be suspended for between one month and two years, depending on the severity of the violation.â Jonathan Greenblatt, the CEO of the Anti-Defamation League, said that Trump should not be given a platform to âspread hate and incite violenceâ. âThere is no reason to believe the former president will behave differently now that the platform has reversed his ban. This isnât a matter of free speech; there are ample services that Trump can use to spread his message. This is a business decision to platform bigotry and divisiveness to drive clicks and engagement, plain and simple.â Free Press Co-CEO Jessica J. GonzÃ¡lez, described the announcement as a âcowardly and unethical decisionâ that âwill cause incalculable harmâ. She urged Meta to reverse course and said Trump would only continue to use the companyâs âpowerful toolsâ to âspread lies and dangerous rhetoric, and incite violence targeted at disenfranchised communities and his ideological enemiesâ. âMeta must bear full responsibility for any harm that results from todayâs extremely reckless decision,â GonzÃ¡lez said. Meta initially outsourced its decision about whether to remove Trump permanently to its oversight board: a group of appointed academics and former politicians, that operate independent of Metaâs leadership to scrutinise the companyâs moderation decisions. That group ruled in May 2021 that Trumpâs penalties should not be âindeterminateâ, but kicked the final ruling back to Meta, and played no role in his readmission to the platform. Nicolas Suzor, a professor at Queenslandâs University of Technology School of Law and member of the Oversight Board, told the Guardian that the announcement âfollows through on [Metaâs] commitments to us to develop clear and accountable processes in high profile cases like thisâ. âMany other tech companies have not done this work (or have gone backwards recently) and their senior executives still make decisions behind closed doors that impact us all.â However, a group of scholars, advocates and activists calling itself the Real Facebook Oversight Board â operating in opposition to Metaâs board â said the decision, âsends a message that there are no real consequences even for inciting insurrection and a coup.â Some free speech advocates have agreed with Clegg, saying it is appropriate for the public to have access to messaging from political candidates. Jameel Jaffer, executive director at the Knight First Amendment Institute at Columbia University and a former American Civil Liberties Union official, defended the reinstatement. He had previously endorsed the companyâs decision to suspend Trumpâs account. âThis is the right call â not because the former president has any right to be on the platform but because the public has an interest in hearing directly from candidates for political office,â he said in a statement on Wednesday. âItâs better if the major social media platforms err on the side of leaving speech up, even if the speech is offensive or false, so that it can be addressed by other users and other institutions.â American Civil Liberties Union executive director Anthony Romero said Meta was making âthe right callâ by allowing Trump back on to the social network. âLike it or not, President Trump is one of the countryâs leading political figures and the public has a strong interest in hearing his speech,â Romero said in a release. The ACLU has filed more than 400 legal actions against Trump, according to Romero. Trump has not indicated whether he will return to the platform but responded to the news with a short statement on Truth Social, saying that âsuch a thing should never happen again to a sitting presidentâ.
headline: âRecklessâ: Fury among rights groups as Facebook lifts Trump ban

article: In a highly anticipated decision, Meta has said it will allow Donald Trump back on Facebook and Instagram following a two-year ban from the platforms over his online behavior during the 6 January insurrection. Meta will allow Trump to return âin coming weeksâ but âwith new guardrails in place to deter repeat offensesâ, Metaâs president of global affairs, Nick Clegg, wrote in a blogpost explaining the decision. âLike any other Facebook or Instagram user, Mr Trump is subject to our community standards,â Clegg wrote. âIn the event that Mr Trump posts further violating content, the content will be removed and he will be suspended for between one month and two years, depending on the severity of the violation.â Trump was removed from Meta platforms following the Capitol riots on 6 January 2021, during which he posted unsubstantiated claims that the election had been stolen, praised increasingly violent protesters and condemned former vice-president Mike Pence even as the mob threatened his life. Clegg said the suspension was âan extraordinary decision taken in extraordinary circumstancesâ and that Meta has weighed âwhether there remain such extraordinary circumstances that extending the suspension beyond the original two-year period is justifiedâ. Ultimately, the company has decided that its platforms should be available for âopen, public and democratic debateâ and that users âshould be able to hear from a former President of the United States, and a declared candidate for that office againâ, he wrote. âThe public should be able to hear what their politicians are saying â the good, the bad and the ugly â so that they can make informed choices at the ballot box,â he said. While it is unclear if the former president will begin posting again on the platform, his campaign indicated he had a desire to return in a letter sent to Meta in January. âWe believe that the ban on President Trumpâs account on Facebook has dramatically distorted and inhibited the public discourse,â the letter said. Safety concerns and a politicized debate The move is likely to influence how other social media companies will handle the thorny balance of free speech and content moderation when it comes to world leaders and other newsworthy individuals, a debate made all the more urgent by Trumpâs run for the US presidency once again. Online safety advocates have warned that Trumpâs return will result in an increase of misinformation and real-life violence. Since being removed from Meta-owned platforms, the former president has continued to promote baseless conspiracy theories elsewhere, predominantly on his own network, Truth Social. While widely expected, the decision still drew sharp rebukes from civil rights advocates. âFacebook has policies but they under-enforce them,â said Laura Murphy, an attorney who led a two-year long audit of Facebook concluding in 2020. âI worry about Facebookâs capacity to understand the real world harm that Trump poses: Facebook has been too slow to act.â The Anti-Defamation League, the NAACP, Free Press and other groups also expressed concern on Wednesday over Facebookâs ability to prevent any future attacks on the democratic process, with Trump still repeating his false claim that he won the 2020 presidential election. âWith the mass murders in Colorado or in Buffalo, you can see there is already a cauldron of extremism that is only intensified if Trump weighs in,â said Angelo Carusone, president and CEO of media watchdog Media Matters for America. âWhen Trump is given a platform, it ratchets up the temperature on a landscape that is already simmering â one that will put us on a path to increased violence.â After the 6 January riots, the former president was also banned from Twitter, Snapchat and YouTube. Some of those platforms have already allowed Trump to return. Twitterâs ban, while initially permanent, was later overruled by its new chief executive, Elon Musk. YouTube has not shared a timeline on a decision to allow Trump to return. Trump remains banned from Snapchat. Meta, however, dragged out its ultimate decision. In 2021, CEO Mark Zuckerberg explained in a post that Trump had been barred from the platforms for encouraging violence and that he would remain suspended until a peaceful transition of power could take place. While Zuckerberg did not initially offer a timeline on the ban, the company punted its decision about whether to remove him permanently to its oversight board: a group of appointed academics and former politicians meant to operate independently of Facebookâs corporate leadership. That group ruled in May 2021 that the penalties should not be âindeterminateâ, but kicked the final ruling on Trumpâs accounts back to Meta, suggesting it decide in six months â two years after the riots. The deadline was initially slated for 7 January, and reports from inside Meta suggested the company was intensely debating the decision. Clegg wrote in a 2021 blogpost that Trumpâs accounts would need to be strictly monitored in the event of his return. How the âguardrailsâ could work Announcing the decision on Wednesday, Clegg said Metaâs âguardrailsâ would include taking action against content that does not directly violate their community standards but âcontributes to the sort of risk that materialized on January 6th, such as content that delegitimizes an upcoming election or is related to QAnonâ. Meta âmay limit the distribution of such posts, and for repeated instances, may temporarily restrict access to our advertising toolsâ, Clegg said, or âremove the re-share buttonâ from posts. Trump responded to the news with a short statement on Truth Social, reposted by others on Twitter, saying that âsuch a thing should never happen again to a sitting presidentâ but did not indicate if or when he would return to the platform. It remains to be seen if he will actually begin posting again on the platforms where his accounts have been reinstated. While he initially suggested he would be âstaying on Truth [Social]â, his own social media platform, recent reports said he was eager to return to Facebook, formally appealing to Meta to reinstate his accounts. But weeks after returning to Twitter, Trump had yet to tweet again. Some have suggested the silence has been due to an exclusivity agreement he has with Truth Social. A report from Rolling Stone said Trump planned to begin tweeting again when the agreement, which requires him to post all news to the app six hours in advance of any other platform, expires in June. Trump has a far broader reach on mainstream social platforms compared with Truth Social, where he has just 5 million followers. Many online safety advocates have warned Trumpâs return would be toxic, and Democratic lawmakers on Capitol Hill urged Meta in a December letter to uphold the ban. Representative Adam Schiff, a Democrat who previously chaired the House intelligence committee, criticized the decision to reinstate him. âTrump incited an insurrection,â Schiff wrote on Twitter. âGiving him back access to a social media platform to spread his lies and demagoguery is dangerous.â Trumpâs account has remained online even after his ban, but he had been unable to publish new posts. Civil rights groups say that regardless of the former presidentâs future actions the Meta decision marks a dangerous precedent. âWhether he uses the platforms or not, a reinstatement by Meta sends a message that there are no real consequences even for inciting insurrection and a coup on their channels,â said a group of scholars, advocates and activists calling itself the Real Facebook Oversight Board in a statement. âSomeone who has violated their terms of service repeatedly, spread disinformation on their platforms and fomented violence would be welcomed back.â Reuters contributed reporting
headline: Trumpâs Facebook and Instagram ban to be lifted, Meta announces

chat_gpt_summary: Donald Trump's advisers have written a letter to Meta, asking for his Facebook ban to be lifted as he gears up for his 2024 presidential campaign. The former president was banned from the social media platform more than two years ago following an unsuccessful attempt to stop the certification of Joe Biden's victory in the 2020 presidential election. Meta has reportedly set up an internal working group to debate whether the ban should be lifted, with a decision expected in the coming weeks. Trump's accounts on Facebook and Twitter have 34 million and nearly 88 million followers, respectively, while on his own rival social media service, Truth Social, he has fewer than 5 million followers.
article: Donald Trump has petitioned Meta to restore his access to Facebook, as he reportedly looks to shift his 2024 presidential campaign into a higher gear. The former president was banned from Facebook more than two years ago, after his followers attacked the US Capitol in an unsuccessful attempt to stop certification of Joe Bidenâs victory in the 2020 presidential election. In a letter to Meta obtained by NBC News on Wednesday, Trump advisers argued that the ban âdramatically distorted and inhibited the public discourseâ and should be rescinded. Meta said it would âannounce a decision in the coming weeksâ. Their verdict stems from a self-imposed deadline: while Trumpâs ban was initially indefinite, the company later pledged to revisit his accounts in January 2023, two years after the suspension began. The company has reportedly set up an internal working group, bringing together senior figures across the organization, to debate the final decision. Facebook and Twitter banned Trump a day after the January 6 attack, which has been linked to nine deaths including suicides among law enforcement. Trump used his Twitter account to encourage supporters to gather near the Capitol. In a speech before the attack, he urged supporters to âfight like hellâ. He then used Twitter to criticize his vice-president, Mike Pence, for not stopping certification while the attack was in progress. A congressional committee recommended that Trump be criminally charged in connection with the attack, the fate of hundreds of his supporters. Twitter lifted its ban on Trump after Elon Musk bought the platform last year. But Trump has not tweeted since, choosing to remain on his own rival social media service, Truth Social. NBC quoted an anonymous Republican who said Trump had been bragging about eventually returning to Twitter and predicted the ex-president would do so. Trumpâs accounts on Facebook and Twitter have 34 million and nearly 88 million followers respectively. On Truth Social, he has fewer than 5 million followers. Trump used Twitter and Facebook extensively when he ran for the presidency in 2016 and throughout his time in office. Impeached over the Capitol attack but acquitted, Trump announced his 2024 run in mid-November. In doing so he sought to take credit for Republicans winning back the US House in the midterm elections, though their majority was much narrower than expected and many candidates Trump endorsed suffered high-profile defeats. Trumpâs ban sparked fierce debate, with Republicans deriding the move as big tech censorship, while others said it was too little too late. Experts have said that the stakes for his potential return are high, considering his extremist rhetoric and propensity for spreading misinformation have only intensified since he left office. âTrumpâs behavior and language have gotten significantly worse and more extreme since he was first suspended from the Facebook platform,â said James Steyer, the founder and chief executive of online safety organization Common Sense Media. âPermitting him to return now would be a serious affront to our democracy and to Metaâs own publicly declared standards. The ban should be made permanent.â
headline: Trump pleads with Meta to restore Facebook account

chat_gpt_summary: Meta, the parent company of Facebook and Instagram, has been urged to amend its policy banning bare-chested images of women by its oversight board. The board recommended that the company "define clear, objective, rights-respecting criteria" when it comes to moderating nudity "so that all people are treated in a manner consistent with international human rights standards". The policy has been criticised for being based on a binary view of gender and a distinction between male and female bodies, which makes rules against nipple-baring "unclear" when it comes to intersex, non-binary and transgender users. Meta has 60 days to respond publicly to the board's recommendations.
article: Facebook and Instagramâs parent company could soon free the nipple. More than a decade after breastfeeding mothers first held a ânurse-inâ at Facebookâs headquarters to protest against its ban on breasts, Metaâs oversight board has called for an overhaul to the companyâs rules banning bare-chested images of women â but not men. In a decision dated 17 January, the oversight board â a group of academics, politicians, and journalists who advise the company on its content-moderation policies â recommended that Meta change its adult nudity and sexual activity community standard âso that it is governed by clear criteria that respect international human rights standardsâ. The oversight boardâs ruling follows Facebookâs censorship of two posts from an account run by an American couple who are transgender and non-binary. The posts showed the couple posing topless, but with their nipples covered, with captions describing trans healthcare and raising money for top surgery. The posts were flagged by users, then reviewed and removed by an AI system. After the couple appealed the decision, Meta eventually restored the posts. The board found that âthe policy is based on a binary view of gender and a distinction between male and female bodiesâ, which makes rules against nipple-baring âunclearâ when it comes to intersex, non-binary and transgender users. It recommended that Meta âdefine clear, objective, rights-respecting criteriaâ when it comes to moderating nudity âso that all people are treated in a manner consistent with international human rights standardsâ. âLactivistsâ spent the 2000s attempting to squash the image of breasts as inherently sexual, and the campaign to #FreetheNipple went mainstream in 2013. The phrase entered pop-feminist parlance in 2013 after Facebook took down clips from the actor/director Lina Escoâs documentary Free the Nipple. The campaign gained wide support on college campuses and was championed by celebrities including Rihanna, Miley Cyrus and Lena Dunham. As recently as last week, Florence Pugh addressed wearing a sheer, hot pink Valentino gown on the red carpet, saying: âOf course, I donât want to offend people, but I think my point is: how can my nipples offend you that much?â In 2015, the Los Angeles-based artist Micol Hebron created stickers of male nipples â which are permitted on Instagram â so that female Instagram users could superimpose them over their own to mock the disparity. Hebron was invited to Instagramâs headquarters in 2019 with a group of influencers to talk about the companyâs nipple policy. âDuring that meeting, we learned that there were no transgender people on the content moderation policy team, and I also observed that there were no gender-neutral bathrooms there,â Hebron said. âTo me, that was all I needed to know to understand the conversation of gender and inclusivity was not being had at Meta.â A Meta representative disputed Hebronâs characterization of the event, adding: âMuch has changed since 2019.â But Hebron said she was âexcitedâ that the oversight board had taken up the issue of gender and sex-based discrimination. âBeyond just âletâs let women be toplessâ, which is not at all my interest, I think itâs really important to hold on to the goal of allowing all bodies to have autonomy,â Hebron said. âIt sounds so frivolous to a lot of people to talk about nipples, but if you think about the ways that governments around the world try to control and repress female-identifying bodies, trans bodies or non-binary bodies, itâs not.â Meta âwelcomes the boardâs decision in this caseâ, a representative said in a statement that noted that the coupleâs photos had been reinstated âprior to the decisionâ. âWe are constantly evolving our policies to help make our platforms safer for everyone,â the spokesperson added. âWe know more can be done to support the LGBTQ+ community, and that means working with experts and LGBTQ+ advocacy organizations on a range of issues and product improvements.â Meta has 60 days to respond publicly to the boardâs recommendations. While advocates may welcome the idea of a freer nipple online, questions remain about how Metaâs automated content-moderation systems will be able to enforce a new policy on nipples. A couple fundraising to afford top surgery is not the same as someone soliciting sex online, but the companyâs AI did not recognize the difference in the post at first. So how will these systems be able to tell the difference between a topless post and porn? âContext is everything, and algorithms are terrible at context,â Emily Bell, director of the Tow Center for Digital Journalism, told the Guardian. âThe interesting question will be the tension over how Meta can create new rules without opening the floodgates to porn, which is why those rules exist in the first place. That ought to be possible, but Iâm skeptical of whether it is if content moderation is automated.â (Bell previously held several positions at the Guardian, including non-executive director of the Scott Trust.) Facebook and Instagram users can also flag posts they believe violate the companyâs policies, as they did for the photo that spurred the boardâs decision. âIt doesnât take a genius to work out that there are certain areas of the culture wars where content moderation gets weaponized,â Bell said. âA post about top surgery should not have been flagged in the first place, but it was. This could have been the actions of an anti-trans bad actor.â Jillian York, an activist and director of international freedom of expression at the Electronic Frontier Foundation, added that it was âtrickyâ for companies that use AI to make the right decision in every scenario. âFor instance, itâs not easy for an automated technology to make a decision about who is a topless adult, versus who is a topless child,â she said. âAI may be able to make a determination between a nine-year-old and a 26-year-old, but what about a 17-year-old and an 18-year-old?â Sarah Murnen, the Samuel B Cummings II professor of psychology at Kenyon College, said the Free the Nipple movement had once centered white, cisgender women â but that was changing. âWhen we talked about this as an issue about cis women, it seemed less important, potentially, than it is now with trans people wanting to be open about their bodies, while anti-trans sentiment is at an all-time-high,â she said. Now, Meta has been advised to loosen the restrictive, binary way it polices bodies online. But many are quick to doubt AIâs potential to protect all users. âThatâs the big lesson of all of this: when you create automated systems, youâre going to have consequences for people who are more marginalized, or the minority in society,â said Bell. âThose are the people who are penalized by the application of an algorithm.â
headline: Free the nipple: Facebook and Instagram told to overhaul ban on bare breasts

chat_gpt_summary: Four friends from India who were on board the Yeti Airlines flight that crashed in Nepal on Sunday recorded their excitement on a Facebook live video just moments before the plane went down. The four men were heading to Pokhara for a trip of a lifetime to visit temples and paraglide in Nepal's famed Annapurna mountain range. The video shows the men laughing and joking before the plane suddenly appears to veer off and crash, with the sounds of the impact captured on the phone camera. The video suggests that the passengers had no warning before the explosion. The crash killed all 68 passengers and four staff on board, including the four Indian friends.
article: In the moments before Nepalâs deadliest air crash in decades on Sunday, four friends from India who were onboard began excitedly recording the descent on a Facebook live video. They were heading to Pokhara for the trip of a lifetime, intending to visit temples and paraglide in Nepalâs famed Annapurna mountain range. âItâs really fun,â one of the men can be heard on the video surveying the city below as the plane began its descent. The friends can be heard laughing and joking as the camera is turned on a smiling Sonu Jaiswal, a 29-year-old father-of-three, who ran a small business back home in India. All appears calm in the plane, with no emergency announcements or warnings from the pilot or staff. But suddenly, the plane appears to veer off with a loud roar, and the sounds of it crashing to the ground are captured on the phone camera, before the screen is filled with flames. The burning debris of the aircraft is momentarily visible on the screen before it goes black. No voices can be heard after that. The harrowing video indicates that the 68 passengers and four staff onboard the Yeti Airlines flight had no idea the plane was in danger before an explosion just as it was landing. Vishal Koswal, 21, a close friend of the four men heard in the video, confirmed the authenticity of the video. He identified the four men, all from Ghazipur district in the state of Uttar Pradesh, as 29-year-old Jaiswal, 28-year-old Anil Rajbhar, 23-year-old Vishal Sharma and Abhishek Singh Kushwaha, 23, who had left for Nepal on 12 January. Local police also confirmed their identities. Koswal said he had meant to join his four friends on the trip to Nepal but had to stay home after a the death of a relative. During their trip, he had spoken to them many times over video call, including a couple of hours before the crash. âSonu was showing us the mountains around on the call and was clearly excited, so were we,â said Koswal. âHe told me on that call that after landing in Pokhara, they would visit some temples there and then in the evening take a train back home.â He described the four friends as like âbrothersâ and said everyone in the area was âvery emotionalâ. âThis all seems like a nightmare, I still cannot believe we have lost all of them,â he added. âI canât watch that crash video again, it is very hard and painful. A big tragedy has fallen over us.â On Monday, rescuers continued the search to recover the final four bodies from the wreckage. There was no hope for survivors, said the authorities. The prime minister of Nepal declared a national day of mourning on Monday. The group of friends from India were among 15 foreign nationals who were onboard the plane. The flight was carrying 57 Nepalis, five Indians, four Russians, two South Koreans, and one person each from Argentina, Britain, Australia and France. It plunged into a gorge moments before it was due to land at Pokharaâs new international airport. It was Nepalâs worst aviation disaster since 1992, when 167 people died onboard a Pakistan International Airlines flight that crashed on approach to Kathmandu. The fire and thick smoke, as well as the treacherous terrain, made the rescue efforts by police and army officers challenging. Soldiers used ropes and stretchers to retrieve bodies from the 300-metre (1,000ft) deep ravine late into the night on Sunday. âWe have so far sent 63 bodies to the hospital,â said police officer AK Chhetri on Monday. Arun Tamu, 44, who was about 500 metres away from the site where the plane crashed, told AFP news agency he was among those who ran to the site to try to help. âA few of us rushed to see if we can rescue anybody. I saw at least two women were breathing. The fire was getting very intense and it made it difficult for us to approach closer,â he said. Nepalâs air industry has boomed in recent years, carrying goods and people between hard-to-reach areas, as well as foreign trekkers and climbers. But it has also been plagued by poor safety due to insufficient training and maintenance. In May 2022, all 22 people onboard a plane operated by Nepali carrier Tara Air died when it crashed, and in March 2018, 51 people died when a US-Bangla Airlines plane crashed near Kathmandu. The European Union has banned all Nepal airlines from its airspace over safety concerns. â¢ This article was updated on 19 January 2023 to record that one passenger initially listed as Irish, proved to be British.
headline: Nepal plane crash: last moments inside cabin caught on passengerâs Facebook live video

chat_gpt_summary: Facebook is facing a critical decision about whether to reinstate Donald Trump's account or to keep him off the platform permanently. The decision is set to be announced later this month, two years after he was suspended for his actions during the Capitol riots in January 6. Lawmakers, activists and extremism researchers have urged the platform to keep him out, stating that he continues to spread election misinformation and incite violence. If Trump is reinstated, it would set a new precedent for how social media firms balance free speech with content moderation, especially when it comes to world leaders and newsworthy individuals.
article: Itâs been a little more than two years since Meta suspended Donald Trump from Facebook and Instagram over his actions during the January 6 Capitol riots. Now, a major decision looms â reinstate Trumpâs account, or keep him off the platform for good? Itâs a widely-watched decision that will set a new precedent for how social media firms balance free speech with content moderation, especially when it comes to world leaders and other newsworthy individuals. The announcement â expected later this month stems from a self-imposed deadline. While Trumpâs ban was initially indefinite, the company later pledged to revisit whether to reinstate his accounts in January 2023, two years after the suspension began. The stakes are high, and with Trump announcing his campaign for re-election for 2024, lawmakers, activists and extremism researchers have urged Meta to keep him out. They say the former presidentâs propensity for misinformation and extremist thinking has only intensified since he left office, and fear he could incite further violence if he is allowed to return. âTrumpâs behavior and language have gotten significantly worse and more extreme since he was first suspended from the Facebook platform,â said James Steyer, the founder and CEO of online safety organization Common Sense Media. âPermitting him to return now would be a serious affront to our democracy and to Metaâs own publicly declared standards. The ban should be made permanent.â In December, Democratic lawmakers on Capitol Hill urged Meta in a letter to uphold the ban, stating that Trump has continued to spread election misinformation and incite violence on his own social platform, Truth Social. âFor Meta to credibly maintain a legitimate election integrity policy, it is essential that your company maintain its platform ban on former president Trump,â the letter said. âBased on Metaâs own statement on standards for allowing Trump back on the platform, his account should continue to be restricted.â The looming decision has also reinvigorated a debate that has been raging for years: how much control should private platforms have over public speech? Legislation regarding the monitoring of hate speech, misinformation and violence have long stalled, leading many to call for more action ahead of the 2024 elections. âThe most critical part of this whole drama is that whole democratic societies are now routinely held hostage to a handful of individuals who have been allowed to own critical digital infrastructure â to control the communication spaces through which society now operates,â said Shoshana Zuboff, author of the Age of Surveillance Capitalism. How we got here The January 6 riots marked a breaking point in the long-standing debate over social media firmsâ role in addressing hate speech and misinformation from public leaders. Many companies allowed Trump to stay on their platforms throughout his time in office despite violations of terms, citing public interest in political figureheadsâ speech.
