But in the days after the riots, during which he posted in praise of his supporters and condemned Mike Pence even as rioters threatened the then vice-presidentâs life, Trump was banned from Twitter, Snapchat, YouTube and Meta platforms. The decisions heralded a political reckoning, with Republicans complaining of censorship and others saying the bans were too little too late. Twitter said its own suspension of Trump would be permanent, though the platform reversed course and reinstated his account after Elon Musk took over as CEO last year. YouTube said the ban was indefinite, and Snapchat has yet to reinstate his accounts. CEO Mark Zuckerberg explained in a 2021 post that Trump had been barred from the platforms for encouraging violence and that he would remain suspended until a peaceful transition of power could take place. âHis decision to use his platform to condone rather than condemn the actions of his supporters at the Capitol building has rightly disturbed people in the US and around the world,â Zuckerberg said. Shortly after the ban, however, the company punted its decision about whether to remove him permanently to its oversight board: a group of appointed academics and former politicians meant to operate independently of Facebookâs corporate leadership. In May 2021, the board ruled that the penalties should not be âindeterminateâ but kicked the final ruling on Trumpâs accounts back to Meta, suggesting it decide in six months â two years after the riots. While Musk unilaterally decided to reinstate Trump after a brief poll on Twitter, Meta has offered more transparency into its decision, publishing public blog posts about the process and stating new measures will be in place to monitor Trumpâs activity should he return. âWhen the suspension is eventually lifted, there will be a strict set of rapidly escalating sanctions that will be triggered if Mr Trump commits further violations in the future, up to and including permanent removal of his pages and accounts,â Nick Clegg, Metaâs president of global affairs, wrote in a blog post in 2021. The company has set up an internal working group with employees from across the company to make the final decision, according to CNN. While it was initially slated for 7 January, that date has come and gone, leaving many to speculate on the outcome. Meta did not respond to a request for a comment regarding a timeline. What would Trumpâs return mean? If Trump does return, many safety advocates acknowledge that the online landscape has changed significantly since his departure. The market is far more fragmented today, with companies such as Parler and Trumpâs own social media platform Truth Social marketing themselves as censor-free alternatives for conservatives. Trumpâs reach on Truth Social â where he has 5 million followers â pales in comparison to Twitter, where he had more than 88 million followers at the time of his ban. Still, the former president has pledged to prioritize his accounts there, in part due to an exclusivity agreement that requires him to post all news to the app six hours in advance of any other platform, according to a May filing to the Securities and Exchange Commission. Nearly two months after his account was reinstated by Musk, the former president has yet to tweet, raising the question of whether he would even return to Facebook if allowed. Trump, for his part, appears to have soured on his preferred platforms of the past. In an interview with Fox News, Trump suggested he would not be tweeting again. âI am staying on Truth. I like it better, I like the way it works, I like Elon, but Iâm staying on Truth,â he said. In the aftermath of his removal from Meta platforms, Trump has been highly critical of Facebook and Zuckerberg. âSadly, Facebook has been doing very poorly since they took me off,â he wrote on Truth Social. âIt has lost $750bn in value and has become very boring.â Facebookâs user base has also repeatedly declined over the past year, giving Trump â who had 34 million followers at the time of his suspension â less of an impact if he were to return. âFacebook is significantly less relevant and potent than it was in 2018 and in 2020,â said Angelo Carusone, president and CEO of media watchdog Media Matters for America. âAlthough the harms are not eliminated, its destructive potential is certainly weaker. It matters because it helps inform what to expect.â Despite the shift, experts say recent events have underscored that online misinformation is as dangerous as ever. Social media helped fuel attacks on government buildings in Brazil this week that mirrored the 2021 Capitol riots, highlighting concerns that not enough has changed in the last two years. âWe can draw a lot of parallels between these situations, and they tie directly back to how these platforms still play a huge role in the distribution of information and incitement of violence,â said Jelani Drew-Davi, campaign director for digital social justice firm Kairos. And Trumpâs own rhetoric has only gotten more extreme since his suspension from Facebook, experts say. At least 350 posts of the more than 2,000 Trump made on Truth Social between April and October 2022 would violate Facebookâs Community Standards and warrant removal, according to researchers at Accountable Tech. Those included 116 posts that endorsed QAnon, a conspiracy movement that has been linked to real-world violence and 239 posts casting doubt on US election validity. Despite the diminishing power of Facebook as a platform, a Trump return would directly contribute to the continuing mainstream acceptance of dangerous QAnon ideologies and other conspiracy theories, said Carusone. âWith the mass murders in Colorado or in Buffalo, you can see there is already a cauldron of extremism that is only intensified if Trump weighs in,â he said. âWhen Trump is given a platform, it ratchets up the temperature on a landscape that is already simmering â one that will put us on a path to increased violence.â
headline: Metaâs decision on Donald Trump is looming. Will he return to Facebook?

chat_gpt_summary: Facebook owner Meta will pay $725m to settle a class-action lawsuit alleging privacy violations related to the Cambridge Analytica scandal. The settlement will end a dispute over the political consultancy accessing the data of tens of millions of Facebook users without their consent and using it to target political adverts. The lawyers leading the case said the settlement would be the largest data privacy or data breach class action settlement ever achieved in the US, 10% higher than the next largest also awarded against Facebook. The settlement still needs to be approved by a judge, and Meta did not admit to wrongdoing.
article: Meta, the Facebook owner, will pay out $725m (Â£600m) to plaintiffs in a class-action lawsuit alleging privacy violations related to the Cambridge Analytica scandal, the company has said in a court filing. The settlement will end a long-running dispute over the revelations that the political consultancy had accessed the data of tens of millions of Facebook users without their consent, and used it to target political adverts. âThis historic settlement will provide meaningful relief to the class in this complex and novel privacy case,â the lawyers leading the case, Derek Loeser and Lesley Weaver, said. They added in a court filing that the settlement âwould be the largest data privacy or data breach class action settlement ever achieved in the United Statesâ, 10% higher again than the next largest â also awarded against Facebook, for signing up users to facial recognition services without their consent. In a statement, a Meta spokesperson said: âWe pursued a settlement as itâs in the best interest of our community and shareholders. Over the last three years we revamped our approach to privacy and implemented a comprehensive privacy programme. We look forward to continuing to build services people love and trust with privacy at the forefront.â The company did not admit to wrongdoing as part of the settlement, which still needs to be approved by a judge. The case revolved around allegations that Facebook had broken state and federal laws by failing to prevent app developers harvesting user data on a widespread basis. Users were misled into believing that the company offered them control over their personal data, the lawsuit argued, when in fact âFacebook, despite its promises to restrict access, continued to allow a preferred list of app developers to access the information of usersâ friendsâ. Facebookâs defence centred on the claim that users could not expect absolute privacy for information they had already posted on the site with the knowledge that it would be shown to their friends. As a result, the company argued, the users had suffered no âtangibleâ harm. That was rejected in 2019 by Judge Vince Chhabria, who said: âFacebookâs motion to dismiss is littered with assumptions about the degree to which social media users can reasonably expect their personal information and communications to remain private. Facebookâs view is so wrong. âSharing information with your social media friends does not categorically eliminate your privacy interest in that information.â At the core of the case are the revelations around Cambridge Analytica, which harvested the data of tens of millions of Facebook users by partnering with a personality quiz operation and using the Facebook API to build extensive profiles on individualsâ behaviour and personalities. Facebook discovered the operation in 2015, but it was only revealed to the public in March 2018, when an Observer investigation uncovered the operationâs involvement in the US election.
headline: Facebook owner to settle class-action suit over Cambridge Analytica scandal

chat_gpt_summary: A rare and striking toadstool species, Amanita sculpta, has been rediscovered in Singapore after over 80 years of no sightings. The species was first collected in 1939 in the Bukit Timah Nature Reserve and was described as a new species in 1962, but was not seen again until a member of the public posted a photo of the fungus on Facebook in August 2020. Serena Lee, a senior manager at Singapore Botanic Gardens, identified the species and notes that its large size and dark colours help it camouflage in its environment. The rediscovery highlights the importance of biodiversity surveys and public participation in documenting sightings.
article: âThe cap is like a chocolate chip cookie,â says Serena Lee, senior manager at Singapore Botanic Gardensâ herbarium, describing the top of the sculptured toadstool (Amanita sculpta). âItâs big and chunky, and has a beige and dark brown cap with pileal warts.â Despite its distinctive appearance and a large fruiting body that can range from 10 to 27cm wide, the sculptured toadstool went awol in Singapore for more than 80 years. It was first collected in the 163-hectare (402-acre) Bukit Timah Nature Reserve, one of the first forest reserves to be created in Singapore, in 1939, and was described as a new species in 1962 by botanist EJH Corner, a former assistant director of the Singapore Botanic Gardens. The toadstool species has been recorded in other parts of Asia, including Malaysia, Thailand, China, Japan and Laos, but is thought to be rare and has been put up for assessment for the IUCN Red List. There were no sightings of the fungus in Singapore until August 2020, when a member of the public posted a photo of a curious-looking toadstool to a Facebook group about the flora of Malaysia and Singapore. âI like exploring different plants and mushrooms that I havenât seen before,â says Serene Toh, who posted the picture. âWhat captured my attention in this case was the toadstoolâs attractive colour and appearance.â Tohâs contribution is seen as a good example of the public assisting scientific research and knowledge, which can aid conservation projects. The photo of the peculiar fungus in its bud stage, which Toh had taken in Bukit Timah Nature Reserve, was forwarded to Lee. âMy colleagues from the national parks board of Singapore and I kept an eye out for the species in the nature reserve, although we were uncertain of its exact location,â Lee recalls. âJust a few days later, though â¦ it was seen at the base of a Shorea leprosula tree, along the main road to the summit of Bukit Timah Hill. âIt was a magnificent specimen,â says Lee, who identified the species. âIts cap was 27cm wide â by far the largest non-bracket type macrofungus weâve ever seen in Singapore. Most species of macrofungi in Singapore have caps that are only 1cm to 5cm wide and barely make it past 10cm in height.â It may seem strange that such a striking and ârather hugeâ toadstool could exist but remain unseen for nearly a century. âDespite the large size of its fruiting body, its dark shadowy colours help it to camouflage against the background,â explains Lee. âSo itâs difficult to spot it if youâre not consciously looking for it. It might simply have gone unnoticed over the years.â Since it was ârediscoveredâ in Singapore, the Amanita sculpta has been closely studied. âHaving the material allows us to carry out genetic sequencing to develop a better understanding of the evolutionary and phylogenetic relationships with other species,â says Lee. âThe rediscovery also underscores the importance of biodiversity surveys to take stock of the fungi and other flora and faunal species that can be found in Singapore. It highlights the ability of some species to persist in even a small forest fragment and underscores Singaporeâs commitment to the conservation of key habitats and biodiversity.â Lee is hopeful the publicâs interest in fungi will continue. âWeâve observed growing public awareness and curiosity in fungi when people go on their walks and hikes in Singapore,â she says. âBy raising public awareness of such species, more people can help to look out for them and document any sightings with their phones or cameras,â she says. âSince we started studying them, rediscoveries, new records and even new genus or species have been found. For instance, in 2021, nine plant, fungal and algal species in Singapore were published as new records or rediscoveries, with more than half found in Bukit Timah Nature Reserve. âThat means a total of 124 new plant species, new records and rediscoveries in Singapore have been published over the past five years.â Find more age of extinction coverage here, and follow biodiversity reporters Phoebe Weston and Patrick Greenfield on Twitter for all the latest news and features
headline: Lost and found: how a Facebook post led to the âchocolate chipâ toadstool

chat_gpt_summary: Meta, the parent company of Facebook, is facing a lawsuit in Kenya over allegations that it allowed posts that incited violence during the war in Tigray to spread on the social media platform. The lawsuit is seeking the creation of a $1.6bn fund for victims of hate speech, with one petitioner stating that his father was murdered after being targeted with racist messages. An investigation in February revealed Facebooks repeated failure to act on posts inciting violence during the conflict in northern Ethiopia, which lasted two years. The lawsuit is also calling for a compensation fund of 200bn Kenyan shillings for victims of hate and violence on Facebook. Amnesty International is among seven organisations supporting the legal action.
article: Meta has been accused in a lawsuit of letting posts that inflamed the war in Tigray flourish on Facebook, after an Observer investigation in February revealed repeated inaction on posts that incited violence. The lawsuit, filed in the high court of Kenya, where Metaâs sub-Saharan African operations are based, alleges that Facebookâs recommendations systems amplified hateful and violent posts in the context of the war in northern Ethiopia, which raged for two years until a ceasefire was agreed in early November. The lawsuit seeks the creation of a $1.6bn (Â£1.3bn) fund for victims of hate speech. One of the petitioners said his father, an Ethiopian academic, was targeted with racist messages before his murder in November 2021, and that Facebook did not remove the posts despite complaints. âIf Facebook had just stopped the spread of hate and moderated posts properly, my father would still be alive,â said Abrham Meareg, who is ethnic Tigrayan and an academic like his father. âIâm taking Facebook to court so no one ever suffers as my family has again. Iâm seeking justice for millions of my fellow Africans hurt by Facebookâs profiteering â and an apology for my fatherâs murder.â The case is asking for a compensation fund of 200bn Kenyan shillings (Â£1.3bn) to be established for victims of hate and violence on Facebook. In February an analysis by the Bureau of Investigative Journalism (TBIJ) and the Observer found that Facebook was letting users post content inciting violence through hate and misinformation, despite being aware that it helped directly fuel tensions in Tigray, where thousands have died and millions been displaced since war broke out in late 2020. The research found that one post from a local influencer, calling for people to âcleanseâ the area of supporters of Tigrayan forces, stayed up for four months after it was reported to the company. The family of Gebremichael Teweldemedhin, a Tigrayan jeweller abducted last December, believe that post and others like it had resulted in many attacks on Tigrayans in Gondar, a city in the Amhara region. Amnesty International is one of seven organisations supporting the lawsuit. âThe spread of dangerous content on Facebook lies at the heart of Metaâs pursuit of profit, as its systems are designed to keep people engaged,â Amnestyâs deputy regional director, Flavia Mwangovya, said. âThis legal action is a significant step in holding Meta to account for its harmful business model.â One of Amnestyâs own staffers, Fisseha Tekle, is a petitioner in the case. âIn Ethiopia, the people rely on social media for news and information,â he said. âBecause of the hate and disinformation on Facebook, human rights defenders have also become targets of threats and vitriol. I saw first hand how the dynamics on Facebook harmed my own human rights work and hope this case will redress the imbalance.â Facebook spokesperson Ben Walters told the Associated Press the company could not comment on the lawsuit because it hadnât received it. He shared a general statement saying: âWe have strict rules which outline what is and isnât allowed on Facebook and Instagram. Hate speech and incitement to violence are against these rules and we invest heavily in teams and technology to help us find and remove this content.â Facebook continues to develop its capabilities to catch violating content in Ethiopiaâs most widely spoken languages, the statement said. Facebook has repeatedly come under fire for expanding into countries with low media literacy, rapidly growing to encompass a large fraction of internet traffic in the area, and failing to devote sufficient resources to moderation in the local languages. That describes its role in Myanmar, where the site faces compensation claims worth more than Â£150bn after legal action was launched in the UK and US last December. Facebook admitted in 2018 that it had not done enough to prevent the incitement of violence and hate speech against the Rohingya, the Muslim minority in Myanmar. An independent report commissioned by the company found that âFacebook has become a means for those seeking to spread hate and cause harm, and posts have been linked to offline violenceâ. The company was also criticised by the UN for its âleading roleâ in the possible genocide.
headline: Meta faces $1.6bn lawsuit over Facebook posts inciting violence in Tigray war

chat_gpt_summary: Australian media companies may be exempt from liability for defamatory third-party comments on their social media posts if proposed defamation law reforms are enacted. The Standing Council of Attorneys General has provided in-principle support for modernizing the nation's defamation laws related to search engines and social media platforms. The proposed amendments include an innocent dissemination defense for internet intermediaries, shielding Facebook page administrators from defamation lawsuits over posts by third parties. They would require a written complaint to the forum administrator before they could be held liable for defamatory comments, and the changes would come into effect in 2024. The reforms aim to balance protecting free speech with the right of individuals to seek redress in appropriate circumstances for harm caused to their reputation.
article: Australian media companies may avoid liability for defamatory third-party comments on their social media posts if reforms supported by the nationâs attorneys general become law. The Standing Council of Attorneys General has given in-principle support to reforms to modernise the nationâs defamation laws relating to search engines and social media platforms. In a decision that had ramifications for any Facebook page administrator, the high court said last year media companies could be held liable for allegedly defamatory comments posted to their Facebook pages. The case was sparked after Dylan Voller, whose mistreatment in the Northern Territoryâs Don Dale youth detention centre led to a royal commission, sued some of Australiaâs biggest media groups including the Sydney Morning Herald, the Australian and Sky News over posts made by the public on their Facebook pages. The New South Wales attorney general, Mark Speakman, said the amendments, which include a new innocent dissemination defence for internet intermediaries, would substantially upgrade Australiaâs uniform defamation laws. âThe new innocent dissemination defence will be available to a person â other than an author, originator or poster of the matter â who provides or administers the online service by means of which the matter is published,â Speakman told Guardian Australia. âThis will include an individual or organisation who uses a facility on a social media platform to create and administer a public page.â Sign up for Guardian Australiaâs free morning and afternoon email newsletters for your daily news roundup Speakman said under the new defence, a person or organisation running a Facebook page would need to receive a written complaint regarding any allegedly defamatory third-party comments before they could be held liable. âOnce the forum administrator has received a complaint, they must take reasonable steps to remove or otherwise prevent access to the matter within seven days in order to rely on the defence,â he said. The changes, which would come into effect in 2024, are aimed at shielding all Facebook page administrators, not just media companies, from defamation lawsuits over posts by third parties. They would provide some relief to media companies in Australia, some of which responded by dedicating more resources for comment moderation on social media, or simply shut off their comments on some posts. In August, when releasing a discussion paper on defamation, Speakman said technology had advanced significantly since Australiaâs uniform defamation laws were drafted 18 years ago. âAlmost anyone can post their views on a wide range of platforms at the touch of a screen or a button,â he said. âIn considering this reform, it is critical that we balance protecting free speech with the right of individuals to seek redress in appropriate circumstances for harm caused to their reputation.â The reforms are a âpragmatic approach that is intended to strike a better balance between protecting reputations and not unreasonably limiting freedom of expression in the various circumstances where third parties publish defamatory matter via internet intermediariesâ, the council said in a communiquÃ©.
headline: Defamation reforms: Australian media may not be liable for Facebook comments in future

article: What a difference a year makes. Last October, Facebook supremo Mark Zuckerberg could barely wait to show the world what he was up to. âToday, weâre going to talk about the metaverse,â he enthused in a slick video presentation. âI want to share what we imagine is possible.â Transitioning almost seamlessly from his real self into a computer-generated avatar, Zuckerberg guided us through his vision for the virtual-reality future: playing poker in space with your buddies; sharing cool stuff; having work meetings and birthday parties with people on the other side of the world; customising your avatar (the avatars had no legs, which was weird). Zuckerberg was so all-in on the metaverse, he even rechristened his company Meta. This month, we saw a more subdued Zuckerberg on display: âI wanna say upfront that I take full responsibility for this decision,â he told employees morosely. âThis was ultimately my call and it was one of the hardest calls that Iâve had to make in the 18 years of running the company.â Meta was laying off 11,000 people â 13% of its workforce. Poor third-quarter results had seen Metaâs share price drop by 25%, wiping $80bn off the companyâs value. Reality Labs, Metaâs metaverse division, had lost $3.7bn in the past three months, with worse expected to come. It wasnât all bad news, though: Zuckerberg announced last month that Meta avatars would at last be getting legs. After decades of spectacular âmove fast and break thingsâ growth, Zuckerbergâs empire is now looking a little fragile. Metaâs share price has fallen by more than 70% this year. Moneyspinners Facebook and Instagram are losing market share and Gen Z users to fresher rivals like TikTok and Snapchat. Appleâs changes to data privacy last year also decimated revenues â its introduction of an âask not to trackâ option on iPhones has effectively starved Facebook of the lucrative data it uses to target ads. Meanwhile, Meta has invested a staggering $100bn on metaverse research and development to date, $15bn in the past year alone â with apparently little to show for it. Zuckerbergâs newfound metaverse obsession could be seen as a preemptive virtual land grab for what is generally agreed to be the future of the internet. It could also represent an attempted second act, for both the 38-year-old and his somewhat tarnished Facebook brand. But the markets seem to be saying âcount us outâ, and according to reports, just 58% of Metaâs own employees said they understood the companyâs metaverse vision. Comments on the latest lay-offs in an anonymous employee survey included, âthe metaverse will be our slow deathâ and âMark Zuckerberg will single-handedly kill a company with the metaverseâ. If nothing else, Zuckerberg has popularised the term âmetaverseâ, even if he didnât invent it, and definitions of what it means vary. Zuckerberg explained it as âan embodied internet where youâre in the experience, not just looking at itâ. Rather than our current 2D, screen-based internet, in other words, the metaverse will be a 3D virtual space, accessed by either a VR headset or AR (augmented reality) glasses, which superimpose a layer of digital information on top of the visible world. Matthew Ball, tech investor and author of The Metaverse: How It Will Revolutionise Everything, defines the metaverse as âa massively scaled and interoperable network of real-time rendered 3D virtual worldsâ, with individual presence and continuity of data. He has to explain it less and less, he says: âA year ago, it was mostly âwhat is the metaverse?â Questions now are a lot more practical: what will be here? When? For whom? How, and why?â The âwhyâ is a particularly good question when it comes to Meta. âYouâre going to be able to do almost anything you can imagine,â said Zuckerberg in his intro video last year. âGet together with friends and family, work, learn, play, shop, create â¦â At the time we were just coming out of the pandemic. Remote working, video calling and e-commerce had suddenly become the norm. âMany people predicted this would be a permanent acceleration that would continue even after the pandemic ended,â Zuckerberg said in a recent staff email. âI did, too, so I made the decision to significantly increase our investments. Unfortunately, this did not play out the way I expected.â Post-pandemic, it turned out people still preferred meeting face to face or on a video call to donning a clunky VR headset and dragging your legless avatar into a virtual meeting room. It has been a similar story on the leisure side. Metaâs Quest VR headsets are the market leader, but most buyers are not using them to flock to Metaâs principal app, Horizon Worlds â which the company describes as âa synchronous social network where creators can build engaging worldsâ. Meta set a target of 500,000 Horizon Worlds users by the end of 2022; the current figure is nearer 200,000 â down from 300,000 in February, which suggests many first-time visitors are not returning. It has been criticised for programming bugs, instability, rudimentary graphics and a general sense of boredom. From my own visits to Horizon Worlds, the 3D motion and audio were fine but the graphics were basic, often garish and textureless: a good two decades behind todayâs best video games. The feeling is of a sparsely attended trade fair. Many of Horizon Worldsâ activities felt more like demonstrations: in a perfunctory wild west town, you can shoot a virtual bottle in a virtual saloon with your virtual pistol (with unsatisfyingly lo-fi results) and ride a hobby horse (literally a virtual horseâs head on a broomstick). At the Marvel superheroes world, you can try on various costumes that enable you to fly or shoot lightning bolts, and thatâs about it. There were few people in either the social âhangoutâ areas or the âgamesâ section, and most of the strangers I encountered seemed to be American children. One had the avatar and voice of a 10-year-old girl. Not even the people making Horizon Worlds have embraced it. Memos leaked in October appeared to show the Meta vice-president, Vishal Shah, urging staff to use their own products more. âIf we donât love it, how can we expect our users to love it?â Shah wrote. âEveryone in this organisation should make it their mission to fall in love with Horizon Worlds. You canât do that without using it. Get in there.â Meanwhile, direct competitors such as VRChat and Rec Room are thriving. âItâs pretty clear they are offering something that Meta doesnât,â says veteran games designer Raph Koster, namely better avatars, a wider choices of games and, critically, bigger crowds (Rec Room has an estimated three million monthly users). âNext to those, Meta looks relatively sterile and empty. Thereâs just a lack of sufficient entertainment in there.â Horizon Worldâs numbers are dwarfed by those of online games (most of which are accessible with and without VR headsets). Fortnite attracts 250 million active players a month. Gaming platform Roblox has more 200 million visitors a month and Minecraft 170 million (two-thirds of whom are under 16 â the exact demographic that is turning away from Facebook and other social media). âHistorically, weâve seen that game worlds generally donât have any trouble attracting an audience,â says Koster. This is not a revelation. âBars with a jukebox or a pool table tend to do better than bars without anything. It doesnât change because you digitise the experience.â Unlike Meta, the games industry began with the âwhy?â It was building complex, sophisticated, popular virtual worlds â proto-metaverses â long before the idea caught Zuckerbergâs eye. As such, it is well positioned for a slice of the metaverse pie. Epic Games, for example, whose Unreal game engine (think of it as the âbrainâ of the game; the software framework that builds the reality in real time) powers not only its bestselling Fortnite but hundreds of other games and applications, making it attractive to independent metaverse-builders. In April, Sony and Lego invested $2bn in Epicâs metaverse vision. In January, Microsoft moved to acquire another games giant, Activision Blizzard, makers of World of Warcraft, Overwatch, Call of Duty and Candy Crush, for nearly $70bn (the deal is currently under antitrust review). Having sprung out of social networks like Facebook, Metaâs model is based on âan attention economy, not a fulfilment economyâ, says Herman Narula, head of the British tech company Improbable. Social media prioritises keeping users passively engaged for as long as possible, whereas gaming seeks to provide fulfilling, active experiences. âThereâs a difference between watching an experience and having an experience,â he says. âIf you look at games like Fortnite and Minecraft â¦ what matters is presence; how many things can you do? In Minecraft, you can move anything about it, you can modify the laws, you can be creative. So what matters is creating a highly creative environment, which allows the normal self-expression.â Improbableâs website claims âwe are the metaverse technology companyâ. Among other things (it works with military as well as gaming companies), the company, which Narula co-founded in 2012, is working on connecting various metaverses together, and hosting large numbers of people in virtual worlds. Whereas most multiplayer online games, like Fortnite, never really put more than 100 people together on one server, Improbable has hosted events bringing together 30,000 people in the same virtual space. Unsurprisingly, Narula is optimistic about the metaverse. In his recent book Virtual Society, he writes: âLike the development of writing, or the advent of the computer age, the dawn of the metaverse will be a grand pivot point in the history of humanity.â The metaverse was valued at nearly $23bn last year and is expected to grow nearly 40% a year for the rest of the decade. As the Epic co-founder and CEO Tim Sweeney put it last year: âThe next three years are going to be critical for all of the metaverse-aspiring companies like Epic, Roblox, Microsoft, Facebook [Meta]. Itâs kind of a race to get to a billion users. Whoever brings on a billion users first would be the presumed leader in setting the standards.â The building blocks of the metaverse are coming together, and Meta is working on many of them: hardware like VR and AR devices, data and network infrastructure, social platforms and interfaces, developer and creator ecosystems â all of which require skilled people (in Metaâs recent 11,000-person cull, Reality Labs was relatively unscathed). âWe are creating a new category that requires significantly and abundantly more resources than it takes to create a single product or collection of products,â says a Meta spokesperson. âItâs misguided to categorise our long-term investment as a loss while we are within our initial phases of development.â So no more âmove fast and break thingsâ; now itâs more of a âmove slowly and build thingsâ vibe. From the outset, Zuckerberg said the metaverse would take five to 10 years to arrive, though some, such as Microsoft CEO Satya Nadella, are saying it is here already. Matthew Ball agrees: âWe have hundreds of millions interacting in 3D virtual worlds each day,â he says, pointing to the likes of Roblox and Minecraft. But it goes beyond gaming: âJohns Hopkins University hospital is now performing surgery with XR [as in âextended realityâ â VR and AR] devices and game engines, while Vancouver airport runs a 3D simulation [a âdigital twinâ of the airport, incorporating real-time information which can be used for training, optimisation, future planning, simulation and testing] and similarly Tesla cars are building a live simulation of San Francisco using Unreal. The pieces are more mature than many give credit, but weâve yet to develop the standards and systems to integrate them in the ways the internet is developed today.â It is unlikely that Meta, or any other big tech company, will âownâ the metaverse, says Ball. âWe often misrepresent the control of big tech,â he says, pointing out that the âBig Fiveâ â Google, Apple, Meta, Amazon and Microsoft â together collect less than 10% of digital revenues, âalthough they exert disproportionate influence over the rest of the internet â¦ It is likely that a similar outcome happens with the metaverse: a handful of vertically and horizontally integrated software and hardware giants amass the substantial share of users, data, revenue, devices, etc, and exert even greater influence. The metaverse is likely to grow big techâs reach, not shrink it.â If Meta does succeed in controlling a substantial slice of the metaverse, though, there are further, deeper concerns. The charge sheet against social media in general, and Facebook/Meta in particular, is extensive: disseminating and amplifying online disinformation and hate speech, unseen and undisclosed political influence, its impact on mental health, the collection and misuse of personal data. âWhatever company owns the metaverse will have better information about crime, better surveillance, better everything than the government will,â says Koster. He points out how much of our lives is already online: our personal records, our rÃ©sumÃ©s, our bank accounts, our friendships, our online movements and behaviours. The metaverse will enable access to even more layers of data: âA lot of the folks who work on the hardware for AR glasses, for example, are concerned about the fact that the glasses can read biometrics off your iris, and that tells them an enormous amount about your medical state, your emotions moment to moment. Virtual worlds are panopticons. The more we digitise the world, thatâs the power weâre handing over to whoever runs that metaverse.â Meta is taking pains to assuage such fears. âThe metaverse is a collective project,â says a spokesperson, âand how to responsibly manage the new types of data that companies may collect is exactly the kind of challenge that needs collaboration and discussion. Itâs not up to any one company to set the rules on this.â All are in agreement that regulation is needed, but judging by how well the internet has been governed so far, the outlook is complicated â potentially liberating; potentially downright dystopian.
headline: âThe metaverse will be our slow death!â Is Facebook losing its $100bn gamble on virtual reality?

chat_gpt_summary: Facebook's cross-check system, designed to protect high-profile users from moderation, did not prioritize protecting free speech and civil rights, according to Meta's oversight board. The board found that the system appeared to favor "business partners" such as celebrities who generate revenue for the company, while journalists and civil society organizations had "less clear paths" to access the program. The board made 32 recommendations, including removing special protection for commercially important accounts if they break content rules frequently and prioritizing moderation of posts that are important for human rights. Meta's president of global affairs, Nick Clegg, said the company would respond within 90 days.
article: A policy designed to protect high-profile Facebook and Instagram users from moderation was structured to satisfy their parent companyâs business interests, Metaâs âsupreme courtâ has found, and did not prioritise protecting free speech and civil rights. The oversight board, which scrutinises moderation decisions on Facebook and Instagram, said the platformsâ âcross-checkâ system appeared to favour âbusiness partnersâ â such as users including celebrities who generate money for the company â while journalists and civil society organisations had âless clear pathsâ to access the programme. âWhile Meta told the board that cross-check aims to advance Metaâs human rights commitments, we found that the program appears more directly structured to satisfy business concerns,â said the board, adding that it had concerns about the âlack of transparencyâ around the programme. It said cross-check grants certain users greater protection than others because content from users on the cross-check list is allowed to stay up while it is vetted by human moderators applying the âfull rangeâ of content policies. Meta described it as a âmistake-prevention strategyâ that protected important users from erroneous content takedowns. Ordinary users, by contrast, are much less likely to have their content reach reviewers who can apply the full range of Metaâs content guidelines. The board said a userâs âcelebrity or follower countâ should not be the sole criterion for receiving the special protection offered by the programme. Meta admitted to the board that criteria for including âbusiness partnersâ on the list included the amount of revenue they generated. Meta also told the board that it exempts some content from takedowns. The company described this system as âtechnical correctionsâ and said it carried out about 1,000 a day. The board recommended that Meta conducted audits of enforcement actions that are blocked under the system. The board added that the technical corrections system is viewed as an âallow listâ or âwhitelistâ. In September last year the Wall Street Journal, using documents disclosed by whistleblower Frances Haugen, reported that Brazilian footballer Neymar had responded to a rape accusation in 2019 by posting Facebook and Instagram videos defending himself, which included showing viewers his WhatsApp correspondence with his accuser. The clips from WhatsApp â also owned by Meta â included the accuserâs name and nude photos of her. Moderators were blocked for more than a day from removing the video, according to the WSJ, while the normal punishment of disabling his accounts was not implemented. An internal document seen by the WSJ said Neymarâs accounts were left active after âescalating the case to leadershipâ. Neymar denied the rape allegation and no charges were filed against the footballer. Citing the Neymar example, the board said that despite Meta saying it had a system for prioritising content decisions, some content still remained online for âsignificant periodsâ while this happened. âIn the Neymar case, it is difficult to understand how non-consensual intimate imagery posted on an account with more than 100 million followers would not have risen to the front of the queue for rapid, high-level review if any system of prioritisation had been in place,â said the board. The board went on to say that the cross-check âbusiness partnerâ category includes users who are likely to generate money for the company, either through formal business relationships or drawing users to Meta platforms. It said due to the âperception of censorshipâ it preferred keeping content up to taking it down. The board said the business partner category was likely to include major companies, political parties and campaigns, and celebrities. The board made 32 recommendations. They included: removing special protection for commercially important accounts if they break content rules frequently; prioritising moderation of posts that are important for human rights; and violating content from cross-check users that is âhigh severityâ should be removed or hidden while reviews are taking place. The board said Meta viewed the risk of a content decision resulting in âescalation at the highest levelsâ to a chief executive or chief operating officer of an organisation as highly sensitive. Such content carries an âextremely high severityâ tag under the cross-check system. It said Meta therefore seemed more focused on business-related consequences for its decisions rather than ones that are human rights-related. Metaâs president of global affairs, Nick Clegg, said that in order to âfully addressâ the boardâs recommendations, the company would respond within 90 days.
headline: Facebook moderation system favours âbusiness partnersâ, says oversight board

chat_gpt_summary: A reader shared their experience of being targeted by fraudsters who posed as their Facebook friend and convinced them that they had won a Facebook lottery. Although the reader did not provide any bank or card details, they did reveal personal information such as their name, home address, date of birth, email, mobile number, and occupation. The reader is concerned that this information may be used or sold by the fraudsters. The columnist advises the reader to enable two-step verification for their email, change passwords that use their date of birth, and sign up for Cifas' protective registration to place a warning flag against their name on the fraud database. The reader is also advised to closely monitor their bank account and be extra vigilant against potential scams.
article: Today I was subjected to an attempted fraud. The fraudsters made contact using Facebook Messenger and the identity of one of my friends, a former colleague. They persuaded me to believe that I had been a winner in a Facebook lottery. I pulled out before giving any bank or card details, but did reveal more information than I would have liked â my name, home address, date of birth, email, mobile and occupation. I am worried that the information I did provide might be used or sold on. If you have any advice on how I can take steps to limit any further damage, I would be very grateful for you to provide it. PC, by email That doesnât sound much fun, but had you handed over your bank card details, it could have been a whole lot worse. In your shoes, I would be aiming to make sure I had two-step verification turned on for my email â if you havenât already. If any of your passwords used your date of birth or similar, I would change them asap. In fact it is probably worth changing them anyway. Unfortunately, you have given the fraudsters enough information to enable them to pose as you to buy goods and services. For this reason I would sign up for the Cifasâs protective registration, which costs Â£25 for two years. This will place a warning flag against your name and other personal details on the Cifas national fraud database. This tells firms using Cifas data to pay special attention when you or someone else uses your details to apply for their products or services. So if someone applies for, say, a mobile phone contract in your name, they should face enough extra security checks to halt the transaction. In the meantime, closely monitor your bank account and be extra vigilant if you get calls from people posing as bank or other employees. Good luck. We welcome letters but cannot answer individually. Email us at consumer.champions@theguardian.com or write to Consumer Champions, Money, the Guardian, 90 York Way, London N1 9GU. Please include a daytime phone number. Submission and publication of all letters is subject to our terms and conditions
headline: Facebook message persuaded me to hand fraudsters my personal details

article: Facebookâs revenge porn plan is working Would you trust Facebook with your nudes? Would you let a company famous for its somewhat loose approach to data privacy have anything to do with intimate photos of yourself? Five years ago Facebook (which is now Meta) asked Australians for nudes in a pilot effort to develop a tool to stop the non-consensual distribution of intimate images; the response was sceptical to say the least. In a surprising twist, though, it looks like Metaâs tactics to stop revenge porn are actually working. Hereâs how the program, which has been developed in partnership with SWGfL, a UK-based non-profit behind the Revenge Porn Helpline, works. If youâve shared an intimate image with someone and are worried that that person might do something nefarious with it, content moderators at Facebook can âhashâ the image â essentially the picture is assigned a digital fingerprint - without it ever leaving your device. If someone then tries to upload that image to Facebook it can be quickly identified and blocked. Itâs obviously not a magic bullet for stopping revenge porn, and it requires putting a lot of trust in Facebook and accepting that a random content moderator is going to be looking at your naked photos, but it gives people a little bit of control over their images. Since the program first launched in Australia, Bloomberg reports, it has helped more than 12,000 people to hash more than 40,000 photos and videos. That media is prevented from being uploaded across Metaâs social networks, Facebook and Instagram. This week TikTok and the dating app Bumble also signed up the program. âWe now have four platforms [participating], but we need thousands,â SWGfLâs chief executive office told Bloomberg. âThe more we can get ingesting the hashes, the more we can reduce the threat and fear victims experience.â The non-consensual distribution of intimate images is a massive and fast-growing problem. Itâs most often discussed in terms of ârevenge pornâ, but there are multiple disgusting facets to it. âCollector cultureâ, for example, which is when people (usually men) pass around intimate images of women online, is an emerging trend. A senior helpline practitioner at the Revenge Porn Helpline described it as âa dystopian version of PokÃ©monâ where âwomen are prizes to be passed around, shared and traded.â This sort of thing happens on multiple platforms and trying to stop it often feels like a dystopian version of Whac-a-Mole. Tech-based solutions like the program developed by Facebook are helpful, but tech alone canât solve the problem. As Clare McGlynn, a professor of law, told the Guardian, culture change and education are hugely important. âEvidence from studies shows that just as teenage girls are pressured to send nudes, teenage boys are also feeling pressure to get nudes and share them, to gain kudos. Collecting digital trophies is becoming part of being a boy and a man â thatâs what we need to change.â Google isnât upholding its pledge to protect abortion data After Roe v Wade was overturned, Google promised that it would delete sensitive search data related to abortions: for example, searches for the location of abortion clinics. However, a new study by the tech advocacy group Accountable Tech has found Google is falling short. Some experts arenât surprised. âDespite the promises of well-intentioned technologists, it is entirely unsurprising that new experiments are showing that sensitive information connected to abortion is being collected and retained by the advertising giantâ one expert in surveillance told the Guardian. Matt Gaetz associate Joel Greenberg gets prison time for crimes including sex trafficking Greenbergâs case has had widespread attention because the former Florida tax collector is a buddy of Florida congressman Matt Gaetz and has been cooperating with the Department of Justiceâs sex trafficking investigation into Gaetz. Trust in women leaders is falling New data from the Reykjavik Index for Leadership shows an alarming drop when it comes to trust in women leaders. Itâs the first decline in this data-point since measurements started in 2018. Only 47% of respondents from G7 countries said they were âvery comfortableâ having a woman as CEO of a major company in their country, down from 54% last year. Men were a lot more likely than women to be critical of a female leader; one in 10 respondents said that they wouldnât be comfortable with a female CEO. Responses to questions about female political leaders were along the same lines. Do we blame Liz Truss for this? Sort of. One theory for the decline in trust is more women have moved into positions of power, breeding resentment among men. When a high-profile woman fails, sheâs also often held up as an example of why women shouldnât be in leadership. Elon Musk says he will start implanting brain chips in people soon Including himself, apparently. Heâs already got a chip on his shoulder, why not get a chip in his brain? Chantal Akermanâs Jeanne Dielman named greatest film of all time in poll Itâs the first time that a film directed by a woman has topped the prestigious Sight and Sound poll. Rest in power, Shatzi Weisberger The beloved Peopleâs Bubbie, a fixture at New York protests, has died age 92. Youâve probably seen viral photos of her at protests holding up signs like âJewish dyke standing with Palestine queersâ or â92 year old dyke saying FIGHT LIKE HELL + LOVE EACH OTHER HARDER.â The week in paintrarichy A freshly baked baguette isnât just delicious itâs also an intangible cultural heritage of humanity, according to Unesco. The baguette was afforded this honour at a recent Unesco meeting in Morocco, where 600 other items, including Tunisiaâs spicy harissa, got the UN seal of approval. French delegates to the Unesco conference were very excited about all this; there was a lot of raucous baguette-waving in the room. Not everyone was impressed though. âThis is not a day of celebration,â bread historian Steven Kaplan told CBC. â¢ This article was amended on 8 December 2022. An earlier version said that Metaâs and SWGfLâs new program for dealing with nudes involved sending the images to Facebook moderators. This has been corrected: the pictures are not shared and do not leave the original device â but a process called hashing creates a digital fingerprint. This blocks these images from being shared.
headline: Facebook asked for nudes to help stop revenge porn and it worked. Can our culture change next? | Arwa Mahdawi

chat_gpt_summary: A high school principal in New South Wales, Australia, has been banned from interacting with students during a police investigation into allegations of historical child sexual abuse involving a student when he was 17 and the teacher was in her late 40s. The mother of the student discovered hundreds of messages dating back around 10 years, and after the young man's death last year, gained access to his social media accounts. The department of education removed the principal from all child-related duties while the claims were investigated. The teacher added the student on Facebook in April of his final year, with initial conversations about marking a quiz he had taken, and soon arranged to meet outside school hours, with hints of physical encounters in messages.
article: A New South Wales high school principal has been banned from interacting with students while police investigate a claim of alleged historical child sexual abuse of a student when he was 17 and she was in her late 40s. Concern was raised when the studentâs mother discovered hundreds of messages between the pair dating back about a decade, when he was in year 12 and she was a deputy principal. The young man died last year and his mother gained access to his social media accounts this year, discovering the communications and reporting them to police, the department of education and the minister, Sarah Mitchell. The department then took ârisk management actionâ and removed the now principal from âall child-related dutiesâ while the claims were interrogated. Messages seen by Guardian Australia appear to show that the teacher added the student on Facebook in April of his final year of school. Initial conversations included her messaging him to say she had marked a quiz he had taken and he had scored the top of the class, congratulating him on the result. A month later she offered to unlock the school gym whenever he wanted it, saying there is âno way u look like someone who hasnât been able to work out muchâ. Within months the communications appeared to show the pair arranging to meet outside school hours, speaking about kissing and discussing that the teacherâs husband âknows about usâ. It is not known whether the pair had a sexual relationship. In one message the teacher reflected that women of her age âdonât go around falling in luv with 17 yr oldsâ. In June that year she messaged him to say he was âvery fine, very young, very badâ. Sign up for Guardian Australiaâs free morning and afternoon email newsletters for your daily news roundup During another exchange she sent him an image that she said was âkind of relevantâ with the ages of Madonna, Tina Turner, Jennifer Lopez and Mariah Carey alongside the ages of their respective partners with significant age gaps. âStill single? Relax, your boyfriend is not born yet,â the graphic read. In the same month, the student asked what he should call her. âI like Miss. The name Miss and you Miss,â he wrote. She replied with a smiling emoji and said âbut donât you think it makes me sound a bit paedophily [sic]â. By early July, messages hint at physical encounters. âThat was not my body â that was my brain interfering,â she wrote. âI can tell you that because every time I have thought about you for the last few months, including now, my body responds ridiculously well. Just not earlier today.â He replies saying his âhips are a bit sore, knees are a bit sore. Good workoutâ. She asked if he had changed his mind about âthis old girlâ before saying she âdidnât think we were going to do that todayâ. She called him a âbadass, cuteassâ and said she had been âhanging out to get a kiss out of you today and next minute â¦â The teacher then insisted she would not tell anyone about what had happened. âDo you have any idea what they would think?â she asked. âMy girlfriends have children older than you.â In another message, the teacher questioned ââ¦what kind of person must I be to do what Iâm doing?â. She said she would marry him âwhen I get out of jail for corrupting youâ. When he responded saying one âcanât corrupt a badassâ, she replied saying that was ânot a defence Iâd be able to use thoughâ. During another conversation she relayed a dream where he picked her up and âtook me out into the countryside somewhere. we just spend the whole day together, hanging outâ, which she said sounded âperfectâ. He replied that he also had dreams about her in which she was naked. She replied that she has those dreams as well. In mid-July, the teacher messaged the student to say her âhusband knows about us and wants it to stopâ and asked to pick him up so they could talk. The next day she contacted him again saying she had to âunfriend you for the moment. I love you.â Upon discovering the messages, the boyâs mother reported her concerns to police and the NSW department of education. The now principal of another high school in NSW was quickly stood down from on-campus duties and police began an investigation. The mother first contacted the department and police about five years ago, while the young man was still alive, after she was told of the alleged inappropriate relationship by another family member. She messaged her son about it but he did not respond. In documents obtained by Guardian Australia, police this year explained to the family that an anonymous report was also lodged the year after the teenager finished school and he had been spoken to at that time. He signed a statement denying anything untoward had happened. The mother was told by police that when she then came forward and wanted them to investigate a few years later, officers reviewed the claims but âgiven the previous signed statement â¦ it was not looked at any furtherâ. She told Guardian Australia she missed her âvery mischievous, very outgoing, very smartâ son. She wanted other parents and former students to be aware of the investigation and did not think the principal should be allowed contact with students again. A spokesperson for the education department confirmed they were âaware of this matterâ. âThe employee concerned is not currently working with students,â the spokesperson said. âFor privacy and confidentiality reasons, we are unable to provide further comment.â A letter to the mother last month from the education minister, Sarah Mitchell, stated the departmentâs professional and ethical standards (PES) investigation was still open and âon hold pending advice from police about criminal chargesâ. âI am assured PES is in regular contact with police and is actively cooperating with, and assisting the officers involved in the matter,â Mitchell wrote. âI understand the department has taken risk management action in the matter, in that the principal has been removed from all child-related duties. âPlease be assured the safety, welfare and wellbeing of children is the departmentâs paramount concern and appropriate action will be taken as soon as possible once the issue of criminal charges is resolved.â A NSW police spokesperson told Guardian Australia that police had âreceived a report of alleged historic child sexual abuse. Inquiries are being conducted by [district police], in partnership with the State Crime Commandâs Child Abuse Squad.â The principal has been contacted for comment. â¢ In Australia, children, young adults, parents and teachers can contact the Kids Helpline on 1800 55 1800, or Bravehearts on 1800 272 831, and adult survivors can contact Blue Knot Foundation on 1300 657 380. In the UK, the NSPCC offers support to children on 0800 1111, and adults concerned about a child on 0808 800 5000. The National Association for People Abused in Childhood (Napac) offers support for adult survivors on 0808 801 0331. In the US, call or text the Childhelp abuse hotline on 800-422-4453. Other sources of help can be found at Child Helplines International
headline: NSW high school principal investigated for historical child sexual abuse after messages found on studentâs Facebook account

chat_gpt_summary: Human rights campaigner Tanya O'Carroll is suing Facebook's owner, Meta, in the UK's high court, alleging that the company is violating her right to object to the collection of her personal data. O'Carroll, who is a senior fellow at legal campaign group Foxglove, claims that Facebook has breached UK data laws by failing to respect her right to demand that the company stop collecting and processing her data for marketing purposes. She is not seeking damages, but instead a yes or no decision on whether she can opt out of being profiled for advertising purposes. A successful case could set a precedent for millions of Facebook, social media, and search engine users. Meta says it takes privacy seriously and offers tools like privacy check-up and ads preferences to help users exercise control over the type of ads they see.
article: A human rights campaigner is suing Facebookâs owner in the high court, claiming the company is disregarding her right to object against the collection of her personal data. Tanya OâCarroll has launched a lawsuit against Mark Zuckerbergâs Meta alleging it has breached UK data laws by failing to respect her right to demand Facebook stop collecting and processing her data. Facebook generates revenue from building profiles of users and matching them with advertisers who direct ads at people targeting their specific interests and backgrounds. OâCarroll told BBC Radio 4âs Today programme: âThis case is really about us all being able to connect with social media on our own terms, and without having to essentially accept that we should be subjected to hugely invasive tracking surveillance profiling just to be able to access social media.â OâCarroll, a senior fellow at Foxglove, a UK legal campaign group that focuses on accountability in the technology industry, is claiming that Facebook has breached article 21 (2) of UK General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR), which gives individuals the right to protest against the processing of their personal data for marketing purposes. OâCarroll said a successful case could set a precedent for millions of Facebook, social media and search engine users. âWith this case, Iâm really using this right thatâs long been there on the law books, but has been up until now not been exercised, which is to simply say âI objectâ, and if we are successful in that then everybody will have that right,â she told the BBC. OâCarroll has lodged a claim in the high court and is awaiting Metaâs acknowledgment of the claim and confirmation that the company intends to defend it, followed by a hearing and court judgment. OâCarroll is not seeking damages but a yes/no decision on whether she can opt out of being profiled for advertising purposes. A Meta spokesperson said: âWe know that privacy is important to our users and we take this seriously. Thatâs why we build tools like privacy check-up and ads preferences, where we explain what data people have shared and show how they can exercise control over the type of ads they see.â
headline: Facebook sued for collecting personal data to target adverts

chat_gpt_summary: The Victorian Labor party spent over $115,000 on a Facebook page named after their opponent, the Liberal leader Matthew Guy, to promote negative ads about his policies and record. The page was the second-biggest political advertiser on Facebook in Australia in the past month before being deleted just a week before election day. The reasons for its deletion are unclear. The Labor party's social media campaign is much larger and more advanced than their opponents, with three times the spending and highly targeted ads on the platform. The Victorian premier, Daniel Andrews, has the largest following of any Australian politician on Facebook, with 1 million followers.
article: The Victorian Labor party spent more than $115,000 on a Facebook page under the name of the Liberal leader, Matthew Guy, to boost paid ads attacking his policies and record in government, before deleting the page just a week out from election day. The circumstances behind the deletion of the page â which was the second-biggest political advertiser on all of Australian Facebook in the past month â are unclear. But it was just part of Laborâs social media campaign, which is vastly larger and more sophisticated than of its Liberal opponents. The government has outspent the opposition by up to three times, and is running far more highly targeted ads on the platform. âEvery advertising dollar thatâs been spent has been thought out, intentional and considered,â a Labor campaign headquarters insider told Guardian Australia. Labor has branded Guy âthe Liberal cuts guyâ in much of its advertising, criticising opposition election policies and decisions he made in government. A website expanding on those messages, thecutsguy.com, carries only a small Labor authorisation message. An accompanying Facebook page, titled Matthew Guy â The Liberal Cuts Guy, began posting ads on 31 October. By 15 November the page had spent $115,893 to boost 1,146 ads, according to Facebook ad library data that showed they were paid for by Victorian Labor. The page itself, as well as its ads, also carried authorisation messages on behalf of Victorian Labor. The page boosted 19 types of ads, all critical of Guy personally. âThe Liberals sacked Matthew Guy after he lost the last election. Now heâs back and so are his plans for cuts,â read one ad, with a link to the âCuts Guyâ website. Sign up for Guardian Australiaâs free morning and afternoon email newsletters for your daily news roundup In the past 30 days on Facebook, only one political advertiser in the country spent more money on political ads than the page. That was Victorian Laborâs main page, with $237,055 spent. All in all, taking in ads from the page of the premier, Daniel Andrews, Labor has spent at least $393,849 in a month. That compares to about $118,000 spent in ads from the Liberalâs main page ($72,000) and Guyâs official Facebook page ($46,335) in the same period. But by Thursday the âCuts Guyâ page disappeared. Facebookâs ad library reported the page âhas been unpublished or deletedâ. Guardian Australia asked the Victorian Labor party if it had voluntarily removed the page, or if it had been deleted by Facebook. No response was received by publication time. Facebook, the Victorian Electoral Commission and the Victorian Liberals were also contacted for comment. Daniel Andrews himself is arguably the most successful social media user in Australian politics, with 1 million followers on Facebook â outnumbering the prime minister, Anthony Albanese (324,000), and his predecessor, Scott Morrison (781,000), as well as his counterparts in NSW (38,000) and Queensland (342,000). Andrewsâ success in building an online following is attributed to him being an early adopter of social media. His director of media, Sabina Husic, is credited with driving his successful following during his first term in office, creating shareable content linked to pop-culture and trending joke formats, and establishing a clear voice and personal narrative. The cadence to his posts during the pandemic led to an entire Facebook group dedicated to mimicking his updates. The premier has also been known to bypass media â including its scrutiny â in favour of making announcements on social media. The multibillion-dollar, 90km underground Suburban Rail Loop was unveiled on Facebook via a slick promotional video with a dramatic soundtrack. The usual unit of four people in the premierâs team who work on his social media had grown during the election, a Labor HQ insider said, though they wouldnât reveal by how many. They said the campaignâs media focus had largely been on TV, social and online media, rather than âtraditional mediaâ such as newspapers and radio, where Andrews has had a long-running feud with 3AW host Neil Mitchell and News Corpâs Herald Sun.
headline: Victorian Labor loses âMatthew Guyâ Facebook page after using it for $115,000 worth of attack ads

chat_gpt_summary: A Noongar woman, Kathy Penny, whose teenage son was seriously injured in an apparent vigilante attack, has been subjected to threats and abuse on social media. Penny's 18-year-old son, Ronaldo, was left in a critical condition when a 49-year-old woman chased him and his friend through Perth's northern suburbs after it was alleged they had stolen a motorcycle. Ronaldo has been charged with a number of offenses including aggravated burglary and stealing offenses. Penny has urged supporters not to retaliate to the online abuse, but has called on Facebook and other social media companies to put a stop to hateful comments. Aboriginal people in Perth have said that racist comments in Facebook community groups have fostered a climate where vigilante violence is accepted.
article: A Noongar woman whose teenage son was seriously injured in an apparent vigilante attack says she has been threatened and abused online, but has urged supporters not to retaliate. Kathy Pennyâs 18-year-old son, Ronaldo, was left in a critical condition when a 49-year-old woman chased him and his friend through Perthâs northern suburbs after it was alleged they had stolen a motorcycle. The woman has pleaded guilty to charges of driving dangerously and causing aggravated grievous bodily harm. âHe was in a coma for six days, with swelling on the brain and bleeding, with a fractured skull and broken femur,â Penny said. âHis injuries are still going to be there permanently, heâs going to be limited for the rest of his life.â Ronaldo has been charged with a number of offences including aggravated burglary and stealing offences. He appeared in court last month and has been remanded to Hakea prison. His 17-year-old friend has also been charged in relation to the incident. Penny said the abuse on social media was âjust hatred and revengeâ. âTheyâre just saying really nasty things. Like he should have died, it was good what happened to him, he deserved it. âFacebook and the social media companies need to put a stop to that â¦ Thereâs over 200 comments. They shouldnât be allowed to say those kinds of things about somebody elseâs son.â Sign up for Guardian Australiaâs free morning and afternoon email newsletters for your daily news roundup Last week Guardian Australia reported that a WA community Facebook group with tens of thousands of members had hosted threatening comments that Aboriginal people in Perth said fostered a climate in which vigilante violence was accepted. Facebookâs parent company, Meta, said in a statement none of the comments highlighted in the report would be removed. âWe reviewed the content links shared across and they did not breach our community standards,â the statement said. Penny said no one should break the law, including her son and his friend, but the same applied to the woman who chased them. âItâs against the law,â Penny said. âTwo wrongs donât make a right, but she did not have the right to do what she did.â Penny said she had forgiven the woman and would not respond to online threats or remarks in support of vigilantism. âIf we retaliated, three wrongs wouldnât make a right, so we just have to wait and hopefully justice will prevail. I forgive her but I canât forget what happened.â The incident prompted WAâs police commissioner, Col Blanch, to warn people against taking matters into their own hands. âWeâve seen it many, many times, people taking chase of offenders when theyâve witnessed a crime,â Blanch was quoted as saying in WA Today. âIt can end in tragedy for yourself, other members of the community or the person that you might be chasing.â Perth parents say hostility and violence towards young Aboriginal people accused of being involved in crime is being fuelled by racist comments in Facebook community groups. Verna Anderson, one of Pennyâs daughters, said Aboriginal children, including her 14-year-old brother, had been chased and threatened while simply walking the suburban streets. âThis was just a couple of days ago ... When a white van started following them and came to the park with them. So they all started hiding behind bushes and he got out of the car and he started shouting out at them,â she said. She believed attacks and anti-social behaviour were becoming more common in Perthâs suburbs. âItâs becoming an everyday thing, even I have been chased and harassed.â She said people on social media were becoming emboldened to suspect young people of criminal activities without any evidence. âI think they think that no oneâs going to do anything. Theyâre just going to get away with it. Because weâre Black,â Anderson said. Concerns were raised recently at a meeting between Aboriginal community elders and Blanch and other senior officers. Donna Nelson, who works with children and runs a community basketball program, said young people and their families were afraid. âThe community is feeling unsafe. Parents are certainly feeling unsafe. Aboriginal people are becoming very concerned about what potentially this could lead to if appropriate action isnât taken. âPeople are more worried about their property. Iâm not saying that we condone wrongdoing in any way. But it is about people taking it in their own hands as opposed to following what should be proper protocols. âRespect is just not being given to our kids and violence is constantly perpetrated on our children.â
headline: Mother of Aboriginal man injured in apparent vigilante attack condemns Facebook abuse

chat_gpt_summary: Queensland Police Service (QPS) is investigating recordings of officers using racist and violent language at the Brisbane city watch house. A police whistleblower, Steven Marshall, who leaked the audio recordings, has faced reprisals from colleagues and was called a "rat" and "dog" in a private Facebook group for police officers. Marshall had previously tried to raise concerns through internal QPS processes, but little formal action was taken. Some serving and former Queensland police officers appear to be involved in the conversation on the Facebook group, defending the recordings as officers being "human" and suggesting that the media is feigning outrage. The QPS has apologised for the "sickening and disturbing" recordings and encourages officers to come forward with complaints.
article: A Queensland police whistleblower who leaked audio recordings of officers using racist and violent language has been called a âratâ and a âdogâ in a private Facebook group for police officers. The QPS has apologised for the âsickening and disturbingâ Brisbane city watch house recordings â which included comments that black people should be beaten and buried â and said the incidents are being investigated. The police commissioner, Katarina Carroll, said on Tuesday that the actions of the whistleblower, Steven Marshall, were âexcellentâ and encouraged officers to come forwards with complaints. Marshall says he made the decision to release the recordings to the Guardian, which were published Sunday, after previous attempts to raise separate matters of concern via internal QPS processes resulted in little formal action, while he says he suffered alleged reprisals from colleagues. He says he did complain internally about one of the recordings, as well as submitting all of them to the state commission of inquiry into police responses to domestic and family violence. The inquiry heard several alleged instances where whistleblowers suffered adverse consequences for making a complaint, including officers who said they had been labelled a âdogâ by colleagues. Guardian Australia has seen screenshots of a discussion about the watch house recordings in a private Facebook group for law enforcement officers. Current and former Queensland police officers appear to be involved in the conversation, which includes attacks on Marshall and comments that the recordings are not problematic. Sign up for Guardian Australiaâs free morning and afternoon email newsletters for your daily news roundup âWho is the fuckin Rat taping the crew[?]â one man posted. The comment was liked by accounts that appear to be Queensland-based police officers. Another comment, from a person who appears to be a former Queensland officer, says: âI believe it was a recording from the watch house counter some DOG has made a complaintâ. Other posts, which are liked by serving and former officers, suggest the recordings are just officers being âhumanâ. âNothing to see here. Boring edited voice recordings of police who put up with shift after shift of shit. If the general public only knew how bad it was out there, they would and should be afraid. âPolice are human and should be able to talk freely within their own stations. After all that is supposed to be their safe place. What a farce.â A Queensland-based poster said: âWell some people just wonât be happy til (sic) the police is full of fluffy numpties who are too scared to do or say anything.â Another, also from Queensland, said: âWere the media feigning outrage to stir up the feral police-haters?
