I didnât hear anything offensive on that tape?â The recordings include officers at the Brisbane city watch house joking about beating and burying black people, complaining âyouâve got to be embarrassed about being whiteâ and raising fears that Australia âwill be fucking taken overâ. The tapes include an officer referring to Nigerians as âjigaboosâ. Officers heard in the recordings have not been stood down or identified by police, Carroll confirmed on Tuesday. Emails seen by the Guardian confirm Marshall complained internally about the officer who used the term âjigaboosâ and that he previously was dealt with by âlocal management resolutionâ â a remedial discussion with a senior officer â and sent back to work. Marshall says he spoke with the officer in charge of the stateâs watch houses, deputy commissioner Mark Wheeler, last month, though he did not share the recordings at the time. He said he raised his concerns, including about racism and sought help finding a job with a different agency due to ongoing reprisals. He says the request was refused. When asked by journalists about that conversation on Tuesday, Wheeler said he spoke to Marshall for a considerable period of time and had followed proper process. âI was certainly not aware of those recordings at that point in time. Not aware at all,â he said.
headline: Queensland watch house whistleblower labelled âdogâ in Facebook group for police

chat_gpt_summary: The pandemic has led to an increased use of social media, but for some it has led to a reassessment of their usage and the impact it has on their lives. Jordan Guiao, Research Fellow at The Australia Institutes Centre for Responsible Technology, said "The way social media is built is Las Vegas crazy, super bright and completely addictive. In the real world we dont live like that." Craft blogger Felicia Semple fell off Instagram in May because it "had become a chore  a stressful, anxiety-ridden ethically-dubious space". But, as social media becomes more pervasive, how do we reconcile the benefits with the need to use it more responsibly?
article: Matt* shouldâve joined Twitter years ago. He fits the user profile perfectly: highly educated, a politics junkie, across the news, loves a debate, and heâs a climate scientist. But unlike many users publicly grappling with Elon Muskâs new universe, threatening to jump ship (but then lingering on the deck), or trying to muster the energy to migrate to another platform and, ahem, âtootâ, Matt is a social media virgin. Unblemished, unsullied â the 46-year-old has never joined a single social media platform. âIâm not very quick to pick up and run with new technologies,â says Matt from the Victorian town of Geelong, âbut that lag time meant that I began to see things I didnât like about their adoption.â Along with privacy and data concerns, he figured most algorithms encouraged outrage and constant use. Like a true scientist, brevity (and committing casual comments to the public record) also put him off: âI didnât know what could be usefully said in 140 characters.â Twitter might be a social media minnow (29.5% of Australian internet users use it at least once a month, compared to Facebook at 76.8%) but watching people tweeting about whether to stay or go in real time is instructive. Itâs a snapshot of a growing awareness among longtime social media users (and people who still dimly remember a time before the internet) about how vulnerable they are to changing algorithms (and owners) and what drew them to social media in the first place. Sign up for Guardian Australiaâs free morning and afternoon email newsletters for your daily news roundup And perhaps unicorns like Matt can show us that thereâs another way to live entirely, that maybe we donât need to Google the word âMastodonâ? Maybe we just â¦ stop? âItâs hard to be that person because most of your networks are there and youâve invested all this time, energy and content. Thereâs a cost to leaving,â says Jordan Guiao, Research Fellow at The Australia Instituteâs Centre for Responsible Technology and author of the new book Disconnect. âThe big platforms rely on that. Everybody knows that theyâre bad news now, but physically moving is still really hard.â The trends arenât exactly reflective of Mattâs monastic stance. By the end of 2021, 82.7% of Australians were active on social media, an annual growth of nearly 1 million users, nudged along by an isolating pandemic and the growth of TikTok. As social media becomes baked into our daily online diet, how does it feel to be excluded from the conversation? I interrogate Matt in the same way I might approach a time traveller from the 1880s, or a very smart baby. How do you keep up with the news? âRadio, print, online.â The zeitgeist? âMost of the time it gets reported there if itâs noteworthy.â What do you do with all your spare time? âI think about it the opposite way around. Where do people find the time to be on social media?â Leaving the Las Vegas (internet) Felicia Semple, 48, from Melbourne fell off Instagram in May. She still hasnât hasnât explained her absence to her not insubstantial follower base â all 24,000 of them. âIt initially happened by accident. I decided I wouldnât post while I was away on holiday, but then I just couldnât make myself go back,â says Semple. Semple started a blog called The Craft Sessions in 2013 to âprovide a space for crafters to come togetherâ to share ideas and inspire each other. Increasingly, Semple wrote about the connection between mental health and crafting, or âthe head stuffâ as she calls it. Joining Instagram initially grew her community in very meaningful ways. But more recently, âevery time Iâd open it I would feel dread, rather than joy. It had become a chore â a stressful, anxiety-ridden ethically-dubious space.â Like many artists recently whoâve built whole careers on the platform, Instagramâs algorithm changes (mainly mirroring the TikTok model of snack-sized video) changed everything. âThe requirements of the algorithm had changed the type of content I was creating,â says Semple. âIt was warping my own creative impulses and my message, by messing with my biology, making me feel that I needed to keep up.â âThe most popular platforms want us to be there with 24/ 7 engagement at all costs,â says Guaio. âThe way social media is built is Las Vegas crazy, super bright and completely addictive. In the real world we donât live like that.â We need to âstart to think about a healthier way of doing it â¦ develop platforms that donât have this kind of extractive business model that relies on us being there every second of the day, or â¦ getting dopamine hits for every like.â Semple knows that the decision to quit Instagram was a luxury, as she wasnât relying on it for income. Many people whoâve built their businesses on social media feel like they have no choice but to adapt. But these days sheâs sleeping better. âI have more time and peace of mind. I finished my psychology degree last week.â Given all that, Semple is thinking of ways to engage with her online community again. âIâve read three books in one monthâ Forty-five year-old Olivia Sinclair Smith works in education. She quit her platform of choice, Facebook, a month ago. Sheâd tried to leave before, but this time she went cold turkey. âI was just mindlessly scrolling through posts and peopleâs bits and pieces and wasting more and more time doing it. I started to feel guilty afterwards, like I was addicted and I couldnât stop.â Since quitting, âI donât feel the guilt and the self-loathing I used to get from staring at crap posted by people I barely know â¦ Iâve read three books in the last month which is unheard of for me.â Sinclair Smith has strategically kept a slice of the platform â Facebook Marketplace. âI made a fake profile which has no friends attached and I use that to look at items to buy.â âI am tempted to join the interest groups using my fake profile,â says Sinclair Smith, but sheâs worried it could be âa gateway drugâ. A great rebalancing? Guiao says people are becoming more discerning. âWe are seeing a bit of a move away from the giant, public, mass-market platforms into smaller and more community focused platforms and private messaging like WhatsApp,â he says. âWeâre actually going back to how we naturally communicate in our physical or our real-world social networks.â Guiao says to expect ourselves to disconnect entirely is unrealistic, especially digital natives. âWeâre going be online now for the rest of our lives. But thereâs something to be said for rebalancing it,â says Guiao. How that rebalancing will work for younger users embracing more broadcast platforms like TikTok and YouTube remains to be seen. For users looking to engage with niche topics and communities on those platforms, it can still be like running through a casino looking for the ball pit and ending up at the craps table instead. âThe challenge is that there isnât a viable alternative â¦ even if we wanted to change, itâs very difficult,â says Guiao. Guiao points to Eli Pariserâs work, who talks about the concept of âdigital parks as quiet spaces to gather. How do we build online versions of that? The âLas Vegasâ internet isnât an inevitability.â Remember, these places have existed. âBefore social media, there were community platforms like blogs and forums and all of those things that [were] built for connection, community and collaboration but werenât built to get you addicted.â Matt has no desire to join the party. But heâs still forced to reckon with social media, given that his children, currently seven and nine, will eventually have to confront it. âIn the social lives of younger people, thereâs a very heavy price to pay for not engaging. All I can do is help them to understand that the priorities they have for their own lives are not even remotely aligned with those of these companies.â âI do also worry about the capacity for them to find refuge in their lives.â Most of us wonât ever be as pure as Matt, but we might get smarter at making social media work for us. Maybe tooting doesnât sound so bad after all. *Name has been changed
headline: The 46-year-old social media virgin: how people ditch Twitter, Facebook and Instagram and survive

chat_gpt_summary: Australia is expected to ban the importation of most vapes, require plain packaging, and remove them from convenience store shelves as part of an unprecedented crackdown on e-cigarettes. The changes, which will be announced in the May budget, aim to stamp out the illegal vaping black market and the rise of addiction in children. Current laws allow the purchase of nicotine-based vapes only with a prescription, yet thousands of online providers and convenience stores continue to sell to minors. The reforms also include restrictions on flavours, colours, and other ingredients. Furthermore, the Albanese Government plans to work with the states and territories to eliminate vape sales in retail settings altogether.
article:
Australia is set to ban the importation of most vapes, introduce plain packaging and strip them from convenience store shelves under world-first reforms.
The biggest crackdown on e-cigarettes in Australian history is set to be unveiled in the May budget amid fears vaping has emerged as a serious behavioural crisis in schools across the nation.
Under current laws vapes with nicotine can only be bought with a prescription from a chemist. 
But that hasnât stopped thousands of convenience stores and online providers selling to kids.
Health Minister Mark Butler will unveil the changes on Tuesday under a crackdown that will also involve the states and territories moving to stamp out the growing black market in illegal vaping.
The changes will include tough new laws to:
- Stop the import of non-prescription vapes
- Increase the minimum quality standards for vapes including by restricting flavours, colours, and other ingredients;
- Require pharmaceutical-like packaging;
- Reduce the allowed nicotine concentrations and volumes; and
- Ban all single use, disposable vapes.
But the reforms wonât stop there, with the Albanese Government preparing to work with states and territories to close down the sale of vapes in retail settings, ending vape sales in convenience stores and other retail settings.
Health experts fear the rise of vapes poses a public health crisis with children who vape three times as likely to take up smoking.
Experts claim thousands of children can no longer sit still in class because they are addicted to vaping after smoking âbubblegumâ flavours that secretly contain nicotine.
Health Minister Mark Butler said it was clear that governments had to act.
âVaping was sold to governments and communities around the world as a therapeutic product to help long-term smokers quit,ââ he said.
âIt was not sold as a recreational product - especially not one for our kids. But that is what it has become: the biggest loophole in Australian history.
âOne in six teenagers aged 14-17 has vaped. One in four people aged 18-24 has vaped. By contrast, only one in 70 people my age has vaped.
âAnd when more than a thousand teenagers aged 15 to 17 were asked where they could get vapes, four out of five of them said they found it easy or somewhat easy to buy them in retail stores.
âThis is a product targeted at our kids, sold alongside lollies and chocolate bars.â
Mr Butler said schools were now struggling to deal with the fallout.
âVaping has become the number one behavioural issue in high schools. And itâs becoming widespread in primary schools,â he said.
âOver the past 12 months, Victoriaâs poisons hotline has taken 50 calls about children under 4 becoming sick from ingesting or using a vape.
âUnder the age of 4! Vapes contain 200 toxic chemicals that do not belong in the lungs, the same chemicals youâll find in nail polish remover and weed killer.
âJust like they did with smoking, Big Tobacco has taken another addictive product, wrapped it in shiny packaging and added flavours to create a new generation of nicotine addicts.
 âVapers are three times as likely to take up smoking, which explains why under 25s are the only cohort in the community currently recording an increase in smoking rates.
âThis must end.â
Vape police could be rolled out to monitor the sale of e-cigarettes to children across Australia including on TikTok, Snapchat and Instagram under a plan that will ban most imports and introduce plain packaging.
VicHealth CEO Sandro Demaio, a globally-renowned public health expert and medical doctor, told news.com.au that as soon as the Albanese Government introduced new import bans enforcement could be much tougher at a state level.
âIn many ways this explosion of vaping has really come out of nowhere over just a couple of years,ââ he said.
âBut the reverse is also possible if we ban the advertising of vapes and actually clamp down on the use of social media to promote these products.
âIf we make them less alluring, so they donât they donât come in Froot Loops flavour and look like a highlighter. They donât have unicorns on the side. That will make them far less appealing.
âAnd basically cut off the tap at the border. Those things will absolutely make a huge difference.â
Dr Demaio said that introducing plain packaging was important because that would then allow enforcement to swing into action.
âObviously, we want to close the access and the huge amount of vapes that have been finding their way into the hands of particularly young people,ââ he said.
âSo what needs to happen at the state level is that there needs to be a licensing scheme in every state.
âThe licences themselves would create revenue, which can support enforcement officers, so weâre not relying on police to enforce the measures that we currently have.
âIn theory, theyâre not currently subject to the laws because they donât contain nicotine. But the vast majority do contain nicotine; theyâre just simply not putting in all the packets.
âAnd really, what needs to be done is to say, âWell, if thereâs no flavours, no colours and the only pathway through a prescription, and they, they, they have pharmaceutical packaging, it then makes it much easier for the states to actually enforce it.â
He warned children were being âviciouslyâ exploited.
âWell, whatâs happened over the last few years is that the tobacco industry and the e-cigarette industry, of which thereâs huge overlap, has seen an opportunity to, you know, get another entire generation of Australians addicted to nicotine with a new product. Thatâs flown under the radar,ââ he said.
âThis industry has used young peopleâs social media. These things are all over social media. You can jump on Tik Tok and there are ads for E cigarettes with a âBuy Nowâ button.
âSocial media is under-regulated in this country. They have flooded the market with really cheap imports from overseas that donât declare that they contain nicotine.
âAnd itâs been a combination of social media, weaponising their data on social media and flooding the market with really cheap and highly addictive imports.â
headline: Australian Government announces crackdown on illegal black market vapes

chat_gpt_summary: Snapchat announced at its developer conference that it will provide its GPT-powered AI chatbot, "My AI," to all users for free. The move aims to differentiate Snapchat from Instagram and TikTok by expanding access to the chatbot, emphasizing the distinction between public and private posts, and offering successful creators a share of revenue generated by their viral content. Users can ask factual questions, request creative content, and engage in conversations with the AI service. The chatbot will also be available in group chats. Snapchat plans to address concerns about age-appropriate advice after criticism during the initial release. Additionally, the platform will introduce new tools for creators, focusing on private communication while allowing for public pages. Eligible creators will receive compensation for their viral success, aiming to support their growth and reduce reliance on external opportunities for income.
article: Snapchat is releasing its GPT-powered AI chatbot to every user for free, the company announced at its annual developer conference, as it tries to chart a distinctive path between the titans of Instagram and TikTok. That means expanding access to its AI chatbot, doubling down on the distinction between public and private posts, and paying successful creators a share of the revenue their viral content generates. First released for paying members of the social networkâs Snapchat+ subscription service, âMy AIâ shows up as another chat contact in the social networkâs app. Similar to ChatGPT, users can ask it factual questions, request creative content, and have back-and-forth conversations with the service. âIt really deepens our ability to serve our mission of helping people express themselves, learn about the world, live in the moment and have fun together,â said Snapâs vice president of product, Jack Brody. Users will also be able to add My AI to group chats, turning to the virtual assistant for any queries that come up in the course of conversation. Paying users will also be able to send photos to their AI helpers and receive completely AI-generated images in return, Brody said. âThe idea is you snap My AI and it can snap you back,â he added. âIn the early days, most of the experiences are really just fun and playful, and exciting to experiment with. Thereâs certainly opportunities to make that a useful feature as well: one of the things thatâs been fun is snapping it some ingredients and it can send you back a recipe.â My AI was criticised for being inappropriate for the companyâs young users when it was originally released in March. In tests run by the Washington Post, the bot cheerily gave advice to a reporter claiming to be 12 years old about how to plan a âsurprise tripâ with their â30-year-old boyfriendâ where they intended to have sex for the first time. Now that the paid trial period is over, Brody says, the app will be more careful about providing age-appropriate advice. âThis early phase of the rollout has allowed us to address some of the challenges that have come up, like adding age awareness. In 99.5% of cases, its responses do conform to our community guidelines.â Snapchat is also introducing new tools for creators who want to use the platform to go viral. In contrast to bigger rivals like TikTok and Instagram, Snapchatâs focus is on private communication rather than public broadcast, Brody said, but new tools will allow creators to split the difference, running a public page at the same time as posting privately for friends and family. âA lot of other platforms really breed this pressure to to be perfect, and weâve seen that that can lead to creator burnout,â he added. âWhat we hear back from them is that Snapchat is a place where they feel like they can be themselves, where they can post without worrying so much about making sure itâs perfect or perfectly edited.â Almost three years after the company launched its TikTok-style Spotlight feed, alongside a $1m daily prize fund for the most-viewed videos, Snapchat is also doubling down on paying creators for their viral success. Eligible users will need at least 50,000 followers on the app, with 25m views and at least 10 public posts a month, but if they do, the company says itâs committed to helping them build a business and grow their audience â not rely on off-platform opportunities to earn money from their fame.
headline: Snapchat making AI chatbot similar to ChatGPT available to every user

chat_gpt_summary: During a parliamentary committee, experts from charities revealed that county lines adverts on Instagram and Snapchat, aimed at grooming children and young people, now resemble professional job adverts. The traffickers constantly change their methods to entrap victims, with children as young as seven getting involved in drug running. The charities emphasized the need for social media platforms to take more responsibility, as the professionally designed adverts attract vulnerable young people who believe they are helping their struggling families. London, West Midlands, Manchester, and Merseyside were identified as key areas for county lines activity, with thousands of children and young people being pulled into exploitation each year.
article: County lines adverts on Instagram and Snapchat designed to groom children and young people now resemble professional job adverts, a parliamentary committee heard on Tuesday. Experts from charities gave evidence to Tuesdayâs cross-party education committee about the constantly evolving scene, with traffickers frequently changing their methods of ensnaring children and young people. Johnny Bolderson, manager at the organisation Catch 22, which helps to support and rescue children and young people groomed into county lines exploitation, told the committee that children as young as seven were now getting involved in drug running. He said: âSocial media platforms need to take more responsibility. Adverts on Instagram and Snapchat for young people to get involved in county lines look professionally done â ârecruitment opportunities availableâ. That has been growing in the last six months. Since Covid, families are struggling, and with really professional advertising young people think they are going to help out their families.â The committee heard that London, West Midlands, Manchester and Merseyside were four of the main areas for county lines activity, and that thousands of children and young people were getting pulled in every year. Rebecca Griffiths, head of the National Counter-Trafficking Service at Barnardoâs, said that the charity had received 300 referrals from various parts of England and Wales in the past three months. âVulnerability is changing all the time. We are seeing much younger children and the modus operandi of traffickers is changing. They are targeting more affluent children. Every child can be exploited criminally,â she said. Some girls have been forced to take on âdebtsâ for their boyfriends they are expected to repay. Children can be given free vapes along with bicycles, sweets, magazines or even free sandwiches to entice them to get involved with county lines groomers. Iryna Pona, policy and impact manager at the Childrenâs Society, said: âVaping is a way of grooming.â According to Bolderson, children can also be reeled in through online gaming platforms where groomers befriend them in internet gaming chatrooms, give them coins to enable them to play more games. The children then owe a debt and find themselves in âdebt bondageâ to the groomers. He said children could be groomed without leaving their bedrooms. Susannah Drury, director of policy and development at the charity Missing People, told the committee that it was partly a public health issue, with a cross-government approach required and children benefiting from early intervention. Of the county lines traffickersâ approach, she said: âThis is a business model thatâs very fluid, very reactive, very agile.â The National Crime Agency has called county lines exploitation âthe most frequently identified form of coerced criminality, with children representing the vast majority of victimsâ. The Home Officeâs 2020 Drugs Review by Dame Carol Black found strong associations between young people being drawn into county lines and increases in child poverty, the numbers of children in care and school exclusions.
headline: âProfessional advertsâ for county lines ensnaring children on Instagram and Snapchat

chat_gpt_summary: Jock Zonfrillo, the 46-year-old chef and judge of MasterChef Australia, passed away in Melbourne just hours before the premiere of the show's latest season. In his final Instagram post, Zonfrillo encouraged fans to watch the season filled with "Secrets & Surprises." The show's airing was postponed for a week due to his sudden death. Zonfrillo, known for his culinary achievements and philanthropy, was remembered as a loving father, husband, brother, and son. He gained recognition as the head chef at Restaurant 41 in Sydney and later opened Restaurant Orana, which received prestigious awards. Zonfrillo's family requested privacy to grieve and celebrate his life.
article:
Jock Zonfrillo asked fans to tune into the newest season of MasterChef in a final Instagram post shared just hours before his death. 
The 46-year-old chef and judge died in Melbourne on Sunday, just a day before the latest edition of the cooking show was set to premiere on Channel 10.
âThe time has come for @masterchefau to kick off a new season filled with Secrets & Surprises! And @jamieoliver of course!â he wrote. 
Network 10 and his family made the announcement in a statement, alongside declaring that the show would be postponed for a week due to his sudden death.
âWith completely shattered hearts and without knowing how we can possibly move through life without him, we are devastated to share that Jock passed away yesterday,â Jockâs family said in a statement on Monday.
âSo many words can describe him, so many stories can be told, but at this time weâre too overwhelmed to put them into words.
âFor those who crossed his path, became his mate, or were lucky enough to be his family, keep this proud Scot in your hearts when you have your next whisky.
âWe implore you to please let us grieve privately as we find a way to navigate through this and find space on the other side to celebrate our irreplaceable husband, father, brother, son and friend.â
Mr Zonfrillo is survived by his wife Lauren Fried and his four children Ava, Sophie, Alfie and Isla.
Network 10 also shared a statement.
âNetwork 10 and Endemol Shine Australia are deeply shocked and saddened at the sudden loss of Jock Zonfrillo, a beloved member of the MasterChef Australia family. Jock passed away in Melbourne yesterday,â the network said.
âJock was known to Australians as a chef, best-selling author, philanthropist and MasterChef judge but he will be best remembered as a loving father, husband, brother and son.â
The renowned chef established himself in Australia as the head chef at Restaurant 41 in Sydney in 2000, before going on to open Restaurant Orana in 2013.
Restaurant Oranaa was named as Restaurant of the Year by Gourmet Traveller in 2018 and by the Good Food Guide in 2019.
He initially worked under renowned Michelin-starred chef Marco Pierre White.
âZonfrillo climbed his way to the top of the gastronomic ladder only to abdicate his position. He still inspires chefs worldwide,â Mr Pierre White said about Mr Zonfrillo in 2022.
Mr Zonfrillo grew up in Glasgow to an Italian father and Scottish mother.
He began working in kitchens as a dishwasher part-time at the age of 13 before going on to leave school to start an apprenticeship in the kitchens of the Turnberry Hotel on the west coast of Scotland.
headline: MasterChef star Jock Zonfrilloâs eerie final post before tragic death

chat_gpt_summary: Tish Cyrus, the mother of Miley Cyrus, is engaged to actor Dominic Purcell after he proposed to her in Malibu. Tish, 55, confirmed the news on Instagram with photos of the couple and a caption expressing her excitement. article:
Miley Cyrusâ mother, Tish Cyrus, is engaged to Dominic Purcell after the Prison Break star proposed in Malibu, California, over the weekend.
The 55-year-old confirmed the exciting news via Instagram on Saturday with two loved-up photos of the pair cuddled up close to each other.
âA thousand times â¦. YES @dominicpurcell,â she captioned her post.
She and Purcell, 53, debuted their romance and went Instagram-official in November 2022, Page Six reports.
Since then, they havenât been shy about showcasing their love in public and on social media.
âHeaded into the New Year HAPPY @dominicpurcell,â Tish captioned a sweet Instagram post last December. âWishing everyone a safe and magical New Yearâs Eve!â
Born in Britain, Purcell moved with his family to Australia at the age of two and started his acting career here in shows like Home And Away, Raw FM and Heartbreak High. 
Reports surfaced earlier this year that Tish and Purcell were getting serious quickly.
âThings couldnât be going better for Tish and Dominic,â a source told Us Weekly in February. â[Tish] truly feels like she found her soulmate.â
News of her romance with Purcell came shortly after her ex-husband, Billy Ray Cyrus, officially moved on with Australian singer Firerose.
The couple â who first sparked engagement rumours in September 2022 â confirmed they were engaged last November.
However, Billy Ray, 61, did not give Firerose (real name, Johanna Rosie Hodges) a ring or a formal proposal.
âBilly looked at me and said, âDo you, do you wanna marry me?ââ the singer recalled to People at the time. âHe said, âI love you. I wanna make this official. I wanna be with you forever.ââ
As previously reported, Tish filed for divorce from the Achy Breaky Heart singer for a third time in April 2022 after 28 years of marriage.
In addition to 30-year-old Miley, Tish and Billy have two other children together: Braison, 28, and Noah, 23. Tish is also the mother of Brandi, 35, and Trace, 34.
As for Purcell, he has four kids â Joseph, 23, Audrey, 22, and 19-year-old twins Lily-Rose and Augustus â with ex-wife film producer Rebecca Williamson.
This story originally appeared on Page Six and is republished here with permission
headline: Tish Cyrus, Dominic Purcell engaged: Mileyâs mum is loved-up

chat_gpt_summary: American rapper Azealia Banks has criticized Australia's music and entertainment industry, calling it "trash" and labeling Australian artists as "untalented/uncultured and unneeded." In a series of Instagram posts, she expressed her disdain for the Australian music scene, except for a few exceptions. Her criticism seemed to stem from allegations of intellectual property theft by an Australian record label. Banks widened her criticism to encompass the entire Australian music industry, citing cultural dissonance and accusing it of being unimportant in the global music culture. She also referenced Australia's colonial history and treatment of Indigenous peoples as factors contributing to its "trash" music and culture.
article:
Azealia Banks has taken a swipe at Australiaâs music and entertainment industry, calling it âtrashâ, while also labelling Australian artists as âuntalented/uncultured and unneededâ.
The American rapper took to Instagram on Monday where she shared several posts ranting about Australiaâs music industry. 
âRealise musical talent is just not in the gene pool,â she wrote.
âAbsolutely no one on earth takes (the Australian music industry) seriously.â
Lamenting at the seemingly endless reserve of talentless Australian performers, Ms Banksâ passionate posts made exceptions for Kylie Minogue, INXS and AC/DC, but called Tame Impala âcheesyâ and Wolfmother âan American rock tribute bandâ. 
No stranger to publicly voicing her grievances with the country and its music scene, the most recent controversy seemingly arose over allegations an Australian record label âcorruptly stoleâ Ms Banksâ intellectual property. 
The singer/rapper/songwriter took to Instagram shortly after reading a piece in The Guardian written by Ben Eltham, who spoke to the hurdles faced by local artists in reaching new audiences in the age of social media. 
Ms Banks said Australian Dance Music record label Sweat It Out incorrectly labelled the genre of her music, implying she was in a vulnerable position when signing the record deal as she was âvery f*cking sickâ at the time. 
Citing âjealousy, racism and desperationâ as the driving force behind Sweat It Outâs âpiss poor remixâ of her new song, âNew Bottegaâ, Ms Banks widened her criticism to capture the entire Australian music industry. 
â(It) is a hip hop record. It is not a dance record,â she said. 
âClearly there is a cultural dissonance here.
âHipHop is the most profitable genre of music in the world right now. EDM (electronic dance music) is f*cking dead.â
Ms Banks went on to say that Australiaâs entertainment industry failed to ârealise how unimportant they are as far as music culture goesâ. 
âAustraliaâs media/music/entertainment industry isnât exactly heralded by the heads of government or anyone in the world as a coveted cultural export,â she said. 
âAustralians donât even want to hear Australian music LOL.â
Ms Banks cited Australiaâs enduring colonial apparatus and its systemic dispossession of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples as the driving force behind its music and culture being âso trashâ. 
âYâall stomped all the blackness out of Australia â which is why your music exports suck,â she said. 
â(Itâs) one of the most culturally stale white nations on the planet.â 
Her posts comes nearly six months after Ms Banks cancelled an Australian show in 2022 and vowed never to return to the nationâs shores.
Lashing out at event promoters over allegations that they failed to pay her, Ms Banks also took aim at Australian currency, calling it âthird-worldâ. 
The performer also cited a âracistâ incident that occurred during her Sydney show in which a bottle of soft drink was thrown at her on stage, subsequently promising she would not return to the land down under.
headline: Azealia Banks rips into Australia

chat_gpt_summary: Celebrity chef Jock Zonfrillo was found dead in a Melbourne hotel near the home his family had recently moved out of. The 46-year-old MasterChef judge was discovered during a welfare check at Zagame's House in Carlton. Zonfrillo's family had relocated to Rome three weeks prior. The cause of his death is unknown. Tributes have poured in from around the world, with fellow chefs and MasterChef contestants expressing their shock and sadness. The 15th season of the cooking show, in which Zonfrillo was a judge, has been temporarily pulled from broadcast.
article:
Celebrity chef Jock Zonfrillo was found dead inside a Melbourne hotel just metres away from the home his family had recently moved out of to make a fresh start overseas.
Zonfrillo, 46, was found dead by police about 2am on Monday following a welfare check at boutique hotel Zagameâs House in inner-city Carlton.
The swanky hotel, which offers rooms for $650 a night, eerily backs onto the rental home Zonfrillo had lived in with his family since 2020.
Local business owners say they witnessed police vehicles arriving at the hotel in the early hours of Monday.
Zagameâs House management denied the MasterChef judge died at their hotel when contacted by news.com.au, despite numerous reports confirming police were called to the building.
Zonfrillo, his wife and their two young kids had reportedly packed up their bags and moved to the Italian city of Rome just three weeks before his death. 
Their home was placed back on the rental market for $3000 a week in April.
A neighbour of Zonfrillo in the Carlton terrace where he and his family had lived told Seven News on Tuesday that Zonfrillo âleft three weeks agoâ.
Carlton resident Stuart Ayer said: âHe left about three weeks ago. Obviously heâs come back and who knows what happened.â
Zonfrilloâs family announced the MasterChef judgeâs death in a statement on Monday afternoon.
âWith completely shattered hearts and without knowing how we can possibly move through life without him, we are devastated to share that Jock passed away yesterday,â his family said in a statement.
âSo many words can describe him, so many stories can be told, but at this time weâre too overwhelmed to put them into words.
âFor those who crossed his path, became his mate, or were lucky enough to be his family, keep this proud Scot in your hearts when you have your next whisky.
âWe implore you to please let us grieve privately as we find a way to navigate through this and find space on the other side to celebrate our irreplaceable husband, father, brother, son and friend.â
Tributes have poured in from all over the world for the late chef.
âIâm in total shock to wake up to the sudden death of chef Jock Zonfrillo. We had the best time working together for this years master chef, I canât tell how good it was to work with him!â Jamie Oliver said on Instagram.
âJock was very generous to me with his time and spirit in the show and for that I was really grateful â¦ Mellisa, Andy & Jock work as the most inspiring judges and mentors and each have there very own unique view and styleâ¦Jock will be so very missedâ¦I canât believe Iâm writing this...â
âSaddened by the devastating news of Jock Zonfrilloâs passing. I truly enjoyed the time we spent together on MasterChef in Australia,â Gordon Ramsay said on Twitter.
âMy deepest condolences and sincere thoughts. I am utterly devastated. We spoke recently,â celebrity chef Joey Vargetto said.
Contestants on the show who spent considerable time with Mr Zonfrillo also expressed their sadness at the loss.
âIâm so shockedâ¦ rest in peace chef, my heart and condolences to loved ones,â MasterChef contestant Reynold Poernomo said on Instagram.
âSo sad to hear this. Rest in peace Jock. You will be missed,â fellow contestant Brendan Pang said.
The popular TV personality had flown back to Australia for the launch of the 15th season of the competition cooking show, where he was a judge.
Zonfrillo was scheduled to take part in a number of media interviews both ahead of and following the first episode, which was due to air on Monday night.
One of these interviews involved the father-of-four appearing as a guest on Channel 10âs The Project in the evening of his death.
He had battled with a crippling addiction to heroin which had taken hold of his life by the time he was 15.
âIâm not proud of it at all,â he said about his drug use. âItâs embarrassing and itâs embarrassing for my parents. But Iâm thankful to have been able to come through the other side of that and Iâm thankful for all the people who helped me at the right moments.â
After getting clean, he followed a successful career path and joined the Channel 10 program in 2019 for the 2020 season alongside Melissa Leong and Andy Allen.
The series has been pulled from broadcast for this week following the news of his death.
headline: Jock Zonfrillo was found by police at Lygon Streetâs Zagameâs House

chat_gpt_summary: Moonbin, a member of the South Korean pop group Astro, has passed away at the age of 25. Moonbin's death adds to a series of tragic losses in the K-Pop industry in recent years.
article:
Moonbin, a member of the South Korean pop group Astro and its sub-unit Moonbin & Sanha, has died, according to police. He was 25.
Authorities told Korean news outlet Yonhap News that the singer, whose real name was Moon Bin, was found dead in his home by his manager in Gangnam-gu, Seoul, at around 8.10pm local time Wednesday.
âHe appears to have taken his own life but an autopsy is being reviewed to determine the exact cause of death,â police said.
The official cause of death is pending, Page Six reports.
Moonbinâs record label, Fantagio, released a statement on Twitter on Wednesday confirming his death.
âFirst of all, I apologise for the sad and heartbreaking news,â the post, loosely translated, began.
âOn April 19, Astro member Moonbin suddenly left us and became a star in the sky.â
The statement noted that Moonbinâs relatives and all of those who worked with him, including bandmates Cha Eun-woo, Rocky, Yoon San-ha, MJ and Jinjin, were âdeeply mourning the deceased in great sadness and shock.â
The team asked fans to ârefrain from speculative and malicious reports so that that the bereaved families, who are deeply saddened by the sudden sad news, can reverently commemorate and greet the deceasedâ.
Moonbinâs funeral will be held âas quietly as possibleâ with only family members, friends and colleagues attending, the statement also said.
Meanwhile, fans flooded the Candy Sugar Pop singerâs 3.8 million-follower Instagram account to honour him.
One heartbroken follower wrote: âYou changed my life. You made me sooooo happy, Bin. Thank you for everything. Iâll love you forever. Rest in peace, my love.â
Another added, âHe always had such a big smile on his face which could automatically make a people smile too but now thatâs happiness is gone making everyone sad and loss of smile.â
A third said, âAs an old K-Poper I hate K-Pop â¦ I feel that those bad days we had in the past have been repeated again â¦ R.I.P. #Moonbin.â
In December 2017, Kim Jonghyun, the former lead singer of top South Korean pop group SHINee, was found dead at his apartment in Seoul.
Then, less than two years later in November 2019, K-Pop star Goo Hara was found dead. She was 28.
This story originally appeared on Page Six and is republished here with permission
headline: Moonbin dead: Astro K-Pop star dies by suicide aged 25

chat_gpt_summary: Renowned chef and MasterChef judge Jock Zonfrillo's final weeks with his family have come to light following his shocking death. Zonfrillo, 46, was on holiday in Europe with his wife and children before returning home for the launch of the new season of MasterChef Australia. His death was confirmed by Channel 10, and the cause of death has not been disclosed. Zonfrillo, known for his passion for food and mixed-cultural background, was deeply loved and respected. Colleagues and friends have expressed their condolences and shared heartfelt tributes. The show's premiere has been postponed in light of his passing.
article:
As Australia is left in shock over the death of chef and MasterChef judge Jock Zonfrillo â more details have come to light about how he spent his final weeks with his family.
The Scottish-born Zonfrillo, 46, was a renowned chef of the much-awarded Orana restaurant in South Australia and joined the Channel 10 program in 2019 for the 2020 season alongside Melissa Leong and Andy Allen.
Production on this yearâs season of MasterChef Australia finished about a month ago with Zonfrillo understood to have been in Europe on holiday with his family over recent weeks.
The Daily Telegraphreports his wife, Lauren, and their two young children, Alfie, 6, and Isla, 2, stayed in Rome when Zonfrillo flew home early ahead of the season launch.
The 46-year-old was also a dad to two adult children, Ava and Sophia, from his first two marriages.
He was understood to take part in a round of media interviews on Monday in the lead-up to the premiere episode.
He was due to be a guest live in the studio on The Project on Channel 10 in Melbourne Monday night.
Zonfrilloâs death was confirmed by Channel 10 in a statement on the same day MasterChef was scheduled to return for its 2023 season. The series has been pulled from broadcast for this week.
He died in Melbourne yesterday. A statement from Victoria Police said officers attended a hotel on Lygon Street for a welfare check, where they located a deceased man at approximately 2am. The police said the death was not being treated as suspicious.
No cause of death has been released. 
His family said: âWith completely shattered hearts and without knowing how we can possibly move through life without him, we are devastated to share that Jock passed away yesterday.
âSo many words can describe him, so many stories can be told, but at this time weâre too overwhelmed to put them into words. For those who crossed his path, became his mate, or were lucky enough to be his family, keep this proud Scot in your hearts when you have your next whisky.
âWe implore you to please let us grieve privately as we find a way to navigate through this and find space on the other side to celebrate our irreplaceable husband, father, brother, son and friend.â
Zonfrillo was born in Glasgow to an Italian father and a Scottish mother, growing up in a household with a strong mixed-culture ethos, which is said to have fuelled his obsession with food.
He started looking for work in the industry when he was 12 years old. He worked an apprenticeship at The Turnberry Hotel at 15 and by the time he was 17, he was working with Marco Pierre White at the famous chefâs restaurant.
He opened Bistro Blackwood and Restaurant Orana after moving to Australia. Orana was consistently awarded as one of the worldâs best culinary establishment. Orana closed in 2020.
A statement from Channel 10 and Endemol Shine Australia said, âNetwork 10 and Endemol Shine Australia are deeply shocked and saddened at the sudden loss of Jock Zonfrillo, a beloved member of the MasterChef Australia family.
âJock was known to Australians as a chef, best-selling author, philanthropist and MasterChef judge, but he will be best remembered as a loving father, husband, brother and son.
âJockâs charisma, wicked sense of humour, generosity, passion and love for food and his family cannot be measured. He will be greatly missed.â
Tributes from his colleagues have started to come in. TV personality Georgia Love wrote on Instagram, âAbsolutely devastating. Jock was so incredibly kind to me, particularly through some really tough times. I am so, so sorry to all his loved ones and everyone who will be affected by this awful news.â
Restaurateur and former My Kitchen Rules judge Colin Fassnidge posted, âRIP my friend, hope to have a whiskey again one day.â
Channel 9 host David Campbell tweeted, âThis is terribly sad. My condolences to his wife and kids and all the people he works with,â while actor Rebecca Gibney wrote, âNo words. Utterly heartbroken for you.â
headline: MasterChef judge and Orana chef Jock Zonfrillo dead at 46
