article:
MasterChef Australia will return to screens on Sunday May 7 with the full support of Jock Zonfrilloâs family, despite the tragic loss of the showâs beloved judge. 
The upcoming season will be dedicated to Jockâs memory, and the contestants will no doubt continue to be inspired by his passion for cooking and mentoring.
 Zonfrillo was a much-loved member of the MasterChef Australia family, known for his warm personality, infectious energy, and incredible culinary skills.
âMasterChef Australia Judge Jock Zonfrillo took great pride in challenging and coaching the contestants and of course inspiring a nation of home cooks,â Channel 10 said in a statement released on Wednesday night.
âIt is with Jock in our hearts that we cherish this season and remember the charismatic and big-hearted Judge and Chef who we knew and loved. Jock will be remembered in the MasterChef Australia kitchen for years to come. 
âA special edition of The Sunday Project will pay tribute to Jock from 6.30pm on Sunday, 7 May.
âWith contributions from friends, he held closely, the show will honour Jock by reflecting on his personal and professional life in a celebration of his incredible achievements.â
While Channel 10 announced the program would not air any earlier than May 8, an insider said any further decisions on the future on the series were the late chefâs familyâs â specifically his wife Lauren Fried â to make.
Filming of the latest season finished several weeks ago, with Zonfrillo flying back from Europe early for promotional interviews for the new series.
Jock had secretly moved to new country
The statement from Ten comes as details have revealed the simple reason Zonfrillo was apart from his family in a Melbourne hotel where he was tragically found dead, just hours before the new season of MasterChef was set to air. 
The popular TV personality had reportedly moved to the Italian city of Rome in the weeks before his death. He had flown back to Australia for the launch of the 15th season of the competition cooking show, where he was a judge. 
A neighbour of Zonfrillo in the Carlton terrace where he and his family had lived told Seven News on Tuesday that Zonfrillo âleft three weeks agoâ.
Carlton resident Stuart Ayer said: âHe left about three weeks ago. Obviously heâs come back and who knows what happened.â
Itâs understood the family journeyed to the European country after filming for the hit culinary TV show concluded about a month ago.
Entertainment reporter Peter Ford wrote on social media on Tuesday evening that Jock âhad actually moved to Rome to liveâ for what âwas to have been an exciting new chapter for the familyâ.
His wife Lauren and their two young children Alfie, 5, and Isla, 2, were still in Rome while Zonfrillo returned to Australia to prepare for the seasonâs launch.
They are believed to be arriving back in Australia late on Tuesday night.
Jock had actually moved to Rome to live. Was to have been an exciting new chapter for the family. https://t.co/qz1aAnWbIH
The 46-year-old also has two other adult children from previous marriages, Ava and Sophia, although itâs not suggested they were on the trip with Zonfrilloâs young family. 
As for why Zonfrillo came to Australia early, The Daily Telegraph reports he was scheduled to take part in a number of media interviews both ahead of and following the first episode, which was due to air on Monday night.
One of these interviews involved the father-of-four appearing as a guest on Channel 10âs The Project in the evening of his death.
Tragically, Zonfrilloâs body was found at 2am on Monday after police were called to his Lygon street hotel to conduct a welfare check.
While inquiries are still underway to determine his cause of death, it is not being treated as suspicious. 
Channel 10 has since announced it will delay the broadcast of the new MasterChef season for one week, following the judgeâs unexpected passing. 
Zonfrillo appears alongside Australian food critic Melissa Leong and cook Andy Allen in the series, which also features English restaurateur Jamie Oliver as a guest. 
The trio replaced the showâs original judges Matt Preston, George Calombaris and Gary Mehigan in 2020.
The role prompted Zonfrillo to move his family from Adelaide to Melbourne in 2021 due to the judge spending half the year in south Victoria for the showâs filming. 
Previews of the highly-anticipated 15th season had been teasing fans for weeks, with Zonfrillo also posting a promo to his Instagram the night before his death.
âThe time has come for @masterchefau to kick off a new season filled with Secrets & Surprises! And @jamieoliver of course!â he wrote.
Network 10 and his family made the shock announcement regarding Zonfrilloâs death on Monday afternoon, while declaring that MasterChef would be postponed for a week due to the judgeâs sudden death.
âWith completely shattered hearts and without knowing how we can possibly move through life without him, we are devastated to share that Jock passed away yesterday,â Jockâs family said in a statement on Monday.
âSo many words can describe him, so many stories can be told, but at this time weâre too overwhelmed to put them into words.
âFor those who crossed his path, became his mate, or were lucky enough to be his family, keep this proud Scot in your hearts when you have your next whisky.
âWe implore you to please let us grieve privately as we find a way to navigate through this and find space on the other side to celebrate our irreplaceable husband, father, brother, son and friend.â
Meanwhile Network 10 said: âNetwork 10 and Endemol Shine Australia are deeply shocked and saddened at the sudden loss of Jock Zonfrillo, a beloved member of the MasterChef Australia family. Jock passed away in Melbourne yesterday,â the network said.
âJock was known to Australians as a chef, best-selling author, philanthropist and MasterChef judge but he will be best remembered as a loving father, husband, brother and son.â
The renowned chef made a name for himself in Australia in 2000 as the head chef of Sydneyâs Restaurant 41, before later opening Restaurant Orana in 2013.
The latter restaurant was awarded Restaurant of the Year by Gourmet Traveller in 2018 and by the Good Food Guide in 2019. 
The Scotland-born culinary king grew up in Glasgow, where his passion for cooking started at the humble age of 13 where he worked as a dishwasher part time.
He later left school to start an apprenticeship in the kitchens of the Turnberry Hotel on the west coast of Scotland before working under Michelin-starred chef Marco Pierre White.
headline: MasterChef Australia to air this Sunday following Jock Zonfrilloâs death

chat_gpt_summary: Argylica Conditsis, a fashion enthusiast from Sydney, started her Babyboo Fashion brand at the age of 17 with a $1000 investment from her part-time job. What began as a hobby of selling embellished shoes quickly turned into a viral success. Over the past 12 years, Babyboo Fashion has transformed into a fashion empire valued at $60 million. With customers in nearly 150 countries, a dedicated team, and a strong social media presence, the brand continues to grow. Despite facing challenges during the pandemic, Babyboo successfully expanded into loungewear. Conditsis advises young entrepreneurs to believe in themselves and embrace the power of social media.
article:
At just 17 years old, fashion-loving Argylica Conditsis took $1000 she had saved from her part-time Pizza Hut job and invested it in her âhobbyâ.
The Sydney teen had a âcrazy ideaâ to sell statement shoes, and began listing them online after embellishing and bedazzling them herself back in 2011.
They were an instant hit â and just 12 years later, her Babyboo Fashion brand has gone from a gamble that began in her bedroom to a growing fashion empire valued at a staggering $60 million.
Itâs not a bad achievement for a young woman who is yet to see her 30th birthday.
âIt has been a bit of a roller coaster after starting when I was really young â I had just finished high school and was on holidays between school and uni when we started,â she told news.com.au.
âI had been working late night and weekend shifts at Pizza Hut during school and making something like $6 an hour, so saving $1000 was a lot for me back then, and I put it all into stock.
âIt was definitely not supposed to be a business â it was just a hobby, but when we first put the shoes online they went viral. I popped them on a Facebook page and it kind of evolved naturally over time.â
Ms Conditsisâ brother William has been with her every step of the way, and she eventually âstole himâ out of uni to work on the business full time, after also dropping out of her own Visual Communications degree to focus on building up the brand. 
Within three years of launching the online business, the pair decided to expand into clothing, and after initially running Babyboo out of Ms Conditsisâ bedroom and taking over âevery inchâ of her parentsâ Baulkham Hills home, it was soon time to expand into a proper warehouse and office.
Today, Babyboo has customers in almost 150 countries around the globe, a team of more than 40 employees and 1.1 million Instagram followers.
Ms Conditsis said one of her secrets to success was really understanding her customers from day one.
âI started bedazzling shoes myself because there were just no products like them out there â¦ I always liked to be the one that stood out with outfits and I realised weâd have to start (making them) ourselves as there was a gap in the market,â she explained.
âIf youâd told me back then weâd be as big as we are today I would have laughed at you â thereâs no way I would have believed it and it is now so much bigger than I ever imagined.
âWe never had a business plan or goal and each year that the business would double would come as a surprise.
âNow itâs more of a structured business with processes and strategies but in the early days it was all trial and error and learning from our mistakes quickly.â
The now-29-year-old said it was a blessing to work so closely with her brother.
âIt has been great to join forces with him â weâre so alike, but have our own strengths and weaknesses that work well together,â she said.
âWill is really good at understanding operations and processes and is very creative as well, and I focus more on the product, brand and social side of things.â
She said the biggest achievement for her personally was building a business from âabsolutely nothingâ with no financial backing to one now valued at $60 million, which has also allowed her to build up a team and community of women who âshare the same passionâ.
âWe empower a lot of women around the world by making them feel good, weâre with hundreds of thousands of women worldwide for all their special occasions,â she said.
âDressing them and making them feel empowered is what gets me up every morning â itâs not just a business, it actually serves a purpose.â
However, it hasnât all been smooth sailing.
Like most retailers, Babyboo took a hit during the Covid pandemic, but was able to quickly pivot and expand into loungewear, which was soon snapped up by those living through brutal lockdowns.
The move saw sales boom â and now, the next step for the thriving business is continuing its international expansion, settling into a new office and warehouse and launching new collections to increase the offering for customers. 
When it comes to advice for other budding young entrepreneurs, Ms Conditsis said it was simple.
âI always say never compare your chapter one to someone elseâs chapter six â eventually, youâll get there, after going through a process of evolving and learning,â she said.
âWhen I was young, there were a lot of people who didnât take me seriously and I got a lot of nos, but I think most of the businesses that will rise in the coming years will be from young people, who are very in tune with social media and have a lot to offer.â
headline: How Argylica Conditsis turned Babyboo Fashion into $60m empire

chat_gpt_summary: Transportable Shade Sheds, a shed supplier on the Sunshine Coast, has gone bankrupt, leaving numerous customers and workers unpaid. The Mooloolaba-based company owes over $1.3 million to around 160 trade suppliers and creditors. The business, along with five related entities, ceased trading prior to liquidation. The liquidators are investigating the cause of the failures and working to secure and sell the assets. Customers who received incomplete orders have expressed frustration, while affected individuals are urged to submit a Proof of Debt form to register their claims. The company's website remains active, but it is under external administration.
article:
A shed supplier on the Sunshine Coast has become the latest casualty to join a spate of companies in the sector which have gone bankrupt in recent months.
Mooloolaba-based business Transportable Shade Sheds has left dozens of Australians out-of-pocket and have failed to pay their workersâ leave entitlements after going into liquidation on April 3.
The failed company is now under external administration and owes more than $1.3 million to about 160 trade suppliers and creditors.
Bill Cotter of Robson Cotter Insolvency Group was appointed liquidator of the company following its collapse.
There are an additional five other companies set up as a group of related entities which have also ceased trading including Vanquish Holdings Pty Ltd, Bend Tube Designs Pty Ltd, Sable Labour Hire Pty Ltd, Tochlo Pty Ltd and TSS Dealers Pty Ltd. 
âThe businesses had ceased to trade shortly prior to the date of liquidation,â a statement from the liquidators read on its website. 
âThe Liquidator will not be trading-on the business operations of the companies during the liquidation process.â
An investigation into the cause of the companies failures is now underway, with the insolvency group currently âsecuring and realisingâ the assets.
Robson Cotter from the independent boutique advisory firm told the Courier Mail there were dozens of customers who had received partial or fully incomplete orders at the time the company went broke.
âThe amount potentially owing to customers with partially or fully incomplete orders delivered is currently unquantified,â he said.
Mr Cotter added several staff from the company were owed money for leave entitlements and superannuation.
Robert Salomon is understood to be the company director of Transportable Shade Sheds which was founded just over two decades ago in 2002.
Mr Salomon built the ânationally recognised company with international aspirationsâ alongside his partner Kylie, which offered a number of easy installation sheds, quickshades and canvacons.
âWe supply our Shade Sheds as a pre-engineered kit that has been designed for anyone to erect. So, no welding or technical knowledge is required,â the company explained on its website.
âWe swage the frames for you and with our slip fit connection system, it is just a matter of simply joining them together!â
The companyâs website remains active despite its insolvency with customers still able to make inquiries to order products.
As for its social media pages, there were little signs to show the company was struggling, with the last post made to the Transportable Shade Sheds (TSS) Instagram and Facebook accounts asking customers to send a picture of their installed purchase.
âHappy Friday! Check out this awesome shot from one of our customers! Have you got any photos of Your Shade Shed? Weâd love to see them,â the post is captioned.
âWe hope you all have a nice weekend!â
Customers who have been impacted by the companyâs closure have resorted to a Facebook group to vent their frustrations about the lack of notice they were given to suggest the company had gone bust. 
One loyal customer who has purchased seven sheds from the company said she ordered two sheds in June last year and paid the deposit only to never receive the products.
âIâm devastated, angry and canât wait for karma and the legal system to catch up with them so they can pay with what they have done to us and other families, including staff,â she wrote.
âThey chased us in the last two weeks for the balance of $15,000 and we refused to pay till the sheds were delivered to our premises in good order first. 
âIâm so glad we never paid them the extra money and now we have to see how we get our deposit back as we worked extremely hard for the money just like everyone else that got scammed by TSS.â 
Meanwhile one Victorian customer was left with the framework and anchors of a shed after he failed to receive its panels.
âI was told when the original framework was out for shipping, that the suppliers of the panels (are) state specific. Wondering if they are laying at a factory or depot somewhere in Victoria,â he said. 
âI really feel for those who have spent the money with zero to show for.â
A third person who claims they were a dealer and reseller for the company said he now has to find $90,000 to refund customer deposits for sheds âthey are not going to getâ. 
âItâs going to put me close to the edge, but I should hopefully just be able to keep my head above water after I have refunded my customers,â he said.
âAt least my customers will get every cent back whereas there must be hundreds, if not thousands of people around Australia that bought directly through them and will not get a penny back, I feel for them.â
The insolvency group recommends affected customers and creditors to submit a Proof of Debt form to register their claim via its email â admin@rcinsol.com.au. 
News.com.au has contacted both Robson Cotter Insolvency group and Transportable Shade Sheds for comment.
headline: Transportable Shade Sheds collapse: Customer furious after learning Sunshine Coast company owes $1.3 million

chat_gpt_summary: Stephanie Broadbridge, a stand-up comedian, experienced a surge of online harassment after a viral video featuring her participating in a "try not to laugh" challenge gained millions of views. Negative and sexist comments flooded the video, with people criticizing her for not laughing at a joke. The online abuse escalated, spreading to her other comedy clips and impacting her live shows. Broadbridge highlights the gendered and threatening nature of the attacks and emphasizes the need for a safe online environment, especially for professionals who rely on social media promotion. She calls for a shift in societal acceptance of online trolling as an inevitable consequence.
article:
COMMENT
It was a Sunday morning, Iâm a stand-up comedian and I was booked for an unusual gig. I would be sitting opposite a male comedian as we read dad jokes from the internet to each other and tried not to laugh. If we did laugh, we had to take a shot of vodka. 
It was early in the morning and Iâm allergic to alcohol so I was pretty motivated to win the challenge. 
I won 10-1. 
The challenge was filmed and turned into short clips for the relatively small Aussie TikTok account YeahMadTV. I was paid $200 and I assumed the video content would disappear into social media land like the billions of other comedy videos that no one ever sees. But thatâs not what happened. 
The clips went viral. One clip currently has over 47 million views and counting. 
Best dog joke ever written. #dadjokes#dadjokesoftheday#dadjoke#jokes#fyp#dadjokesoftiktok
The joke? What do you call a dog that can do magic? A Labra-cadabrador.
Why was it so popular? Because people hated me and left vicious, sexist comments to let me know exactly how much. The more they commented, the more views the video received. 
When the clip was posted, the important information that I was a performer in a âtry not to laugh challengeâ wasnât included. Instead, it was captioned âBest dog joke ever writtenâ so when I didnât laugh at the joke, I just looked mean.
The commentary seemed to be that how dare I, a woman, not laugh at the funny manâs joke (not his joke, a joke off the internet). I must be a Karen, a feminist, a cat lady, a [redacted] who doesnât have a sense of humour. The few people in the comments who tried to stick up for me by explaining it was a challenge, were also attacked.
I contacted YeahMadTV and they removed some of the nastiest comments and put in the comments that it was the âtry not to laughâ challenge but it didnât stop there. The video developed a life of its own. 
One anonymous account reposted the clip on 9gag, a social media platform that allows users to upload and share content from other social media sites. It was shared under the caption âShe has no sense of Humourâ. The thousands of comments on 9gag, that I canât delete, are so disgusting that I couldnât get through them.
Once I realised YeahMadTV had tagged me, I untagged myself immediately but the trolls still found me.
They wrote negative comments on every stand-up comedy clip I had on TikTok and Instagram. 
I was running ads for my live stand up shows at the Melbourne International Comedy Festival and those ads all had to be removed because of the trolling. 
It is very hard to be funny when every time I tell a joke on stage, I can picture these vile comments screaming at me from the audience.
On the final night of my Melbourne Comedy Festival run I broke down. I left the stage ten minutes into my show and burst into tears. I have been performing comedy almost every single night for seven years and this has never happened to me before. I am professional and reliable. I donât cancel. I built my reputation on being âthe chick that doesnât cancelâ.
Yes, of course, men get negative comments online too, but this was different. The language was gendered. It was violent. It was threatening. The attacks were intended to silence me, intimidate me and humiliate me, because I had committed a mortal sin of womanhood, not laughing at a manâs crappy joke. I know Iâm the least objective person in this situation but itâs hard to deny the lashings of misogyny. 
Sure, I could delete social media. If I stop putting myself out there, then people will stop trolling me. But I am a stand-up comedian. This is my job. Part of that job is promoting myself online and I deserve to feel safe at work. 
Itâs not just the arts where a strong social media presence is a requirement. Social media is an integral part of most careers. Nearly every employer checks you out online before hiring you, so to say âjust ignore itâ is completely unreasonable.
Thatâs asking me to ignore the cheapest and most efficient way to promote myself. âDonât worry about itâ or âdonât post things if you donât want to get attackedâ does not resolve the issue. I am worried about it. Itâs disgusting, itâs sexist and itâs ruining my career.
Given social media is an important part of our work life and women are trolled more than men how is that workplace equality? Why are we accepting trolling as a consequence of being online?
The number of women in comedy I have spoken to that have received similar treatment online is truly horrifying. Some have quit comedy, some have been seeking mental health treatment ever since, some just put up with it as part of the deal.
I donât have a solution, but I would suggest that next time you are tempted to write a mean comment on a random clip for no other reason except that youâre bored, maybe donât.
Stephanie Broadbridge is a stand-up comedian.
headline: Comedian Stephanie Broadbridge on trolling after joke TikTok video viewed 47 million times

chat_gpt_summary: A former Chinese diplomat, Victor Gao, has criticized Australia's ban on TikTok on government devices, calling it "racism" and warning against antagonizing a country with 1.4 billion people. The Australian government implemented the ban due to security concerns and fears that the Chinese-owned social media platform could be used for espionage. Gao argued that Australia should have confidence in its own systems and not view TikTok as a threat. However, cybersecurity experts have highlighted the extensive data collection capabilities of the app. The ban on TikTok has been enforced in several other countries, further straining the relationship between Australia and China.
article:
A former Chinese diplomat has labelled Australiaâs TikTok ban on government devices âracismâ, telling the Government: âYou do not want to have an enemy with 1.4 billion people.â
In an interview with 60 Minutes, former diplomat and CCP mouthpiece Victor Gao said of the ban: âProbably itâs racism, probably itâs racial discrimination, probably itâs banning Chinese again, which was a disaster many years ago.
âNow you want to do that again? It will not be a success.â
The Australian Government banned the Chinese-owned social media platform from all government devices, citing fears over security. It follows similar bans in many other countries around the world.
âThis has been informed by security agenciesâ advice on work thatâs been done and provided to the government, so thatâs the decision weâve taken is around government-issued devices,â Finance Minister Katy Gallagher said earlier this month.
Concerns over the scope of personal information that TikTok harvests and its parent company ByteDanceâs apparent links to the communist regime has led governments around the world to believe that China could be weaponising the social media app to spy on their citizens.
Cybersecurity expert Robert Potter previously told 60 Minutes that the app collects a lot more data than other social media sites.
âIt can collect your keystroke patterns, body language, face and body features. It can access photos or passwords that are stored in your phone over time,â he said.
âThereâs a super location field that allows them to collect which direction youâre facing, how fast youâre moving, how high off the ground you are, your latitude and longitude.â
However Mr Gao said Australia shouldnât feel threatened by the app.
âAustralians need to be really confident about their own system, rather than being threatened by TikTok. Banning it is not a sign of strength. Itâs not a sign of superiority, itâs not a sign of confidence. Itâs just the opposite,â he said.
He also said the ban could cause further tensions in Australiaâs already strained relationship with China.
âI would urge the Australian Government to really treat China as an equal, because you do not want to have an enemy with 1.4 billion people,â he said.
Meanwhile, TikTok Australia and New Zealand general manager Lee Hunter insists the ban is politically motivated, saying there was âno evidenceâ to support that peopleâs data was at risk.
He also told 60 Minutes TikTok Australia will not hand over personal information to the CCP.
âWe need to be careful about how we work with China, but at the end of the day TikTok is not China. Weâre an entertainment platform. Weâre about giving people interesting videos in their day,â he said.
All the countries that have total or partial bans on TikTok:
Australia isnât alone in its ban of TikTok from government devices. Many countries around the world have taken similar measures.
Australia: TikTok banned from all federal government-owned devices.
New Zealand: On March 17, New Zealand announced TikTok would be banned from the phones of government politicians at the end of the month. But it only applies to about 500 people in the parliamentary complex.
Estonia: At the end of March, Estoniaâs outgoing minister of IT and foreign trade, Kristjan JÃ¤rvan, said TikTok would be banned from smartphones issued by the state to public officials.
UK: On March 16, an immediate ban was announced of the app on government official devices.
EU governing bodies: The European Parliament, European Commission, and the EU Council have all banned TikTok on staff devices, citing cybersecurity concerns.
France: On March 24, the French government banned the installation and use of ârecreationalâ applications such as TikTok, Netflix and Instagram on the work phones of 2.5 million civil servants.
Netherlands: The government discourages the use of all apps from âcountries with an aggressive cyber-programâ on phones distributed by the government. TikTok wasnât mentioned by name.
Norway: On March 23, the Norwegian parliament banned TikTok from devices issued to government employees.
Belgium: On March 10, Belgium announced it was banning TikTok from devices owned or paid for by Belgiumâs federal government for at least six months.
Denmark: On March 6, Denmarkâs Defence Ministry announced it would âban the use of the app on official unitsâ as a cybersecurity measure.
USA: Government agencies were given until the end of March to delete TikTok from federal devices and systems. However some US politicians have been advocating an outright ban. However, a bid to ban TikTok from operating in the United States altogether was blocked in the senate on March 30. Now, though, Montana has passed a bill to ban TikTok outright from the state. If signed into law, it could come into effect from January 2024.
Canada: The country announced on February 28 it was banning TikTok from all government-issued devices.
India: In 2020, India imposed a ban on TikTok and some other Chinese apps, shortly after a clash between Indian and Chinese troops at a disputed Himalayan border.
Taiwan: In December 2022, Taiwan imposed a TikTok ban on all government devices.
Pakistan: Pakistani authorities have temporarily banned TikTok at least four times since October 2020, citing concerns that the app promotes immoral content.
Afghanistan: Taliban leaders banned TikTok in 2022 on the grounds of protecting youths from âbeing misledâ.
headline: Chinese diplomat blasts Australian Government ban on TikTok

chat_gpt_summary: Australia is planning to implement strict reforms on vaping, including banning the importation of most vapes, introducing plain packaging, and removing them from convenience store shelves. The move is a response to concerns about vaping becoming a behavioral crisis in schools and the growing black market. The changes will also involve increasing quality standards, restricting flavors and ingredients, reducing nicotine concentrations, and banning disposable vapes. Health experts believe that vaping poses a public health crisis, with children who vape being three times more likely to take up smoking. The government aims to address the issue through comprehensive regulations and enforcement.
article:
Australia is set to ban the importation of most vapes, introduce plain packaging and strip them from convenience store shelves under world-first reforms.
The biggest crackdown on e-cigarettes in Australian history is set to be unveiled in the May budget amid fears vaping has emerged as a serious behavioural crisis in schools across the nation.
Under current laws vapes with nicotine can only be bought with a prescription from a chemist. 
But that hasnât stopped thousands of convenience stores and online providers selling to kids.
Health Minister Mark Butler will unveil the changes on Tuesday under a crackdown that will also involve the states and territories moving to stamp out the growing black market in illegal vaping.
The changes will include tough new laws to:
- Stop the import of non-prescription vapes
- Increase the minimum quality standards for vapes including by restricting flavours, colours, and other ingredients;
- Require pharmaceutical-like packaging;
- Reduce the allowed nicotine concentrations and volumes; and
- Ban all single use, disposable vapes.
But the reforms wonât stop there, with the Albanese Government preparing to work with states and territories to close down the sale of vapes in retail settings, ending vape sales in convenience stores and other retail settings.
Health experts fear the rise of vapes poses a public health crisis with children who vape three times as likely to take up smoking.
Experts claim thousands of children can no longer sit still in class because they are addicted to vaping after smoking âbubblegumâ flavours that secretly contain nicotine.
Health Minister Mark Butler said it was clear that governments had to act.
âVaping was sold to governments and communities around the world as a therapeutic product to help long-term smokers quit,ââ he said.
âIt was not sold as a recreational product - especially not one for our kids. But that is what it has become: the biggest loophole in Australian history.
âOne in six teenagers aged 14-17 has vaped. One in four people aged 18-24 has vaped. By contrast, only one in 70 people my age has vaped.
âAnd when more than a thousand teenagers aged 15 to 17 were asked where they could get vapes, four out of five of them said they found it easy or somewhat easy to buy them in retail stores.
âThis is a product targeted at our kids, sold alongside lollies and chocolate bars.â
Mr Butler said schools were now struggling to deal with the fallout.
âVaping has become the number one behavioural issue in high schools. And itâs becoming widespread in primary schools,â he said.
âOver the past 12 months, Victoriaâs poisons hotline has taken 50 calls about children under 4 becoming sick from ingesting or using a vape.
âUnder the age of 4! Vapes contain 200 toxic chemicals that do not belong in the lungs, the same chemicals youâll find in nail polish remover and weed killer.
âJust like they did with smoking, Big Tobacco has taken another addictive product, wrapped it in shiny packaging and added flavours to create a new generation of nicotine addicts.
 âVapers are three times as likely to take up smoking, which explains why under 25s are the only cohort in the community currently recording an increase in smoking rates.
âThis must end.â
Vape police could be rolled out to monitor the sale of e-cigarettes to children across Australia including on TikTok, Snapchat and Instagram under a plan that will ban most imports and introduce plain packaging.
VicHealth CEO Sandro Demaio, a globally-renowned public health expert and medical doctor, told news.com.au that as soon as the Albanese Government introduced new import bans enforcement could be much tougher at a state level.
âIn many ways this explosion of vaping has really come out of nowhere over just a couple of years,ââ he said.
âBut the reverse is also possible if we ban the advertising of vapes and actually clamp down on the use of social media to promote these products.
âIf we make them less alluring, so they donât they donât come in Froot Loops flavour and look like a highlighter. They donât have unicorns on the side. That will make them far less appealing.
âAnd basically cut off the tap at the border. Those things will absolutely make a huge difference.â
Dr Demaio said that introducing plain packaging was important because that would then allow enforcement to swing into action.
âObviously, we want to close the access and the huge amount of vapes that have been finding their way into the hands of particularly young people,ââ he said.
âSo what needs to happen at the state level is that there needs to be a licensing scheme in every state.
âThe licences themselves would create revenue, which can support enforcement officers, so weâre not relying on police to enforce the measures that we currently have.
âIn theory, theyâre not currently subject to the laws because they donât contain nicotine. But the vast majority do contain nicotine; theyâre just simply not putting in all the packets.
âAnd really, what needs to be done is to say, âWell, if thereâs no flavours, no colours and the only pathway through a prescription, and they, they, they have pharmaceutical packaging, it then makes it much easier for the states to actually enforce it.â
He warned children were being âviciouslyâ exploited.
âWell, whatâs happened over the last few years is that the tobacco industry and the e-cigarette industry, of which thereâs huge overlap, has seen an opportunity to, you know, get another entire generation of Australians addicted to nicotine with a new product. Thatâs flown under the radar,ââ he said.
âThis industry has used young peopleâs social media. These things are all over social media. You can jump on Tik Tok and there are ads for E cigarettes with a âBuy Nowâ button.
âSocial media is under-regulated in this country. They have flooded the market with really cheap imports from overseas that donât declare that they contain nicotine.
âAnd itâs been a combination of social media, weaponising their data on social media and flooding the market with really cheap and highly addictive imports.â
headline: Australian Government announces crackdown on illegal black market vapes

chat_gpt_summary: Conservative MP Alicia Kearns criticized Liz Truss, the former prime minister, for her planned trip to Taiwan, calling it "Instagram diplomacy" and a vanity project. Truss intends to show solidarity with Taiwan amid tensions with Beijing, but Kearns believes the trip lacks substance and could worsen the situation for the Taiwanese people. Truss's visit may disrupt the UK government's balanced approach to China, as Foreign Secretary James Cleverly emphasizes avoiding a complete breakdown in relations. Truss's spokesperson defended the trip, stating that the Taiwanese government invited her, and Kearns should apologize for engaging in political attacks.
article: The Conservative chair of the foreign affairs select committee has launched a blistering attack on Liz Truss over the former prime ministerâs planned trip to Taiwan, calling it âthe worst kind of Instagram diplomacyâ. Alicia Kearns said she thought Trussâs trip planned for next week was little more than a vanity project aimed at keeping her profile high after her brief spell as prime minister last year. Truss is planning to travel to show âsolidarityâ with the Taiwanese people amid aggression from Beijing. Taiwan is a self-governing democracy, but Beijing regards it as a renegade province which must be reunited with the mainland. Trussâs trip has the potential to upset the British governmentâs carefully balanced approach to Chinese relations, with the foreign secretary, James Cleverly, arguing the UK should not âpull the shutters down on Chinaâ. Kearns said: âThe trip is performative, not substantive. It is the worst kind of example of Instagram diplomacy.â She added that the trip was likely to make life harder for the Taiwanese people, who already have to live with a higher level of Chinese military action on their doorstep after the visit by Nancy Pelosi, then the speaker of the US House of Representatives. Beijing responded to that visit by dispatching warships and military jets to surround the island and firing missiles over it. âIt is deeply unhelpful because it escalates the normal situation in Taiwan,â Kearns said. âTaiwanese people already have to live with more Chinese military manoeuvres because of Nancy Pelosiâs visit. Liz Truss doesnât have any influence any more â this is more about keeping herself relevant.â A spokesperson for Truss hit back saying: âThe former prime minister has been invited to visit by the Taiwan government. They are better placed to know what is in the interests of the Taiwanese people than the MP for Rutland. âThe future of Taiwan as a free democracy is at stake. Alicia Kearns should apologise for misusing her position as a select committee chair to engage in petty political attacks.â Truss announced on Tuesday she planned to visit the island, calling it a âbeacon of freedom and democracyâ. The trip follows one to Washington last month, where she gave the annual Margaret Thatcher freedom lecture to the conservative thinktank the Heritage Foundation. She used that speech to attack âwokeismâ and argue that her downfall had been the result of a conspiracy by vested interests within the government. The government has not commented except to say that it would not get involved in the âindependent travel decisions of a private citizen who is not a member of the governmentâ.
headline: Liz Trussâs plan to visit Taiwan called âworst kind of Instagram diplomacyâ

chat_gpt_summary: Annie McAdams, a personal injury lawyer from Houston, Texas, has filed a civil action suit against Meta, the parent company of Facebook and Instagram, on behalf of a client who suffered years of sexual exploitation. The lawsuit alleges that Meta knowingly created an environment conducive to human trafficking, facilitating the buying and selling of people for sex on Instagram. The plaintiff claims she was contacted by a man on Instagram who later sold her to multiple sex buyers through the platform. Despite Meta's attempts to dismiss the case, the lawsuit may proceed, potentially setting a significant precedent regarding social media companies' liability. Meta denies the allegations and emphasizes its efforts to combat sex trafficking.
article: On 14 March 2022, Annie McAdams, a personal injury lawyer running a small firm in Houston, Texas, filed a civil action suit on behalf of one of her clients. The plaintiff was a 23-year-old woman, who had endured years of sexual exploitation at the hands of a convicted trafficker. The defendant was one of the most powerful technology companies in the world. Contained within McAdamsâs federal suit was a series of allegations that Meta â the owner of Facebook and Instagram, which are used by more than 3 billion people every day â had knowingly created a breeding ground for human trafficking and was actively facilitating the buying and selling of people for sex online. The lawsuit alleges that the companyâs products â particularly Instagram â connects vulnerable victims with human traffickers and sex buyers, and provides traffickers with the means to groom those victims. It says that human trafficking victims are regularly posted on Instagram and sold for sex against their will and claims that the company has failed to take adequate steps to stop this. In the court documents, the plaintiff â who we are calling Shawna â says she was 18 when she was first contacted on Instagram by a man she didnât know. She claims that the man â referred to as RL in the court papers â sent her messages on her public profile and on Instagramâs direct-messaging service and that this campaign of grooming led to her agreeing to meet him in person. Two days after their first meeting, she claims that RL began to sell her to sex buyers on Instagram. She claims that RL posted explicit pictures of her on Instagram along with emojis such as dollar signs, crowns and roses, widely recognised by law enforcement and trafficking experts as indicators of commercial sex adverts. â[Meta Inc] knew that the use of these codes were blatant red flags â¦ and were actually sex trafficking advertisements designed to sell her for sex, but [Meta] did nothing to remove or prevent those repeated posts, despite having the ability to do so,â the court papers say. Shawna alleges that over the course of a year she was sold on Instagram to multiple sex buyers. She says she was threatened with homelessness or violence by RL if she refused to fulfil her âquotaâ of sex acts. She went on to testify against RL in a federal criminal trial in Texas and he was subsequently sentenced to 40 years for sex trafficking. However, the lawsuit claims that at the time it was filed to the court in Houston, Instagram had not removed the traffickerâs Instagram account. McAdams claims that despite repeated attempts by Meta to get the case dismissed, Shawna, who is seeking damages from the company, is now on the brink of taking her civil claim against Meta further through the US court system than any other case has managed. She believes that there are now no serious legal obstacles between her case and bringing Meta before a jury in 2024 to face allegations that it played an integral role in the trafficking of her client. A spokesperson for Meta said that Meta prohibits sex trafficking on its platforms âin no uncertain terms â¦ we vigorously deny the claims made against Meta in this suit.â It is not the first time that Meta â in either of its guises as Meta Platforms Inc or Facebook Inc â has faced lawsuits containing similar allegations. Yet in the two decades since it was launched by Mark Zuckerberg from a Harvard dorm, his company â which rebranded from Facebook to Meta in 2021 â like other technology companies with servers based in the US, has never faced prosecution for illegal and harmful content and activities on its platforms. For decades, social media companies have sheltered behind an obscure clause in the 1996 Communications Decency Act â called section 230, which concludes that technology companies are not legally responsible for crimes that occur on their platforms. Section 230 states that providers of âinteractive computer servicesâ â which includes the owners of social media platforms and website hosts â should not be treated as the publisher of material posted by users. Since the act was passed, tech companies such as Meta have argued successfully in US courts that section 230 provides them with immunity from prosecution for any illegal content published on their platforms, as long as they are unaware of that contentâs existence, building a fortress of legal precedent. Section 230 does not shield online platforms from federal criminal charges if they are seen as responsible for facilitating trafficking. And a recent amendment to section 230 â known as the Fosta-Sesta package â means that companies can be held liable under state and civil laws but must be shown to have knowingly assisted or facilitated sex trafficking. Other cases have attempted to swerve section 230, but in her federal suit, McAdams is instead tackling it head-on, arguing that it has been misunderstood and was never intended to protect a social media company which, she claims, knowingly allows crimes against children to occur on its platforms. âThe problem is not section 230,â McAdams says. âThe problem is 20 years of bad precedent and the courtâs misinterpretation of 230. In no place does it say that there should be immunity. There is a big difference between immunity and no liability.â McAdamsâ decision to tackle the interpretation of liability under section 230 comes as changing legal winds across the US challenge the lack of accountability granted to tech companies. The debate around section 230 has become highly polarised. Those who want the clause amended say that the legal safe haven it has provided for internet companies means they have no incentive to root out illegal content on their sites. Others warn that amending section 230 would curb free speech and dismantle democratic values online. Some sex worker groups also warn that undermining section 230 would harm their business and make them unsafe. McAdams says that the only way to stop social media platforms being used as online marketplaces for sex trafficking is through the courts. Along with Shawnaâs case, McAdams has several similar suits filed against Meta across the US in which other plaintiffs allege that Meta enabled, facilitated and profited from their sex trafficking. âAfter years of being silenced, I hope my clients will have their day in court,â she says. âTheir bravery and resilience has started something that could finally see the internet become a safer place for children and open the door for other survivors to be heard. I have many, many more victims waiting to have their cases reviewed. This is just the start.â A Meta spokesperson said: âSex trafficking is abhorrent â¦ we cooperate with law enforcement so they can find and prosecute the criminals who commit these heinous acts, and we use technology to help keep this abuse off our platforms.â âOur goal is to prevent people who seek to exploit others from using our platform, and we work closely with anti-trafficking experts and safety organisations around the world to inform these efforts. We will continue to join with others across society in the fight against sex trafficking and the predators who engage in it.â
headline: The lawyer whose sex trafficking case against Instagram could spell trouble for big tech
