chat_gpt_summary: Meta, the parent company of Facebook and Instagram, will introduce a paid verification service for users, following Twitter's footsteps. The service, initially rolling out in Australia and New Zealand, will cost $11.99 per month on the web and $14.99 on iOS and Android. Verified users will receive a blue badge, increased visibility, extra protection against impersonation, and customer support. The verification process will require government ID documents and a posting history. The service will not be available to businesses initially. Meta's move comes as it faces declining ad revenue and economic challenges, with a recent workforce reduction of 11,000 employees. In a separate development, Twitter announced it would limit SMS-based two-factor authentication to paid Twitter Blue subscribers, raising concerns about potential security risks for non-subscribers.
article: Facebook and Instagram users will soon need to pay to be verified on the social media platforms, as Meta follows in the footsteps of rival platform Twitter. Mark Zuckerberg, Metaâs chief executive, announced in a Facebook post on Sunday that the service would first roll out in Australia and New Zealand later this week. The company said it would cost US$11.99 a month on web or US$14.99 on iOS and Android (or, in Australia, $19.99 on web or $24.99 on iOS and Android). Zuckerberg said in addition to a blue badge the service would offer âextra impersonation protectionâ, improved reach for verified users and direct access to customer support. In a blog post, Meta said it would rely on government ID documents to prove the identity of verified accounts, to avoid the embarrassment of accounts impersonating people and brands â as happened when Twitter initially rolled out its paid verification service. Accounts must also have a posting history and users must be at least 18 years old. The service would not be available to businesses at this stage, Meta said. The increased visibility of posts from verified users would âdepend on a subscriberâs existing audience size and the topic of their postsâ, the company said. Those with smaller audiences might see more of an impact. Sign up for Guardian Australiaâs free morning and afternoon email newsletters for your daily news roundup The company said it would also offer âexclusive stickersâ on Facebook and Instagram stories and Facebook reels. Meta cut 11,000 staff in November â the equivalent of 13% of its workforce â amid falling ad revenue and economic downturn. The companyâs share price fell by more than 70% in 2022 before a rebound and in July it reported its first ever fall in revenue. Twitterâs CEO, Elon Musk, responded to the news in a tweet saying it was âinevitableâ Meta would follow Twitter. Twitter restricts SMS two-factor authentication to paid accounts Separately, Twitter announced on Friday it would provide SMS-based two-factor authentication only to users who are subscribed to the US$8-a-month ($11.65) Twitter Blue service from 20 March. The company currently provides free two-factor authentication through third-party apps and a security key, which are considered more secure than SMS-based systems. If non-subscriber accounts that use SMS authentication do not switch before the deadline, Twitter said it would disable two-factor authentication for that account. The move has sparked concerns that it could lead to widespread hacks on accounts next month if they fail to switch over. Twitterâs last transparency report prior to Muskâs takeover shows that as of December 2021, although just 2.6% of active Twitter accounts use two-factor authentication, 74.4% of those use SMS as their method of authentication. Musk has claimed Twitter was being âscammedâ US$60m a year from fake two-factor authentication messages. He separately supported a tweet claiming the scams were being run by telecommunications companies that had set up bot accounts to run the two-factor authentication process to get revenue from the text messages from Twitter.
headline: Facebook and Instagram to get paid verification as Twitter charges for two-factor SMS authentication

chat_gpt_summary: The UK Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) has targeted over 10,000 misleading financial promotions and scams on social media platforms like Instagram, Facebook, YouTube, and TikTok. The FCA issued a record number of takedown notices and alerts as the use of social media marketing, particularly aimed at younger age groups, surged. Google, Meta, TikTok, Twitter, and Microsoft's Bing adjusted their advertising policies following FCA intervention, but the regulator emphasized the need for more action by tech companies to protect consumers. The FCA employed advanced technology and hired personnel to identify problematic firms and misleading adverts, resulting in the review and takedown of thousands of websites and platforms.
article: More than 10,000 misleading financial promotions and scams aimed at consumers via social media sites such as Instagram, Facebook, YouTube and TikTok have been identified and targeted by the financial watchdog during the past year. The Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) said the use of social media marketing channels and the rise of so-called âfin-fluencersâ â particularly directing investment products at younger age groups â exploded last year, resulting in a record number of takedown notices and alerts. The FCA ordered businesses to amend or remove 8,582 promotions during 2022, 15 times the 573 recorded the previous year. It also published almost 1,900 alerts to consumers about potential scammers, up more than a third up on 2021. Google, which owns YouTube, Meta, which owns Instagram and Facebook, TikTok, Twitter and Microsoftâs Bing have changed advertising policies to ensure that regulated firms are involved in adverts for financial products after FCA intervention. However, the regulator said it was still monitoring whether the companies were effectively blocking illegal adverts. âMore needs to be done by tech companies to protect consumers,â the FCA said. âGiven the substantial number of illegal promotions we continue to identify, our expectation is that every social media platform improves their capability to identify and remove the illegal financial promotions on a proactive basis.â The crackdown included taking action against a company that attempted to take advantage of the cost of living crisis, targeting more than 70,000 online followers that the FCA deemed were potentially vulnerable consumers. An online retail broker with more than 1.1 million UK customers, with a primary market of millennial age investors, was ordered to halt a marketing campaign after the FCA identified âserious concernsâ that its promotions, which used social media influencers, were âtargeting vulnerable customers with significant debtâ. The FCA also sought to get an unregistered cryptocurrency exchange offering products to UK consumers to be shut down, and separately alerted 55 consumers who had been identified on a scammers list targeting consumers who had been searching for loans online. âFinancial promotions must be fair, clear and not misleading,â said Sarah Pritchard, executive director, markets, at the FCA. âThis year, we will continue to put pressure on people using social media to illegally promote investments, which put peopleâs hard-earned money at risk.â The FCA said advances in the technology it uses to identify problem firms and misleading adverts had also fuelled the increase in cases last year. It has hired more than 100 people in roles such as machine learning and data analysis to build automated tools to scan thousands of websites every day. The watchdog said it looked at about 180,000 websites last year, resulting in about 4,500 websites and social media platforms being reviewed. This resulted in 1,441 alerts being issued and 400 of the offending websites being taken down. Last year, the Advertising Standards Authority sent enforcement notices to 50 firms in the cryptocurrency sector warning them that they must clearly explain the risks for potential investors. The watchdog slapped bans on a bitcoin firm for urging that it was âtime to buyâ or miss out, and on football club Arsenalâs campaign to get fans to buy its crypto âtokensâ.
headline: Scams: FCA blocks more than 10,000 ads from Instagram, Facebook and YouTube

chat_gpt_summary: Meta, the parent company of Facebook and Instagram, has announced that former US President Donald Trump will be allowed back on the platforms after a two-year ban. However, there will be new "guardrails" in place to deter repeat offenses. If Trump violates community standards, his content will be removed and he could face suspensions ranging from one month to two years. The decision, which Meta described as allowing for "open, public and democratic debate," has drawn criticism from civil rights advocates concerned about the potential for misinformation and real-life violence. Trump was banned from several other social media platforms following the Capitol riots in January 2021.
article: In a highly anticipated decision, Meta has said it will allow Donald Trump back on Facebook and Instagram following a two-year ban from the platforms over his online behavior during the 6 January insurrection. Meta will allow Trump to return âin coming weeksâ but âwith new guardrails in place to deter repeat offensesâ, Metaâs president of global affairs, Nick Clegg, wrote in a blogpost explaining the decision. âLike any other Facebook or Instagram user, Mr Trump is subject to our community standards,â Clegg wrote. âIn the event that Mr Trump posts further violating content, the content will be removed and he will be suspended for between one month and two years, depending on the severity of the violation.â Trump was removed from Meta platforms following the Capitol riots on 6 January 2021, during which he posted unsubstantiated claims that the election had been stolen, praised increasingly violent protesters and condemned former vice-president Mike Pence even as the mob threatened his life. Clegg said the suspension was âan extraordinary decision taken in extraordinary circumstancesâ and that Meta has weighed âwhether there remain such extraordinary circumstances that extending the suspension beyond the original two-year period is justifiedâ. Ultimately, the company has decided that its platforms should be available for âopen, public and democratic debateâ and that users âshould be able to hear from a former President of the United States, and a declared candidate for that office againâ, he wrote. âThe public should be able to hear what their politicians are saying â the good, the bad and the ugly â so that they can make informed choices at the ballot box,â he said. While it is unclear if the former president will begin posting again on the platform, his campaign indicated he had a desire to return in a letter sent to Meta in January. âWe believe that the ban on President Trumpâs account on Facebook has dramatically distorted and inhibited the public discourse,â the letter said. Safety concerns and a politicized debate The move is likely to influence how other social media companies will handle the thorny balance of free speech and content moderation when it comes to world leaders and other newsworthy individuals, a debate made all the more urgent by Trumpâs run for the US presidency once again. Online safety advocates have warned that Trumpâs return will result in an increase of misinformation and real-life violence. Since being removed from Meta-owned platforms, the former president has continued to promote baseless conspiracy theories elsewhere, predominantly on his own network, Truth Social. While widely expected, the decision still drew sharp rebukes from civil rights advocates. âFacebook has policies but they under-enforce them,â said Laura Murphy, an attorney who led a two-year long audit of Facebook concluding in 2020. âI worry about Facebookâs capacity to understand the real world harm that Trump poses: Facebook has been too slow to act.â The Anti-Defamation League, the NAACP, Free Press and other groups also expressed concern on Wednesday over Facebookâs ability to prevent any future attacks on the democratic process, with Trump still repeating his false claim that he won the 2020 presidential election. âWith the mass murders in Colorado or in Buffalo, you can see there is already a cauldron of extremism that is only intensified if Trump weighs in,â said Angelo Carusone, president and CEO of media watchdog Media Matters for America. âWhen Trump is given a platform, it ratchets up the temperature on a landscape that is already simmering â one that will put us on a path to increased violence.â After the 6 January riots, the former president was also banned from Twitter, Snapchat and YouTube. Some of those platforms have already allowed Trump to return. Twitterâs ban, while initially permanent, was later overruled by its new chief executive, Elon Musk. YouTube has not shared a timeline on a decision to allow Trump to return. Trump remains banned from Snapchat. Meta, however, dragged out its ultimate decision. In 2021, CEO Mark Zuckerberg explained in a post that Trump had been barred from the platforms for encouraging violence and that he would remain suspended until a peaceful transition of power could take place. While Zuckerberg did not initially offer a timeline on the ban, the company punted its decision about whether to remove him permanently to its oversight board: a group of appointed academics and former politicians meant to operate independently of Facebookâs corporate leadership. That group ruled in May 2021 that the penalties should not be âindeterminateâ, but kicked the final ruling on Trumpâs accounts back to Meta, suggesting it decide in six months â two years after the riots. The deadline was initially slated for 7 January, and reports from inside Meta suggested the company was intensely debating the decision. Clegg wrote in a 2021 blogpost that Trumpâs accounts would need to be strictly monitored in the event of his return. How the âguardrailsâ could work Announcing the decision on Wednesday, Clegg said Metaâs âguardrailsâ would include taking action against content that does not directly violate their community standards but âcontributes to the sort of risk that materialized on January 6th, such as content that delegitimizes an upcoming election or is related to QAnonâ. Meta âmay limit the distribution of such posts, and for repeated instances, may temporarily restrict access to our advertising toolsâ, Clegg said, or âremove the re-share buttonâ from posts. Trump responded to the news with a short statement on Truth Social, reposted by others on Twitter, saying that âsuch a thing should never happen again to a sitting presidentâ but did not indicate if or when he would return to the platform. It remains to be seen if he will actually begin posting again on the platforms where his accounts have been reinstated. While he initially suggested he would be âstaying on Truth [Social]â, his own social media platform, recent reports said he was eager to return to Facebook, formally appealing to Meta to reinstate his accounts. But weeks after returning to Twitter, Trump had yet to tweet again. Some have suggested the silence has been due to an exclusivity agreement he has with Truth Social. A report from Rolling Stone said Trump planned to begin tweeting again when the agreement, which requires him to post all news to the app six hours in advance of any other platform, expires in June. Trump has a far broader reach on mainstream social platforms compared with Truth Social, where he has just 5 million followers. Many online safety advocates have warned Trumpâs return would be toxic, and Democratic lawmakers on Capitol Hill urged Meta in a December letter to uphold the ban. Representative Adam Schiff, a Democrat who previously chaired the House intelligence committee, criticized the decision to reinstate him. âTrump incited an insurrection,â Schiff wrote on Twitter. âGiving him back access to a social media platform to spread his lies and demagoguery is dangerous.â Trumpâs account has remained online even after his ban, but he had been unable to publish new posts. Civil rights groups say that regardless of the former presidentâs future actions the Meta decision marks a dangerous precedent. âWhether he uses the platforms or not, a reinstatement by Meta sends a message that there are no real consequences even for inciting insurrection and a coup on their channels,â said a group of scholars, advocates and activists calling itself the Real Facebook Oversight Board in a statement. âSomeone who has violated their terms of service repeatedly, spread disinformation on their platforms and fomented violence would be welcomed back.â Reuters contributed reporting
headline: Trumpâs Facebook and Instagram ban to be lifted, Meta announces

chat_gpt_summary: The oversight board of Meta, the parent company of Facebook and Instagram, has recommended an overhaul of the platforms' rules banning bare-chested images of women but not men. The board's decision follows Facebook's censorship of two posts showing a transgender and non-binary American couple posing topless with their nipples covered. The board found that the policy was based on a binary view of gender and recommended defining clear, objective criteria that respect international human rights standards. While advocates welcome the move, concerns remain about how Meta's automated content-moderation systems will distinguish between topless posts and pornography.
article: Facebook and Instagramâs parent company could soon free the nipple. More than a decade after breastfeeding mothers first held a ânurse-inâ at Facebookâs headquarters to protest against its ban on breasts, Metaâs oversight board has called for an overhaul to the companyâs rules banning bare-chested images of women â but not men. In a decision dated 17 January, the oversight board â a group of academics, politicians, and journalists who advise the company on its content-moderation policies â recommended that Meta change its adult nudity and sexual activity community standard âso that it is governed by clear criteria that respect international human rights standardsâ. The oversight boardâs ruling follows Facebookâs censorship of two posts from an account run by an American couple who are transgender and non-binary. The posts showed the couple posing topless, but with their nipples covered, with captions describing trans healthcare and raising money for top surgery. The posts were flagged by users, then reviewed and removed by an AI system. After the couple appealed the decision, Meta eventually restored the posts. The board found that âthe policy is based on a binary view of gender and a distinction between male and female bodiesâ, which makes rules against nipple-baring âunclearâ when it comes to intersex, non-binary and transgender users. It recommended that Meta âdefine clear, objective, rights-respecting criteriaâ when it comes to moderating nudity âso that all people are treated in a manner consistent with international human rights standardsâ. âLactivistsâ spent the 2000s attempting to squash the image of breasts as inherently sexual, and the campaign to #FreetheNipple went mainstream in 2013. The phrase entered pop-feminist parlance in 2013 after Facebook took down clips from the actor/director Lina Escoâs documentary Free the Nipple. The campaign gained wide support on college campuses and was championed by celebrities including Rihanna, Miley Cyrus and Lena Dunham. As recently as last week, Florence Pugh addressed wearing a sheer, hot pink Valentino gown on the red carpet, saying: âOf course, I donât want to offend people, but I think my point is: how can my nipples offend you that much?â In 2015, the Los Angeles-based artist Micol Hebron created stickers of male nipples â which are permitted on Instagram â so that female Instagram users could superimpose them over their own to mock the disparity. Hebron was invited to Instagramâs headquarters in 2019 with a group of influencers to talk about the companyâs nipple policy. âDuring that meeting, we learned that there were no transgender people on the content moderation policy team, and I also observed that there were no gender-neutral bathrooms there,â Hebron said. âTo me, that was all I needed to know to understand the conversation of gender and inclusivity was not being had at Meta.â A Meta representative disputed Hebronâs characterization of the event, adding: âMuch has changed since 2019.â But Hebron said she was âexcitedâ that the oversight board had taken up the issue of gender and sex-based discrimination. âBeyond just âletâs let women be toplessâ, which is not at all my interest, I think itâs really important to hold on to the goal of allowing all bodies to have autonomy,â Hebron said. âIt sounds so frivolous to a lot of people to talk about nipples, but if you think about the ways that governments around the world try to control and repress female-identifying bodies, trans bodies or non-binary bodies, itâs not.â Meta âwelcomes the boardâs decision in this caseâ, a representative said in a statement that noted that the coupleâs photos had been reinstated âprior to the decisionâ. âWe are constantly evolving our policies to help make our platforms safer for everyone,â the spokesperson added. âWe know more can be done to support the LGBTQ+ community, and that means working with experts and LGBTQ+ advocacy organizations on a range of issues and product improvements.â Meta has 60 days to respond publicly to the boardâs recommendations. While advocates may welcome the idea of a freer nipple online, questions remain about how Metaâs automated content-moderation systems will be able to enforce a new policy on nipples. A couple fundraising to afford top surgery is not the same as someone soliciting sex online, but the companyâs AI did not recognize the difference in the post at first. So how will these systems be able to tell the difference between a topless post and porn? âContext is everything, and algorithms are terrible at context,â Emily Bell, director of the Tow Center for Digital Journalism, told the Guardian. âThe interesting question will be the tension over how Meta can create new rules without opening the floodgates to porn, which is why those rules exist in the first place. That ought to be possible, but Iâm skeptical of whether it is if content moderation is automated.â (Bell previously held several positions at the Guardian, including non-executive director of the Scott Trust.) Facebook and Instagram users can also flag posts they believe violate the companyâs policies, as they did for the photo that spurred the boardâs decision. âIt doesnât take a genius to work out that there are certain areas of the culture wars where content moderation gets weaponized,â Bell said. âA post about top surgery should not have been flagged in the first place, but it was. This could have been the actions of an anti-trans bad actor.â Jillian York, an activist and director of international freedom of expression at the Electronic Frontier Foundation, added that it was âtrickyâ for companies that use AI to make the right decision in every scenario. âFor instance, itâs not easy for an automated technology to make a decision about who is a topless adult, versus who is a topless child,â she said. âAI may be able to make a determination between a nine-year-old and a 26-year-old, but what about a 17-year-old and an 18-year-old?â Sarah Murnen, the Samuel B Cummings II professor of psychology at Kenyon College, said the Free the Nipple movement had once centered white, cisgender women â but that was changing. âWhen we talked about this as an issue about cis women, it seemed less important, potentially, than it is now with trans people wanting to be open about their bodies, while anti-trans sentiment is at an all-time-high,â she said. Now, Meta has been advised to loosen the restrictive, binary way it polices bodies online. But many are quick to doubt AIâs potential to protect all users. âThatâs the big lesson of all of this: when you create automated systems, youâre going to have consequences for people who are more marginalized, or the minority in society,â said Bell. âThose are the people who are penalized by the application of an algorithm.â
headline: Free the nipple: Facebook and Instagram told to overhaul ban on bare breasts

chat_gpt_summary: The oversight board at Meta, the owner of Instagram, has overruled the social media platform's decision to delete a track by drill artist Chinx, who was recently released from prison. The board found that the police's claim that the track could lead to retaliatory violence was unfounded and criticized the breach of free speech principles. However, Chinx now faces new license conditions, including notifying the police and probation service of any releases and avoiding incitement or encouragement of violence. The case sheds light on the state's approach to drill music and the restrictions faced by artists in the genre.
article: Since being released from prison on licence last October, drill artist Chinx (OS), from the Regentâs Park Estate in north-west London, has written 17 music tracks. Each one could have sent the 24-year-old, desperate not to fall back into his past life after serving four years of an eight-year sentence for possession of a firearm with intent to harm, back to jail. This week, the oversight board at Meta, the owner of Instagram, overruled a decision by the social media platform, made in January on the request of the Met police, to delete one of Chinxâs tracks, Secrets not Safe, from the site. His own Instagram account was also deleted. In a development that hit the headlines, the board found that Scotland Yardâs claim to Instagram that the track could lead to âretaliatory violenceâ was not founded, adding that basic principles of free speech, equality and transparency had been breached in allowing a police operation to censor a musician in secret. But Chinx, who has asked for his real name not to be used, says the story does not stop there. âTheyâve given me new licence conditions which are to notify the police and probation service within 24 hours of any release, yeah, and to also have lyrics attached to that,â the young musician says, speaking from an estate in St Johnâs Wood, north London. âThereâs no approval phase. So, itâs not like I send in my lyrics and they say yeah, and you can release this. It is just you have to let us know, deliver the tunes out and if you mess up, you mess up.â He goes on: âA second condition is to not incite or encourage what is reasonably seen as inciting violence around gang hostility. Quite broad. Itâs not really fair. âReasonably seenâ is whatever the police see as a problem.â A misstep could lead to four more years in jail. The case highlights the unprecedented approach taken by the state to drill, a form of rap music that originated from the streets of Chicago, and is notable for its focus on violence and its dark provocative lyrics, fast beats and haunting melodies. In 2019, drill rappers Skengdo and AM were given suspended prison sentences for performing a song in a particular postcode and containing certain lyrics. As part of its investigation into the removal of the track, Metaâs oversight board found that the Met had filed 286 requests to take down or review posts about drill music in the 12 months from June 2021, and that 255 of those had resulted in the removal of content. The police contend that, rather than over-policing a form of music enjoyed predominantly by young black men, they are trying to keep them safe. Chinx, while recognising the excesses of some, says he is just trying to turn his life around and this music, reflecting on the life he knows, offers him a chance. Chinx, nicknamed after his resemblance to a US drill artist of the same name, had 12 convictions to his name before being arrested for possession of a Walther P38 pistol in 2017. He spent four years in seven prisons, including HMPs Belmarsh and Wormwood Scrubs. He performs with his face covered, and maintains anonymity as he seeks to keep his music and family life separate. But he wants, he says, to stay away from the lifestyle he once had on north Londonâs Regent Park Estate. It is why he is churning out his music despite the perilous restrictions encircling him. âEvery moment counts,â he says. âThatâs my mindset. Iâve been behind so Iâve got to do what Iâve got to do three or four times harder.â His work, he says, is entertainment, no matter the violence. The track that was deleted by Instagram was largely fiction. His other works, including those due to appear on a forthcoming album out next February, reflect on his life in jail. How, he asks, is the celebration of violence in Hollywood movies any different to his own? âTo me, it is similar to a James Bond film,â he says. âJames Bond is an MI5 officer who does contract killings. Yeah. So I mean, thatâs his job as a profession when you make a whole movie out of it and make it seem like itâs cool to go around killing. All you can control is what you can control â me as an individual. I canât control what someone else is going to do based on my lyrics.â
headline: Met monitoring song lyrics of rap artist it tried to censor on Instagram

chat_gpt_summary: Meta's oversight board has compelled the company to reinstate a clip of drill music on Instagram that was removed at the request of the Metropolitan police. The board ruled that the removal was a mistake and that the track did not violate Facebook or Instagram's rules. It criticized the breach of free speech, equality, and transparency principles, emphasizing the need for independent evaluation of law enforcement requests regarding artistic expression from marginalized groups. The board also raised concerns about potential over-policing of certain communities and called for a public and standardized system for content removal requests.
article: Metaâs oversight board, the quasi-independent âsupreme courtâ of Facebook and Instagram, has forced the company to reinstate a clip of drill music originally removed from Instagram at the request of the Metropolitan police. The clip, a short excerpt of the song Secrets Not Safe by Chinx (OS), was removed after the Met flagged the track to Meta, arguing that it could lead to âretaliatory violenceâ in the context of the London gang scene. The force told Meta it contained a âveiled threatâ, referencing a shooting in 2017, and as a result the company manually removed 52 posts containing the track and automated systems removed it a further 112 times. Now, the oversight board says those removals were a mistake. The track does not break Facebook or Instagramâs rules, it argues, and basic principles of free speech, equality and transparency were breached in allowing a police operation to censor a musician in secret. âWhile law enforcement can sometimes provide context and expertise, not every piece of content that law enforcement would prefer to have taken down should be taken down,â the board said in its ruling. âIt is therefore critical that Meta evaluates these requests independently, particularly when they relate to artistic expression from individuals in minority or marginalised groups for whom the risk of cultural bias against their content is acute.â As part of its investigation into the removal of the track, the oversight board filed multiple freedom of information requests with the Met police, finding that the force had filed 286 requests to take down or review posts about drill music in the 12 months from June 2021, and that 255 of those had resulted in the removal of content. Over the same period, it had not made a single request to remove any other music genre, the force said. âThis intensive focus on one music genre among many that include reference to violence raises serious concerns of potential over-policing of certain communities,â the board argued. The board also asked the Met how it ensured that free speech rights were protected, and what its specific policies were about flagging content to social networks. The force said it was unable to answer, with decisions made on a case-by-case basis. Crucially, the Met did not allege any of the drill music that it had asked Meta to take down had broken UK law. Instead, its argument was that the music had broken Facebook and Instagramâs community standards, since it was âpotentially threatening or likely to contribute to imminent violence or physical harmâ. The police did not provide public evidence to back up that claim. Because the internal Meta team that works with the police comprises senior specialists, users whose content is taken down also have no ability to appeal. In a statement, Meta said: âWe do not remove content simply because law enforcement requests it â we take action if content is found to violate our policies or local law. As part of our robust review process, we assess whether a request is consistent with internationally-recognised standards on human rights, including due process, privacy, free expression and the rule of law.â The oversight board recommended that, in the future, Meta should have a public and standardised system for content removal requests from law enforcement and other state actors, including asking for evidence to back up claims that a policy has been violated, and to review its decisions in aggregate to assess for systemic biases against communities or minorities. Although it is funded by Meta, and its co-chairs were selected by the social network, the oversight board operates largely independently, and has the power to overrule the moderation teams of Facebook and Instagram, and to force content to be reinstated to the site, as it has done in this case. It can also issue non-binding recommendations for the companyâs future policies, which Meta reserves the right to refuse but has agreed to respond to even if it decides not to enact them.
headline: Instagram told to reinstate music video removed at request of Met police

chat_gpt_summary: Australian mining billionaire Gina Rinehart was photographed at Donald Trump's 2024 presidential campaign launch at Mar-a-Lago, according to a photo posted by Trump's son Eric on Instagram. Rinehart, the executive chair of Hancock Prospecting, has been a public supporter of Trump since 2016. She praised Trump's election win and urged Australia to follow his lead on reducing government regulations and cutting taxes. Rinehart has also attended a state dinner hosted by Trump and is associated with the Trumpettes, an all-female supporter group. The photo also captured Mike Lindell, the founder of MyPillow and a Trump backer.
article: The Australian mining billionaire Gina Rinehart was pictured at Donald Trumpâs 2024 presidential campaign launch at Mar-a-Lago in Florida on Wednesday, in the background of a photo posted to Instagram by the former presidentâs son Eric. Rinehart, the executive chair of mining and agricultural company Hancock Prospecting, has publicly backed Trump since at least 2016, when he was elected president. In a speech to a mining conference in Mount Isa in November 2016, she said she had recently met with members of Trumpâs campaign team including Rudy Giuliani and then-campaign manager Kellyanne Conway. â¢ Sign up for Guardian Australiaâs free morning and afternoon email newsletters for your daily news roundup She said Trump and his team had won the 2016 election despite âconstant and unrelenting negative coverageâ, because they âlistened to the people of Americaâ who wanted âless government tape, secondly less taxation, and for the USA to grow and be economically strong againâ. Rinehart urged Australia to follow Trumpâs lead on his plan to cut âfederal government tapeâ by 50% in his first months of office, and to cut company tax to 15%. Rinehart, considered Australiaâs richest person and one of the richest women in the world, also attended a 2019 state dinner hosted by Trump at the White House for former Australian prime minister Scott Morrison. She is also named as a member of the Trumpettes, an all-female Trump high society supporter group founded in the US in 2015, according to multiple social media posts from the network. She is referred to in one of their posts as the âlead Trumpette in Australiaâ. In 2018 the group dubbed Rinehart âTrumpette of the weekâ. The Trumpettes were founded by Hollywood reporter turned socialite Toni Holt Kramer. The group says on its site âyour job as a Trumpette is to help get the real Donald J. Trump elected â¦ introduce the real man to your family, your friends, the people you work with and anyone you come in contact with â¦ and then be ready to explain why you think Donald Trump will be the best president for all of Americaâ. Also seen in the photo posted by Eric Trump, standing just behind Rinehart, was Mike Lindell, the founder of MyPillow, an alleged conspiracy theorist who has also heavily backed Trump. Guardian Australia has contacted Rinehart for a response.
headline: Gina Rinehart pictured at Donald Trumpâs campaign launch in Instagram photobomb

chat_gpt_summary: Matt, a climate scientist and self-proclaimed social media virgin, reflects on the growing awareness among longtime social media users about the vulnerabilities and downsides of platforms like Twitter and Instagram. Concerned about privacy, data, algorithmic manipulation, and the addictive nature of social media, Matt has never joined any social media platform. While he acknowledges the difficulties of leaving established networks, he believes there may be another way to live without constant online engagement. Others who have quit social media platforms have found more time, peace of mind, and opportunities for personal growth, indicating a potential shift away from mass-market platforms towards smaller, community-focused alternatives.
article: Matt* shouldâve joined Twitter years ago. He fits the user profile perfectly: highly educated, a politics junkie, across the news, loves a debate, and heâs a climate scientist. But unlike many users publicly grappling with Elon Muskâs new universe, threatening to jump ship (but then lingering on the deck), or trying to muster the energy to migrate to another platform and, ahem, âtootâ, Matt is a social media virgin. Unblemished, unsullied â the 46-year-old has never joined a single social media platform. âIâm not very quick to pick up and run with new technologies,â says Matt from the Victorian town of Geelong, âbut that lag time meant that I began to see things I didnât like about their adoption.â Along with privacy and data concerns, he figured most algorithms encouraged outrage and constant use. Like a true scientist, brevity (and committing casual comments to the public record) also put him off: âI didnât know what could be usefully said in 140 characters.â Twitter might be a social media minnow (29.5% of Australian internet users use it at least once a month, compared to Facebook at 76.8%) but watching people tweeting about whether to stay or go in real time is instructive. Itâs a snapshot of a growing awareness among longtime social media users (and people who still dimly remember a time before the internet) about how vulnerable they are to changing algorithms (and owners) and what drew them to social media in the first place. Sign up for Guardian Australiaâs free morning and afternoon email newsletters for your daily news roundup And perhaps unicorns like Matt can show us that thereâs another way to live entirely, that maybe we donât need to Google the word âMastodonâ? Maybe we just â¦ stop? âItâs hard to be that person because most of your networks are there and youâve invested all this time, energy and content. Thereâs a cost to leaving,â says Jordan Guiao, Research Fellow at The Australia Instituteâs Centre for Responsible Technology and author of the new book Disconnect. âThe big platforms rely on that. Everybody knows that theyâre bad news now, but physically moving is still really hard.â The trends arenât exactly reflective of Mattâs monastic stance. By the end of 2021, 82.7% of Australians were active on social media, an annual growth of nearly 1 million users, nudged along by an isolating pandemic and the growth of TikTok. As social media becomes baked into our daily online diet, how does it feel to be excluded from the conversation? I interrogate Matt in the same way I might approach a time traveller from the 1880s, or a very smart baby. How do you keep up with the news? âRadio, print, online.â The zeitgeist? âMost of the time it gets reported there if itâs noteworthy.â What do you do with all your spare time? âI think about it the opposite way around. Where do people find the time to be on social media?â Leaving the Las Vegas (internet) Felicia Semple, 48, from Melbourne fell off Instagram in May. She still hasnât hasnât explained her absence to her not insubstantial follower base â all 24,000 of them. âIt initially happened by accident. I decided I wouldnât post while I was away on holiday, but then I just couldnât make myself go back,â says Semple. Semple started a blog called The Craft Sessions in 2013 to âprovide a space for crafters to come togetherâ to share ideas and inspire each other. Increasingly, Semple wrote about the connection between mental health and crafting, or âthe head stuffâ as she calls it. Joining Instagram initially grew her community in very meaningful ways. But more recently, âevery time Iâd open it I would feel dread, rather than joy. It had become a chore â a stressful, anxiety-ridden ethically-dubious space.â Like many artists recently whoâve built whole careers on the platform, Instagramâs algorithm changes (mainly mirroring the TikTok model of snack-sized video) changed everything. âThe requirements of the algorithm had changed the type of content I was creating,â says Semple. âIt was warping my own creative impulses and my message, by messing with my biology, making me feel that I needed to keep up.â âThe most popular platforms want us to be there with 24/ 7 engagement at all costs,â says Guaio. âThe way social media is built is Las Vegas crazy, super bright and completely addictive. In the real world we donât live like that.â We need to âstart to think about a healthier way of doing it â¦ develop platforms that donât have this kind of extractive business model that relies on us being there every second of the day, or â¦ getting dopamine hits for every like.â Semple knows that the decision to quit Instagram was a luxury, as she wasnât relying on it for income. Many people whoâve built their businesses on social media feel like they have no choice but to adapt. But these days sheâs sleeping better. âI have more time and peace of mind. I finished my psychology degree last week.â Given all that, Semple is thinking of ways to engage with her online community again. âIâve read three books in one monthâ Forty-five year-old Olivia Sinclair Smith works in education. She quit her platform of choice, Facebook, a month ago. Sheâd tried to leave before, but this time she went cold turkey. âI was just mindlessly scrolling through posts and peopleâs bits and pieces and wasting more and more time doing it. I started to feel guilty afterwards, like I was addicted and I couldnât stop.â Since quitting, âI donât feel the guilt and the self-loathing I used to get from staring at crap posted by people I barely know â¦ Iâve read three books in the last month which is unheard of for me.â Sinclair Smith has strategically kept a slice of the platform â Facebook Marketplace. âI made a fake profile which has no friends attached and I use that to look at items to buy.â âI am tempted to join the interest groups using my fake profile,â says Sinclair Smith, but sheâs worried it could be âa gateway drugâ. A great rebalancing? Guiao says people are becoming more discerning. âWe are seeing a bit of a move away from the giant, public, mass-market platforms into smaller and more community focused platforms and private messaging like WhatsApp,â he says. âWeâre actually going back to how we naturally communicate in our physical or our real-world social networks.â Guiao says to expect ourselves to disconnect entirely is unrealistic, especially digital natives. âWeâre going be online now for the rest of our lives. But thereâs something to be said for rebalancing it,â says Guiao. How that rebalancing will work for younger users embracing more broadcast platforms like TikTok and YouTube remains to be seen. For users looking to engage with niche topics and communities on those platforms, it can still be like running through a casino looking for the ball pit and ending up at the craps table instead. âThe challenge is that there isnât a viable alternative â¦ even if we wanted to change, itâs very difficult,â says Guiao. Guiao points to Eli Pariserâs work, who talks about the concept of âdigital parks as quiet spaces to gather. How do we build online versions of that? The âLas Vegasâ internet isnât an inevitability.â Remember, these places have existed. âBefore social media, there were community platforms like blogs and forums and all of those things that [were] built for connection, community and collaboration but werenât built to get you addicted.â Matt has no desire to join the party. But heâs still forced to reckon with social media, given that his children, currently seven and nine, will eventually have to confront it. âIn the social lives of younger people, thereâs a very heavy price to pay for not engaging. All I can do is help them to understand that the priorities they have for their own lives are not even remotely aligned with those of these companies.â âI do also worry about the capacity for them to find refuge in their lives.â Most of us wonât ever be as pure as Matt, but we might get smarter at making social media work for us. Maybe tooting doesnât sound so bad after all. *Name has been changed
headline: The 46-year-old social media virgin: how people ditch Twitter, Facebook and Instagram and survive

chat_gpt_summary: Stephanie Broadbridge, a stand-up comedian, participated in a "try not to laugh" challenge with another comedian. The clips of their challenge went viral on TikTok, with one video receiving over 47 million views. However, the captions and lack of context led to vicious and sexist comments directed at Stephanie. The negative comments escalated when the video was reposted on 9gag, resulting in trolling across her social media platforms and forcing her to remove ads for her live shows. Stephanie's experience highlights the gendered and violent nature of online harassment, affecting her mental well-being and career. She emphasizes the need for a safer online environment, particularly in industries where social media presence is crucial.
article:
COMMENT
It was a Sunday morning, Iâm a stand-up comedian and I was booked for an unusual gig. I would be sitting opposite a male comedian as we read dad jokes from the internet to each other and tried not to laugh. If we did laugh, we had to take a shot of vodka. 
It was early in the morning and Iâm allergic to alcohol so I was pretty motivated to win the challenge. 
I won 10-1. 
The challenge was filmed and turned into short clips for the relatively small Aussie TikTok account YeahMadTV. I was paid $200 and I assumed the video content would disappear into social media land like the billions of other comedy videos that no one ever sees. But thatâs not what happened. 
The clips went viral. One clip currently has over 47 million views and counting. 
Best dog joke ever written. #dadjokes#dadjokesoftheday#dadjoke#jokes#fyp#dadjokesoftiktok
The joke? What do you call a dog that can do magic? A Labra-cadabrador.
Why was it so popular? Because people hated me and left vicious, sexist comments to let me know exactly how much. The more they commented, the more views the video received. 
When the clip was posted, the important information that I was a performer in a âtry not to laugh challengeâ wasnât included. Instead, it was captioned âBest dog joke ever writtenâ so when I didnât laugh at the joke, I just looked mean.
The commentary seemed to be that how dare I, a woman, not laugh at the funny manâs joke (not his joke, a joke off the internet). I must be a Karen, a feminist, a cat lady, a [redacted] who doesnât have a sense of humour. The few people in the comments who tried to stick up for me by explaining it was a challenge, were also attacked.
I contacted YeahMadTV and they removed some of the nastiest comments and put in the comments that it was the âtry not to laughâ challenge but it didnât stop there. The video developed a life of its own. 
One anonymous account reposted the clip on 9gag, a social media platform that allows users to upload and share content from other social media sites. It was shared under the caption âShe has no sense of Humourâ. The thousands of comments on 9gag, that I canât delete, are so disgusting that I couldnât get through them.
Once I realised YeahMadTV had tagged me, I untagged myself immediately but the trolls still found me.
They wrote negative comments on every stand-up comedy clip I had on TikTok and Instagram. 
I was running ads for my live stand up shows at the Melbourne International Comedy Festival and those ads all had to be removed because of the trolling. 
It is very hard to be funny when every time I tell a joke on stage, I can picture these vile comments screaming at me from the audience.
On the final night of my Melbourne Comedy Festival run I broke down. I left the stage ten minutes into my show and burst into tears. I have been performing comedy almost every single night for seven years and this has never happened to me before. I am professional and reliable. I donât cancel. I built my reputation on being âthe chick that doesnât cancelâ.
Yes, of course, men get negative comments online too, but this was different. The language was gendered. It was violent. It was threatening. The attacks were intended to silence me, intimidate me and humiliate me, because I had committed a mortal sin of womanhood, not laughing at a manâs crappy joke. I know Iâm the least objective person in this situation but itâs hard to deny the lashings of misogyny. 
Sure, I could delete social media. If I stop putting myself out there, then people will stop trolling me. But I am a stand-up comedian. This is my job. Part of that job is promoting myself online and I deserve to feel safe at work. 
Itâs not just the arts where a strong social media presence is a requirement. Social media is an integral part of most careers. Nearly every employer checks you out online before hiring you, so to say âjust ignore itâ is completely unreasonable.
Thatâs asking me to ignore the cheapest and most efficient way to promote myself. âDonât worry about itâ or âdonât post things if you donât want to get attackedâ does not resolve the issue. I am worried about it. Itâs disgusting, itâs sexist and itâs ruining my career.
Given social media is an important part of our work life and women are trolled more than men how is that workplace equality? Why are we accepting trolling as a consequence of being online?
The number of women in comedy I have spoken to that have received similar treatment online is truly horrifying. Some have quit comedy, some have been seeking mental health treatment ever since, some just put up with it as part of the deal.
I donât have a solution, but I would suggest that next time you are tempted to write a mean comment on a random clip for no other reason except that youâre bored, maybe donât.
Stephanie Broadbridge is a stand-up comedian.
headline: Comedian Stephanie Broadbridge on trolling after joke TikTok video viewed 47 million times

chat_gpt_summary: Eddy May, an Australian driver, found himself stranded when a tyre on his electric Mercedes-Benz EQC-400 went flat. He used the car's in-car customer service feature to call Mercedes and arrange a tow truck. While praising the company's response, May raised concerns about electric vehicles lacking spare tyres due to space limitations caused by batteries. Some viewers criticized the inconvenience of needing a tow truck and taxi instead of a simple tyre change. Despite the incident, May defended the environmental benefits of electric vehicles, highlighting their lower emissions compared to traditional cars.
article:
An Australian driver has revealed a glaring problem with electric vehicles after finding himself stranded on the side of the road when one of his tyres went flat.
Eddy May was driving home in his electric Mercedes-Benz EQC-400 on Sunday just before midday when his rear left wheel deflated, leaving him and his wife stranded on the side of the road in Adelaide. 
Making use of an in-car customer service offered in the luxury model, he pressed a button and spent five minutes on the phone with Mercedes about the tyre.
âIâve spoken to them, theyâre sending a tow truck,â Mr May told his followers in a clip shared to TikTok. 
âQuick five minutes on the phone, a $200 cab charge voucher to get home, [and the] carâs going to get towed to Mercedes and the carâs going to be fixed tomorrow apparently,â he said. 
About 35 minutes later, the $128,000 vehicle was loaded onto a tow truck and the coupleâs taxi arrived. 
By just after 12pm, they were on their way home. 
âPretty good. Well done Mercedes,â Mr May said. 
But his video praising Mercedes for their service raised questions over why a spare tyre wasnât kept inside the car as it would be for petrol cars. 
âThereâs no spare in this f**king car because all the room is taken up with batteries and so forth,â Mr May said. 
Most electric vehicles donât come with spare tyres given the extra space and weight they require. 
âI would be severely unimpressed with needing a tow truck, taxi ride, loan car and what 1-2 days without my car over a flat tyre,â one comment on the video read. 
âI would much prefer the 10 minutes to change the tyre,â another wrote. 
âGreat service, interesting way of saving the planet and reducing carbon emissions. Taxi ride and tow truck compared with carrying a spare tyre,â a third said. 
Mr May argued the vehicle still worked out to be friendlier on the environment overall, even though it used a lot of resources when a tyre blew out. 
In response to someone who described the car a âjokeâ, he said it was still ahead in terms of emissions. 
â24,000 kms with no petrol or oil and 38 kms on a diesel truck. I still think itâs doing okay,â he said.
headline: Major problem with electric vehicle exposed in TikTok

chat_gpt_summary: A 13-year-old boy from Ohio has died after participating in a viral TikTok challenge that involved swallowing multiple benadryl pills to induce hallucinations. The dangerous trend, which started in 2022, has led to hospitalizations among Australian teens. The boy, Jacob Stevens, experienced seizures and was rushed to the hospital, where he was kept on life support for six days before his family made the heartbreaking decision to let him pass. Jacob's father is now raising awareness about the dangers of social media challenges and advocating for age restrictions on over-the-counter drugs and platforms like TikTok. The US FDA has issued a warning about the risks of the "Benadryl Challenge."
article:
A 13-year-old boy in the US has died after taking part in a viral TikTok challenge. 
The challenge involves swallowing up to 14 benadryl pills â an antihistamine allergy medication â to induce hallucinations, with participants then posting videos of their experience on social media. 
Believed to have been started in 2022, the trend has already caused a spate of hospitalisations among Australian teens attempting to participate.
Jacob Stevens from Ohio began to seize up after ingesting a lethal dose.
He was immediately rushed to the hospital as his body began to shut down. 
Tragically, after six days on life support, his family made the heart-wrenching decision to let him pass, as his brain functions had ceased.
Jacobâs father, Justin, is now dedicated to warning parents and teens of the dangers of social media and has shared a photo of Jacob hooked up to life support in the hospital to spread awareness.
âIt was too much for his body,â the grieving father said via ABC 6, recalling the âworst day of his lifeâ.
âNo brain scan, there was nothing there. They said we could keep him on the vent, that he could lay there, but he will never open his eyes, heâll never breathe, smile, walk or talk.â
âIt didnât matter how bad of a day I was having, no one could make me smile, Jacob could make me smile,â Justin recalled through tears.
Justin and his family have also begun pushing politicians to take steps to prevent other kids from partaking in such challenges by putting age restrictions on over-the-counter drugs like Benadryl. 
He has also suggested imposing an age restriction for creating accounts on TikTok, forcing users to provide identification before being allowed on the platform.
The US Food and Drug Administration has issued a statement warning of the dangers of participating in the âBenadryl Challengeâ and is aware of reports of teenagers ending up in emergency rooms or dying after taking part.
âTaking higher than recommended doses of the common over-the-counter (OTC) allergy medicine diphenhydramine (Benadryl) can lead to serious heart problems, seizures, coma or even death,â the FDA wrote.
âWe are aware of news reports of teenagers ending up in emergency rooms or dying after participating in the Benadryl Challenge encouraged in videos posted on the social media application TikTok.â
Queensland Ambulance Service confirmed an alarming number of call-outs in recent weeks after the trend became popular.
Seizures and head wounds were among the injuries sustained for those who took part, QAS said.
âThere were four calls in one hour in South East Queensland and all of those children needed transport to hospital,â a spokeswoman said last year.
Among the harmful side effects from high doses are seizures and a racing heart rate.
Its damage has been so far reaching, the trend prompted drug manufacturer Johnson and Johnson to issue a warning in its popularityâs wake.
âWe understand that consumers may have heard about an online âchallengeâ involving the misuse or abuse of diphenhydramine,â the company said.
âThis challenge, which involves the ingestion of excessive quantities of diphenhydramine, is a dangerous trend and should be stopped immediately.â
headline: Benadryl Challenge: US teenager dies after trying TikTok trend

chat_gpt_summary: A former Chinese diplomat criticized Australia's TikTok ban on government devices, calling it "racism" and warning against creating an enemy with 1.4 billion people. The Australian government imposed the ban due to security concerns and fears of data harvesting by the Chinese-owned platform. Cybersecurity experts have highlighted the app's extensive data collection capabilities. However, TikTok Australia's general manager denied the risk and stated that TikTok is an entertainment platform, not China. Several other countries, including the US, UK, and France, have also implemented bans or restrictions on TikTok over cybersecurity concerns.
article:
A former Chinese diplomat has labelled Australiaâs TikTok ban on government devices âracismâ, telling the Government: âYou do not want to have an enemy with 1.4 billion people.â
In an interview with 60 Minutes, former diplomat and CCP mouthpiece Victor Gao said of the ban: âProbably itâs racism, probably itâs racial discrimination, probably itâs banning Chinese again, which was a disaster many years ago.
âNow you want to do that again? It will not be a success.â
The Australian Government banned the Chinese-owned social media platform from all government devices, citing fears over security. It follows similar bans in many other countries around the world.
âThis has been informed by security agenciesâ advice on work thatâs been done and provided to the government, so thatâs the decision weâve taken is around government-issued devices,â Finance Minister Katy Gallagher said earlier this month.
Concerns over the scope of personal information that TikTok harvests and its parent company ByteDanceâs apparent links to the communist regime has led governments around the world to believe that China could be weaponising the social media app to spy on their citizens.
Cybersecurity expert Robert Potter previously told 60 Minutes that the app collects a lot more data than other social media sites.
âIt can collect your keystroke patterns, body language, face and body features. It can access photos or passwords that are stored in your phone over time,â he said.
âThereâs a super location field that allows them to collect which direction youâre facing, how fast youâre moving, how high off the ground you are, your latitude and longitude.â
However Mr Gao said Australia shouldnât feel threatened by the app.
âAustralians need to be really confident about their own system, rather than being threatened by TikTok. Banning it is not a sign of strength. Itâs not a sign of superiority, itâs not a sign of confidence. Itâs just the opposite,â he said.
He also said the ban could cause further tensions in Australiaâs already strained relationship with China.
âI would urge the Australian Government to really treat China as an equal, because you do not want to have an enemy with 1.4 billion people,â he said.
Meanwhile, TikTok Australia and New Zealand general manager Lee Hunter insists the ban is politically motivated, saying there was âno evidenceâ to support that peopleâs data was at risk.
He also told 60 Minutes TikTok Australia will not hand over personal information to the CCP.
âWe need to be careful about how we work with China, but at the end of the day TikTok is not China. Weâre an entertainment platform. Weâre about giving people interesting videos in their day,â he said.
All the countries that have total or partial bans on TikTok:
Australia isnât alone in its ban of TikTok from government devices. Many countries around the world have taken similar measures.
Australia: TikTok banned from all federal government-owned devices.
New Zealand: On March 17, New Zealand announced TikTok would be banned from the phones of government politicians at the end of the month. But it only applies to about 500 people in the parliamentary complex.
Estonia: At the end of March, Estoniaâs outgoing minister of IT and foreign trade, Kristjan JÃ¤rvan, said TikTok would be banned from smartphones issued by the state to public officials.
UK: On March 16, an immediate ban was announced of the app on government official devices.
EU governing bodies: The European Parliament, European Commission, and the EU Council have all banned TikTok on staff devices, citing cybersecurity concerns.
France: On March 24, the French government banned the installation and use of ârecreationalâ applications such as TikTok, Netflix and Instagram on the work phones of 2.5 million civil servants.
Netherlands: The government discourages the use of all apps from âcountries with an aggressive cyber-programâ on phones distributed by the government. TikTok wasnât mentioned by name.
Norway: On March 23, the Norwegian parliament banned TikTok from devices issued to government employees.
Belgium: On March 10, Belgium announced it was banning TikTok from devices owned or paid for by Belgiumâs federal government for at least six months.
Denmark: On March 6, Denmarkâs Defence Ministry announced it would âban the use of the app on official unitsâ as a cybersecurity measure.
USA: Government agencies were given until the end of March to delete TikTok from federal devices and systems. However some US politicians have been advocating an outright ban. However, a bid to ban TikTok from operating in the United States altogether was blocked in the senate on March 30. Now, though, Montana has passed a bill to ban TikTok outright from the state. If signed into law, it could come into effect from January 2024.
Canada: The country announced on February 28 it was banning TikTok from all government-issued devices.
India: In 2020, India imposed a ban on TikTok and some other Chinese apps, shortly after a clash between Indian and Chinese troops at a disputed Himalayan border.
Taiwan: In December 2022, Taiwan imposed a TikTok ban on all government devices.
Pakistan: Pakistani authorities have temporarily banned TikTok at least four times since October 2020, citing concerns that the app promotes immoral content.
Afghanistan: Taliban leaders banned TikTok in 2022 on the grounds of protecting youths from âbeing misledâ.
headline: Chinese diplomat blasts Australian Government ban on TikTok

chat_gpt_summary: A conspiracy theorist has claimed that the construction of U-turn bays on a road in Victoria, Australia, is evidence of a plot to implement "15-minute cities" or "smart cities." The theorist believes that these cities, where essential services are located within a short distance, will restrict people's movement and increase government control. However, critics argue that the U-turn bays are simply for improved access and safety. The debate over the concept of 15-minute cities has sparked discussions online, with proponents highlighting the convenience and health benefits while skeptics raise concerns about restrictions and surveillance.
article:
A 15-minute city conspiracy theorist has made a bold claim about the construction of multiple U-turn bays on a Victorian road, as debate over the urban-planning concept continues globally. 
In a video shared to Twitter, an Australian podcaster filmed herself driving along Narre Warren North Road which is situated 38km southeast of Melbourne and is currently undergoing upgrades.
The roadworks commenced in 2020 and are part of the state governmentâs Big Build project which entailed the addition of extra lanes, installation of traffic lights and road safety improvements. 
Final asphalting works, guardrail and signage installations, line markings and vegetation works are currently underway with the project expected to be completed by mid this year.
In line with the project, extra U-turn bays were created for safer and easier access to streets adjacent to the main road. 
However, the conspiracy theorist believes these turnaround lanes have been installed to serve a more dire purpose, believing more 15-minute or 20-minute cities are set to pop up in the future. 
Also known as smart cities, the notion is an urban development idea where everything you need access to is located within a short distance.
This may include schools, shops, GP clinics and even the office or your place of work, all within the same zone. 
The concept is the brainchild of Franco-Colombian urbanist Carlos Moreno who came up with the idea to prompt more sustainable, convenient and healthier living.
Key elements of the theory include keeping essential services close, creating a sense of community solidarity and inspiring green urban living.
However, not all are convinced, with some conspiracists comparing the theory to a Stalin-style plot to keep people in lockdown or under the governmentâs control.
In the case of the woman who filmed herself driving along Narre Warren North Road, she believes the road upgrade project will become a âCheckpoint Charlieâ for smart cities.
âThis used to be a country road. Not only are they building wires and towers but theyâre also putting in interestingly three or four U-turn opportunities,â she explained in the video.
âI guess thatâs because youâll get a warning â youâre about to leave your 20-minute city, your district, your zone (and itâs your) last chance to turn back obviously before the fines start.â
As she drives further down the road, the woman highlights three âpillars with weird blue lightsâ positioned in the middle of the road next to several parked tradie cars. 
âUp here to the right youâll see three bollards â¦ I think this right here is the checkpoint,â she claims in the video. 
âThereâs now all of these opportunities to pull a U-turn and go back the way you came.
âIn the future, going out to the countryside is not something theyâre going to allow you to do without you handing over your money.â
The tweet, which has received over 1.3 million views and 692 likes, has amassed debate over the urban planning concept online with many arguing the woman has taken her thoughts âtoo farâ.
âThis is ridiculous. U-turns, or access for emergency vehicles? Or both? Forget something and need to go back home? A U-turn is handy. This is not a nefarious thing,â one person tweeted.
â15 minute (cities) have been around for ages and have nothing to do with climate change lockdowns. Itâs literally about ease of access and reducing dependency on cars,â a second person said.
âNo one is preventing you from going further away in your car.â
A third comment read: âThe wires reduce accidents. The breaks in the wire provide access points for emergency vehicles to turn. 
âThese safety measures can be found on roads around Australia.â
Meanwhile, one man suggested the push for electric vehicles (EV) over petrol cars could be another excuse to restrict people to their âzoneâ.
âIâm thinking this is one of the major reasons they want EV versus gas vehicles, fewer and less range!â he said. 
The debate online follows huge rallies around the world as conspiracy theorists criticise the concept, which has already come into effect in 16 cities globally including Paris and Shanghai. 
Edmonton Canada was also another city which tried to implement the idea, however received backlash from its residents.
âYou will spend 90 per cent of your life in this 15-minute area as they are monitoring your carbon footprint,â a flyer circulating warned.
Meanwhile, those who agree with the theory have slammed its critics, including registered nurse Christopher Patterson and national radio broadcaster Triple J Hack. 
âThere are a lot of noted intellectuals on TikTok telling me I should be suspicious of convenience,â Triple J Hack reporter Shalailah Medhora said in a radio package last month. 
Dr Patterson, who is also a University of Wollongong lecturer, explained there are numerous health benefits to the theory that many sceptics are overlooking.
âThe main (benefit) is giving people back their freedom (and) time,â Dr Patterson said.
âThe time you get back you could put into (your) health or sitting in green spaces to connect back with your community and family.â
headline: 15-minute cities: Womanâs bizarre claim about Victorian road project

article:
A fitness fanatic has clapped back at a judgmental troll in a hilarious way after she was slammed for her choice of outfit at the gym.
Avid gym-goer and TikTok user Beba showed that she wasnât going to let anyone tell her what to wear while working out and shared her response in a video, The Sun reported.
The influencer showed her reaction âwhen the lady at the gym thinks my top is too revealing.â
âI hate when b***hes be like âhumble yourself.â B***h, Iâm not humbling to make you feel good about yourself,â Beba said.
S
he continued: âUp your game, b***h. You feel insecure around me, you feel like less than? Thatâs your problem.
âThat sounds like your own personal issues you need to talk about with your therapist, b***h,â the content creator said.

The content creator showed off her impressive physique in the stylish outfit.
Her toned midriff and sculpted abs were clearly visible as she clapped back at her hater.

Another follower said: âMe yesterday in my Fenty sports bra with the girlies sitting pretty.â
âAnd thatâs on PERIODT,â commented a third person who related to body shaming.
This article originally appeared on The Sun and was reproduced with permission

chat_gpt_summary: Dr. Gerry Curatola, a dentist and founder of Rejuvenation Dentistry, cautions against four dental practices that can negatively impact dental health. He discourages the use of mouthwash, stating that it may contain preservatives harmful to the mouth's microbiome. Curatola criticizes root canals, citing risks and the presence of dead tissue. He warns that charcoal toothpaste can be abrasive and erode tooth enamel. Furthermore, he advises against metal fillings due to the potential release of mercury vapor and suggests alternative options like ceramic, porcelain, or resin fillings.
article:
A dentist has revealed the four mistakes people make that wreak havoc on their smiles â and they have nothing to do with nightmarish TikTok challenges.
Dr. Gerry Curatola, who founded New York-based Rejuvenation Dentistry, is advising against some commonplace dental practices â such as brushing with charcoal toothpaste and undergoing root canals.
Heâs even condemned a common product sold at supermarkets.
Mouthwash
Put down the Listerine, the enamel expert argues.
âMouthwash has absolutely no value in oral care,â he cautioned to the Daily Mail in an interview published Saturday. âItâs another man-made creation by the consumer products industry.â
Despite guidance that certain mouthwashes can keep bacteria, plaque, tooth decay and gingivitis at bay, Curatola insists they could cause harm.
He claims some mouthwashes contain preservatives, such as parabens, that can destroy the mouthâs microbiome.
âIâm always amazed that dentists are giving people little bottles of mouthwash on their cleaning visit thatâs loaded with alcohol, artificial dyes and colours like that fluorescent blue colour, made from coal tar, which is a known carcinogen,â Curatola said.
According to Healthline, mouthwashes can be harmful if overused.
Experts warn against frequent mouthwash usage due to potential teeth staining from dyes, removal of the healthy microbiome and a potential cancer risk, for which there is limited evidence.
Root canals
Over 41,000 root canals are performed every day in America â but Curatola refuses to be part of that trend.
âItâs the only procedure we do where we keep human dead tissue inside you,â he explained.
The treatment involves removing bacteria and decay from the tooth, disinfecting the area, filling the roots, and sealing them to prevent further decay.
Not only are they painful and, like any procedure, carry risks, but they have also been linked to increased endotoxin levels. However, there is limited research on the phenomenon.
âThese are bacteria and bacterial by-products that can dysregulate your immune system. So theyâre really not healthy for the patient long term,â Curatola said.
Healthline dispelled the purported connection between cancer and root canals, arguing the âmythâ causes unnecessary fear in those who would benefit from the procedure.
Root canal risks include persistent infections, improper seals and inadequate filling, but the greatest risk could be an untreated canal.
Charcoal toothpaste
Activated charcoal has surged in popularity with promises of whitening teeth and providing fresh breath.
But Curatola warns it can be abrasive and even ruin tooth enamel.
âItâs the equivalent of using Ajax on your teeth,â he explained. âIf youâre brushing with it every day, youâre going to wave your enamel away, and your teeth are going to get more sensitive.â
Despite being sold by Colgate and other major dental brands, limited research has suggested that charcoal toothpaste may be too abrasive for everyday use and often does not contain fluoride, the mineral that facilitates a healthy smile.
Metal fillings
While not as widespread anymore, metal fillings were once commonplace in dentistry.
The fillings, also called dental amalgam, are often a mixture of liquid mercury and powdered alloy.
The mercury content in the fillings has the potential to release mercury vapour into the mouth, which could be inhaled by the lungs.
Mercury exposure has been linked to numerous adverse health affects, prompting a 2020 warning against the use of metal fillings in high-risk individuals.
Curatola recommends other options, such as ceramic, porcelain or resin fillings.
This article was originally published by the New York Post and reproduced with permission
headline: Iâm a dentist â youâre ruining your teeth with these four common mistakes

chat_gpt_summary: Australia is planning to implement world-first reforms on vaping, including banning the importation of most vapes, introducing plain packaging, and removing them from convenience store shelves. Health Minister Mark Butler aims to address the behavioral crisis of vaping in schools by cracking down on illegal sales and implementing tougher regulations. Experts warn about the public health risks posed by vaping, particularly among children, who are more likely to take up smoking. The proposed reforms also involve working with states and territories to end vape sales in retail settings and restricting advertising on social media platforms.
article:
Australia is set to ban the importation of most vapes, introduce plain packaging and strip them from convenience store shelves under world-first reforms.
The biggest crackdown on e-cigarettes in Australian history is set to be unveiled in the May budget amid fears vaping has emerged as a serious behavioural crisis in schools across the nation.
Under current laws vapes with nicotine can only be bought with a prescription from a chemist. 
But that hasnât stopped thousands of convenience stores and online providers selling to kids.
Health Minister Mark Butler will unveil the changes on Tuesday under a crackdown that will also involve the states and territories moving to stamp out the growing black market in illegal vaping.
The changes will include tough new laws to:
- Stop the import of non-prescription vapes
- Increase the minimum quality standards for vapes including by restricting flavours, colours, and other ingredients;
- Require pharmaceutical-like packaging;
- Reduce the allowed nicotine concentrations and volumes; and
- Ban all single use, disposable vapes.
But the reforms wonât stop there, with the Albanese Government preparing to work with states and territories to close down the sale of vapes in retail settings, ending vape sales in convenience stores and other retail settings.
Health experts fear the rise of vapes poses a public health crisis with children who vape three times as likely to take up smoking.
