Experts claim thousands of children can no longer sit still in class because they are addicted to vaping after smoking âbubblegumâ flavours that secretly contain nicotine.
Health Minister Mark Butler said it was clear that governments had to act.
âVaping was sold to governments and communities around the world as a therapeutic product to help long-term smokers quit,ââ he said.
âIt was not sold as a recreational product - especially not one for our kids. But that is what it has become: the biggest loophole in Australian history.
âOne in six teenagers aged 14-17 has vaped. One in four people aged 18-24 has vaped. By contrast, only one in 70 people my age has vaped.
âAnd when more than a thousand teenagers aged 15 to 17 were asked where they could get vapes, four out of five of them said they found it easy or somewhat easy to buy them in retail stores.
âThis is a product targeted at our kids, sold alongside lollies and chocolate bars.â
Mr Butler said schools were now struggling to deal with the fallout.
âVaping has become the number one behavioural issue in high schools. And itâs becoming widespread in primary schools,â he said.
âOver the past 12 months, Victoriaâs poisons hotline has taken 50 calls about children under 4 becoming sick from ingesting or using a vape.
âUnder the age of 4! Vapes contain 200 toxic chemicals that do not belong in the lungs, the same chemicals youâll find in nail polish remover and weed killer.
âJust like they did with smoking, Big Tobacco has taken another addictive product, wrapped it in shiny packaging and added flavours to create a new generation of nicotine addicts.
 âVapers are three times as likely to take up smoking, which explains why under 25s are the only cohort in the community currently recording an increase in smoking rates.
âThis must end.â
Vape police could be rolled out to monitor the sale of e-cigarettes to children across Australia including on TikTok, Snapchat and Instagram under a plan that will ban most imports and introduce plain packaging.
VicHealth CEO Sandro Demaio, a globally-renowned public health expert and medical doctor, told news.com.au that as soon as the Albanese Government introduced new import bans enforcement could be much tougher at a state level.
âIn many ways this explosion of vaping has really come out of nowhere over just a couple of years,ââ he said.
âBut the reverse is also possible if we ban the advertising of vapes and actually clamp down on the use of social media to promote these products.
âIf we make them less alluring, so they donât they donât come in Froot Loops flavour and look like a highlighter. They donât have unicorns on the side. That will make them far less appealing.
âAnd basically cut off the tap at the border. Those things will absolutely make a huge difference.â
Dr Demaio said that introducing plain packaging was important because that would then allow enforcement to swing into action.
âObviously, we want to close the access and the huge amount of vapes that have been finding their way into the hands of particularly young people,ââ he said.
âSo what needs to happen at the state level is that there needs to be a licensing scheme in every state.
âThe licences themselves would create revenue, which can support enforcement officers, so weâre not relying on police to enforce the measures that we currently have.
âIn theory, theyâre not currently subject to the laws because they donât contain nicotine. But the vast majority do contain nicotine; theyâre just simply not putting in all the packets.
âAnd really, what needs to be done is to say, âWell, if thereâs no flavours, no colours and the only pathway through a prescription, and they, they, they have pharmaceutical packaging, it then makes it much easier for the states to actually enforce it.â
He warned children were being âviciouslyâ exploited.
âWell, whatâs happened over the last few years is that the tobacco industry and the e-cigarette industry, of which thereâs huge overlap, has seen an opportunity to, you know, get another entire generation of Australians addicted to nicotine with a new product. Thatâs flown under the radar,ââ he said.
âThis industry has used young peopleâs social media. These things are all over social media. You can jump on Tik Tok and there are ads for E cigarettes with a âBuy Nowâ button.
âSocial media is under-regulated in this country. They have flooded the market with really cheap imports from overseas that donât declare that they contain nicotine.
âAnd itâs been a combination of social media, weaponising their data on social media and flooding the market with really cheap and highly addictive imports.â
headline: Australian Government announces crackdown on illegal black market vapes

chat_gpt_summary: Missouri Republican senator Josh Hawley criticizes social media influencer Andrew Tate for promoting toxic masculinity and mistreating women in his new book. Hawley compares Tate's behavior to that of a child pretending to be a man. While Hawley's mention of "a locker room" could be seen as a reference to former President Donald Trump, he avoids mentioning Trump in the book. Hawley has been viewed as a potential contender for the Republican nomination in 2024 but denies rumors of being Trump's running mate. The senator's book discusses the negative influence of pornography on American men but does not address Trump's controversial history with women.
article: In his new book, the Missouri Republican senator Josh Hawley derides Andrew Tate, a social media influencer and self-proclaimed âking of toxic masculinityâ, for âsleeping with as many women as possible, berating them, abusing them and celebrating it all as manly, as âfreedomââ. Criticising Tate for âfake bravadoâ and âendless boastingâ, Hawley adds: âEvery man who has been in a locker room recognises the type â¦ those arenât the words of a man; those are the words of a child pretending to be a man.â The senatorâs evocation of âa locker roomâ could be an allusion to Donald Trump, who as Republican candidate for president in 2016 memorably dismissed as âlocker room talkâ the Access Hollywood tape, hot-mic audio in which he described kissing and grabbing women â even by the genitals â without their consent. But it isnât. Hawley does not mention Trump even once in his new book, Manhood: The Masculine Virtues America Needs. The book will be published in the US next week. The Guardian obtained a copy. The Guardian contacted Hawley for comment, asking if his criticism of Tate could and should be applied to Trump, the frontrunner for the Republican presidential nomination. No reply was forthcoming. Tate was arrested in Romania in December, on charges of organised crime, rape and human trafficking. Hawley has been viewed as a possible contender for the Republican nomination in 2024 but has said he will not run. He has also dismissed rumours that Trump, who enjoys clear leads in polling despite deepening legal jeopardy on a number of fronts, would pick him as his running mate. âNobody wants to be vice-president,â Hawley said. But Hawley has also said, in what the Washington Post said was close to an endorsement: âTrump is going to be the nominee, I think itâs inevitable. After what Alvin Bragg did, I think that Donald Trump is absolutely going to be the nominee, and yeah, Iâll support him.â Alvin Bragg is the Manhattan district attorney who last month charged Trump with 34 felony counts related to his hush money payment to Stormy Daniels, a porn star, regarding her claims of a sexual affair. Trump denies the affair but spent $130,000 to quieten Daniels shortly before the 2016 election. In his new book, in which Trump is conspicuous by his absence, Hawley dwells at length on pornography and its deleterious influence over modern American men. Trump has been married three times, has frequently bragged about his sexual conquests and has seen his infidelity widely documented by tabloid media. In 2019, Barry Levine and Monique el-Faizy published a book on the subject, All the Presidentâs Women. More than 20 women have accused Trump of sexual misconduct or assault. He denies all wrongdoing but one civil case is now at trial in New York. E Jean Carroll, a former magazine columnist, alleges that Trump raped her in a New York department store changing room in the mid-1990s. In video of Trumpâs deposition released to the public last week, Trump was asked about the Access Hollywood tape and his claim to be able to grab women âby the pussyâ because, as a star, he could âdo anythingâ. Trump said: âWell historically, thatâs true with stars.â He was asked: âItâs true you can grab them by the pussy?â He said: âWell, if you look over the last million years, I guess thatâs been largely true. Not always, but largely true. Unfortunately or fortunately.â âYou consider yourself a star?â âI think you can say that, yeah.â Trump was also asked if he had seen other women while married to his first wife, Ivana Trump. He answered: âI donât know.â Trumpâs affair with Marla Maples, who eventually became his second wife and to whom he was married at the time of the alleged attack on Carroll, was a tabloid staple in the 1980s. One famous New York tabloid headline, engineered by Trump, saw Maples proclaim him the provider of the âBest Sex Iâve Ever Hadâ. In his new book about Manhood, writing about Andrew Tate, Hawley condemns an âidea of success [that] apparently involved sleeping with as many women as possible, berating them, abusing them and celebrating it all as manly, as âfreedomââ. The senator, who has said he will support Trump for president, adds: âEvery man who has been in a locker room recognises the type. The fake bravado, the endless boasting. âThose arenât the words of a man; those are the words of a child pretending to be a man he thinks someone will like or respect.â
headline: Josh Hawley book ridicules TikTok misogynist Andrew Tate â but is silent on Trump

chat_gpt_summary: Staffordshire ceramic dog statues, once a common sight on Victorian mantelpieces, are experiencing a resurgence in popularity, particularly among a new generation. Vintage marketplace Vinterior has reported a 115% increase in searches for these statues compared to the previous year. The dogs sold out quickly at a recent pop-up store, indicating the growing demand. The appeal lies in their kitschy and whimsical appearance, appealing to both collectors and younger generations looking to add humor and character to their homes. The trend has caused prices to rise, and buyers are advised to look for distinctive features that distinguish high-quality pieces.
article: Pairs of Staffordshire ceramic dogs, once commonplace on Victorian mantelpieces, are having a sudden resurgence with a boom in demand from a new generation. The vintage marketplace Vinterior reports that searches for Staffordshire dog statues is up 115% year-on-year. When Vinterior launched a recent pop-up store in Londonâs Selfridges, it was the dogs not the Danish dining chairs that were the first items to sell out. The antiques specialist, John Howard, is somewhat surprised but thrilled to see the Victoriana look back in vogue. âThe market changed significantly around 10 years ago with the end of the Laura Ashley era. But now we are seeing demand for more kitsch pieces again. Itâs a bit of a cool in-joke to have a pair,â he said. The original inspiration for the ceramic animals is said to have been Queen Victoriaâs beloved Kings Charles spaniel Dash. Howard says the best quality Staffordshire dog statues were made by small potteries in Staffordshire from 1845 to 1870. Fashioned from press-moulded earthenware, they were hand-painted and many were given glass eyes. From the 1900s onwards they were mass-produced and the quality dropped. However, they are not necessarily âfakeâ: many were made using original moulds, but the detailing is more blurred. Lucy Ward, Vinteriorâs brand director, said there were two distinct groups buying the dogs â collectors with a long-term passion and the younger Instagram and TikTok generation. She explains the latter love the dogsâ playful and whimsical appearance and want to inject a touch of humour to their homes. The architect and interior designer Ben Pentreath falls into the former camp. He bought his first pair more than 15 years ago from a junk shop in Dorchester. They sit proudly on his mantelpiece at home in Dorset, while eight other pairs and six singles are peppered around the house. Until recently, the standard hallmarks of a millennial home have veered towards the minimal. Think grey walls, a potted fiddle-leaf fig and the ultimate influencer signifier â a bum/boob-shaped vase. The Wall Street Journal described it as âa colourless existenceâ. But maybe now Scandi is out, chintz is in. Describing the four-legged knick-knackâs comeback as âcyclicalâ, Pentreath said: âEveryone went mad for them in the late 60s and early 70s, when the whole world went into full on Victoriana-mode. That all went into the bin in the 80s and 90s along with Morris & Co fabrics and seagrass carpets. Just for now, all that is back in taste.â He compares it to the 1970s when âeveryone freaked out about imminent global collapse. Nothing is more reassuring than a pair of dogs smiling at you happily from your mantlepiece as if to say it will all be OK in the end.â This naff-to-nostalgic trend is having a knock-on effect on prices. Howard says that before, a standard pair dating from the 1880s could easily be picked up for Â£120. Listings online now average about Â£400. Pentreath said he had also come across more fakes with âno air holes in the base, and not quite authentic weathering, chips and dingsâ. When it comes to choosing between different genuine versions, Howard said, âthe better ones have certain features that distinguish them from the mundaneâ. He suggested searching for âa front leg that is separately moulded, a curly tail and a defined nose with some George Michael-esque stubbleâ. One of his customers, a former rock star, has more than 300 pairs but only buys pairs with pink noses. âI always say look at the face. Itâs like looking at a bloke. Pick one you like. Youâre going to be staring at it for a long time.â
headline: Staffordshire dog statues back in vogue with TikTok generation

chat_gpt_summary: A court trial has revealed that two men died in a car crash orchestrated as part of a murder plot to silence one of the victims from exposing his affair with a married woman. Saqib Hussain and Mohammed Hashim Ijazuddin were pursued by two vehicles at high speeds before their car hit a tree and burst into flames. Prosecutors presented WhatsApp messages suggesting that the woman's daughter, a TikTok influencer, had threatened to harm Hussain. The woman and her daughter, along with six other defendants, are on trial, charged with murder. The defendants deny the charges. The trial is ongoing.
article: Two men died in a fireball when their car was driven off the road in a murder plot devised to silence one of the victims from revealing his affair with a married woman, a court has heard. Saqib Hussain, 21, and childhood friend Mohammed Hashim Ijazuddin, 21, were killed on 11 February 2022 when their car hit a tree as they were being pursued by two vehicles at speeds approaching 100mph. One of the vehicles contained Ansreen Bukhari, 45, who had had an on-off affair with Hussain for about three years and recently decided to call it off, jurors were told. WhatsApp messages show her daughter, 23-year-old TikTok influencer Mahek Bukhari, known as Maya, told her mother: âIâll get him jumped by guys, and he wonât know what day it is.â Prosecutor Collingwood Thompson KC said Hussain âcould not acceptâ the elder Bukhariâs decision and had started to blackmail her, threatening to tell her husband and sons about their relationship, and publish sexually explicit videos and photographs. The mother and daughter, from Stoke-on-Trent, are on trial with six other defendants accused of luring Hussain and his friend to a Tesco car park on the outskirts of Leicester before pursuing them at speed and ramming their car off the road. The couple are charged with murder alongside Natasha Akhtar, 22, Raees Jamal, 22, Rekan Karwan, 28, Mohammed Patel, 20, Sanaf Gulammustafa, 22, and Ammeer Jamal, 27. All eight defendants deny two counts of murder and an alternative charge of manslaughter. At the prosecution opening at Leicester crown court on Monday, jurors were played the 999 call Hussain made shortly before his crash, where he could be heard saying: âIâm being followed by two vehicles. Theyâre trying to block me in. âTheyâve got balaclavas on. Theyâre trying to ram me off the road. Theyâre trying to kill me. Iâm going to die.â Their vehicle split in two and was consumed in a fireball when it hit a tree on the A46 outside Leicester, and it was this 999 call which alerted police to the fact it was ânot a tragic accident,â Thompson said. âTheir investigation revealed a story of love, obsession, extortion and ultimately cold-blooded murder,â he added. Thompson said Hussain, from Banbury, Oxfordshire, had told a number of friends about his relationship with Bukhari and said that he loved her, although the pair would often get into arguments and stop communicating for periods of time. When she ended the relationship in January 2022, Hussain became âincreasingly obsessive, professing his love for her and begging her to continue the relationship,â Thompson said. The court heard how he began blackmailing her with sexually explicit photos and videos, and demanding back the Â£3,000 he claimed he had spent on her over the course of the relationship, but Bukhari was reluctant to call the police fearing it would lead to her husband finding out about the affair. âHad she done that we would not be in this court trying allegations of murder,â Thompson said. Instead she confided in her daughter, Marek, who at the time had about 230,000 followers on TikTok. The prosecution claimed she was essential in recruiting Karwan and the other defendants who caused the crash. Thompson said they âset a trapâ for Hussain where they planned to seize his phone containing the incriminating photos and videos. âBut even doing that he could send a message to Ansreen Bukhariâs husband, which would ruin Ansreenâs marriage and damage her reputation. Further, Mahek Bukhari was an influencer on social media and the revelation of that affair might even have caused damage to her standing,â Thompson told the court. The trial continues.
headline: TikTok influencer Mahek Bukhari in court over alleged murder plot

chat_gpt_summary: TikTok is reportedly profiting from the sale of illegal and potentially hazardous beauty products, including counterfeit cosmetics and prescription-only skin creams. Despite claiming a "zero tolerance" approach to rogue sellers, counterfeit versions of popular brands such as Dior, Vaseline, and Maybelline are being promoted on TikTok's in-app marketplace. Products containing banned ingredients and prescription-only medications are openly advertised as well. Analysis indicates that TikTok's rules on prohibited items are not effectively enforced, with illicit beauty products frequently promoted to users. The prevalence of counterfeits raises concerns about safety and consumer protection.
article: TikTok is profiting from the sale of illegal and potentially dangerous beauty products, including counterfeit cosmetics and prescription-only skin creams, despite claiming to take a âzero toleranceâ approach to rogue sellers. Counterfeit versions of Dior perfumes, Vaseline lip balms and Maybelline mascaras are among products being touted by third-party vendors via TikTokâs in-app marketplace. Skin-whitening lotions containing banned ingredients and potent acne creams that should only be supplied with a prescription were also being openly advertised last week. The products are being sold via TikTok Shop, an in-app shopping feature which allows users to buy products they see promoted by influencers and brands. There is also a âshopâ tab where users can browse products, from cosmetics and clothing to toilet rolls and sports drinks. Since launching in 2021, the feature has helped turn TikTok into a destination for online retail, with a recent poll by market research firm Savanta finding that UK respondents under 26 used it to make 19 purchases per year â more than through Instagram or Facebook. TikTok, which takes 5% commission on sales, says it has strict rules on what can be sold via TikTok Shop, including prohibiting âthe advertising and saleâ of all counterfeit products. It also bans the sale of prescription-only medicines, such as the acne skin cream, and of skin-whitening creams that contain banned ingredients. âBy ensuring the safety and authenticity of products sold on our platform, we create a positive shopping experience that users can have confidence in,â the policy adds. But analysis suggests the rules are not being effectively enforced, with illicit beauty products routinely being promoted to users via their content feeds and search results. Last week, nine out of the first 12 results shown to people searching âperfumeâ in the TikTok Shop section of the app appeared to be counterfeit. The products included variations of Diorâs Sauvage perfume, with names such as âSuaveâ and âSavageâ, and a copy of Viktor and Rolfâs Flowerbomb perfume, which looks the same at first glance but was actually called âMark and Victorâ. Searches for mascara and other makeup items also led to recommendations for products that appeared to be fake. In some cases, the items remained live on the marketplace even when they were explicitly labelled as âdupesâ. The prevalence of counterfeits has led to warnings from some TikTok Shop customers. A UK-based woman who bought a Â£25 beauty gift bag said she was âfumingâ after being sent a single lip gloss that was clearly a counterfeit. âBe careful who you order from on TikTok Shop,â she said in a video. âPlease check your sellers because thereâs so many fakes going around. Itâs not worth the loss of money. I canât even get hold of the company and funnily enough theyâve now got nothing on their shop.â Another TikTok Shop customer said she was sent a poor-quality perfume that âliterally smells like nail varnishâ after ordering from what she thought was a reputable seller on TikTok. She messaged the seller to ask for a refund but was told that because the item had been opened it couldnât be returned. In a video for followers she added: âIf you are going to buy this perfume please check out the shops youâre buying it from and avoid these guys. I lost out on my money.â Health and consumer experts say the products are unlikely to have undergone safety testing in line with UK standards and contain unknown, potentially toxic ingredients. Many of the illicit products sold via TikTok Shop are made in China and shipped to the UK, according to TikTokâs listings data, with details about their origin and manufacturing processes unknown. Tests of seized counterfeit cosmetics by the Police Intellectual Property Crime Unit have previously found that many contain âtoxic levelsâ of arsenic, mercury and lead. If something goes wrong, customers are left exposed, Gavin Terry, lead officer for intellectual property at the Chartered Trading Standards Institute, said. âIf somebody has a counterfeit product and they put it on their skin and have an allergic reaction, theyâll go to the brand. And thatâs one way these horror stories develop. The brand will say, âThatâs not my productâ. Thereâs no quality control and no guarantee theyâre safe.â Terry added that there had been an increase in the sale of counterfeits on social media in recent years, with endorsements from influencers driving demand. âThe influencers are the soft face of it. Behind that thereâs a criminal organisation. And the social media platform is an intermediary â they create the conduit,â he said. In 2021, a report for the Intellectual Property Office found that the role of influencers was key to affecting consumer purchases of counterfeit products. Of 1,000 women aged 16 to 60 who were surveyed, 13% said they had been prompted by social media endorsements to buy counterfeit products. In addition to the fake products, prescription-only gels containing tretinoin, which is used for the treatment of acne, were available to buy through TikTok Shop last week. Tretinoin can lead to interactions with other medications and cause foetal abnormalities if taken while pregnant so must be used with medical supervision. Dr Jane Ravenscroft, of the British Association of Dermatologists, said the illicit sale of skin creams was a âmajor concernâ and a âpublic health riskâ. âUnfortunately, people selling these prescription products illegally are preying on peopleâs insecurities and naivety. Social media adds fuel to the fire,â she said. TikTok blocked searches for âtretinoinâ and removed listings from third-party vendors that referred to the ingredient after being alerted by the Observer. Selling prescription-only drugs without a prescription is a criminal offence. Listings for skin-whitening creams containing the banned ingredient hydroquinone were also removed. TikTok said it took intellectual property infringement and the illicit sale of medical products seriously, and that those breaking the rules could be banned from the platform. It said it had removed hundreds of products and merchants from TikTok Shop so far this year, including around 50 listings flagged by the Observer. In 2022, it launched an Intellectual Property Protection Centre, a tool it said would help brands identify product listings that breach their IP.
headline: TikTok cashing in on sale of counterfeit cosmetics and prescription skin creams

chat_gpt_summary: According to Internet 2.0, the cybersecurity company that previously exposed TikTok's data collection practices, the social media company has expanded its collection of location information to include altitude data. This new capability could potentially reveal the floor level of a user inside a building. TikTok had previously been criticized for collecting extensive data, including contact lists and calendars, but dismissed the concerns as baseless. Internet 2.0 stated that TikTok has never directly addressed the issues raised in their report, and the director of the company expressed distrust towards TikTok's behavior and lack of transparency. TikTok denied the claim, stating that GPS data is not collected in Australia. The Senate committee hearing on foreign influence on social media is ongoing.
article: The Australian-US cybersecurity company that last year revealed the extent of TikTokâs data collection says the social media company has increased what location information it collects to include altitude, which could tell it what floor of a building a user is on. Last year Internet 2.0 released a study on the data TikTok attempts to collect on user devices, which includes contact lists and calendars, and its scanning of hard drives and geolocating devices on an hourly basis. At the time TikTok described the report as âbaselessâ and said it was no different to the data other social media apps seek. After the report a number of western countries, including Australia, banned the app from government-issued devices amid fears about whether the Chinese government could access data under national security law. The director of Internet 2.0, David Robinson, on Thursday told a Senate committee hearing on foreign influence on social media that TikTok had never directly addressed the issues his firm had raised in the report. Sign up for Guardian Australiaâs free morning and afternoon email newsletters for your daily news roundup â[TikTok] have never come back to us and argued the points about the data and their source code,â he said. âSo itâs their word against the source code. âTheyâve called us names. They said we donât understand what the code is. But theyâve never come back and qualified or quantify their position.â He said the company had undertaken another analysis of the updated source code and discovered that in addition to latitude and longitude data from a userâs device, the app was now seeking altitude information. âSo if youâre in a high-rise building, they can tell what floor youâre on now,â Robinson said. âAnd that wasnât previously in their code last year.â A spokesperson for TikTok rejected the claim, saying GPS data was not collected in Australia, and only collected overseas where users enabled it. âWe do not collect GPS location data from users in Australia, nor do we seek permission for this,â they said. âTo clarify, in other regions where a user has enabled and grants access to location services, TikTok collects this information based on device GPS data.â The spokesperson said Internet 2.0 admits their analysis is ânot conclusive and doesnât include a detailed source code review, which they admit is the best way to assess data collection practicesâ. âWhatâs been presented are misleading, inconsistent results based on a flawed and biased analysis that lacked any real depth.â Robinson said with other apps where Internet 2.0 had analysed the source code â such as with Telegram and Proton â the companies explained their code or provided more evidence as to what the code does. He said TikTok had never approached it that way. âNo oneâs perfect,â he said. âBut to be honest about it, and go, âYes, weâve had an issue. We didnât know about it, weâre checking it, weâre fixing itâ â thatâs normal behaviour, thatâs trustworthy behaviour, in our opinion. âBut to call us names and basically never, never, never show your code and explain it makes me not trust them.â The hearing continues on Friday.
headline: TikTok data collection could reveal what floor a user is on, cybersecurity firm says

chat_gpt_summary: TikTok may face a ban in the United States unless it divests itself from Chinese ownership, according to Brendan Carr, a commissioner of the US Federal Communications Commission. Concerns over surveillance and national security have prompted calls for a ban, with several countries already prohibiting TikTok's use on government devices. TikTok has taken measures to address these concerns, including moving US user data to domestic servers and allowing scrutiny of its source code. However, Carr insists that only a complete ban or severing ties with China would be acceptable.
article: TikTok will either need to divest itself from Chinese ownership or face a ban in the United States, according to the commissioner of the US federal communications commission, Brendan Carr, who accused the company of âgaslightingâ the public on surveillance concerns. Appearing before the Australian Senate inquiry into foreign influence through social media, the Trump appointee said concern about TikTok in the US was âbroad and deepâ, and crossed party lines. Following the United Kingdom, Australia and other countriesâ ban of the app from government devices, the US is considering a full ban nationally. Legislation enacting a statewide ban was recently passed in Montana. TikTok has attempted to head off any potential ban by moving US user data to third-party servers within the country. It is also allowing its source code to be scrutinised by US tech firm Oracle, which will screen TikTok app updates. Carr told the committee while that was ultimately an issue being handled by the US Treasury department, there was a common view among Democrats and Republicans that the data could not be prevented from being accessed by Chinese government officials under the 2017 national security law. Carr, the most senior Republican member on the FCC, said only an outright ban of the app in the United States or removing all corporate ties to China would be acceptable. âUltimately, I think some sort of â¦ legislation that imposes a ban or a genuine divestiture is the way forward right now,â he said. âThe argument that somehow TikTok is going to stand up to the CCP is belied by their inability to do it at any point in time publicly. For instance, when asked in US media interviews, whether they acknowledge the existence of the Uyghur genocide, their official on TV refused to address it.â Carr said that a Project Texas plan might work for other Chinese companies, but TikTokâs actions to date meant there was no trust for the United States. âWeâve had this years-long approach that strikes me is nothing short of a gaslighting in terms of their misrepresentations,â he said. A spokesperson for TikTok said divestment wouldnât solve the problem if national security is the objective. âA change in ownership would not impose any new restrictions on data flows or access. The best way to address concerns about national security is with the transparent, US-based protection of US user data and systems, with robust third-party monitoring, vetting, and verification, which we are already implementing.â The Australian government has announced no plans beyond the ban of TikTok from government devices, but the Coalition is likely to push the Labor government for more restrictions on the app. The chair of the inquiry and shadow home affairs minister, senator James Paterson, opened the hearing by saying that the inquiry would serve as a starting point on making Australians a harder target for foreign interference. âWe cannot allow foreign authoritarian regimes to have unfettered access to the devices of millions of Australians and the powerful opportunity that offers them to influence our democracy,â he said. âThe work starts today to make us a harder target against the threat of cyber enabled foreign interference.â TikTok this week issued a factcheck on claims made about the app, and denied that Australian user data could be accessed in China. The inquiry is holding initial hearings on Thursday and Friday, and is due to report back to parliament in August.
headline: TikTok must divest itself of Chinese ownership or face ban, FCC commissioner tells Australian inquiry

chat_gpt_summary: TikTok Australia published a factcheck in response to concerns over Chinese ownership, its headquarters, content manipulation, censorship, and data sharing. The factcheck downplayed Chinese ownership by stating that only 20% of its parent company, ByteDance, is owned by its founder, ignoring other significant Chinese ownership. It claimed not to be headquartered in China, despite previous statements referring to ByteDance as a "Chinese-headquartered" company. TikTok denied content manipulation and censorship allegations, but leaked documents revealed censorship instructions. While TikTok claimed user data is protected under local laws, a Department of Homeland Security report suggests Chinese laws could still apply. The factcheck acknowledged that data collection practices are not unique to TikTok, potentially undermining the effectiveness of government bans on the app.
article: The Chinese social media app TikTok has been under fire recently. The Australian government announced a ban of the app on government-owned devices earlier this month. The ban has been implemented at a government level in other western countries including the US, the UK, New Zealand, Canada and France. On Monday, TikTok Australia published a self-described factcheck, titled The Truth About TikTok: Separating Fact from Fiction, on TikTokâs site and on LinkedIn. However, the report, Myth vs fact, did not tell the full story. We decided to take a close look at some of the companyâs claims. On Chinese ownership The factcheck labels it a âmythâ that âTikTokâs parent company, ByteDance Ltd, is Chinese ownedâ. In an attempt to downplay Chinese ownership, it says roughly 60% of its parent company, ByteDance, is owned by global institutional investors. The remainder is made up of employees across the globe (20%), as well as the companyâs founder (20%), who TikTok describes as âa private individual and not part of any state or government entityâ. Sign up for Guardian Australiaâs free morning and afternoon email newsletters for your daily news roundup But this confirms that at least 20% and likely much more of the company is, in fact, Chinese-owned. A submission to Australiaâs parliamentary inquiry on foreign influence through social media claimed that the companyâs founder, Zhang Yiming, âhas links to provincial united front organisations in Fujianâ. The CCPâs united front is a Chinese government organisation that works to advance the partyâs interests â particularly abroad. TikTok has dismissed the research paper that formed the basis of the submission. On being headquartered in China The factcheck also labelled it a âmythâ that âTikTok and ByteDance are headquartered in Chinaâ, saying âByteDance does not have a single global headquartersâ. ByteDance is incorporated in the Cayman Islands, but in the companyâs appeal against the US official divestment order in 2020, ByteDance repeatedly described itself as a âChinese-headquarteredâ company. The âmanipulationâ of content TikTok claims it does not â[manipulate] content in a way that benefits the Chinese government or harms Australian interestsâ. The factcheck says the company âdoes not permit any government to influence or change its recommendation modelâ and that users can âfind a variety of content and views expressed about certain political issues or events, including those which are critical of the Chinese governmentâ. It is difficult to verify these claims because the TikTok algorithm that governs what users see on their âFor Youâ page is secret. After the TikTok chief executive, Shou Zi Chew, appeared before US Congress earlier this year some users reported they began seeing pro-Chew videos in their feed, but TikTok denied the suggestion it was deliberating serving users pro-TikTok content and others said it was more likely a result of the appâs algorithm responding to users having pro-TikTok feelings. On censorship The company claimed it does not censor âTikTok content on behalf of the CCP or Chinese governmentâ. But leaked moderator documents obtained in 2019 by the Guardian revealed TikTok had instructed its moderators to censor videos that mention Tiananmen Square, Tibetan independence, or the banned religious group Falun Gong. TikTok argued at the time that the documents were outdated. National intelligence law TikTok labelled it a âmythâ that âunder its 2017 National Intelligence law, the Chinese government can compel ByteDance to share Australian TikTok user dataâ. TikTok claims that Australian TikTok user data is stored in Singapore, Malaysia and the US, and is âsubject to local lawsâ, arguing this would protect the China law being applied outside China. However, a Department of Homeland Security report argues the law can be applied to data held domestically in China or abroad. Data collection At least one of the claims in TikTokâs factcheck is well supported by the available evidence: that the app itself is ânot unique in the amount of information it collectsâ. Social media companies of all stripes collect and share user data, a practice they defend as typical across the industry. As Guardian Australia reported last week, the ban on government employees downloading the TikTok app to their work devices may be rendered ineffective due to these data-sharing practices.
headline: TikTok Australia has launched a factcheck on itself. But does it tell the full story?

chat_gpt_summary: The rise of TikTok's food content, characterized by bizarre and outrageous recipe hacks, has garnered attention and controversy. From ironed toasties to Doritos-filled tacos, creators on the platform experiment with unconventional food combinations that often elicit strong reactions. While some creators intentionally provoke viewers for attention and engagement, others embrace the shock value to entertain and amuse. With views and shares driving monetization opportunities, these viral food videos offer a mix of fascination, disgust, and even possible fetishistic appeal. However, amidst the chaos, there is still a place for more traditional and practical recipes on TikTok, albeit often overshadowed by the attention-grabbing content.
article: I have just ironed my husband a toasted sandwich like some kind of tradwife and to be honest, Iâm disappointed with his reaction. Admittedly, there were a few issues. The steam didnât help, plus I wrapped it in too much tinfoil, so the heat couldnât penetrate. The main problem, though, was that holding an iron meant I automatically started ironing the package, pressing hard and going to and fro industriously. The result is flat, very flat. âWe have a sandwich toaster,â my husband points out, holding the crepe-thin delicacy between finger and thumb. He should be thrilled: this is the closest Iâve come to cooking for him in months. He tries it, reluctantly. âItâs very soft. Did you put mustard in it?â âI thought it would help,â I say. âIt doesnât.â Unless you are a particularly online person, you are probably asking why, at this point. Itâs a question I have asked myself repeatedly, in a rising pitch of incredulity and distress as I dived deep into TikTok food â or FoodTok, if you will. Because that is where the ironed toastie comes from: itâs part of a new generation of TikTok recipe hacks that embody a provocative, frankly deranged âwhy not?â philosophy. Weâve come a long, wrong way since 2021âs viral feta pasta. Now, in addition to ironed toasties, you can enjoy a beatifically smiling blonde putting dried pasta in a blender to create an approximation of flour, then adding an egg to create a sort of dough. She then fashions lumpy, fat noodles, which she boils, tops with tomato sauce and declares âexactly like fresh pastaâ. Comments include the likes of âYOU VIOLATED THE PASTAâ, âMaâam, blink twice if someone is holding you hostageâ and many irate Italians. But that is not even as bad as the unholy tacos made by boiling beef, eggs and cheese in a bag of Doritos. Thereâs a whole genre of sponsored-by-diabetes content, where beautiful, young, slim women combine terrifying quantities of marshmallows, sweets, chocolate, butter, cereal, preprepared cookie dough and the like into âincredibleâ desserts that should be illegal. Many videos are titled: âWhy am I just finding out about â¦â to which the answer is surely: âBecause it should be on trial at The Hague.â You can watch people boil up crisps to make mashed potato, or dump uncooked dried pasta in the oven covered in a house-brick sized portion of cream cheese and a jar of sauce. Dry packet ramen oven-baked in tomato sauce and cheese is called âpizzaâ (I worry for Italyâs collective blood pressure). How about marinading chicken in the sink, or massaging mountains of mac and cheese on a worktop? âEverybodyâs so creative!â TikToker @Tanaradoublechocolate, who seeks out culinary atrocities to comment upon, says. At the risk of sounding like Grampa Simpson yelling at clouds â which is exactly how I feel exploring FoodTok â what is going on? âThereâs a long and storied history of gross-out food on social media,â says Chris Stokel-Walker, social media expert and the author of TikTok Boom. Twisted, the social media food brand that just announced a collaboration with Iceland, started out in 2016 and dared us to make the likes of deep-fried barbecue chicken-stuffed pizzadilla. Now, says Stokel-Walker, âItâs been supercharged by the arrival of TikTok.â The app is designed and engineered to âcapture peopleâs attention as they are scrolling through that endless feed of contentâ and one good way to do it is precisely âthe outlandish, the gross-outâ. It is a notion echoed by Jonah Berger, professor at the Wharton school in Pennsylvania and bestselling author of Contagious, a study of social transmission and virality, who notes that these videos combine surprise and often disgust. âThe more surprising something is, the more likely we are to share it with others. And disgust is a high arousal emotion that also causes us to pass things on.â So is this content engineered to provoke? Some of it, definitely. âI never work to appear genuine,â says Eli Betchik of @elis_kitchen, the self-proclaimed âmost evil chef on TikTokâ. âIf anyone asks, I say: âYeah, I do this for attention.â I think itâs pretty obvious I do.â It is a mark of Betchikâs evil genius that every video of theirs makes me shout âNo!â in genuine anger at some point. Betchik was behind the much-reviled potato crisp mash, and a horrifying sandwich made of blended peas, pineapple, cheese and nuts, with the bread coated with mayo, then fried, among other outrages. Betchik is a fine art jeweller, who started their channel after discovering TikTok at jewellery school. âI thought, I already love experimenting with food and trying new things â I could probably take that a few steps further and use it for some good old-fashioned shock-value entertainment.â Their first video was fried mayonnaise. I make a strangled noise hearing this. âYeah, it was horrible,â confirms Betchik. Another early favourite was meatballs boiled in lime juice âuntil the juice was a thick syrup. Iâm salivating because I can still taste the sourness. It was the most violent flavour Iâve ever had.â Outrage is the point, and, Betchik says, people enjoy feeling it. âObviously, what Iâm doing is to gross people out, but people keep coming back â they wouldnât keep coming back if they didnât get something out of it. I find that sometimes people get happy when theyâre upset in the right way.â On their jewellery TikTok account @eli_metal, Betchik says, a mean comment would take days to digest, but with the food, itâs a mark of success. The one comment they wonât accept is that these horrendous creations are wasteful: impressively, worryingly omnivorous, Betchik finishes almost everything. In addition, âI try to use foods that are close to going bad or things that have been donated to me. And if I canât eat it, I compost all the scraps.â Itâs not clear if this level of diligence is common practice among the creators, but it feels doubtful. Mean commenters on the @myjanebrain TikTok account include a certain Gordon Ramsay, who angrily described a chicken stuffed in a pumpkin, garnished with cinnamon sticks and many onions as âHalloween salmonella right there.â âIt was pretty awesome,â says Jane, a preternaturally cheery 27-year-old Canadian and full-time content creator who prefers not to give her surname, perhaps for fear of reprisals from Italians angered by her ramen âpizzaâ. âBut I know the chicken was fully cooked. It was moist, it had great flavour.â Jane ended up in the realm of what is sometimes called ârage-baitâ cooking accidentally. Her early videos, she says, were straight instructional content, but she pivoted when her fried chicken recipe went viral. âIt got 31m views, 3,000 comments,â says Jane â this is, of course, highly populated TikTok territory, the hashtag #FoodTikTok had accumulated 112bn views by the end of 2022, for example. âI thought it would be positive but it was more like: âYouâre the worst chef Iâve ever seen.â So I realised that I would have no idea what people were going to think of my videos.â She started focusing on finding the âcraziest combinationsâ, including one titled âI learned this hotdog trick in Englandâ, in which she makes jelly from pickle juice, adds frankfurters and eats it in a bread bun. âThat is absolutely not English,â I challenge her hotly, TikTok commenter style. âI canât remember; it was from some sort of British something,â she says. âI was going to ask you why you make pickle juice jelly!â What makes people angriest, though, she says, is her cooking techniques. âAs soon as you cook for the internet you open yourself up to all the critics who are so specific in the way they cook.â Both Jane and Eli are clear that their content is knowingly provocative rather than instructional, whether viewers understand that or not. âA lot of people take this content at face value when you have to remember weâre through the looking-glass on social media, where these things are being deliberately gamed for the benefit of those that create it,â says Stokel-Walker. All attention is good attention, since views and shares â including the genre of angry or incredulous âduetâ videos where other creators (including Ramsay) comment on their depravity â are the point. Thatâs how you make money after all: successful TikTokers can become part of the appâs creator fund and get paid â admittedly pennies â per view. Stokel-Walker says that success can allow creators to pivot to the kind of genuinely lucrative mainstream collaborations that Twisted has managed. There is another possibly upsetting angle: fetish. âVideos where they point a lot and touch things and make super-repulsive stuff are apparently fetish,â a baker friend tells me airily, when I inquire if she uses TikTok recipes. It turns out thereâs a fairly widespread suspicion this is a thing. The messier foods could fulfil a âsploshingâ fetish: getting sexual gratification from food mess. âIâve seen this aired,â says Stokel-Walker. âCertainly, it appeals to your senses. Itâs like a slow-motion car crash in food form, where youâre like, how more disgusting can this get?â TikTok user @lenarae.lh analyses food videos and pronounces them fetish or non-fetish on the basis of how the women â it is almost always women â use their hands, splash or squirt stuff suggestively or massage phallic things. A friend also directs me to the work of a creator called @cedriklorenzen who specialises in whacking pieces of raw meat, dribbling, drizzling and taking his top off. Itâs a better appetite suppressant than Ozempic: after watching, I never want to eat, have sex, or indeed see anything again. There is actually plenty of good, normal food on TikTok. Asking around, people mention recipes for homemade crispy chilli sauce, broccoli pasta, sesame dip and various noodle dishes theyâve tried, then added to their repertoire. Seema Pankhania, a 25-year-old former chef de partie at Gordon Ramsayâs Lucky Cat who posts as @seemagetsbaked, has 1.3 million followers for her eminently achievable, delicious-looking recipes. They are pleasingly lo-fi, especially her pyjama recipes for hungover, no bones days and ultra simple versions of Indian classics â her butter chicken has 1.7m likes (she also recommends her âsuper simple creamy chicken curryâ. But even Pankhania, a proper cook, is aware it is all grist to the gnatâs attention span TikTok mill. She aims to keep videos under a minute long (âthe shorter the better; people are going to get boredâ) and has no illusions that much of the food content is only meant to be consumed with the eyes. âThereâs a whole other field of cooking on TikTok which is indulgent,â she says, giving the example of elaborate lasagnes. âNobody is going to make it, but itâs very nice and satisfying to watch.â Clearly that goes for the bizarre and the gross-out stuff too in some more depraved way. âAt the end of the day, social media is entertainment, right?â says Pankhania. âMost of it is just for entertainment and people arenât actually going to be cooking a lot of it.â Given much of food TikTok isnât meant to be cooked, or is intentionally tongue in cheek, Iâm sure Iâm missing the point entirely as I cram half a packet of spaghetti into my blender. A flimsy thing, it protests loudly with an ominous smell of burning rubber. I whiz up vermicelli instead, dump the âflourâ on the worktop and add an egg, making a claggy mess. I have to add normal flour â surely invalidating the whole madness â to form a dough ball capable of being rolled out. The resultant approximate noodles are dumped in boiling water. I take them out based on vibes alone â TikTok recipes are wildly unspecific â then my family gather to taste and criticise. My husband â whose former student staple of peas and camembert prepared in a kettle would be a runaway TikTok hit â declares it raw. âItâs not terrible,â one son ventures. âItâs not good either,â says the other, correctly. I dare not attempt anything of Betchikâs, and Jane recommends her own recipe for cinnamon buns baked in cream and coffee, topped with sugar, butter and flattened toffees â but I am 48 and my organs will explode if I eat that. My wimpâs version â a vegan bun sliced and covered in oat cream, sugar and cinnamon â comes out of the oven ominously black; my just deserts for messing with the recipe, I suppose. I eat it all anyway â itâs a cinnamon bun and cream, whatâs not to like? â then, exhausted and hyperglycaemic, I close TikTok, hopefully for good. Everybodyâs so creative! I wish they werenât.
headline: The disgusting food of TikTok: is it designed to eat, provoke â or arouse?

chat_gpt_summary: Inflation and rising food prices in the UK have led to a surge in TikTok videos focusing on grocery shopping and budgeting. Users film their supermarket trips, sharing the cost of their groceries and offering money-saving tips. The videos provide a glimpse into the reality of grocery shopping and the impact of rising prices, challenging the notion of average spending figures. TikTok has become a platform for open conversations about the cost of living, offering viewers insight into different shopping strategies. However, TikTok creators note that the platform doesn't provide significant financial benefits for their content.
article: Before Rachel Nixon goes to the supermarket, she sketches a quick shopping list in her head. In the garage she usually has a sack of potatoes, and meat, green veg and bread in the freezer. For the bits in between, she will head either to her local, membership-only brand discounter, the Company Shop in Barnsley, or to a mainstream supermarket such as Aldi. âToday Iâm going with a Â£50 budget to feed five of us â Â£10 a day, Â£2 per person per meal. Iâll go home and look at what Iâve got in the freezer, check the rice, pasta. Itâs make do and mend.â Unlike other shoppers, Nixon has a press pass, because when sheâs filling her basket, she will also be filming a TikTok on her phone, and the Company Shop management requires permission. Her content, which âbegan as a jokeâ, follows her around the aisles, scrutinising produce and bargains against the biggest question at any supermarket in 2023: how can this cost this much? At many mainstream shops, Nixon says: âA Â£50 shop is now an Â£80 shop. People in the middle are floundering around.â Inflation is something everyone has noticed â even Cardi B went online to decry the price of American lettuce â but not everyone feels the impact at the checkout. If you are experiencing the pinch, TikTokâs intuitive âFor Youâ page will be a disjointed research trip to the countryâs supermarkets, trailing behind the trolley in the company of total strangers who share information that used to be a stable and private part of our lives â what we spend on food. âCome shopping with me at Lidl.â âRealistic food haul from Aldi.â âÂ£58 shop at M&S.â âFarmFoods underrated gems.â The scroll goes deep into the massive digital gumbo of TikTok, where the simple act of spending and saving money at the supermarket has dug a deep content stream â in global lifetime counts, #shopwithme has amassed 3.9bn views and #costofliving 1.5bn views, according to figures from TikTok, which is owned by the ByteDance company, headquartered in China. With these shoppers, you watch as they pick out a weekly food shop, formulating a guess for the receipt reveal at the end. Youâll hear a soundtrack of trolley rattles and packaging rustling off the shelves as someone youâll never meet explains theyâre not buying gravy this week (thereâs some in the freezer), and they wonât be picking up bread because theyâre gluten-free and Pete who does eat bread is on a work trip. The receipt reveal has become a grimly unpredictable game, since inflation has been repricing foodstuffs at the fastest rate since 1977 and in lurid proportions, particularly for lower-priced items such as pasta, tea and bread. Of course, as Nixon says: âItâs not just food. The cost of gas, electric, breathing â everything has gone up. When will something give? We all have households to run.â The governmentâs official figures saw food inflation rise to 18.2% in the year to January 2023, based on about 200 items in a representative basket. Other bodies such as the Food Foundation use a different basket of goods, and put food inflation higher. Iâve seen TikTokers joke about taking out a mortgage to buy butter, but generally speaking the social undertow of the videos is far from funny. The unwritten template for the #shopwithme videos is based on honesty: whatâs going in the basket and why, and how much it costs. Honesty, but also disbelief. Jayne, a twentysomething teacher, describes her area of Cambridgeshire as relatively affluent, and with two incomes and no dependents in her household, she and her partner can afford a Â£300 monthly food budget, which they direct mostly to M&S Foodhalls. âM&S is quite small, so I get less distracted. Tesco has clothing, candles, I donât think Iâd be as disciplined. I just stick to my list.â This became the focus of her TikTok account, almost entirely a run of her routine supermarket shops at M&S. âThere isnât a place [like TikTok] where people are sharing such an intimate part of their life. Iâve seen videos on what it costs to run a two-bed household in Wiltshire â thereâs a natural curiosity from people, and if youâre willing to share parts of your life, it takes away from the unrealistic glamour of social media. I canât believe how much people are interested in whatâs going into the basket. I never expected the videos to do well,â says Jayne. This curiosity seems to be a consequence of missing information: though the internet may tell us the average person spends about Â£40 a week on food, that doesnât seem right â or to put it another way, it feels as though the average figure is lying to us. When an industrial park can make neighbours of supermarkets that are miles apart in cost and branding, it begins to seem like there is no point to an average figure, when differences between prices are also cultural distances. âIt costs a bomb to live in London,â says Nishat Tahsin, a biotech/bioengineering doctoral student who joined TikTok during lockdown, and now has more than 200,000 followers. Her content is about cooking imaginatively on a budget (think butter chicken puff pastry pie, or Bangladeshi satni citrus salad), but also organising grocery shopping habits. âI never used to have a food budget, but now itâs more expensive to live I always make a plan at the weekend for what Iâm doing during the week. Loads of students prioritise study, then food later. I look at what I have in the freezer, then the costs that would come with it to make a meal.â At the beginning of each term, she bulk buys starches and bakery goods, adding fresh foods along the way in smaller shops, and heading to Asian or African markets for spices by the kilo. âI can do a weekly shop for under Â£20. A whole chicken for Â£3, go splits with flatmates on potatoes and onions, buy bread, cheese, milk, maybe a bit of nutmeg. But thatâs because I buy essentials every few months.â For the freezer, she flat-packs meat portions and fish fillets, and grates up cheese blocks so high-value protein is never wasted. Tahsin isnât like her friends in this regard â she notes how many students have been buying toilet paper on TikTok (bales of 60 rolls for as little as Â£18), and âtheyâre buying things left, right and centre on TikTok Shop. They donât want to spend the time and money at Asda.â TikTok itself has inverted the surface logic of spontaneous buying on the platform by investing in a campaign around its library of money-saving tips. And brands that approach Tahsin also want a part of the problem. âEvery time I do a brand deal they mention their new USP would be combating the cost of living crisis.â Over time, I noticed a lot of people on TikTok name-checking specific brands, and began to wonder if campaign spend was behind it. M&S Foodhalls, for example, is getting traction on a âthis is surprisingly affordableâ theme on #shopwithme TikTok. The brand confirmed all the content is organic and not paid for, but says it has noticed a âhuge surgeâ of it in recent months. Even an official Waitrose TikTok account gamely had a go at joining the Â£20-a-week family shop trend. The question is, does this help anyone? Dr SinÃ©ad Furey is a lecturer in consumer management and food innovation at Ulster University, focused on food insecurity. âThere is no substitute for food,â she says bluntly. âBut we are still talking about not knowing where the next meal comes from. For every one of us who goes to a food bank, there are nine of us who donât. Stigma, pride, whatever. Food insecurity isnât acute; it is chronic.â For her research, she followed a cohort of 60 shoppers and analysed their supermarket habits. âThereâs a huge reliance on shopping lists to frame or curtail your spend,â she says. âThere is nobody better than those in lower-income households at micromanaging budgets. They know the price of a pint of milk across different stores and they know when the yellow stickers go on. It annoys me that thereâs a presumption that lower-income consumers are bad with their money.â Shona Goudie at the Food Foundation leads the organisationâs Basic Basket programme, which has been tracking food prices based on baskets of goods at Tesco, as developed by Loughborough University and the Joseph Rowntree Foundation for male and female archetypal shoppers. âThe government looks at food price inflation but we donât feel it reflects what people are really buying, or the nutrition factor. We started tracking prices a year ago, and itâs increased 22% in that period.â Mitch Lane is a nuts and bolts salesman who lives near Walsall, in the West Midlands. Like Tahsin, he joined TikTok during lockdown, at the request of his daughter: âShe wanted another follower,â he says. âI was mostly doing the dad dances and press-up challenges. But one day I was cooking up a chilli con carne and [the video] went really well. I started to do âfakeawaysâ â how to make your own Nandoâs, burgers. Simple stuff, one-pan meals.â This developed into a budget-conscious series of cookery ideas, under the moniker âMeals by Mitchâ, with the shopping receipt under Â£5 shown first, and the method to follow. âAs the cost of living developed into an absolute joke, I kept seeing budget meals where people drizzled balsamic vinegar from their pantry. I donât have a pantry. I wanted to do everything for a flat fiver.â Lane has picked up 1.2m followers and a book deal, and he is certain that âthe cost of living has propelled itâ. Other TikTokers who share photogenic techniques for prepping breakfast, lunch and dinner into neat ranks of Tupperware boxes or elongating the lifespan of lemons in jars of fridge water have also enjoyed success. But Lane wants to keep things grounded in reality. âIâve lived on a budget most of my life. Itâs not new to me. If I walked into a supermarket with a fiver, I used to get more. The budget meals are getting harder, whether itâs the price per kilo for veggies or the pasta and dried foods. People are finding it tough.â Fraser Reynolds, a personal trainer based near Stirling, Scotland, started filming calorie-minded food TikToks from his motherâs âtiny council house kitchen â no gadgetsâ. This morphed into a recipe series he describes as âthe poor manâs Joe Wicksâ, with a popular stream of â12 meals for 20 quidâ. However, heâs had to rethink this, âbecause I cannot keep it under the price. In the past three months Iâve struggled putting it together because to keep it under Â£20 Iâm going to give you the main ingredients and assume you have the spices already at home.â Though TikTok is worryingly good at distracting attention with dogs pressing doorbells or Wisconsin grandmothers dispensing life wisdom, it is arguably one of the few sources of a public, open conversation about how far money goes across different sections of society. Not what it looks like, aspirationally, but what it looks like literally, with a weekly shop spread out on the kitchen countertop. âIf people are showing the receipts and what theyâve bought, it definitely helps,â Lane says. âItâs good for people to see that if you write a list and stick to the brief, and are not dashing stuff into the trolley, and you base a shop around it, itâs a guaranteed money saver.â Does being on TikTok as a creator bring anything extra to the table? âTikTok â there ainât really any money in it,â Lane says. âWeâre talking such a minimal amount per view. I get Â£150 a month off it, something like that. You couldnât live off it.â Nixon says she receives, as a ârelative minnowâ with 27,000 followers, about 12p a day from TikTok. Meanwhile, Tahsin has been thinking about âselling seasoning for cheaper than a supermarket on TikTok Shopâ. For her, the platform is a creative and relatively kind place. âI get a lot of diversity in my comments. In the UK our generation is really open to trying anything. I get requests for oxtail Jamaican curry, or Turkish kebabs. A lot of British people will want to know how to make samosas. Itâs nice that people are less critical on TikTok. People will eat anything when theyâre hungry.â â¢ This article was amended on 19 April 2023. An earlier version suggested Walsall was in Birmingham. While it is close to that city, Walsall is a separate town and borough in the West Midlands.
headline: Supermarket sweep: how TikTok can help you save money on your food shopping

chat_gpt_summary: Labor senator Helen Polley has garnered attention for her unconventional method of cooking hardboiled eggs. In a TikTok video, she demonstrated wrapping a raw egg in aluminum foil, submerging it in water, and microwaving it for six to seven minutes. While putting metal objects in microwaves is generally discouraged, Polley's technique works because metals reflect most of the microwaves away from their surface. The water surrounding the egg-in-foil acts as insulation and aids in cooking the egg. However, there is a risk of explosions when heating whole eggs in microwaves, so caution is advised. A safer alternative is cracking the egg and poaching it in water.
article: Labor senator Helen Polley has raised eyebrows with an unusual technique for cooking hardboiled eggs. In an âegg hackâ video posted to TikTok, the Tasmanian senator completely wrapped a raw egg in aluminium foil, submerged it in a plastic container of water, and said she microwaved it for six to seven minutes for a hard boil. âEvery time Iâm cooking them in my Canberra office â¦ everyoneâs just really taken aback, saying: you canât put foil into the microwave!â Polley told Guardian Australia. âThis is something Iâve been doing for probably 25 years, if not longer, and Iâve never had a mishap. âI didnât perfect this,â the senator added. âIt was my mother-in-law who demonstrated it to me many years ago.â Polleyâs technique runs counter to general wisdom to avoid putting metal objects into microwaves. So how has the senator managed to avoid setting off fire alarms in Parliament House? Metal heads Microwaves are a frequency of electromagnetic radiation that work primarily by heating up the water molecules in food. Metals, on the other hand, absorb much less of this radiation, and tend to reflect most of the microwaves away from their surface. Itâs why microwave ovens are entirely lined with metal, with a thin metal mesh embedded in their front doors. Sign up for Guardian Australiaâs free morning and afternoon email newsletters for your daily news roundup Technically, a microwave oven is an example of whatâs known as a Faraday cage, according to Prof Zdenka Kuncic, a physicist at the University of Sydney. âItâs preventing the electromagnetic radiation from seeping outside.â Exposing a metal object to microwave radiation will mean the metal absorbs some of it, but can also lead to electrostatic sparks, particularly if the metal is thin, pointed, or has sharp corners, as in the case of crumpled aluminium foil. âYou really only need a very thin layer of metal to cause sparks,â Kuncic said. âGenerally speaking, even if you had really thick metal, the absorption and the sparking would really only affect â¦ the outermost layer.â US guidelines suggest aluminium foil can be used in the microwave in certain circumstances, such as using small pieces of smooth foil to âshieldâ parts of food so they donât overheat. Kuncic said in Polleyâs case, the water surrounding the egg-in-foil served two purposes. âOne is to insulate the electrical sparks from the foil â to prevent them from flying around. The second thing is to actually help cook the egg, which would otherwise not really cook because itâs got foil around it.â âMicrowaves work by jiggling around the all the water molecules. When youâve got a little tub of water in there, itâs heating up the water,â she said. âThe egg would be to some extent insulated by the foil directly from the microwaves, [but] the water surrounding it will heat up and that heat can get transferred through the foil into the egg to cook it.â Dr Nathan Kilah, a senior lecturer in chemistry at the University of Tasmania agreed: âThe water there is basically preventing the aluminium from arcing [sparking] in a way that it normally would.â Eggsplosion risk In 2019, a contributor to a Woolworths community site detailed the same technique as Polleyâs, but one of the respondents, who did not submerge the egg in water, warned: âLast year I blew up my new $600 microwave doing this.â Foil aside, whole eggs with shells are prone to explosion when cooked or heated in the microwave. One case report published in the British Medical Journal, titled âPenetrating ocular trauma from an exploding microwaved eggâ, details the plight of a nine-year-old girl who reheated an already boiled egg with an intact shell âat full power for about 40 secondsâ. âThe heated egg was removed from the microwave oven and placed in a bowl. Around 30 seconds later, as she was carrying it to the dining area, the egg exploded with part of it hitting her right eye and face,â the report noted, going on to detail the eye surgery she subsequently required. Kilah explained: âThe water in the egg turns to steam, and â¦ it canât escape from the shell, which leads to it exploding. The air space in the egg would also expand with the heat. âAdding an egg directly to boiling water can make it crack â so the air is expanding against the shell, but itâs not so dramatic, as the internal egg temperature doesnât warm up as quickly.â A safer option for those who are insistent upon cooking their eggs in the microwave would be to crack the egg first and poach it in water.
headline: Cracking method or recipe for disaster? The science behind a Labor senatorâs TikTok microwave egg-in-foil hack

chat_gpt_summary: The ban on TikTok from Australian government devices may be ineffective if public servants and politicians continue to use the app on their personal mobile devices, warns Dr. Katharine Kemp from the University of New South Wales. Using personal email addresses to log into apps on both work and personal phones allows data matching, enabling TikTok to access information held on government devices. This issue is not unique to TikTok, as social media companies commonly share data from multiple platforms. To address privacy concerns effectively, a ban on data-matching between apps would be necessary in addition to banning TikTok.
article: TikTok could still access information held on Australian government devices if public servants and politicians continue to use the app on their personal mobile devices, according to a legal academic from the University of New South Wales. Dr Katharine Kemp, who focuses on consumer law and has researched a wide variety of privacy policies for digital apps, said the loophole could limit the effectiveness of the ban on TikTok from government devices. âIf the employee uses their personal email address to log into apps on both their work phone and their personal phone, TikTok and the other company could match data from the two separate phones,â she said. This kind of data sharing is not exclusive to TikTok, and social media companies defend it as typical across the industry. Kemp said through collecting multiple data points related to a device, companies can then uniquely identify that device and track it in what is called âfingerprintingâ. TikTok declined to comment, but the companyâs privacy policy indicates information can be shared from other social media platforms in cases where that account is used to log in to TikTok, as is common practice with Facebook, Twitter, Instagram and Google accounts. Sign up for Guardian Australiaâs free morning and afternoon email newsletters for your daily news roundup Last week the federal attorney general, Mark Dreyfus, announced that federal public servants and politicians with government-issued phones must delete the Chinese-owned app from their devices as soon as possible, and would not be permitted to install it except in limited circumstances. In announcing the ban, the government stated TikTok âposes significant security and privacy risks to non-corporate commonwealth entities arising from extensive collection of user data and exposure to extrajudicial directions from a foreign government that conflict with Australian lawâ. Last week the government faced criticism from the Greens for focusing on TikTok alone rather than the privacy concerns of all social media apps. Kemp said in order for the TikTok ban to be effective, the government would also need to ban data-matching between the apps. âData security and privacy choices canât be addressed by removing an app from a particular device,â she said. âTikTok and other digital platforms donât just collect personal data from a single digital âlocationâ. âThey have collection points all over the place that feed information back to the platform, even when you use different devices for different apps.â A spokesperson for Dreyfus directed Guardian Australia to the department. The department spokesperson did not directly address the issues raised, but said the existing government device ban would âminimise the security and privacy risks posed by the TikTok applicationâ. The opposition spokesperson on cybersecurity, Senator James Paterson, said the government ban was the first step. âRemoving it was important but is not a panacea,â he said. âA comprehensive response which encompasses risks like these and also those posed by other applications is clearly necessary. I hope the Albanese government is doing that work right now.â The move to ban TikTok from government devices followed similar bans in other parts of the world including the UK, Canada, New Zealand and the US. The latter is contemplating a nationwide ban on the app. TikTok this week quietly launched an app for select Android-based TVs in Australia.
headline: TikTok can still access data from Australian government devices via app on personal phones, academic warns
