Shortly before the US Super Bowl this week, Sportsbet published a video ad with a young woman drawing attention to ânovelty betâ markets on Rihannaâs half-time performance. The video ran the âgamble responsiblyâ tag in small print. âGirls group chat going wild because Rihanna is dropping Super Bowl half-time show teasers and Sportsbet has markets on it,â the video caption said as a young woman typed into her phone. The novelty markets allowed people to bet on what outfit Rihanna would wear, what props she would use, how long she would sing for and what colour liquid would be poured on the winning coach after the match. Sign up for Guardian Australiaâs free morning and afternoon email newsletters for your daily news roundup Sportsbet has published other videos featuring the Sydney-based influencer Luisa Dal Din. One video ran the caption âme pretending I know horse racing to impress my crushâ. A spokesperson for TikTok said the ads were only shown to users 21 or older and were closely monitored. Their frequency was also restricted and users could opt out of seeing them. A Sportsbet spokesperson said the ads had been age-restricted to âminimise the risk of exposure to minors while connecting with adult audiences on the platforms they enjoyâ. Toby Ralph, an advertising expert, said Sportsbet was using the TikTok trial to maximise its client base and profits. âThis means finding new markets. [Young women] who couldnât give a shit about the merits of the Chiefs or the Eagles can be induced to pony up cash by connecting to a bet on Rihanna, and suggesting that the tribe they want to join is crazy for it,â Ralph said. âDoes this lead to ethical concerns? No. From an advertising perspective, if itâs legal, they will go all in.â The Alliance for Gambling Reform has expressed concern about regulatory oversight of the trial, despite TikTokâs insistence it is strictly controlled. Late last year the alliance complained about the ads to the Victorian Gambling and Casino Control Commission, alleging a breach of the advertising rules. The complaint was dismissed. âAs Sportsbet is licensed by the Northern Territory gambling regulator, it is suggested that you lodge your complaint with the Northern Territory Racing Commission,â a VGCCC manager said in an email seen by Guardian Australia. An alliance spokesperson said the TikTok trial âopens the floodgatesâ to a demographic of Australians who have not always been exposed to gambling advertisements. âThe sponsored posts have been gender-targeted with young women being told they can now place bets on superficial things like BeReal times, Love Island and White Lotus season three,â an alliance spokesperson said. Dr Simone McCarthy, a gambling researcher at Deakin University, said young women were an untapped market for the gambling industry. âGambling is becoming normalised for women and a lot of this has to do with the marketing they see,â McCarthy said. âOur research shows that young women perceive that gambling advertising has begun to appeal to women and that women are increasingly featured in gambling advertising. âWe saw this with tobacco. When [companies] saturated the male market they started designing products that were appealing to women and this same strategy is now being used with novelty bets.â
headline: Sportsbet is targeting young women on TikTok to diversify male client base, experts say

chat_gpt_summary: Hedi Slimane, the designer for Celine, created a disco-themed fashion show at Paris nightspot Le Palace. The event combined fashion, music, and youth subcultures, drawing in celebrities and club kids. Slimane's rock 'n' roll aesthetic was showcased with leather trousers, daring outfits, and nods to indie and electroclash music. The show celebrated special occasions and community, emphasizing the joy of going out and finding one's tribe. Slimane's approach has been successful for Celine, driving commercial performance and reaching a Û2bn turnover.
article: If itâs fashionable to be immersive, Hedi Slimane is Ã  la mode. His menswear show for Celine involved a takeover of the Paris nightspot Le Palace, where on the opening night back in 1978 Grace Jones had her clothes torn off by the plastered crowd and was covered by Yves Saint Laurent, on hand with a well-placed cummerbund. Downstairs, almost 50 years later, the place was still fabulous and bedecked with sequins. With a fashion show, gig and party, Slimaneâs mission â along with showing the clothes for autumn 2023 â was to create a disco to die for, a playground for the eraâs new club kids. And, of course, they came, clad in dramatic looks â for instance, the experimental musician Yves Tumour, who was resplendent in a blue wig, outrageously embellished black leather jacket and fishnet stockings. Meanwhile, the street outside was closed in anticipation of the arrival of Lisa from Blackpink, K-popâs biggest girl band. Slimaneâs talent is to create a parallel universe in which fashion, music and youth subcultures all come together to create a dazzling whole. On Friday night, first there was a fashion show, then a concert by the Irish band the Murder Capital and the Libertines, and then a party that stretched until 3am, populated by the club kids of Paris who were the nightâs real stars, and some celebrities ranging from Catherine Deneuve to Wiz Khalifa. At the beginning of the show, Pete Doherty caused some consternation by bringing his large dog with him to the front row, but sadly the many TikTokers in attendance were denied their viral moment when the mutt remained well-behaved and was finally led off by a dog handler. In this beguiling other world, Slimaneâs rockânâroll aesthetic reigned supreme. Since the pandemic, the designer has cocked a snook at the fashion week schedules, preferring either to show films instead of catwalk shows, or to stage huge extravaganzas that take in bands and a party. In December in Los Angeles, he staged a show that included performances by the Strokes and Iggy Pop and a runway that posited a return to skinny jeans â a trend that, as the designer of Dior Homme in the early 00s, he pretty much invented. And Slimaneâs instincts have proved lucrative, too â Celine has achieved the â¬2bn turnover that the LVMH boss, Bernard Arnault, set as a target when the Frenchman took over the house in 2018. Slimane had previously applied his rockânâroll aesthetic to Saint Laurent, a tenure that was controversial among some fashion critics but supercharged the labelâs commercial performance. At the Celine show, Slimane was at his most uncompromising. Dozens of pairs of leather trousers were marched down the catwalk, culminating in a shocking pink, diamante-studded two-piece that Khalifa told the Guardian he would be pleased to wear. Aside from that, in classic Slimane styling there was a fake-fur coat worn over a suit jacket, over a vest with a leopardskin scarf. Slimane has dressed rock stars for years, from David Bowie and Mick Jagger to Jack White of the White Stripes, who was also in attendance. If indie sleaze â the revival of the early 00sâ hedonistic looks â was a theme, Slimane was also nodding to electroclash, the early 00s club phenomenon that rebooted 80s synthpop and took its visual cues from Leigh Boweryâs legendary club Taboo. As well as in-your-face fashion, the show also honoured the community that Slimane has built up over more than two decades. Afterwards, the Libertines played, fronted by Doherty, Slimaneâs erstwhile muse when the singer was at the height of his indie rock fame, but who is now, happily, burly and middle-aged. The performance yielded the pleasing spectacle of Khalifa nodding along to the lyrics âthey all get them out for the boys in the bandâ. Slimane has remained unshakeable in his enthusiasm for indie music, despite the fact that in the internet era it has faded as an avatar of youthful rebellion. Nevertheless, the young Parisians in the audience lapped it up, underlining the fact that the whole evening was ultimately a celebration of the simple joy of going out. At its root, Slimaneâs Celine is about the pleasure of special occasions. He is instinctively aware of the meaning of clothes â the frock you wear for your birthday, the shoes that make you feel as if you can take on the world. Displaying such an extreme iteration of this idea â even the tracksuit tops were styled with leather trousers â Slimane paid tribute to the youth of Paris. But ultimately the show was about community in the internet age, the power of togetherness and of finding your impeccably dressed tribe.
headline: Hedi Slimaneâs Celine show revives early 00s hedonism for TikTok age

chat_gpt_summary: The debate over TikTok's security risks and data privacy continues to escalate. The app faces accusations of providing user data to the Chinese government and potentially influencing users in alignment with Chinese foreign policy. While evidence supporting these claims is lacking, concerns persist. Western governments, including the US and several European countries, have taken measures to restrict TikTok's use. TikTok has made efforts to address these concerns, such as establishing data centers in the US and Europe. The controversy surrounding TikTok highlights the need for broader data privacy legislation.
article: The FBI has called it a national security threat. The US government has passed a law forcing officials to delete it from their phones. Texas senator Ted Cruz has denounced it as âa Trojan horse the Chinese Communist party can use to influence what Americans see, hear, and ultimately thinkâ. And in March its CEO will defend its existence before the US Congress. For those unaware of the debate broiling on the other side of the Atlantic, the target of this strong rhetoric might prove surprising: an app best known for viral dances, launching generation Z media stars, and sucking teens down an hours-long content abyss. But the rancorous debate over TikTok that began under the Trump administration has rolled on under President Biden. In addition to a ban of the app on all federal government devices, at least 27 states have blocked TikTok on devices theyâve issued, affecting a number of state schools and universities, too. A bipartisan bill, introduced in Congress last December, stipulates banning the appâs use by everyone in the United States. TikTok scepticism is spreading to Europe too. Some politicians â echoing their Washington-based counterparts â contend that TikTok poses a security risk, warning it could potentially hand user data to Chinese authorities, and/or be wielded as a propaganda tool for the Chinese government â subtly influencing TikTokâs more than 1 billion monthly active users in a direction that dovetails with Chinese foreign policy goals. Itâs emblematic of ratcheting Sino-western tensions, where tussling over technology is as much about genuine paranoia over espionage as it is a useful arena for geopolitical grandstanding. In the age of the âsplinternetâ â which has seen the once-open web fracturing across different jurisdictions â anxieties over data sovereignty and information flows are on the rise. How western governments respond to TikTok could mark a decisive step in how technology is regulated in the decades to come. While accusations that TikTok hands over user data to the Chinese government are so far unsubstantiated, the appâs claims over its trustworthiness took a blow in December with the revelation that employees at ByteDance (TikTokâs parent company) accessed TikTok data in an attempt to track the whereabouts of several western journalists in order to discover their sources within the company. TikTok says the incident involved improper data access and that the employees responsible have been fired, but the transgression has nevertheless served as a lightning rod for apprehensions surrounding the company and the appâs data privacy protocols. Alicia Kearns MP, the Conservative chair of both the Foreign Affairs Select Committee and of the China Research Group, has previously called upon TikTok to provide testimony about the data privacy of UK users. âIn their evidence, they said something like âThis could never happenâ,â says Kearns. âWell, obviously that is not true, and it has happened.â (Last October, ByteDance tweeted that âTikTok has never been used to âtargetâ any members of the US government, activists, public figures or journalists.â) TikTok met European commissioners last month to discuss data privacy and content moderation, in the context of how the company plans to comply with the EUâs new digital services regulation. âTheyâre starting to realise that TikTok is not just another app to communicate, or send videos to one another, or for amusement,â says Belgian MEP Tom Vandendriessche. âTikTok is gathering the data of our citizens.â Itâs worth noting TikTok is not the only company that has engaged in this practice: American businesses, including Microsoft and Uber, have also been found guilty of tracking individual users through their products in the past. But in the US, the news arrived at a highly sensitive time for the company. âThis should be the final nail in the coffin for the idea that the US can trust TikTok,â tweeted Brendan Carr, a member of the US Federal Communications Commission. *** The conversation in Europe is a little different. So far, the bloc has been less willing to single out TikTok on the basis of the location of its parent company. It is scrutinising the app over data privacy concerns: Irelandâs data protection commissioner opened two probes into the company in 2021 â one focusing on its handling of childrenâs data, the other to check that its data transfers to China complied with EU data legislation. (A draft decision has been submitted on the first inquiry.) However, this is not unique to TikTok. The likes of Facebook and Google have also become ensnared in Europeâs data privacy laws, and the EU is currently wrangling with the US over whether EU data should be allowed to be sent there, for fears it could be hoovered up by US intelligence agencies. âWhile some questions about TikTok and our Chinese heritage have become politicised, we take national security concerns very seriously,â says Theo Bertram, vice-president of public policy and government relations, Europe at TikTok. Regardless of where you are, how seriously should you take the warnings? Some technology experts say the accusations are somewhat overblown. Both the data privacy and content manipulation threats cited by politicians currently lack convincing evidence, says Graham Webster, research scholar and editor in chief of the DigiChina Project at the Stanford University Cyber Policy Center in California. âI think both of these theories are possible, but at this point they both require a significant amount of imagination to actually constitute a US national security threat,â says Webster. He doesnât think itâs unreasonable at this stage to think that Chinese officials might have unauthorised access to TikTok user data. âBut you would have to make an argument for why that access can be used in such a way that constitutes a national security threat,â he says. This is because the data held by TikTok isnât unique. The app can collect location data, but must ask users before tracking detailed GPS data. If the user declines, only their rough whereabouts can be gathered. (In fact, a TikTok spokesperson claims its employees didnât succeed in the attempted tracking of journalists precisely for this reason.) Whatâs more, the same data is gathered by any number of apps â and is routinely sold on to third-party data brokers who make it available to prospective buyers. âThere are lots of ways that foreign governments can access data in the United States,â says Anupam Chander, professor of law and technology at Georgetown University Law Center, Washington DC. âTikTok seems to be an unlikely target of data gathering by the Chinese government, because of the largely public nature of the activity on the app.â *** Data privacy issues aside, what about the âTrojan horseâ argument advanced by the likes of Cruz? Is TikTok secretly inculcating in generation Z a taste for Chinese Communist party talking points? In 2019 the Guardian revealed that the appâs content guidelines for moderators on how to deal with inflammatory content yielded the serendipitous by-product of stifling any mention of Tiananmen Square, Tibetan independence or Falun Gong â all topics that are suppressed by Beijing. At the time, the company insisted the documents didnât reflect its current policy and that it had since embraced a localised content moderation strategy tailored to each region. A 2021/22 study by Natoâs Strategic Communications Centre of Excellence found that TikTok compared favourably to other platforms on combating inauthentic manipulation (coming second to Twitter, and ahead of Facebook, Instagram and YouTube). The report recommended more cooperation with external researchers to make it easier to study content moderation on the platform, something a TikTok spokesperson says the app is aiming to grow. Although TikTok has repeatedly said that western user data is not stored in China, that it has never, and would never, share user data with Chinese officials, and that its global content moderation strategy is not beholden to Beijing, over the past six years, TikTok and Washingtonâs committee on foreign investment in the United States (CFIUS) have been negotiating a deal aimed at finally allaying the concerns of US politicians. The $1.5bn Project Texas involves the establishment of a data centre that will store US user data in Texas, under the watchful eye of Oracle, the American software giant headed up by billionaire GOP funder and Trump ally Larry Ellison. To address fears about content manipulation that serves the Chinese government, Oracle will also inspect the appâs source code and content algorithms. TikTok is now making similar arrangements for Europe. The company is setting up a data centre in Ireland that will store the data of users in the UK and EU. These measures would place the appâs data practices under far more scrutiny than its Silicon Valley competitors, according to Webster. âBased on the reporting of what [Project Texas] would look like,â he says, âit sounds like theyâre talking about measures that should basically mitigate these potential security threats â as much as is reasonable, in my opinion.â Whether it will be enough to satisfy regulators is another issue. One party eyeing the negotiations with interest is Facebook, which views TikTok as an existential threat. Last year, the Washington Post revealed a Facebook-backed lobbying campaign targeting TikTok that specifically played on data privacy fears. This could prove money well spent, given that TikTok users say in the event of the app being banned they would probably pivot to (the Facebook-owned) Instagram or other social media apps. More bans raise the prospect of legal challenges on the basis of freedom of speech or expression. The obvious parallels between banning apps and the Chinese governmentâs strict internet controls have been widely noted â a phenomenon thatâs particularly ironic for Republicans, who have spent the past few years pounding the drum for supposed freedom of speech. But there is agreement on one thing â that this should serve as a catalyst for the US to finally start thinking about data privacy more generally. âThe idea of foreign ownership as being the critical basis for intervention [on TikTok] seems unwise,â says Chander. âWe should have a broader approach that examines the national security risks posed by data flows more generally.â Heâs not alone in hoping the TikTok debate might spur progress on the establishment of national data privacy legislation that would protect American consumers on all apps, not just TikTok.
headline: TikTok: how the west has turned on gen Zâs favourite app

chat_gpt_summary: TikTok has conducted a test in Australia that resulted in the sound being removed from many users' videos. The test aimed to analyze music usage on the platform, but it affected not only background music but also entire audio tracks, including educational and news content. The lack of warning or communication from TikTok has caused frustration among creators, potentially impacting their livelihoods. The test may push some creators to switch to other platforms, jeopardizing TikTok's relationship with the music industry. TikTok has apologized and plans to restore full access after the test period.
article: A month-long test by social media platform TikTok has resulted in many of its Australian users having the sound removed from their videos, rendering them unwatchable. According to a spokesperson for TikTok, it has been testing in Australia to analyse how music is accessed and used on the platform. âWhile the test is under way, we expect that some of our users will not be able to access our full music and sounds library. For more than half of our community there will be no change to their experience and the test will not impact them,â a spokesperson for the platform said. However, rather than just the background music being removed, entire audio tracks have been muted, including those used in videos for educational and news content. For Mary McGillivray, a large Australian creator who makes art history content, this has meant approximately 57% of her back catalogue has been rendered unwatchable for a significant portion of her audience. âItâs really confusing, because for a lot of my content I upload my own audio tracks, where Iâve paid for a licence from an external provider, so these arenât even TikTok sounds â¦ theyâve been flagged as violating TikTokâs community guidelines, but there isnât even a place for me to respond to the âviolationâ and provide my music licence,â McGillivray said. She said this has been particularly stressful given that neither the creators or users received any warning from TikTok indicating the existence of the test or their participation in it. McGillivrayâs only source of information has been through other, larger creators, with a direct line to workers at the company. âItâs very disappointing,â McGillivray said. âCreators are not guinea pigs, weâre the people who provide the content and therefore the entire value of a platform â¦ it does make you feel like itâs a platform that doesnât value its creators as much as it should.â ABC News and Guardian Australia have also had sound removed on a number of TikTok videos. McGillivray said it was luck she had alternative revenue streams, but other big name creators have told Guardian Australia that the test poses a serious threat to their livelihoods this month, with scheduled brand collaborations now at risk. The alienation of these users comes at a tricky time for the platform. The Guardian understands a number of large TikTokers have been approached by other short-form video platforms and offered lucrative deals for exclusive content. Some have now said this test may be the âfinal strawâ and they will make the switch. TikTok has developed a symbiotic relationship with the music industry in recent years â with the use of popular songs in videos becoming an integral part of the appâs appeal, and in turn a trackâs ability to go viral on TikTok influencing its success. Reports published by Bloomberg suggest TikTok has been engaged in lengthy negotiations with various large record labels over the share of ad revenue they receive in turn for allowing the use of their tracks on the app. The Australian test is being viewed by some as an attempt by TikTok to see if usage remains steady despite limited access to music, thus strengthening their parent company, ByteDanceâs, bargaining position. The company has now set up a feedback form for affected creators. In a public statement TikTok apologised for any âdisappointmentâ caused, stating it looked âforward to restoring the full catalogue at the conclusion of the test period.â
headline: Australian TikTok creators could dump app after month-long test removed sound from videos

chat_gpt_summary: The practice of secretly recording and exposing men's unwanted attention towards women at the gym has become a trend on TikTok. Videos under the hashtag "gym weirdos" show instances of men attempting to flirt or bother women during their workouts. Studies indicate that a significant percentage of women feel uncomfortable and experience harassment while exercising in public. While some dismiss these complaints, others, including male trainer Joey Swoll, acknowledge the issue and advocate for proper gym etiquette. Gym spaces have historically been gendered, and the rise of women weightlifting has led to more instances of unwanted advances.
article: Women have long been hyper-vigilant about unwanted male attention at the gym. But before smartphones, the sense they were being stared at was more of a feeling than a certainty. Now catching perceived offenders in action has become its own sport on TikTok, with women covertly leaving their phones on record and then watching the resulting video to see who was staring at their behind while they were doing squats. On the app, the pitiless hashtag âgym weirdosâ has over 1.9m views, with videos showing men attempting to flirt with or pick up women who just want to get through their sets unbothered. Gina Love is one such TikTok detective. She goes to the gym at least four times a week, because the endorphin boost that comes from a good deadlift counteracts the daily stress of life. âWatch this creep come over to my personal bubble while doing [Romanian deadlifts],â Love wrote in the caption of an encounter she posted on TikTok, which was liked over 50,000 times. âThe gym was practically empty, and so many corners to be in and he chose this one.â In the clip, the man stands directly behind Love as she lifts dumbbells before deciding to leave. âI would say I experience creeps 15% of the times I work out,â Love, who is 29 and lives in Atlanta, told the Guardian. This usually manifests as a man staring at her for an âuncomfortably longâ amount of time. âItâs almost like theyâre trying to undress you in their heads,â Love said. Some might say inappropriate looks or creepy comments are as much of a feature in the gym for women as broken workout equipment or crowds. One study from 2021 found that 76% of women feel uncomfortable exercising in public due to harassment. In another survey from Run Repeat, 56% of women reported facing harassment during their workouts. Love sometimes leaves the gym when the staring is too much. âIt makes me feel disgusted, anxious and my survival instinct kicks in,â she said. âIâll typically cut my workout short because I canât get back into feeling comfortable with that person around me.â Love swaps stories with friends: one recently told her that a man had tried to secretly record her during a workout. Comments on her videos, and others posted by women with similar experiences, elicit different reactions. Some commenters agree that gyms feel like predatory spaces. But others dismiss the womenâs complaints as overreactions. âItâs not your personal space,â one person wrote in reply to Loveâs clip. âWTF is a personal bubble at a public gym?â another asked. Joey Swoll is a male trainer and TikToker who calls himself the âCEO of gym positivityâ. He frequently reposts these videos with commentary on gym etiquette, either exonerating the so-called âcreepâ or validating the frazzled womanâs feelings to his 6 million TikTok followers. Last month, an influencer named Jessica Fernandez posted a video from the gym showing a man glancing in her direction as she worked out. âI hate this, I hate when thereâs weirdos,â she said under her breath in the clip. âFeral, feral, feral, like fucking feral.â The man then asked her if she needed help with a weight, and she declined. Swoll responded to her video, writing: âWomen are harassed in gyms and it needs to stop, but you are not one of them. An act of kindness or a glance does not make you a victim.â The video was liked over 812,000 times, and Fernandez ultimately apologized for her post. Swoll and Fernandez did not respond to requests for comment. Why canât men mind their own business at the gym? Natalia Mehlman Petrzela, a historian and author of the new book Fit Nation: The Gains and Pains of Americaâs Exercise Obsession, said that gyms had long been gendered spaces. Historically, separate menâs and womenâs gyms existed, or health clubs hosted intentional âladiesâ daysâ. âWhen I hear about men ogling or hitting on women at the gym, I am often reminded of how for decades, women exercising was considered a kind of sexy spectacle,â Petrzela said. In June of 1972, for instance, New York held its first Mini-Marathon, which was televised and hosted by the hosiery brand Lâeggs. Playboy Bunnies flanked the starting line of the race. âItâs clear from the footage that some of the male spectators were there to leer at, rather than cheer on, the womenâs athletes,â Petrzela said. Even as second-wave feminism of the 1970s and 80s encouraged women to sign up for workout classes en masse, late-night hosts constantly joked about watching Spandex-clad personalities like Debbie Drake or Jane Fonda gyrate on TV for something âother than the exerciseâ. In the 1980s, after co-ed gyms became the norm, columnists wrote articles about how gyms were âthe new singles barsâ, a concept that powered the 1985 romantic comedy Perfect, starring John Travolta as a reporter who falls for a perpetually sweating health coach, played by Jamie Lee Curtis. The majority of todayâs gyms are co-ed, and the idea of going back to women-only workout spaces remains controversial. Last year, Connecticutâs supreme court ruled that these areas violated a state law banning discrimination based on gender. Despite this, certain sections of the gym tend to be unofficially sex-segregated. âWomen are overrepresented in the studios and on cardio equipment while men disproportionately flock to the weight floor,â Petrzela said. âBut the boom in popularity of women weightlifting, and thus being more present in a part of the gym that has traditionally been more male, means that there are probably more instances of those unwanted advances.â This means that women like Love, who find so much joy in working out, have to negotiate with their sense of safety any time they want to head to the gym. âThis behavior from men encourages me to work out at the earliest time possible, typically when the gym opens,â she said. âI tend to go with a friend because creeps are more timid when there are two girls together. I try to keep my clothing incognito: oversized hoodie and a hat. Itâs sad that girls canât be comfortable wearing whatever they please to work out without being harassed.â
headline: âWatch this creepâ: the women exposing gym harassment on TikTok

chat_gpt_summary: The author discusses the trend of styling homes like celebrities' luxurious showrooms and the allure of house porn on social media. They explore the concept of a "non-aesthetic home" as a counter to this trend, where TikTok users share videos of messy, lived-in spaces. The author experiments with living in a non-aesthetic home but quickly finds themselves overwhelmed by the mess and unable to let go of their neurotic tendencies. Eventually, they give in and start cleaning again.
article: You have seen the videos: the celebrities trotting through their squillion-dollar manors on camera, beckoning towards the signifiers of their (and their underpaid assistantsâ) impeccable, lavish taste. If you scrunch your eyes enough, you can picture yourself living there too: among Troye Sivanâs stupidly chic tchotchkes; in Dakota Johnsonâs entirely green kitchen; alongside Kylie Jennerâs inexplicable, outsize James Turrell sculpture. Because I am a writer, my only hope is to marry rich. But that has not stopped me from trying â to the distress of many housemates â to style my hovel like these palatial showrooms, on the off-chance that I become suddenly famous and Architectural Digest decides to email me. I spend my days endlessly fussing and rearranging homewares. I like to think of myself as a Marketplace maven, except for the times I wimp out of a tough negotiation and end up getting scammed by a side table seller (actually this is every time). I tell any and all houseguests that turning on overhead lighting is like killing my firstborn. Well, no, that one is a lie. Overhead lighting would be worse. Call it mass delusion, but I am far from alone. House porn, while hardly a new phenomenon, has made victims of us all over the last three years, sucking us into its fastidiously styled vortex as we languished at home; just look at the deluge of Instagram accounts hawking midcentury goods and bubbly glassware. Buying trend pieces like checkerboard rugs, tiled tables and mushroom lamps makes us feel celebrity-adjacent â like we, too, have a design agency on speed dial and more than $5 to our name. (I am embarrassed to say I own two-thirds of these items.) Yes, overconsumption is bad. Yes, screw fast furniture, algorithmic tastes, egregious displays of wealth, etc etc. But no amount of protest can dim the tiny, monkey part of my brain that lights up when I place a candle into an absurdly shaped holder at just the right angle. If I hadnât ghosted my therapist she would probably tell me that this is the result of my upbringing with two parents whose primary hobby was mopping, but then again therapists love to tell you everything is about your upbringing. Sign up for the fun stuff with our rundown of must-reads, pop culture and tips for the weekend, every Saturday morning But another form of therapy is spreading on TikTok as an antidote to this trend. Itâs a call to arms for the ânon-aesthetic homeâ â a hashtag with close to nine million views and counting. Users share videos of broken cabinetry, toys strewn across the floor, sauce stains on walls and doors. You get the point â which is that, like everything on social media, real life doesnât (and neednât) resemble the interiors we see online. âReminder,â one popular video goes. âItâs okay to have a non-aesthetic, visibly lived-in home.â When I encounter this video in my feed, I groan like a petulant child. Also like a petulant child, I eventually acquiesce: would forcing myself to live in a ânon-aesthetic homeâ make my life â¦ better? I set some ground rules for my new, supposedly unencumbered existence: no cleaning up crumbs, no dish-washing, no furniture fussing, no tidying up of any kind unless absolutely necessary â so basically what it feels like to be a straight man. Within 10 minutes, there are flecks of toast on the dining table and I can feel myself heading into withdrawal. A vein is throbbing in my temple. My hand clenches; the involuntary urge to reach for a dish cloth surges through me. Maybe, I say to my housemate â who has graciously allowed me to sully our home for 48 hours â just maybe, I will come out of this a more relaxed person. She immediately laughs. By the end of the day, I am longing for death: sweet release from this nightmare specifically designed to inflict pain on me. There are glasses stacked on the counter, a tea towel crumpled somewhere, a coffee brewer left abandoned in the sink, a rice cooker open like a gaping maw on the bench. I accidentally knock a chair an inch to the left and am not allowed to reset it. âArggghhhhhhhh!â I scream into the void and an extremely untidy void screams back. My partner comes over and does not notice the whirlwind that has beset the space, because â fine â objectively the space does not look so different, only slightly more ruffled. But I am not objective. I am obdurate and neurotic, and all I can see is clutter (which probably means I shouldnât have ghosted my therapist). âWhat if Architectural Digest walks in RIGHT NOW??â I moan. My pleas go unheard. We are more than halfway through the experiment. The house is now well and truly ânon-aestheticâ, unless that aesthetic is âfood fightâ. I now understand why my parents loved mopping so much. With hours to go, I leave the house for temporary reprieve â so blissfully unaware of whatâs to come. I am prone to exaggeration, but I promise this next part is the unadorned truth: I return home to find the dryer completely unhooked from the wall after a particularly vigorous cycle, hanging precariously from a single hinge, all of its contents emptied onto the floor still sopping. This, I decide, is enough to make anyone religious: a surefire sign from above to punish me for my feeble attempts to live carelessly. I buckle in the face of this mighty mountain of mess. Then I start cleaning again.
headline: I tried the TikTok ânon-aestheticâ home fad. But it was a nightmare designed to inflict pain on me | Michael Sun

chat_gpt_summary: The author discusses the use of coded language and emojis on social media platforms like TikTok to avoid censorship or shadow-banning. They mention an incident involving Julia Fox, who misunderstood the meaning of "mascara" in a TikTok comment and faced backlash. The author highlights the challenges of navigating online communication and suggests that the only sure way to avoid controversy is to stay off the internet.
article: OK, quick: define âmascaraâ. If you answered âa substance you apply with a wand to your eyelashesâ or something along those lines, then congratulations â you are officially not a young person on TikTok. If you run in those circles, however, then âmascaraâ is code for a variety of things ranging from a vibrator to a penis to a romantic partner. Julia Fox, the Uncut Gems actor, came to this eye-opening revelation in an extremely awkward way last week. She made a jokey comment on a viral TikTok video in which someone talked about their âmascaraâ being stolen and was promptly accused of making light of sexual assault. After a frankly ridiculous backlash, Fox apologised and explained that she thought the person was talking about âmascara like as in makeupâ. Which, if you are not very young (Fox turns 33 on Thursday) and not extremely online, is a perfectly natural thing to think. âMascaraâ is far from the only code word being used on social media. There are well-founded concerns that posting about âcontroversialâ or explicit subjects might get your account âshadow-bannedâ, meaning the platform artificially limits your reach. To avoid this happening, users have started getting creative. People will talk about having âseggsâ, for example, or use âaccountantâ as a stand-in for sex worker. Anti-vaxxers on Instagram apparently refer to vaccinated people as âswimmersâ. My personal favourite? âLe dollar beanâ is code for lesbian (itâs how TikTokâs text-to-speech feature pronounces âle$bianâ). Emojis are also deployed artfully: the corn emoji (ð½) is a censor-friendly way to talk about pornography. This modern-day cockney rhyming slang has been termed âalgospeakâ, because you are gaming the algorithm. Perhaps Foxâs faux pas has put the fear of God into you (as it has me). Perhaps you are wondering if the next time you make an innocent gag on a TikTok about sausage rolls you will be accused of genocide denial. I wish I had failsafe advice on how to avoid this fate. Alas, the only way to stay on the right side of the internet is to stay off the internet. â¢ Arwa Mahdawi is a Guardian columnist
headline: Mascara? Accountants? Le dollar beans? On TikTok, nothing means what you think it does | Arwa Mahdawi

chat_gpt_summary: Shou Zi Chew, CEO of TikTok, will testify before the House energy and commerce committee in March amid growing concerns over data privacy. The Chinese-owned app has faced bans on government and school devices and a potential bill to block its use in the US entirely. Republican lawmakers demand more information on TikTok's impact on young people and potential exploitation of minors. TikTok denies allegations of Chinese Communist party access to user data and hopes to address concerns before Congress. The White House has not commented on supporting a legislative ban or the ongoing security review.
article: As the US legislative battle over TikTok continues to escalate, Shou Zi Chew, the chief executive of the video-sharing app, will make his first appearance before Congress to testify next month. Chew will testify before the House energy and commerce committee on 23 March, Republican representative Cathy McMorris Rodgers confirmed in a statement on Monday, as scrutiny of the Chinese-owned app over data privacy concerns grows. The news comes after the app was banned on government devices and school campuses in a number of states in recent months, as well as on federal devices after a ban was passed in Congress in December. Next month the House foreign affairs committee plans to hold a vote on a bill aimed at blocking the use of TikTok entirely in the US. âByteDance-owned TikTok has knowingly allowed the ability for the Chinese Communist party to access American user data,â McMorris Rodgers said, adding that Americans deserve to know how these actions affect their privacy and data security. TikTok has denied these claims, stating: âThe Chinese Communist party has neither direct nor indirect control of ByteDance or TikTok,â according to a company spokesman. It confirmed on Monday that Chew will testify. âWe welcome the opportunity to set the record straight about TikTok, ByteDance and the commitments we are making to address concerns about US national security before the House committee on energy and commerce,â the spokesman said, adding the company hopes âby sharing details of our comprehensive plans with the full committee, Congress can take a more deliberative approach to the issues at handâ. McMorris Rodgers and other Republican lawmakers have demanded more information from TikTok regarding the appâs impact on young people, concerns about harmful content and details on potential sexual exploitation of minors on the platform. TikTok was first targeted in earnest by the Trump administration in 2020, with a sweeping executive order prohibiting US companies from doing business with ByteDance, TikTokâs parent company. In the three years since, the company has sought to assure Washington that the personal data of US citizens cannot be accessed and its content cannot be manipulated by Chinaâs Communist party or anyone else under Beijingâs influence. While Biden revoked the Trump administration ban in June 2021, the reversal was made with a stipulation that the US committee on foreign investment (CFIUS) conduct a security review of the platform and suggested a path forward to avoid a permanent ban. That review has been ongoing as the CFIUS and TikTok have been in talks for more than two years aiming to reach a national security agreement to protect the data of US TikTok users. The White House on Friday declined to comment on whether it would support a legislative ban on TikTok or the status of the talks. Reuters contributed to this article
headline: TikTok CEO to testify before US Congress next month over data privacy

chat_gpt_summary: Jane Austen's works, including screen adaptations and young adult reimaginings, are attracting a younger audience than ever before. The Jane Austen Centre in Bath has seen an increase in young visitors, some as young as eight. Internet memes and TikToks have contributed to Austen's popularity, with a recent study suggesting she is the most memed writer after Shakespeare. Young readers appreciate Austen's wit, relatable characters, and the absence of dystopian themes. Reimaginings and film adaptations have made her novels accessible to a new generation, fostering a connection to the past.
article: âI declare after all there is no enjoyment like reading! How much sooner one tires of anything than of a book!â wrote Jane Austen in Pride and Prejudice. This weekend, 210 years after the publication of the second of her six novels, Austenâs work is providing as much enjoyment as ever â and to a younger audience than the author probably ever dreamed of. âWe have seen an increasing number of young Janeites visiting,â said Alice Hodges, who works at the Jane Austen Centre in Bath. These include children as young as eight. As well as screen adaptations and young adult fiction reimaginings of Austen and her novels, interest is being driven by a proliferation of internet memes and TikToks. These have spawned so many videos, images and hashtags online that it prompted a recent study led by a Cambridge academic entitled OMG Jane Austen. One of its authors has suggested Austen is the most memed writer after Shakespeare. The Bath museum features actor guides who play characters from the books, something that goes down well with younger visitors, says Hodges. It also offers the chance to try on costumes and write with quills. Eleven-year-old Clem Melling, who lives near Huddersfield, West Yorkshire, will be visiting the centre in June for her next birthday. âJane Austenâs writing is so energetic and fun, I love how witty, funny and clever she is,â she says. âThe focus on friendships and relationships means that you arenât concentrating on historical details all the time. The way she makes funny, sarcastic comments about her characters makes it feel as though sheâs talking to you like a friend.â Clemâs sister, Gillie, 10, is also a Janeite. Her favourite character is Eleanor Tilney from Northanger Abbey âbecause sheâs very calm and more relatable to modern girls, especially an introverted girl like meâ. Their mum, Hazel Davis, 46, a writer, welcomes her daughtersâ interest in Austen. She says: âI am a bit tired of books for children and young adults that are dystopian or apocalyptic. Itâs nice to read books with the girls that address human concerns but without angst. âThereâs no dumbing down with Austen. Sheâs smart, funny and insightful, and itâs so lovely that they relate to her writing so much. Itâs also a great, fun way to teach history â and especially feminist history. Many of her role models are intelligent and sparky women fighting to change their circumstances.â Julia Golding runs an Austen-inspired podcast, What Would Jane Do?, and is the author of the Jane Austen Investigates series of books, which reimagine the author as a child detective. She, too, has noticed a lot of younger readers coming to the work of the writer, who died in 1817. âIt may seem unlikely at first â what does this generation with all their social media options and frenetic visual culture find in Austen?â says Golding. âThen you realise thatâs the answer. Jane Austen allows everyone to step aside and take a breath in the beautiful worlds she creates. Then we see that we share more with the past than we imagined.â Even in a world where young girlsâ role models seem to be found on Love Island, Instagram and TikTok, there is a space for Austen, says Golding. âHer works are strangely applicable to our online existence. In the smaller worlds of her novel â a village, a great house â everyone is under a microscope, just as young people are with their connectivity,â she says. âJane Austen mightâve worn a bonnet and muslin but you feel, reading her, that she wouldâve been an amazing best friend for us now and help us get out of trouble.â Younger readers often come to Austen through reimaginings such as Goldingâs books, or film adaptations. Olive Jenkins, 16, who lives near Esher, Surrey, discovered her four years ago when she saw the 2005 film of Pride & Prejudice on Netflix. âFrom then, I felt a connection to how true the love presented in this story was, despite complications that make the plot interesting,â says the A-level student, who went on to read the book after seeing the film. âI felt that, despite the tricky language, she imparts a very clear and euphoric idea of love, which is a sense that I only ever get when reading classical literature.â Dr Rita J Dashwood, who specialises in 18th- and 19th-century studies at the University of Liverpool, has researched how media riffing off Austenâs work has affected the authorâs legacy and brought new readers to the source material. âThe number of recent young adult novels that reimagine Austenâs works â particularly her most popular one, Pride and Prejudice â such as Ibi Zoboiâs Pride (2018) and Alice Osemanâs Solitaire (2014), as well as new media series such as The Lizzie Bennet Diaries (2012) for YouTube, make Austenâs novels accessible to young people in new and engaging ways,â she says. âMy experience as a university lecturer is also that, by the time students come to university, they have admired Austen for years, having encountered her both through the original novels and popular culture adaptations of her work.â
headline: OMG! Itâs Jane Austen... the TikTok generation embraces new heroine

chat_gpt_summary: Several college campuses in the US have banned TikTok on their Wi-Fi networks, leading students to express frustration on the platform. These bans are part of a larger battle over data privacy concerns and Chinese influence on TikTok. State and federal lawmakers have imposed bans, while schools can block certain websites and apps on campus networks. However, experts suggest these bans are easily circumvented, and critics argue that they are politically motivated and ineffective. Calls for broader efforts to address data privacy issues on all social media platforms have been made.
article: The US battle with TikTok over data privacy concerns and Chinese influence has been heating up for years, and recent measures have brought college campuses to the forefront - with a number of schools banning the app entirely on campus wifi. Students have responded, of course, on TikTok. Taking advantage of viral sounds, they have expressed outrage at their favourite app being blocked at universities like Auburn, Oklahoma and Texas A&M in the past few months. âDo they not realize people in college are actually adults?â one user wrote. âWe should make our own independent decision to use TikTok or not,â another said. But how did we get here? The actions come amid a cascade of TikTok bans by state and federal lawmakers in the US, who say the appâs China-based parent company, ByteDance, could collect sensitive user data and censor content that goes against the demands of the Chinese Communist party. TikTok was first targeted in earnest by the Trump administration in 2020, with a sweeping executive order prohibiting US companies from doing business with ByteDance. That measure was later revoked by Joe Biden in June 2021, but the companyâs problems were far from over. The current president stipulated that the US committee on foreign investment (CFIUS) conduct a security review of the platform and suggested a path forward to avoid a permanent ban. That review is ongoing, with no timeline released for a final decision. Meanwhile, states have taken action of their own, with Congress passing a ban of TikTok on all federal devices in December and 31 individual states banning the app on government devices, most of which were passed in the last two months. Most of the campus bans have been carried out in states that have already passed their own rules against the app, but questions remain about how impactful such measures will be. How does banning TikTok work? Schools often block or regulate traffic to certain websites on campus wifi networks, including harmful content and pornography and such measures can extend to specific apps. Similar measures have been taken in the past like with controversial anonymous social media platform Yik Yak. But tech experts say these bans are quite easy to circumvent, as the app will only be banned on shared campus wifi and not on individual devices. To bypass the block, students can simply turn off wifi and use personal cellular data, as one expert told me in my story on the topic this week. âThis specific ban will likely count as barely an inconvenience for the students subject to it, and it would be incredibly difficult, if not impossible, both technically and ethically, to enforce students using TikTok on their own personal devices,â said Mike Parkin, senior technical engineer at cybersecurity firm Vulcan Cyber. An increased number of students exclusively using data rather than wifi could cause additional issues, like data networks being clogged on campuses, making student devices run more slowly and ineffectively. âThis is an extension of the clumsy and extreme state actions we have seen taken against TikTok at state levels,â said Angelo Carusone, president of the non-profit media watchdog Media Matters for America. âThe ban will be ineffective and does nothing except score political points and tax already flimsy infrastructure.â âA red herringâ? Many internet freedom advocates have questioned the policies, saying they amount to censorship and are largely ploys for influence at a time when targeting Chinese technology is politically beneficial. Others say such actions will only ramp up in coming months as election season approaches and politicians try to outdo each other with new measures. âItâs fertile ground, but TikTok is a red herring because such security concerns exist with all platforms,â Carusone said. âIt ends up being a hyper-political issue that does not respond to actual threats.â Meanwhile, many who oppose such measures have called for a broader effort to address some of the issues raised by TikTokâs recent legal battles, including the need for a national data privacy law, mandating data transparency, and encrypting messaging on social platforms. âThese problems exist on every social media app out there, not just TikTok,â said Gillian Diebold of the Center for Data Innovation. If you want to read the complete version of the newsletter please subscribe to receive TechScape in your inbox every Tuesday
headline: TechScape: Is âbanningâ TikTok protecting users or censorship? It depends who you ask

chat_gpt_summary: Several US college campuses, including Auburn University, University of Oklahoma, and Texas A&M, have banned TikTok on their Wi-Fi networks due to data privacy concerns. These bans are seen as an extension of actions taken by state and federal lawmakers against TikTok, citing potential data collection and censorship by its parent company, ByteDance. Critics argue that such bans are ineffective and politically motivated. Students can easily bypass the bans by using cellular data, and some experts suggest addressing broader data privacy issues across social media platforms instead.
article: Thereâs a new frontline opening up in the US war on TikTok: college campuses. The China-based app has already been banned on all federal government devices and on government devices in 31 states over data privacy concerns. Now restrictions are spreading to universities, with the Auburn University, University of Oklahoma, Texas A&M and others all blocking the platform from school wifi networks in recent weeks. Such bans are possible because school policies allow for the blocking of traffic to certain websites on campus wifi networks, measures that are typically reserved for harmful content and pornography. But those policies can also extend to specific apps, which has been done in the past with platforms like anonymous social media account Yik Yak. Students at schools impacted by the bans have already taken to TikTok to complain, using popular memes and viral sounds to speak out. âThis regime is ridiculous,â one user wrote. Others seem to be testing the limits of such policies: âIâm not allowed to post TikToks anymore, so letâs see if I can,â another user said. âDo you guys see this video?â (The policies only prevent access to TikTok on school networks and do not prevent posting to the app using cellular data.) Some internet freedom advocates are also questioning the policies, calling them a misguided form of censorship. And others say such bans amount to pandering at a time when targeting Chinese technology is politically beneficial. âThis is an extension of the clumsy and extreme state actions we have seen taken against TikTok at state levels,â said Angelo Carusone, president of the non-profit media watchdog Media Matters for America. âThe ban will be ineffective and does nothing except score political points and tax already flimsy infrastructure.â The university bans come amid a cascade of actions against TikTok in recent months by lawmakers who say its China-based parent company could collect sensitive user data and censor content that goes against the demands of the Chinese Communist party. In late December, Congress passed a measure banning the platform on all federal government devices and similar bans have taken hold in more than 30 states in the past year, including Maryland and Georgia. Many internet freedom advocates have highlighted the irony of states and schools purportedly combatting Chinese censorship by censoring these apps themselves. âIf it werenât so alarming, it would be hilarious that US policy makers are trying to âbe tough on Chinaâ by acting exactly like the Chinese government,â said Evan Greer, deputy director of non-profit advocacy group Fight for the Future. âThis is classic, state-backed Internet censorship.â While bans on state and school devices are easier to implement, the university measures will be much more logistically difficult, experts say, since students can still easily get around them by using cellular data instead. âThis specific ban will likely count as barely an inconvenience for the students subject to it, and it would be incredibly difficult, if not impossible, both technically and ethically, to enforce students using TikTok on their own personal devices,â said Mike Parkin, senior technical engineer at cybersecurity firm Vulcan Cyber. This could also lead to data networks being clogged on campuses, making student devices run more slowly and ineffectively. TikTok spokesperson Jamal Brown criticized the ban, and warned there could be unintended consequences for studentsâ ability to share information and connect on campus. âWeâre disappointed that so many states are jumping on the political bandwagon to enact policies that will do nothing to advance cybersecurity in their states and are based on unfounded falsehoods about TikTok,â he said. Most of these bans were enacted by schools that take government funds in states such as Texas where lawmakers are already waging political war on TikTok. This chapter marks just the latest example of global culture wars playing out on college campuses, Carusone said. Whether the counterculture movement of the 1960s, the Satanic panic of the 1980s, or allegations of liberal indoctrination on college campuses that began in the 1990s and continue today, young people are often used as pawns in larger political battles. âCollege campuses can be an important frontline for how the rest of the culture and the political landscape deals with the actual problem,â he said. âPart of the reason political figures feel as though they can get away with these kinds of things is that they feel there wonât be political consequences, they think young people donât have political power.â Carusone said the battle will only ramp up in coming months, as we move into a presidential primary season during which being âtough on Chinaâ is seen as beneficial to both Democrats and Republicans. âThis is going to be a new focus where theyâre all going to try to out-match each other,â he said. âItâs fertile ground, but TikTok is a red herring because such security concerns exist with all platforms. It ends up being a hyper-political issue that does not respond to actual threats.â The bans distract from legitimate issues at hand, said Gillian Diebold of the Center for Data Innovation, including data privacy, app security and national security. What would be more effective, she added, are measures like passing national data privacy legislation, or mandating transparency around what data is collected and enforcing end-to-end encryption on all social media apps. âTargeting one single app is not going to make a dent in combatting these real issues,â she said. âThese problems exist on every social media app out there, not just TikTok.â
headline: The new frontier in the US war on TikTok: university campuses

chat_gpt_summary: The author explores the popularity of true crime content on TikTok and its influence on amateur sleuthing. They humorously describe their own attempt to create a "binder" of personal data in case they are ever murdered, mimicking the style of true crime investigations. The author highlights the absurdity and fascination surrounding the genre while acknowledging its potential ugliness. The passage showcases the author's affinity for true crime and the theatrical nature of their endeavor.
article: If I was a more dedicated podcast listener, I am certain I would be a nutter for true crime, a genre with which I share many core values: a zeal for prying into the lives of total strangers, a generally melodramatic way of talking, an overactive imagination which crafts grand, paranoid narratives from the most quotidian of events. (These are also the traits of anyone who did theatre in high school.) TikTok, apparently, agrees. When Serial exploded the genre in 2014, the power of amateur sleuths â and the sway they possessed over the real-world results of justice â was still a novelty. Now, nearly a decade on, new mysteries sweep through TikTok at dizzying pace. Everyone from awkward boyfriends to supposedly nefarious fiances are held to account on the platform by users conducting their own frenzied investigations, hoping to catch their suspects cheating, philandering and premeditating. The jurors: a million deranged zoomers. The tone: nothing short of fever pitch â the type that accompanies all good conspiracy theories. All of this can be ugly. But it can also be funny: as in a video which has made the rounds in the past month where one true crime obsessive shows off their fastidiously arranged binder containing fingerprints, handwriting samples, locks of hair, medical records â in case they, you know, get murdered and someone decides to start a podcast about it. See above: theatre kids. Theyâve labelled this a â5 things in case I go missing binderâ, which is a very dry way to describe your own kidnapping. Like all TikToks, the video makes it look somehow sane and easy to collect all the things that would be necessary in a murder investigation. But I wasnât so sure. *In an extremely true crime voice* I knew I had to investigate, and by investigate I mean assemble my own assortment of personal data in the unlikely scenario that I am murdered. (If you are reading this, please do not murder me.) I make a quick decision to forgo the fingerprint samples, as I have not had access to an ink pad since I was seven and deep into my spy era, when I would subject everyone around me to spontaneous and annoying âforensicâ âinspectionsâ. This says a lot about me. Moving onwards: a lock of hair. Luckily, I am able to unearth a pair of barber scissors from the back of the toiletries cupboard. I grit my teeth and lop off one measly bang â then I realise, via a very unscientific Google search, that you are meant to rip your hair out from its roots so that a DNA sample can eventually be procured by a bored 20-year-old scrolling through TikTok. Because I have the pain tolerance of a toddler, I opt out of this cruel and unusual punishment and instead sticky-tape the chunk Iâve already chopped off to a sheet of A4 paper. Next, a handwriting sample â easy enough, though I am convinced my carpal muscles have atrophied to the point that merely holding a pen could give me an immediate RSI. As usual, I am being melodramatic. I am not, however, being melodramatic when a bolt of fear strikes me at the thought of attaining my medical records â the fourth requirement in this binder. For posterity, I phone up the last doctorâs office I haphazardly looked up. They put me on hold for 15 minutes and the line goes dead. I apologise to all future podcasters who are now unaware I had asthma from the ages of five to 12. At last, my binder is almost complete. The final piece is a list of everyone I know and their contact details because, according to the TikTok, âmy friends and exes are the first people they need to bring in for questioningâ. Personally, it seems like the primary suspects should be my enemies, but what do I know? I reach out to an ex and tell him I am including him in my file. âIf you were to murder me,â I ask him, âhow would you do it?â Perhaps, I think, he will reply with something ludicrous: a sensational homicide plot straight out of a slasher. Or maybe heâll be cautious, or even outraged that I could implicate him in such wicked deeds. Instead, his response is entirely unblinking. âSlow poison or choking,â he texts back instantly, as if he has stewed on this many times before. This is when I know the binder has gone too far. Michael Sun is Guardian Australiaâs editorial assistant for features, culture and lifestyle. Twitter @mlchaelsun
headline: TikTok is overrun by amateur sleuths â so which clues should I leave in case I go missing? | Michael Sun

chat_gpt_summary: Over 20 children in Indonesia were injured after participating in a TikTok trend involving a street snack infused with liquid nitrogen known as "dragon's breath." The government has issued warnings about the dangers of consuming food with liquid nitrogen, as it can cause burns, food poisoning, and even death if consumed before evaporation. The Ministry of Health has called for supervision of establishments using liquid nitrogen and educational measures in schools to raise awareness of the risks.
article: More than 20 children have been hurt in Indonesia after taking part in a TikTok trend in which they are filmed devouring a street snack infused with liquid nitrogen known colloquially as âdragonâs breathâ. The government has warned of the dangers of using liquid nitrogen in ready-to-eat food and urged greater vigilance after some children suffered stomach burns and food poisoning while eating chiki ngebul or chikibulis â a rainbow assortment of candies coated in a cloud of liquid nitrogen mist. The liquid nitrogen causes the snack to appear to smoke when consumed but if it is consumed before the liquid nitrogen has evaporated, there is the potential for intestinal burns and perforations, and in the most severe cases it can lead to death, said Dr Dicky Budiman, an Indonesian doctor and researcher of global health security at Griffith University. Skin burns and severe breathing difficulties are other potential risks, the Indonesian ministry of healthâs director general, Maxi Rein Rondonuwu, said in a statement. No deaths have been reported, but the ministry said around 25 children have been affected, with two hospitalised. Budiman said the number of children affected could be much higher. The ministry has asked local health agencies to supervise restaurants using liquid nitrogen whilst informing them of how consumers can enjoy it safely. âMobile hawker food outletsâ are advised against selling such snacks at all. It has also asked schools to educate children about the dangers. On TikTok, dozens of videos, accompanied by dance music, show teenagers and young children with tendrils of smoke coming from their mouths as they devour chiki ngebul. In one video that has racked up nearly 60,000 views, a toddler can be seen puffing the smoke through the hole in the sweet. Although the snack has been around for several years and liquid nitrogen is commonly used in food, such snacks are now easier to access than they historically have been, said Budiman. âMaybe now itâs decreasing [in price] and not only easier to access but also the number of new businesses using this liquid nitrogen is also increasingâ, he said. Theyâre often sold by street vendors, and many food handlers donât know how to use liquid nitrogen properly, while children arenât aware of its dangers, said Budiman. âFor some teenagers, the experience [of] dangerous things [generates] more enthusiasm. They [are] eager to try it. Thatâs a dangerous thing,â he said.
headline: Children hurt eating liquid nitrogen âdragonâs breathâ snack in Indonesian Tiktok trend

chat_gpt_summary: Alex Reifsnyder, a TikTok user with 167k followers, uses a physics simulator called Floating Sandbox to create shipwreck simulations. His videos, depicting ships sinking from tidal waves, icebergs, and lightning, attract millions of views. Viewers find the content satisfying and therapeutic, with some requesting additional destruction. Reifsnyder believes his videos are educational and not meant to mock tragedies. The appeal of such simulations lies in the human tendency to pay attention to situations that provide information about threats or danger at a low cost.
article: A shark swims slowly and serenely beneath the Bismarck seconds before it sinks deep into the ocean. Seemingly out of nowhere, the battleship tilts and falls; its bow crashes on to the seabed. Its hull floods before briefly resurfacing out of the water. Then the voiceover says: âOh! Uh oh, uh oh, uh oh! Boom!â The Bismarck snaps in half and sinks. This was not the Bismarckâs real end, but a shipwreck simulated by Alex Reifsnyder, a 27-year-old retail supervisor from Pennsylvania. Reifsnyder uses the physics simulator Floating Sandbox to sink ships with tidal waves, icebergs and lightning for between one and two hours almost every night. On his TikTok page @an_angry_flyy, 167,000 loyal followers cannot get enough. Not even they seem to know exactly what draws them. A comment under one video from October reads: âDonât know what I am watching â¦ and why â¦ but I still come back every day.â Though some are given a soundtrack of slow, sinister music and others upbeat pop, all Reifsnyderâs videos seem to capture the terror of an eerie expanse of ocean that has the power to crush you and drag you down. The comment section reveals that viewers cannot help but picture themselves onboard: âImagine your boat goes completely airborne,â reads one, while others joke: âIâm fine, I had my seatbelt on,â and âIâd survive.â There is also a clear appetite for further destruction: âCan fire be added or an explosion?â asks one commenter. Another requests: âCould you drop it from the sky into the water?â More than 1.7 million people watched the Bismarck go boom in early October, and Reifsnyderâs most popular video has 21m views. In it, an unfathomably tall wave approaches the Bismarck as Hans Zimmerâs Cornfield Chase from the film Interstellar plays. The ship is lifted up into the air; its stern slams into the ocean and snaps in half. Water pours into the ship. In pieces, it sinks to the seabed. âIâve always had an interest in the Titanic, the Britannic, the Lusitania. Iâve watched a lot of history videos on these ships,â says Reifsnyder, who began wrecking ships in July 2022 after two years of failing to get fans by streaming the shooting game Call of Duty. Finding fans has not been a problem this time. âA lot of people find it really satisfying,â he says. âItâs actually pretty therapeutic to watch boats sink. In my streams, I create a very relaxing and inclusive environment for everybody and anybody.â Initially, Reifsnyderâs viewers were mostly men aged 15 to 35, but recently others have hopped onboard. âI have noticed more females coming in and watching,â he says, âI even have people that speak languages that I canât even recognise.â Reifsnyder is bilingual and occasionally speaks Spanish on streams. âA lot of people tell me I have a great narration voice,â he says. His commentary varies from deadpan and descriptive to excitably absurd: âItâs going to get yeeted into the air!â, âOh my, into the spikes she goes.â Dr Coltan Scrivner, an expert on morbid curiosity, argues that what keeps people coming back is that it is a form of learning. âHumans, like other animals, have a built-in cognitive bias that encourages them to pay attention to situations that can inform them about threats or danger,â says the research scientist at the Recreational Fear Lab in Aarhus University, Denmark. Scrivner says such âthreat informationâ is especially appealing âwhen the cost to look is low â such as when we watch the news, play a game or see a simulation. âOur minds see a simulated shipwreck as an opportunity to learn important and consequential information at a very low cost. This makes it difficult to look away.â Reifsnyder, too, views his content as educational, not about mocking tragedies. Unlike other games, thereâs ânobody onboardâ the ships of Floating Sandbox, and no population counter that ticks down as a vessel sinks. âThis is all about history, and weâre learning physics here,â Reifsnyder says. âHydrodynamic physics are accounted for in the game, thermodynamics are accounted for, gravity is accounted for.â Or to put it another way: Uh oh, uh oh, uh oh! Boom!
headline: âUh oh â¦ boom!â: TikTok is in love with simulated shipwrecks

chat_gpt_summary: In the absence of Alex Reifsnyder, TechScape's rotating cast of writers continues to cover tech news. Elon Musk remains a prominent figure, with recent tweets and the decline of Tesla's share price. The behavior of tech executives like Musk raises concerns about their disregard for norms and consequences. On the other hand, Apple's rumored release of a virtual and augmented-reality headset may revive interest in the metaverse. TikTok faced backlash after it was revealed that staff members spied on reporters, damaging the company's reputation.
article: Hello and welcome to TechScape. Alex is now off on paternity leave, and in his place a rotating cast of writers will give their takes on the world of tech. Apologies to any readers who have begged Alex for fewer stories about Elon Musk and crypto, but in a post-Twitter takeover world there are no quiet weeks for tech reporters. In the last few weeks, Musk has handed over documents for the latest edition of the âTwitter Filesâ to controversial author Alex Berenson (with the not-so revelatory news that Twitter was asked not to spread vaccine misinformation); hinted that weâre getting 4,000-character long tweets; and tweeted messages about the arrest of disgraced influencer and the âking of toxic masculinityâ Andrew Tate. All of this has happened while the share price of his electric car company, Tesla, has cratered. For good or ill â and it appears mostly, so far, to be ill â Musk became the main character of 2022, Trumping tech. Which is why I hope youâll forgive us for focusing quite so much on him â and continuing to do so into 2023. Because, like Trump, Muskâs way of doing things has a butterfly effect beyond Twitter. Musk (pictured above) is redrawing the TechScape, and how we as journalists (and politicians as regulators) should treat it. Alex Hern has, like I have, long treated big tech with a healthy dose of scepticism. The Guardian was among the main outlets to hold Facebookâs feet to the fire during the Cambridge Analytica scandal; it uncovered issues with TikTokâs content moderation system; it (rightly) laughs at the metaverse. Itâs long been obvious that social media executives canât always grapple with the issues they need to, given their companiesâ central role in our society, and I personally have felt that theyâre just not up to the job of understanding their own impact. Yet with hindsight we might now appreciate how lucky we were. Even if big techâs executives werenât always up to the task, they recognised the enormity of the problem. Mark Zuckerberg made plenty of bad decisions and acted many times in his own flagrant self-interest, but he seemed to realise his companyâs position in our lives meant he had to try and keep his platform in check. Thereâs little sense of that with Musk. The risk is that, just as politicians started flouting the norms after they realised Donald Trump got away with it, other tech executives could start doing the same. We may look back on 2022 and think we never had it so good when it comes to big techâs behaviour â which is a worrying thought. The metaverse â¦ lives? Breaking news this week that the flatlining folly known as the metaverse could â and I stress could â be resuscitated. Ever since Facebook overhauled its entire business and rebranded itself as Meta in late 2021, the metaverse has been little more than a dream of Mark Zuckerbergâs looking for a use case. The reason? No consumer wants to spend thousands of pounds on virtual reality hardware (pictured above) that could increase the likelihood of tripping in their own home just to enter a universe with sub-Sims graphics. Until now. Bloomberg reports that Apple is due this spring to unveil a virtual and augmented-reality headset, in what is the worldâs worst-kept secret. Itâs a significant moment, not least because thereâs a supposition (which may be wide of the mark) that Apple could do to virtual reality headsets, and therefore the metaverse, what it did to the smartphone in 2007. Back then, people didnât see the point of having an all-in-one device that could replace oneâs camera as adeptly as it could take a call. They didnât always see the point of apps. But 16 years on, weâre in thrall to Appleâs world. The theory is that the headset, which may be called Reality Pro, could propel the metaverse out of the realm of wonky tech nerds and into the mainstream. But as with everything Apple, itâll come at a (hefty) cost. The metaverse just got interesting again. Ticktock for TikTok? Another major news story broke in the tech world. TikTok slipped up for the first time â and it was a biggie. Two days before Christmas, TikTok sent an internal email from parent company ByteDance general counsel Erich Andersen revealing that staff members spied on reporters covering the company. I have some experience covering TikTok and, like a phalanx of reporters, I have been searching for the story that torpedoes the company. Not out of malice, but because every tech company has skeletons in the closet. So far, plenty of talented reporters couldnât find much beyond the issues that blight every big tech company: bullying (Â£), content moderation missteps and white lies (Â£) that aim to make the platform seem less intrusive than it is. It turns out that we didnât need to dig to find the smoking gun. TikTok did it for us. Itâs hard to overestimate how much of an own goal their spying is for TikTok.
