chat_gpt_summary: University of Idaho professor Rebecca Scofield has filed a defamation lawsuit against TikTok user Ashley Guillard, a self-proclaimed psychic. Guillard accused Scofield of killing four students from the university, spreading baseless claims through TikTok videos. The lawsuit states that Guillard's false accusations have damaged Scofield's reputation and caused her fear for her safety. Despite cease and desist letters, Guillard continued making defamatory posts. No suspects have been publicly identified in the murder case, and Moscow police have warned against speculative and false information.
article: A University of Idaho professor has filed a defamation lawsuit against a self-proclaimed psychic on TikTok after the tarot card reader accused her of killing four of the schoolâs students, whose murders shocked the US last month. The federal lawsuit filed by the universityâs history department chair Rebecca Scofield on Wednesday alleges that TikTok user Ashley Guillard spread baseless claims which falsely linked the professor to the 13 November slayings of Xana Kernodle, 20; Ethan Chapin, 20; Maddie Mogen, 21; and Kaylee Goncalves, 21, in Moscow, Idaho. âAshley Guillard â a purported internet sleuth â decided to use the communityâs pain for her online self-promotion,â the lawsuit seeking damages said of Guillard, whom Scofield has never met before. Guillard has sought to take credit for solving other high-profile murders, including that of musician Takeoff, the third member of the rap group Migos. âShe has posted many videos on TikTok falsely stating plaintiff Rebecca Scofield â¦ participated in the murders because she was romantically involved with one of the victims,â the lawsuit added. âGuillardâs statements are false. Professor Scofield did not participate in the murders, and she had never met any of the victims, let alone entered a romantic relationship with them.â Guillardâs TikTok account â which states âAshley is Godâ in the bio â features dozens of videos in which she hypothesizes over the killings, often through tarot card readings. Guillard claims that Scofield had been romantically involved with one of the students and ordered their murders in attempts to hide the relationship, according to the lawsuit. In one of the videos, Guillard wrote: âI donât care what yâall say â¦ REBECCA WAS THE ONE TO INITIATE THE PLAN.â In another video, Guillard said: âRebecca Scofield is going to prison for the murder of the 4 University of Idaho Students whether you like it or not.â The lawsuit recounts how Scofield was with her husband in Portland, Oregon, visiting friends when the students were murdered. âGuillardâs videos have been viewed millions of times, amplifying Guillardâs online persona at the expense of professor Scofieldâs reputation,â said the lawsuit, which states that none of the victims ever took a class with Scofield. âShe does not recall ever meeting any one of these students,â the lawsuit said. It added: âShe does not know why Guillard picked her to repeatedly falsely accuse of ordering the tragic murders and being involved with one of the victims. Professor Scofield does know that she has been harmed by the false TikToks and false statements.â On 29 November, a lawyer sent a cease and desist letter to Guillard on behalf of Scofield. Guillard continued to post videos accusing Scofield of the murders in Moscow. On 8 December, a second cease and desist letter was sent, asking Guillard to take down her âdefamatory postsâ, the lawsuit said. âRather than change her conduct, Guillard made a TikTok showing the cease-and-desist letter â¦ and explaining that if professor Scofield, through counsel, believed that Guillard was making false statements, counsel would need to âfile actual legal documents in a federal court â¦ asking me to remove itâ.â Scofieldâs lawsuit describes how she fears that she and her family could be targeted with physical violence. Guillard has since released several TikToks in response to the lawsuit, including one in which Guillard taunts Scofield by stating: âIâm ON FIRE with excitement! SEE YOU IN COURT REBECCA SCOFIELD!!â In another video, Guillard writes: âYou sure you want to do this Rebecca SCOFIELD? This isnât going to end well for you.â So far, no suspects have been arrested or even publicly identified in the case, leaving the university community on edge. A Moscow police statement from earlier this month warned against âspeculation, without factual backing, [that is] stoking community fears and spreading false factsâ. âWe encourage referencing official releases for accurate information,â it said. The relative of one person who was considered a person of interest in the case â but has since been cleared as a suspect â spoke about how difficult the rampant speculation has been. The aunt of Jack DuCoeur, the ex-boyfriend of Kaylee Goncalves, told the New York Post her nephew ânot only lost the love of his life, and what we all thought and he probably thought as well, would be his future wife â you know, get married and have kids and all of thatâ. But also, the aunt â Brooke Miller â said, âhalf of Americaâ thinks DuCoeur could âbe responsibleâ for the murders, particularly online users. Guillard has been among those to insist on calling DuCoeur a potential suspect and that he somehow may have been involved in the murders despite the police clearing him. â¢ This article was amended on 26 December 2022. An earlier version incorrectly referred to Scofield instead of Guillard in relation to the second cease and desist letter and in the attribution of a video quote.
headline: Professor sues TikTok accuser for linking her to Idaho studentsâ murders

chat_gpt_summary: According to research by the Center for Countering Digital Hate (CCDH), TikTok's recommendation algorithm promotes self-harm and eating disorder content to teenagers within minutes of them showing interest in these topics. The study found that even under-18 users were exposed to dangerously restrictive diets, pro-self-harm content, and material romanticizing suicide. The algorithm was shown to be particularly effective in pushing such content to vulnerable accounts. TikTok stated that the study did not reflect real-life user experiences and highlighted its efforts to consult with health experts and provide supportive resources.
article: TikTokâs recommendation algorithm pushes self-harm and eating disorder content to teenagers within minutes of them expressing interest in the topics, research suggests. The Center for Countering Digital Hate (CCDH) found that the video-sharing site will promote content including dangerously restrictive diets, pro-self-harm content and content romanticising suicide to users who show a preference for the material, even if they are registered as under-18s. For its study the campaign group set up accounts in the US, UK, Canada and Australia, registered with ages of 13, the minimum age for joining the service. It created âstandardâ and âvulnerableâ accounts, the latter containing the term âloseweightâ in their usernames, which CCDH said reflected research showing that social media users who seek out eating disorder content often choose usernames containing related language. The accounts âpaused brieflyâ on videos about body image, eating disorders and mental health, and also liked them. This took place over a 30-minute initial period when the accounts launched, in an attempt to capture the effectiveness of TikTokâs algorithm that recommends content to users. On âstandardâ accounts, content about suicide followed within nearly three minutes and eating disorder material was shown within eight minutes. âThe results are every parentâs nightmare,â said Imran Ahmed, CCDHâs chief executive. âYoung peopleâs feeds are bombarded with harmful, harrowing content that can have a significant cumulative impact on their understanding of the world around them, and their physical and mental health.â The group said the majority of mental health videos presented to its standard accounts via the For You feed â the main way TikTok users experience the app â consisted of users sharing their anxieties and insecurities. Body image content was more harmful, the report said, with accounts registered for 13-year-olds being shown videos advertising weight loss drinks and âtummy-tuckâ surgery. One animation that appeared in front of the standard accounts carried a piece of audio stating âIâve been starving myself for youâ and had more than 100,000 likes. The report said the accounts were shown self-harm or eating disorder videos every 206 seconds. The researchers found that videos relating to body image, mental health and eating disorders were shown to âvulnerableâ accounts three times more than to standard accounts. The vulnerable accounts received 12 times as many recommendations for self-harm and suicide-related videos as the standard accounts, the report said. The recommended content was more extreme for the vulnerable accounts, including methods of self-harm and young people discussing plans to kill themselves. CCDH said a mental health or body image-related video was shown every 27 seconds, although the content was dominated by mental health videos, which CCDH defined as videos about anxieties, insecurities and mental health conditions, excluding eating disorders, self-harm and suicide. The group said its research did not differentiate between content with a positive intent â such as content discovering recovery â or negative content. A spokesperson for TikTok, which is owned by the Chinese firm ByteDance and has more than 1 billion users worldwide, said the CCDH study did not reflect the experience or viewing habits of real-life users of the app. âWe regularly consult with health experts, remove violations of our policies and provide access to supportive resources for anyone in need,â they said. âWeâre mindful that triggering content is unique to each individual and remain focused on fostering a safe and comfortable space for everyone, including people who choose to share their recovery journeys or educate others on these important topics.â TikTokâs guidelines ban content that promotes behaviour that could lead to suicide and self-harm, as well as material that promotes unhealthy eating behaviours or habits. The UKâs online safety bill proposes requiring social networks to take action against so-called âlegal but harmfulâ content being shown to children. A DCMS spokesperson said âWe are putting a stop to unregulated social media causing harm to our children. Under the Online Safety Bill, tech platforms will need to prevent under-18s from being exposed to illegal content assisting suicide and protect them from other harmful or age-inappropriate material, including the promotion of self-harm and eating disorders, or face huge fines.â â¢ In the UK, the youth suicide charity Papyrus can be contacted on 0800 068 4141 or email pat@papyrus-uk.org. In the UK and Ireland, Samaritans can be contacted on 116 123 or by emailing jo@samaritans.org or jo@samaritans.ie. In the US, the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline is 1-800-273-8255. In Australia, the crisis support service Lifeline is 13 11 14. Other international helplines can be found at www.befrienders.org. You can contact the mental health charity Mind by calling 0300 123 3393 or visiting mind.org.uk.
headline: TikTok self-harm study results âevery parentâs nightmareâ

chat_gpt_summary: Squishmallows, a line of soft, huggable pillows with faces, has become a viral sensation on TikTok, driving sales and popularity. The low-priced toys, with over 3,000 designs, have seen a 300% increase in UK sales this year, with a total of 200 million sold worldwide. Their success is attributed to the power of social media, as fans share their collections online. Squishmallows appeal to consumers through trends like wellness and collecting, providing comfort and sensory appeal. Plans are underway to expand the brand into new product areas.
article: Times are tough and budgets are squeezed, so it is perhaps no surprise that the runaway success story in Toyland this Christmas is Squishmallows, the squidgy, huggable pillows-with-a-face that became a viral sensation on TikTok. The Â£8 toys are flying off retailersâ shelves with UK sales up 300% this year and stores on track to sell 4m. This pattern is being repeated around the world as total Squishmallows sales doubled in less than a year to surpass 200m this summer â a success story that FrÃ©dÃ©rique Tutt, toy expert at market researchers NPD, said reflected the staggering âpower of social mediaâ. For the uninitiated, Squishmallows are a line of whimsical, stuffed creatures. They can be fruit, vegetable or animal or, in keeping with this quirky world, a hybrid â think pug dressed as watermelon or penguin in a pineapple costume. They rose to prominence on social media as fans â the toys are particularly popular with teenage girls â shared their collections online, resulting in more than 9bn video views on TikTok alone. This was aided by famous devotees such as Kim Kardashian, Lady Gaga and the US social media star Charli DâAmelio posting about the toys to their huge numbers of followers. Tutt said Squishmallows united several big consumer trends including wellness and collecting. âIt is a bit of âcuddlesâ,â she said of the sensory appeal of the supersoft, cushionlike toys. âPeople are also collecting more than ever, we see that in our data with things like PokÃ©mon and Panini stickers. Pull those things together and add the power of social media, and Squishmallows became a viral sensation.â Launched in 2017, there are now 3,000 Squishmallow designs, each with a unique name and biography, a facet that stokes their appeal for collectors who seek out characters they relate to. For example Cam the Cat, one the US brandâs first characters, likes skateboarding, the beach and cat naps. Gerhard Runken, the senior vice-president of brand and marketing at Jazwares, which owns Squishmallows, said the low-priced toys struck a chord during the Covid era when people were spending more time at home and needed a âlittle hug or something soft to play withâ. The toys are popular with children and adults who relate to them in different ways, he said. âSquishmallows are fun to have around the house, you can collect them, theyâre fun to sleep with, lay on, and share,â said Runken of the toys, which range in size from 18cm to 50cm, with the largest ones selling for Â£50 to Â£60. âWhile we donât say in our brand statement that we are a mental health pillow, we embrace how they help people.â One of the most appealing things about the toys is how they feel, he said. They are covered in a special stretchy fabric while the filling, which utilises recycled plastic bottles, feels like a marshmallow. âWe process it more than other peopleâs fillings and it really gives us that cloud-type feel,â explained Runken. Even the legendary investor Warren Buffett is a collector, in a sense. His Berkshire Hathaway conglomerate recently bought the investment company that owns Jazwares. The Squishmallows brand has big plans for the future as it moves beyond toys into new product areas such as clothing, bedding and stationery. The Entertainer toy chain said it would sell 1m of the toys this year. âSquishmallows has been phenomenal,â said its founder, Gary Grant. âYou see people touching, pulling and stretching them. It is not just any soft toy, it is very cuddly and tactile. âThe other thing that weâve noticed is the age group appeal is much wider than children. Where weâve got shops in university towns and cities, weâve had university students buying them. Itâs bonkers but thatâs what is happening.â
headline: Squishmallows go from TikTok sensation to top Christmas toy

chat_gpt_summary: Pop songs with bridges, once a staple in the genre, are becoming less common, raising concerns among artists and fans. TikTok, streaming services, and algorithms are cited as factors contributing to this shift. Shorter song lengths and the desire for repetition may explain the trend. However, bridges still have potential to stand out and engage listeners. Music is evolving, and while bridges may be evolving or taking new forms, their absence doesn't necessarily diminish the quality of music
article: Back in March, the Australian singer Hatchie tweeted: âWhy are pop songs with a bridge a dying breed?â She wasnât the only one pondering that question; it was a sentiment that would be echoed in a post by the TikTok musician Boy Jr in August, who â to the tune of Video Killed the Radio Star â told her 300,000 followers that the very platform she was posting from had, along with streaming services and algorithms, âkilled the bridge in pop songsâ. In another TikTok post that garnered 100,000 likes in November, user, R00keries wrote âshoutout to every artist that still writes bridges in their songs â¦ theyâre the best part and I hate that theyâre going awayâ. Indeed, if you have listened to pop music at all in the past few years, you may have noticed that something is missing. The bridge â that part of the song where verse and chorus give way to an alternate section that ramps up the tension (or the fun) â is seemingly on the wane. Where a big, barnstorming section â perhaps complete with an epic key change, a la CÃ©line Dionâs My Heart Will Go On or, er, Avril Lavigneâs Sk8er Boi â may have once been de rigueur, these days you often just get another verse or a moody final chorus. Bridge-free hits of recent years have included the country-inspired smash Old Town Road by Lil Nas X, Gayleâs pop-punk breakout single ABCDEFU, and Harry Stylesâs Late Night Talking, whose muzak-y R&B sound largely loops for its three-minute running time. Of all of the UK No 1 singles in 2022, only a handful have a definitive bridge â among them Kate Bushâs 1985 hit Running Up That Hill, which found viral success again thanks to Stranger Things. On his heartstring-tugging single Forget Me, Lewis Capaldi offers a redo of the chorus, and even Taylor Swift â often acclaimed as the contemporary queen of the bridge by pop fans (and Time magazine), for tracks such as All Too Well and Cruel Summer â opted for a third verse on her No 1 single Anti-Hero, rather than going into full-on key-change mode. It is a trend that hasnât gone unnoticed by those in the know, with none other than Sting calling out the seeming dearth of bridges in a 2021 interview with the music producer and YouTuber Rick Beato. âThe structure is slightly simpler now â¦ itâs more minimalist,â he said. âThe bridge has disappeared. For me, the bridge is therapy â¦ the structure is therapy. In modern music, most of it, youâre in a circular trap â¦ Youâre not getting that release.â But is the bridge actually disappearing, and is TikTok â with its short, meme-heavy format â to blame? Twenty-year-old Caity Baser is a singer-songwriter from Southampton who started uploading her music to the social media app during lockdown, inspired by the likes of Kate Nash, Rizzle Kicks and her own dating dramas, and has since gone on to sign with EMI. âI was really stressed about going to uni, and having no money,â she says. âSo I wrote a song about it [Average Student]. I almost deleted it, but then I turned my phone back on and it had half a million views â¦â For Baser, it is unlikely that artists are specifically ditching bridges to appeal to the siteâs users (âI wonât not put a bridge in because Iâm like: âOh, TikTok wonât like it.â I love a bridgeâ), but rather that pop songs themselves are getting shorter, leading artists to be more concise. âI think [shorter songs] are a bit of a clever thing,â she says. âYou want to hear them again; you want to play them again.â It is a sentiment shared by Sophia Ikirmawi, a London-based music publicist. âSongs are definitely shorter but itâs not just for TikTok, itâs for streaming,â she says. âIf you have an album full of shorter songs, people can play through the album more quickly, and your sales will go up.â It is difficult to know exactly which parts of a song might go viral on an app such as TikTok which, in turn, could tempt artists to adopt more repetitive song structures, but Ikirmawi warns against generalisations. âI donât know how much people are thinking about TikTok,â she says. âItâs difficult to know what will go viral. Look at how random songs like an Abba track or [Thatâs Not My Name by] the Ting Tings can blow up on there â¦ youâd be foolish to change a song just to try and go viral.â Ikirmawi cites Harry Stylesâs As It Was, for example â with its âLeave Americaâ line which crowds screamed at the singer on tour as an unsubtle protest against him spending so much of his time in the US â as proof that the bridge still has potential to jostle out a singalong chorus for attention. Olivia Rodrigoâs Drivers License, released in 2021, is another example that goes against the grain, with its âRed lights / Stop signsâ crescendo arguably the most memorable part of the song. âThereâs a generation of pop singers who have grown up with Taylor Swift, and are obsessed with [her sound],â says Ikirmawi of Rodrigo and contemporaries such as Maisie Peters and Griff, both of whom are also partial to a bridge. For Charlie Harding, co-host of the Vulture podcast Switched on Pop, the âbridge or no bridgeâ question is inextricably linked with the evolution of music itself. âSong form in general is changing,â he says. âPeople are experimenting more and more. Bridges go back to classical pop, when you had to give the listener some kind of reprieve to earn your final section. There are probably a few reasons why people donât feel compelled to write a bridge today. One of those is certainly a long disconnect from classical pop, and songs have been getting shorter for a long time.â Harding adds that the ubiquity of software-made music based around eight- to 16-bar loops can make a bridge âdifficult to write, because youâve built your whole song around this loop, and now you need to generate completely new material. Frankly it might be too much of a deviation.â Besides, who is to say what a bridge is now anyway? For Harding, Swiftâs third Anti-Hero verse fulfils the same brief of dipping the energy before a final build up, even if it sounds more like a verse or a âdown chorusâ (the stripped-back, energy-free version of a refrain you hear just before a triumphant finale). He does, however, reject the idea that music is becoming simpler overall. While there may be âmore things that stay in commonâ throughout a song, in the form of chord loops, Harding sees it as âleaning into a different musical language â¦ Today you have layers upon layers of unique sounds that can make a four-bar chord loop really interesting, with new things constantly happening. Iâm very hesitant to say that things have become simpler or weâve become dumber; itâs just that different things are taking precedence.â It seems, ultimately, that bridges are not going away for good but merely evolving, or taking on new forms in the age of streaming and social media virality. And, even if you may be hearing fewer of them right now, that doesnât mean that music is necessarily worse for it. âLook at Jolene by Dolly Parton,â says Baser. âNo bridge â and itâs a smash. Thereâs no right or wrong.â
headline: Is TikTok killing off the pop music bridge?

chat_gpt_summary: Governor Greg Abbott of Texas has ordered state agencies to ban TikTok on government-issued devices due to security concerns. The order cites TikTok's data-sharing practices with the Chinese government and the potential access China-based employees have to US user data. Other Republican lawmakers in different states have implemented similar bans, with Indiana's attorney general even suing TikTok for misleading users about content and data security. TikTok has responded, stating that the bans are fueled by misinformation and expressing disappointment at being cut off from government agencies.
article: Governor Greg Abbott of Texas on Wednesday ordered state agencies to ban TikTok on government-issued devices, citing security concerns of the appâs data-sharing practices with the Chinese government. âTikTok harvests vast amounts of data from its usersâ devices â including when, where and how they conduct Internet activity â and offers this trove of potentially sensitive information to the Chinese government,â according to one of the letters the governor sent to state agency leaders. âWhile TikTok has claimed that it stores US data within the US, the company admitted in a letter to Congress that China-based employees can have access to US data. It has also been reported that ByteDance planned to use TikTok location information to surveil individual American citizens,â it added. The letter also cited Chinaâs 2017 National Intelligence Law, stating that businesses are required to assist China in intelligence work including data sharing. It recounted that TikTokâs algorithm had already censored topics politically sensitive to the Chinese Communist party, including the Tiananmen Square protests. Several other Republican lawmakers across the country have implemented similar TikTok bans. Indianaâs attorney general went a step further and sued the social media app, claiming the video-sharing platform misleads its users, particularly children, about the level of inappropriate content and security of consumer information. Todd Rokita claimed in the complaint filed on Wednesday that while TikTok says it is safe for users 13 years and older, the app contains âsalacious and inappropriate contentâ available to young users âfor unlimited periods of time, day and night, in an effort to line TikTokâs pockets with billions of dollars from US consumersâ. As part of Abbottâs order, state agency leaders are required to immediately ban its employees from downloading and using the app on any government-issued device including cellphones, laptops, tablets, desktop computers and âother devices capable of Internet connectivityâ. In addition, Abbott announced a direct joint action by the stateâs department of public safety and department of information resources to address the appâs âvulnerabilitiesâ on personal devices by 15 January 2023. Every state agency will then be given a month to set its own policy regarding the use of the app on employeesâ personal devices. Abbottâs order follows in the footsteps of Marylandâs governor, Larry Hogan, who on Tuesday also ordered the ban of Tiktok and several other China and Russia-based platforms in the stateâs executive government branch. âThere may be no greater threat to our personal safety and our national security than the cyber vulnerabilities that support our daily lives,â Hogan, a Republican, said in a statement, adding: âTo further protect our systems, we are issuing this emergency directive against foreign actors and organizations that seek to weaken and divide us.â Similarly, Wisconsinâs Republican representatives in Congress on Tuesday called on Governor Tony Evers to delete TikTok from all state government devices, calling it a national security threat. âWisconsinites expect their governor to be aware of the dangerous national security threats TikTok poses and to protect them from this avenue for CCP intelligence operations,â said Senator Ron Johnson and the representatives Mike Gallagher, Tom Tiffany, Glenn Grothman, Bryan Steil and Scott Fitzgerald said in a letter. The Maryland directive comes a week after South Dakotaâs governor, Kristi Noem, also a Republican, banned state employees and contractors from accessing TikTok on state-owned devices, citing its ties to China. Similarly, the South Carolina governor, Henry McMaster, on Monday asked the stateâs department of administration to ban TikTok from all state government devices it manages. Nebraskaâs governor, Pete Ricketts, blocked TikTok on state electronic devices in August 2020. In response, TikTok said that the recent slew of bans âare largely fueled by misinformation about our companyâ. âWe are always happy to meet with state policymakers to discuss our privacy and security practices,â TikTok spokesperson Jamal Brown told the Associated Press. âWe are disappointed that the many state agencies, offices, and universities that have been using TikTok to build communities and connect with constituents will no longer have access to our platform.â
headline: Texas bans TikTok on government devices amid China data-sharing fears

chat_gpt_summary: The Treasury's review of the news media bargaining code in Australia recommends assessing social media platforms like TikTok and Twitter for potential payments to news companies for their content. The code has already facilitated agreements between Google, Meta (owner of Facebook and Instagram), and news publishers. However, other platforms have not been included, and the report suggests periodic inquiries by the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (ACCC) to determine their inclusion. Media companies advocate expanding the code to cover platforms like TikTok, while Google and Meta have existing agreements with news publishers.
article: Social media sites like TikTok and Twitter could be assessed for whether they should pay news companies for content, under recommendations from the Treasuryâs review of the news media bargaining code. In its first year of operation, the code was a success, facilitating 23 agreements between Google and news publishers, and 13 agreements between Meta, the owner of Facebook and Instagram, and news publishers, according to a Treasury report released on Thursday. Andrew Forrestâs Minderoo Foundation also helped negotiate an agreement with the platforms representing 24 publishers in May this year. Publishers including Guardian Australia and Nine said that in the absence of the code, there would not have been meaningful licensing negotiations with the platforms. The ABC said it used the funding to appoint 57 regional positions, including reporters in 19 locations, 10 of which did not previously have them. Under the code implemented by the former Coalition government, the treasurer can designate a digital platformâs involvement and that would bring on strict rules around negotiations with news publishers. So far no digital platform has been designated â the Morrison government was able to leverage the threat of the code being applied to bring Meta and Google to the table. But this has meant some news publications have not been able to negotiate with the companies and other digital platforms such as TikTok and Twitter have not been included. Treasury recommended the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (ACCC) conduct periodic inquiries into what other platforms should be included. Sign up for Guardian Australiaâs free morning and afternoon email newsletters for your daily news roundup Media companies have already suggested expanding the code. In a submission to an ACCC review of social media, Nine said TikTok had a ârapidly growing and unfair market powerâ and was an âunavoidable business partnerâ for news in Australia, meaning it should be covered by the code. The report noted that some of the clauses in existing agreements would end the contracts should the digital platforms be designated under the code, meaning the news companies would not receive whatever outstanding funding had yet to be paid. Googleâs director of government affairs and public policy, Lucinda Longcroft, said Googleâs contribution to the news industry in Australia now covered 70 Australian news businesses, representing 200 mastheads, the majority of which were local or regional. Many of Googleâs agreements run for five years, while all of Metaâs agreements run for three years. The shorter run for Metaâs agreements raises questions about whether the company will come to the table with a new agreement when the deals expire. Meta cut a number of roles from its Australian news team as part of a global restructure last month that saw 11,000 people leave the company. The company had already indicated its plan to end in-house curation of Facebook news in Australia by 2021. Meta declined to comment on the Treasury report, but in a response to the cuts announcement last month, its Australia and New Zealand managing director, Will Easton, indicated the companyâs focus had shifted. âWhile we have maintained news partnerships resources in Australia, user preferences have shifted to creator-driven content in products such as Watch and Reels, and this is where we will focus moving forward.â The Treasury report has recommended a review of the code after four years of operation. The Public Interest Journalism Initiative criticised this proposal, however, saying it would be after many of the deals have expired. The communications minister, Michelle Rowland, and the assistant treasurer, Stephen Jones, said they would consider the recommendations of the report. Jones said the platforms âmust continue to negotiate in good faith with news businesses to ensure they are fairly remunerated for the news content they createâ.
headline: Twitter and TikTok could be called to negotiate under Australiaâs news media code

chat_gpt_summary: The Melbourne victory celebration prompts envy in Sydney, where a live site will be set up for the Socceroos' match against Argentina. Bailey Wright dedicates the win to his seriously ill mother-in-law. In other news, Christine McVie of Fleetwood Mac passes away, a review examines concussion in contact sports, the Medibank hacker declares "case closed," TikTok bans tanning videos, Australia's emissions target falls short, a US railroad strike is blocked, China's zero-Covid strategy impacts its economy, and an Iranian man is shot dead after celebrating a World Cup match.
article: Have we recovered from the victory hangover? There were iconic scenes at Melbourneâs Federation Square, prompting envy in the harbour city where no such live site exists. That will be remedied for this Sundayâs Socceroos clash with Argentina, with the New South Wales government announcing it will set up a live site in the Sydney CBD â specific location TBD. The victory was a heartfelt tale for player Bailey Wright, who shortly after leaving the field received a text from his wife about the condition of his seriously ill mother-in-law. âIâve just come in from a message from my wife,â Wright said. âI just want to dedicate this to my wife â bless her â and her mum. Iâll be honest, Iâm not sure if sheâs still with us.â Top news Christine McVie dies | The voice behind Fleetwood Mac classics including Everywhere and Donât Stop has âpassed away peacefullyâ following a short illness. She was 79 years old. Tributes have flowed from across the music industry, with sometimes fellow band member and Crowded House frontman, Neil Finn, calling McVie a âsupremely gifted songwriter and a warm and wonderful friendâ. Concussion in sport | An inquiry proposed by the Greens with Labor and Coalition support will examine concussion and repeated head trauma in contact sports at all levels, for all genders and age groups. It comes amid growing concern about chronic traumatic encephalopathy (CTE), a disease which former AFL concussion doctor Paul McCrory has been accused of downplaying the risks of. Medibank hackerâs data dump | The cyber-criminals behind the Medibank hack have declared âcase closedâ after posting a file on the dark web that looks to be the remainder of the customer data they acquired. The health insurer said it was in the process of analysing the data but that it âappears to be the data we believed the criminal stoleâ. TikTok tanning ban | The social media company will ban videos that encourage tanning and add educational content to its platform in its place, after concerns raised by Australian medical experts. In September, Melanoma Institute Australia co-medical directors, Prof Georgina Long and Prof Richard Scolyer, took issue with the app for its popular #sunburnchallenge hashtag. Emissions target falling short | Australia is on track for a 40% reduction in emissions by 2030, short of the 43% target set by the Albanese government. The climate change minister, Chris Bowen, said the projection is still an improvement on the Morrison government, when projections âwere at only 30%â. âThat is, weâve lifted the outlook by a third in just our first six months,â Bowen said. US railroad strike | The House of Representatives voted to approve a bill to block a railroad strike, after president Joe Biden called on Congress to intervene, warning the strike would âdevastate our economyâ. The sticking point is a demand for sick pay, which is not provided to workers. Progressive pushback in support of worker demands resulted in a second House vote to mandate sick pay, but itâs unclear whether that will pass the Senate. China economy worries | As well as prompting social unrest, there are signs Chinaâs zero-Covid strategy is throttling the worldâs second largest economy. Chinaâs GDP is forecast to grow by 3.2% this year, well below the official target of 5.5%. This would make 2022 the slowest year for GDP growth in more than 40 years, excluding the Covid-affected rate in 2020. The IMF said this forecast could be cut even further. Iranian shot dead | Mehran Samak, 27, was shot dead by security forces after honking his car horn in celebration of Iranâs exit from the World Cup. Samak âwas targeted directly and shot in the head by security forces â¦ following the defeat of the national team against Americaâ, the Oslo-based group Iran Human Rights said. Collingwood Do Better | Itâs been two years since an expert review found systemic racism at the AFL club. The club says itâs undergone significant transformation since, and Iâve spent the day chatting to the president and current and past players to see whatâs changed. Keep your eyes on our site, story will be up 8.30pm tonight â and thanks to my colleague Kris Swales for helping with this newsletter today while I was down at the club. Full Story Anthony Albanese and the new politics â with Katharine Murphy The Labor party went to the 2022 election promising Australians a new kind of politics. Six months on, is the party living up to this promise? Listen to this 26-minute episode. What they said â¦ *** âEveryone was buzzing, screaming a lot of nonsense. So much emotion. But we want to dream big, and when we came to this tournament we always said we want to get out of the group. The first thing Arnie said was: âLetâs go one more.ââ â Mathew Leckie The starâs goal advanced Australia to the World Cupâs last 16, where theyâll face powerhouse Argentina. That match will be played this Sunday 6am AEDT. In numbers These are results from two separate surveys conducted by the Australian Council of Trade Unions and the Australia Institute. Before bed read Weâre handpicking the most unmissable arts, festivals and gigs in every major city all through December, January and February. Whether youâre looking for free things to do in Sydney today, family-friendly shows in Melbourne this weekend or whatâs coming up this month in Brisbane or Perth, search our guide to find whatâs on near you. Sign up If you would like to receive this Afternoon Update to your email inbox every weekday, sign up here. And start your day with a curated breakdown of the key stories you need to know. Sign up for our Morning Mail newsletter here.
headline: Afternoon Update: Socceroos victory hangover; TikTok bans tanning videos; and a summer guide to cool gigs

chat_gpt_summary: TikTok will ban tanning videos and promote sun safety education after concerns were raised by Australian medical experts. The platform faced criticism for its popular #sunburnchallenge hashtag, which glamorized tanning. TikTok will implement pop-up banners against tanning content, remove concerning material, and promote user-generated content about sun safety and melanoma dangers. Melanoma is the most common cancer among 20 to 39-year-olds in Australia. The move has been welcomed by health professionals who aim to discourage tanning and reduce skin cancer risks.
article: Social media giant TikTok has announced it will actively ban videos that encourage tanning and add educational content to its platform after alarm from Australian medical experts over the platformâs sharing of pro-tanning material. In September, Melanoma Institute Australia co-medical directors Prof Georgina Long and Prof Richard Scolyer, speaking at the National Press Club, took issue with the video-sharing app for its popular #sunburnchallenge hashtag. Speaking alongside Olympian and melanoma survivor Cate Campbell, Long warned social media influencers were glamorising tanning with hashtags like âsunburnt tanlinesâ, which had more than 200m views. She urged platforms, television stations and influencers to âchange the cultural narrative around sunburn and tanningâ in Australia, which, alongside New Zealand, has the highest skin cancer incidence and mortality rate in the world. In response to the backlash, TikTok has announced a widespread education campaign that will impose a pop-up banner for an anti-tanning content â and for all searches around tanning, summer and sunburn. The campaign, targeting people between 20 and 39, will also remove âconcerning contentâ related to âdangerousâ tanning activities, including the popular #sunburnchallenge hashtag, which has more than 8.4m views worldwide. The TikTok trend encourages users to post videos of their most painful, blistering sunburns, âawkward tan-linesâ and peeling skin for dramatic effect, with tips on reducing the severity of a burn. TikTokâs general manager in Australia and New Zealand, Lee Hunter, said the platform would encourage user-generated content about sun safety and the dangers of melanoma among young people. Melanoma is the most common form of cancer among 20 to 39-year-olds in Australia and the nationâs most deadly form of skin cancer, accounting for more than 1,000 deaths a year. Cancer Australia estimates 17,756 new cases of melanoma of the skin will be diagnosed in 2022, making it the third most common cancer nationwide behind prostate cancer and breast cancer. âWeâll actively promote the creator content related to the campaign, which means everyone aged between 20 and 39 will see the message,â Hunter said. âAnd everyone who searches for a hashtag related to summer sun, tanning and many other summer time phrases will see the â¦ banner and will be provided with information that outlines the dangers of tanning.â The platformâs first video features youthful Australian influencer âstarrâ lathering sunscreen on a beach and dismissing tanning to her alter ego as âcookedâ. The Melanoma Institute Australia chief executive, Matthew Browne, said it had been lobbying the social media platform for months to curb concerning content on its platform, which could influence young and susceptible social media users. Thirty-two per cent 32% of the platformâs users are between 16 and 24. âOur medical directors put out a plea about the urgent need to stop the glamorisation of tanning, to save young lives, and we are delighted TikTok answered that call,â Browne said. âOne Aussie is diagnosed with melanoma every 30 minutes and it claims more lives than the national road toll. Tanning is actually skin cells in trauma. âThere is no safe way of sun tanning, including the concept of getting a protective âbase tanâ at the start of summer.â The Royal Australian College of General Practitioners president, Dr Nicole Higgins, said it was a âsmart moveâ from TikTok amid the ongoing popularity for tanning among young people. âWe are having enough difficulty discouraging patients, particularly young people, from tanning themselves and risking skin cancer without social media platforms making that job even harder,â she said. âWe have the highest rates of skin cancer in the entire world, with more than 12,000 invasive melanoma diagnoses every single year. âI cut melanomas out of people very regularly, including young people â¦ What may seem glamorous or appealing can actually be deadly.â TikTok has faced backlash in the past over viral challenges, including the âblackout challengeâ where users to choked themselves until they passed out, and the âBenadryl challengeâ, encouraging large intakes of antihistamines in an attempt to produce hallucinogenic effects.
headline: TikTok to ban videos that encourage sunburn and tanning after alarm from medical experts

chat_gpt_summary: Matt Hancock, former UK Health Secretary, has surprisingly made it to the final of "I'm a Celebrity...Get Me Out of Here!" despite initial backlash. Public relations experts attribute his success to support from young TikTok users, who were mobilized by his PR team to vote for him repeatedly. Hancock's TikTok account gained over 77,000 followers and his videos have been viewed 400 million times. Critics argue that his popularity among younger audiences will not redeem his tarnished political career.
article: When Matt Hancock entered the Iâm a Celebrity â¦ Get Me Out of Here! jungle, pundits predicted he would be the first to be voted out. His decision to appear on the ITV show, despite his record during the pandemic and the fact he is a sitting MP, had provoked anger and disgust. More than 1,700 people complained to Ofcom, the broadcast regulator, and the Covid-19 Bereaved Families for Justice group issued a searing statement. âThe fact that he is trying to cash in on his terrible legacy, rather than showing some humility or seeking to reflect on the appalling consequences of his time in government, says it all about the sort of person he is,â a spokesperson said. But despite the criticism â or perhaps because of it â the former health secretary has won the backing of an unlikely crowd, lasting more than two weeks in the jungle and surviving eight eliminations to make it to the final today. Support from young TikTok users â boosted by a concerted effort from his PR team â appears to have been key to his on-screen success, according to public relations experts and political rivals. Over the past few days, before the final on ITV on Sunday evening, members of Hancockâs PR team were lobbying for votes on the app â encouraging people to vote for him repeatedly and giving them step-by-step instructions. One video, addressed to âteam Mattâ, said their mission was to âkeep Matt in the jungleâ. It added that they should âdownload the Iâm a Celebrity... app and vote five times,â or call the voting number. âAlways use all my votes to keep Matt in!â one TikTokker wrote in response. Another video was billed as a âstep by step guide to keep Matt in the jungleâ and showed someone scrolling through the app on their phone and voting for Hancock repeatedly. The TikTok campaign is not a breach of the rules: ITVâs website says viewers can vote up to five times each via the app, while those voting by text or phone can vote up to 600 times from a single number before it is deemed suspicious and unfair to the other contestants. But it is a deliberate strategy. Since 8 November, Hancockâs PR team has posted 24 videos of him on the app, all linked to his appearance in the jungle. He now has more than 77,000 followers and at least 511,800 likes across his official TikTok account, while videos of him overall have been watched 400 million times, according to TikTokâs internal data. Aside from Hollyoaks actor Owen Warner, the equivalent stats for other stars are far poorer. Former rugby player Mike Tindall, who was voted out last night, has less than 3,500 followers, with just over 26,000 likes, while what appears to be the official account for former England footballer Jill Scott, who was tipped as the favourite to win going into the final tonight, has about 2,180 followers and less than 900 likes. On Twitter and Instagram, the other Iâm a Celebrity... contestants admittedly have a bigger presence. But it is TikTok â where videos have been promoted by the algorithm and hashtags such as #matthancockfanclub have gained traction â that has been so crucial for Hancock, said PR guru Mark Borkowski. âI think TikTok has been quite important to him. I think [users] see him as some sort of anomaly, something that is winding up the older generation, so why donât we just play mischief?â Borkowski said. He added: âThe people instructing him back in Blighty have done a very good job with TikTok. A lot of it is instructing the audience what to do, to use the app, how to vote for Matt. And that bit has been clever.â But software used by Borkowskiâs team to track media coverage shows comments on articles and social media posts about Hancock, 44, are still largely negative. During his time as health secretary, the MP for West Suffolk oversaw the unlawful discharge of hospital patients into care homes at the height of the pandemic and broke transparency rules by failing to publish details of multibillion-pound government PPE contracts. He was subsequently forced to resign as health secretary after the Sun published footage of him kissing his aide Gina Coladangelo while social distancing rules were in place. While Borkowksi believes that the publicâs view of Hancock remains dim, he says younger fans could help him win. He does not believe it will pay off, however. âI donât think he has a political career after it. I think heâll be ridiculed,â Borkowksi said. âHeâs like a pantomime villain. I can see him doing odd advertising campaigns.â Ian Houlder, a Conservative councillor in Hancockâs West Suffolk seat, was equally scathing. He too believes Hancockâs success on the programme is down to younger audiences. âI think itâs down to demographics; itâs the Corbyn effect,â said Houlder, 73. He wants Hancock to resign but fears his TV stint will embolden him in future, and called on the local Conservative association to hold a membership vote on deselecting him. âWhat I hope is that he doesnât come back thinking: âIâm the most famous person in England and Iâm going to carry on as MP.â Iâll go absolutely spare. Itâs awful that he thinks he can just walk away from his constituency,â he said. Jo Hemmings, a behavioural and media psychologist, was more positive in her assessment. She said Hancock had defied expectations on the show by getting to the final and coming across as âsomeone who has more human qualities than perhaps they anticipated and as not such a bad guy after allâ. She admits to being baffled by the sea change in public opinion â from him being seen as the face of pandemic mishandling, rule-breaking and death to being viewed as likable campmate - and believes it will have upended producersâ expectations. âThey were playing with peopleâs minds by putting him in there. He clearly isnât perceived as a villain of the piece. I think he was put in to fulfil that role,â she said. âHe went in there to be laughed at, humiliated, punished and actually he has done well,â she added. âHeâs getting out of it what he intended to get out of it.â Hancockâs team said he had been âworking on constituency mattersâ in the jungle, adding that the programmeâsâproducers have agreed that Matt can communicate with his team if thereâs an urgent constituency matter while heâs on the showâ.âAs soon as Mattâs time in camp is up, he will return to Suffolk to hold surgeries where he will catch up with his constituents and discuss matters of concern,â a spokesperson said. They said that he would be making a donation to a hospice and causes supporting dyslexia from his fee, although they have not yet said how much of the rumoured Â£400,000 will be given to charity.
headline: How did he survive? PR and TikTok votes kept Matt Hancock in Iâm a Celebrity jungle

chat_gpt_summary: Malaysia is holding a closely contested general election with a record number of young voters after the voting age was lowered to 18. Politicians have targeted the youth through Instagram and TikTok to secure their support. Concerns over voter turnout arise due to political infighting and recent flooding. The three main coalitions, including the ruling Barisan Nasional, are vying for power, but analysts predict there may not be a clear majority. Economic stability and addressing youth issues such as jobs and education are key campaign promises.
article: Malaysians are voting in a tightly contested general election on Saturday, after two weeks of fierce campaigning in which politicians have sought to woo millions of young voters by embracing Instagram and TikTok trends. Saturdayâs election is the first since constitutional changes lowered the voting age to 18 and automatically registered voters, meaning there are 6 million more voters than at the previous election in 2018. It is believed to be the first time people under 40 make up the majority of the electorate. More than 9,000 polling centres will open for 10 hours on Saturday but there is concern about voter turnout. On top of widespread flooding and forecasts of further rain, many voters are weary after years of political infighting. The government that won power in 2018 collapsed in less than two years, and the country has had three different prime ministers in four years. The current prime minister, Ismail Sabri Yaakob, of the UMNO party, called the snap election in October in an attempt to strengthen his Barisan Nasional (National Front) alliance. He is up against two other coalitions vying to form a government: Pakatan Harapan (Alliance of Hope), led by the reformist opposition leader Anwar Ibrahim, and Perikatan Nasional (National Alliance), led by the former prime minister Muhyiddin Yassin. UMNO had dominated Malaysian politics for decades, before it was ousted in the 2018 elections â a result driven by popular anger over the multibillion-dollar 1MDB financial scandal. Najib Razak, a former prime minister, was imprisoned recently for 12 years on charges related to 1MDB. Analysts say it is unlikely there will be a clear majority â which requires a minimum 112 of 222 parliamentary seats â after Saturdayâs vote. âThe question will be which coalition will have the bigger number of seats with a strong negotiating position,â said Dr Azmil Tayeb, a political analyst. A new battleground In the battle to win over first-time voters, politicians have embraced social media, with TikTok emerging as a new battleground in the race to secure youth votes. There are now 1.4 million 18- to 21-year-olds who are newly eligible to vote, out of a total voting population of 21.1 million. Muhyiddin Yassin, 75, the chair of Perikatan Nasional (PN), is among those to have tapped into TikTok trends during campaigning. In one video that has been liked hundreds of thousands of times, he swipes away the logos of rival political coalitions to the strains of the song Swipe by the Singaporean hip-hop artist Alyph. Syed Saddiq, who became Malaysiaâs youngest minister after the 2018 elections, is especially active on social media, posting clips of campaign speeches, pleas for young people to vote â as well as clips of his two cats. In one video, he does 60 seconds of press-ups (the time it takes to register for postal voting) to persuade people how quick the process is. Divya Latha Ramesh, 23, a student and first-time voter, said that in the run-up to the election her social media feeds had been saturated with politics. âRecently all my fyp [For You page] recommendations are about politics,â she said. âSocial media is a huge platform to attract young votersâ attention.â Divya Latha wants a government that will bring about a more equal society, reduce poverty and put an end to affirmative action policies that have for decades benefited the Malay majority over ethnic Chinese and Indian minorities in areas such as education. âI hope for a government that cares about its own people regardless of their race, age and skin colour,â she said. Raja Nur Arissa, 21, also voting for the first time, said while she had some friends who supported UMNO, young people were more likely to be conscious of the 1MDB scandal. âThere are not many from the younger generation that still support [Najib],â she said. Arissa, a student and a social media influencer, said she wanted a government that cared about human rights, and that would take weather-related disasters seriously. Some of her friends were affected during recent flooding, not once but twice, due to failures of the government warning system, she said. She hopes that, soon, younger leaders could also emerge. âAlthough they say experience makes a great leader, we should also give a chance to the younger ones to prove that the next generation can be better. Many youth now are struggling to make a living.â Azmil, the analyst, said that on social media the three major coalitions had focused on promising stability and economic prosperity. âEspecially for young peopleâs jobs, high cost of living, student debt, access to education, these are the typical promises. It resonates a bit more now as we have a global recession.â On the brink of power Anwar Ibrahim, the opposition leader and former deputy prime minister, has drawn huge turnouts at his events, according to Azmi Hassan, a senior fellow at Nusantara Academy for Strategic Research (NASR). But he said the atmosphere was more subdued than in 2018, when Anwarâs coalition benefited from huge public anger over the 1MDB scandal. Anwar has promised reforms such as limiting the prime ministerâs term to 10 years, and making assistance needs-based rather that race-based. He has been on the brink of power several times during his turbulent political career . It was Anwarâs reformist coalition â an unlikely alliance formed with his former rival Mahathir Mohamad â that defeated Barisan Nasional in 2018. Mahathir had promised Anwar he would succeed him as prime minister, but he resigned from office before the promise could be fulfilled. Dr Oh Ei Sun, a political analyst and a senior fellow at the Singapore Institute of International Affairs, said loyalty among UMNO voters should not be underestimated this year. âI think a party such as UMNO has the ability, an uncanny ability, to mobilise their voters to still come out to vote, therefore flooding would benefit UMNO,â said Ei Sun.
headline: Malaysiaâs TikTok election: under-21s head to polls for first time

chat_gpt_summary: TikTok has partnered with publishers and retailers, including HarperCollins UK, WH Smith, Bloomsbury, and bookshop.org, to sell books directly through its online marketplace. The move comes as #BookTok gains popularity, with over 90 billion views on book-related content. Users can now purchase books within the app, expanding TikTok's existing marketplace offerings. While some users appreciate the accessibility and immediate purchase options, concerns have been raised about commercialization and the lack of diversity in book selections.
article: TikTok has proved to be a hugely successful way to promote books in recent years, with publishers attributing the popularity of books such as It Ends With Us by Colleen Hoover and The Seven Husbands of Evelyn Hugo by Taylor Jenkins Reid in large part to recommendations on the app. Now TikTok has decided to sell books directly, announcing partnerships with publishers HarperCollins UK, WH Smith, Bloomsbury and bookshop.org, all of which will sell books via TikTokâs online marketplace. #BookTok is one of the social media platformâs most popular hashtags, reaching more than 90bn views to date, and as a result TikTok has formed several partnerships off the back of its success, including with the Hay festival and publisher Penguin Random House (PRH), where since September, app users have been able to tag any PRH title in their videos. However, these new partnerships mark the first time users have been able to buy books directly through TikTok. Any merchant signed up to TikTok Shop can advertise and sell products to users within the app. The marketplace has been gradually expanding to include fashion, consumer electronics, beauty and fresh and frozen goods â and now books. TikTok Shopâs senior director of e-commerce Patrick Nommensen, said: âIt has been incredible to witness the BookTok community sharing its passion for reading, and reshaping the publishing world in the process.â He added: âWith these new partnerships, weâre delighted to be making it even easier for book lovers to buy the latest BookTok recommendations without ever leaving the platform, while also providing new avenues for publishers both large and small to reach their audiences.â He also suggested that future publisher partnerships may be on the horizon, adding that he and his colleagues âlook forward to welcoming more merchants on to TikTok Shop UK in the future, as our platform continues to evolve as the ultimate destination for books and literature.â Jo Surman, group digital and technology director at HarperCollins UK, said: âWeâve really enjoyed the last year working with TikTok and our authors to create content engaging with the thriving TikTok community.â Selling books through the app was âthe natural next stepâ, she said. Meanwhile, Nicole Vanderbilt, managing director at bookshop.org, said: âWeâre pleased to be partnering with TikTok Shop â not only to give BookTokers and their communities another way to buy from their local independent through bookshop.org, but also to help booksellers enhance their own BookTok skills.â The increased commercialisation of BookTok hasnât always been received positively by TikTok users, however. When a TikTok book club was launched earlier this year, app user TheLibbyRuth said: âWhile I enjoy content created by businesses, I think the best part about TikTok is the authentic and unpolished aspect of it, and I would hate to see it become overly commercialised, especially with the lack of diversity in publishing.â BookToker zai_rambles, who focuses on books by and about Black people, said the shop was a good thing, but needs to be developed further. âOf course itâs making books a lot more accessible for people more casually on BookTok,â she said. âPeople donât only save the videos, now they can see the video and buy [the book] immediately which I think is definitely going to encourage people to read more.â The shop, however, is ânot varied enoughâ, she thinks. âIt is quite limited and there are very popular books there, yes, but Iâm finding that most of the books that I recommend or that I want to read are not on TikTok bookshop.â What makes BookTok âso beautifulâ, she believes, âis the fact that you can find so many different kinds of genres and stories.â The TikTok bookshop âneeds to mirror that as wellâ. As part of the launch of the books category of the TikTok shop, the social media platform has collaborated with some of its creators, including Laurens Little Library and AP Beswick, to âgrow the BookTok community furtherâ.
headline: TikTok to sell books directly to users via marketplace

chat_gpt_summary: Wakefield Wines, an off-licence in Wakefield, UK, has become a viral sensation on TikTok. People travel from across the country to film videos at the shop, known for selling the sought-after "hydration drink" called Prime by YouTubers Logan Paul and KSI. Despite the high prices, customers are drawn to the experience. While some adults are unaware of the shop's fame, young customers practice catchphrases from the videos. The shop's employee defends the prices, but KSI advises fans not to pay inflated amounts.
article: Darren Grieves has travelled 130 miles (209km) from Carlisle with his three children to spend Â£66 on four drinks from an off-licence in Wakefield. The wagon driver has brought Darcy, 12, and nine-year-olds Lacy and Ryan to a fairly nondescript shop in the West Yorkshire city centre that has become an unlikely TikTok sensation. Wakefield Wines â or Wakey Wines, as it is more popularly known â is a viral hit, with people travelling from all over the UK to film videos, which each have hundreds of thousands of views, quoting popular catchphrases like âWhatâs the best shop in Wakey? Wakey Wines!â, âAbdul come closer, Abdul go backâ and âBingo bingo Gala bingoâ. It began when the shop, which is otherwise a normal off-licence, became known for being one of the only places youngsters can get hold of Prime, a âhydration drinkâ made by the YouTubers Logan Paul and KSI. It has also been called the UKâs most expensive newsagent, selling bottles of the sought-after drink for Â£19.99, a whopping 10 times the price of the drink in Asda, where it is now sold out. On Thursday, the Grieves family bought two bottles of the blue raspberry flavour and one of the lemon lime, as well as a can of camel milk â also a hit on TikTok â for Â£66. âIâve been sucked into it,â Grieves said, clutching his Â£6.50 camel milk outside the shop and looking slightly bewildered. âThe kids got me into it and Iâve been watching the videos every day. Itâs gone absolutely crazy. âIâve never done anything like this before,â he added, laughing. âItâs not worth it.â Lacy disagreed though, saying her friends will be jealous that she got her hands on a drink that is sold out on the YouTubersâ website. âIâll take the bottle to school. People put water in them,â she said. Though it is now perhaps as big as Binley Mega Chippy, a takeaway in Coventry that was also a TikTok triumph, the shopâs fame has passed many of its grownup customers by, despite some clues, such as cigarette lighters with the shopâs catchphrases being displayed on the counter. Melanie Pickering, who works at a solicitors firm in Wakefield, was buying snacks in the shop when she learned of Wakefield Winesâ success. âI had no idea but I think itâs very cool actually. I always like small local businesses doing well,â she said. Also visiting was teacher Jim Hutchinson and a class of six 15-year-olds who had stopped by after a trip from St Helens in Merseyside to the National Coal Mining Museum nearby, at the insistence of one of the students. The initial impression was underwhelming for Poppy Birkett, who exclaimed: âIs this all the hype? Youâve got to be joking.â But the teenagers took pictures outside the shop, with Bella Chaffers saying people at school would be impressed. âMy friends have definitely heard of it. Everyoneâs seen it on TikTok,â she said. When asked for her thoughts, Andoh remarked: âWe have gone from the rich diversity of the Abbey to a terribly white balcony. I am very struck by that. I am also looking at those younger generations and thinking: âWhat are the nuances that they will inhabit when they grow?ââ

article:
Moonbin, a member of the South Korean pop group Astro and its sub-unit Moonbin & Sanha, has died, according to police. He was 25.
Authorities told Korean news outlet Yonhap News that the singer, whose real name was Moon Bin, was found dead in his home by his manager in Gangnam-gu, Seoul, at around 8.10pm local time Wednesday.
âHe appears to have taken his own life but an autopsy is being reviewed to determine the exact cause of death,â police said.
The official cause of death is pending, Page Six reports.
Moonbinâs record label, Fantagio, released a statement on Twitter on Wednesday confirming his death.
âFirst of all, I apologise for the sad and heartbreaking news,â the post, loosely translated, began.
âOn April 19, Astro member Moonbin suddenly left us and became a star in the sky.â
The statement noted that Moonbinâs relatives and all of those who worked with him, including bandmates Cha Eun-woo, Rocky, Yoon San-ha, MJ and Jinjin, were âdeeply mourning the deceased in great sadness and shock.â
The team asked fans to ârefrain from speculative and malicious reports so that that the bereaved families, who are deeply saddened by the sudden sad news, can reverently commemorate and greet the deceasedâ.
Moonbinâs funeral will be held âas quietly as possibleâ with only family members, friends and colleagues attending, the statement also said.
Meanwhile, fans flooded the Candy Sugar Pop singerâs 3.8 million-follower Instagram account to honour him.
One heartbroken follower wrote: âYou changed my life. You made me sooooo happy, Bin. Thank you for everything. Iâll love you forever. Rest in peace, my love.â
Another added, âHe always had such a big smile on his face which could automatically make a people smile too but now thatâs happiness is gone making everyone sad and loss of smile.â
A third said, âAs an old K-Poper I hate K-Pop â¦ I feel that those bad days we had in the past have been repeated again â¦ R.I.P. #Moonbin.â
In December 2017, Kim Jonghyun, the former lead singer of top South Korean pop group SHINee, was found dead at his apartment in Seoul.
Then, less than two years later in November 2019, K-Pop star Goo Hara was found dead. She was 28.
This story originally appeared on Page Six and is republished here with permission
headline: Moonbin dead: Astro K-Pop star dies by suicide aged 25

chat_gpt_summary: Barry Humphries, the legendary Australian comedian and creator of iconic comedy characters like Dame Edna Everage and Sir Les Patterson, has died at the age of 89. He passed away peacefully in Sydney's St Vincent Hospital in Darlinghurst following health issues caused by a broken hip. In a statement, his family said he never lost his brilliant mind, wit, and generosity of spirit. Humphries was an entertainer to his core, touring up until the last year of his life. The Victorian government is in talks with the family about how best to pay tribute, which could include a state funeral.
article:
Legendary Australian comedian Barry Humphries has died at the age of 89.
His family has said he ânever lost his brilliant mindâ even at the end. While Prime Minister Anthony Albanese has remembered him as the âbrightest star in the galaxyâ and King Charles said he was âsaddenedâ by the tragic news. 
Humphries â famed for iconic comedy characters like Dame Edna Everage and Sir Les Patterson â died on Saturday following recent health issues caused by a broken hip.
Just weeks ago, Humphries had spoken of the âridiculous reasonâ behind the health ailment that would ultimately claim his life. 
His wife Lizzie was at his side as were his daughters Emily and Tessa while his UK based sons Rupert and Oscar flew in to join them. His 10 grandchildren were also present when he passed.
In a statement the Humphries family said he died peacefully at Sydneyâs St Vincent Hospital in Darlinghurst, east of the CBD. 
âHe was completely himself until the very end, never losing his brilliant mind, his unique wit and generosity of spirit,â the statement said.
âWith over seventy years on the stage, he was an entertainer to his core, touring up until the last year of his life and planning more shows that will sadly never be.
âHis audiences were precious to him, and he never took them for granted.
âAlthough he may be best remembered for his work in theatre, he was a painter, author, poet, and a collector and lover of Art in all its forms. He was also a loving and devoted husband, father, grandfather, and a friend and confidant to many.
âHis passing leaves a void in so many lives.
âThe characters he created, which brought laughter to millions, will live on.â
The Victorian government is in talks with the family of Barry Humphries about how best to pay tribute which could include the possibility of a state funeral.
âWeâre in conversation with his family in relation to the best way to honour his legacy and his contribution to Victoria, so thereâll be more information to come,â Victoriaâs minister for tourism, sports and major events, Steve Dimopoulos, said on Sunday.
He added a range of options are being discussed.
âThe primary mover of these things is the family because itâs their gift effectively to decide in conversation with government,â he said.
âSo, yes, it could be that [a state funeral]. It could be many other things to honour his legacy.
âRidiculousâ health battle
Humphries had been readmitted to hospital just days after being discharged after his health âworsenedâ.
Entertainment reporter Peter Ford broke news of Humphriesâ readmission to hospital on Sevenâs Sunrise, sharing that the comic had been determined to be back on stage by the end of the year
âBarry wonât give up easily. Whether thatâs a realistic goal, I donât know â¦ I am told that Barryâs health has worsened in the last week,â said Ford.
But his health complications due to ongoing issues from hip replacement surgery, an ordeal heâd been suffering from for several months, proved too much. 
Humphries revealed in an interview with the Sydney Morning Herald last month that heâd been in âagonyâ since breaking his hip.
âIt was the most ridiculous thing, like all domestic incidents are. I was reaching for a book, my foot got caught on a rug or something, and down I went,â he explained, revealing he was undergoing âvery painfulâ rehabilitation sessions.
Tribute flow for Humphries
Prime Minister Anthony Albanese took to Twitter soon after the news of Humphriesâ passing with a photo of Dame Edna Everage. 
âFor 89 years, Barry Humphries entertained us through a galaxy of personas, from Dame Edna to Sandy Stone,â he wrote. 
âBut the brightest star in that galaxy was always Barry.
âA great wit, satirist, writer and an absolute one-of-kind, he was both gifted and a gift. May he rest in peace.â
Global comedy superstar Ricky Gervais shared his parting thoughts on Humphries. 
âFarewell, Barry Humphries, you Comedy genius.â
For 89 years, Barry Humphries entertained us through a galaxy of personas, from Dame Edna to Sandy Stone.But the brightest star in that galaxy was always Barry.A great wit, satirist, writer and an absolute one-of-kind, he was both gifted and a gift.May he rest in peace. pic.twitter.com/oSAKpxPGae
Farewell, Barry Humphries, you Comedy genius.
Comedian Matt Lucas of Little Britain fame also paid tribute. 
âI wonder if all geniuses are as lovely as Barry Humphries,â he said. 
âThank you for delighting and inspiring us. Quite simply, you were the greatest.â
Peter Ford shared his tribute to the Australian entertainment icon.
âEven though the last paragraph has been inevitable for many days, itâs still incredibly sad,â he said. 
âWhat a brilliant mind and what a legacy. Australia will send many other more funny people into the world â but I canât imagine any will match Barry Humphries.â
British comedian Mark Gattis, creator of The League of Gentleman series, said the world was âblessedâ to have Barry Humphries. 
âStaggeringly inventive and permanently fascinated. An artist, a genius and a very, very, very, VERY funny man. Goodnight, possum.â
An Australian comedy legend
Born in 1934, Humphries started his comedy career in 1953 when he was still in his teens, joining the newly-formed Melbourne Theatre Company and debuting a character that would soon become a legend in her own right: Purple-haired Melbourne housewife, Edna Everage.
A prolific actor and writer across stage, film and television, Humphriesâ international career skyrocketed when he relocated to London in the 1960s. 
Humphriesâ film career began with the 1967 Peter Cook movie Bedazzled and continued through 1972âs The Adventures of Barry McKenzie, 1981âs Shock Treatment, 1997âs Spice World and 2003âs Finding Nemo. 
But Humphriesâ was arguably best known hilarious stage and television appearances as characters like Everage and Patterson. Dame Edna was chat show gold: Take this classic 2004 appearance on Michael Parkinsonâs chat show, where Dame Edna has the host and fellow guests Dame Judi Dench and Sharon Osbourne eating out of the palm of her hand â all while constantly insulting all three. 
While Humphries was recently beset by health problems since his hip-breaking fall, the legendary entertainer was still able to make headlines with his famous wit in recent years: A 2021 live appearance on British television sparked laughs â and controversy â when Humphries appeared to confuse the fill-in host with the showâs regular host, who had recently come out as gay. Some viewers didnât realise Humphries was in on the joke, as he never broke his poker face while congratulating the wrong host for his bravery in coming out. 
Humphries, who wed four times, is survived by his wife of 24 years, Elizabeth Spender, and four children.
headline: Barry Humphries dead at 89 after re-entering hospital

chat_gpt_summary: Jock Zonfrillo, a celebrity chef and judge on MasterChef, has been found dead in a Melbourne hotel just weeks after he moved out of the rental home he had been living in with his family.
