article:
Celebrity chef Jock Zonfrillo was found dead inside a Melbourne hotel just metres away from the home his family had recently moved out of to make a fresh start overseas.
Zonfrillo, 46, was found dead by police about 2am on Monday following a welfare check at boutique hotel Zagameâs House in inner-city Carlton.
The swanky hotel, which offers rooms for $650 a night, eerily backs onto the rental home Zonfrillo had lived in with his family since 2020.
Local business owners say they witnessed police vehicles arriving at the hotel in the early hours of Monday.
Zagameâs House management denied the MasterChef judge died at their hotel when contacted by news.com.au, despite numerous reports confirming police were called to the building.
Zonfrillo, his wife and their two young kids had reportedly packed up their bags and moved to the Italian city of Rome just three weeks before his death. 
Their home was placed back on the rental market for $3000 a week in April.
A neighbour of Zonfrillo in the Carlton terrace where he and his family had lived told Seven News on Tuesday that Zonfrillo âleft three weeks agoâ.
Carlton resident Stuart Ayer said: âHe left about three weeks ago. Obviously heâs come back and who knows what happened.â
Zonfrilloâs family announced the MasterChef judgeâs death in a statement on Monday afternoon.
âWith completely shattered hearts and without knowing how we can possibly move through life without him, we are devastated to share that Jock passed away yesterday,â his family said in a statement.
âSo many words can describe him, so many stories can be told, but at this time weâre too overwhelmed to put them into words.
âFor those who crossed his path, became his mate, or were lucky enough to be his family, keep this proud Scot in your hearts when you have your next whisky.
âWe implore you to please let us grieve privately as we find a way to navigate through this and find space on the other side to celebrate our irreplaceable husband, father, brother, son and friend.â
Tributes have poured in from all over the world for the late chef.
âIâm in total shock to wake up to the sudden death of chef Jock Zonfrillo. We had the best time working together for this years master chef, I canât tell how good it was to work with him!â Jamie Oliver said on Instagram.
âJock was very generous to me with his time and spirit in the show and for that I was really grateful â¦ Mellisa, Andy & Jock work as the most inspiring judges and mentors and each have there very own unique view and styleâ¦Jock will be so very missedâ¦I canât believe Iâm writing this...â
âSaddened by the devastating news of Jock Zonfrilloâs passing. I truly enjoyed the time we spent together on MasterChef in Australia,â Gordon Ramsay said on Twitter.
âMy deepest condolences and sincere thoughts. I am utterly devastated. We spoke recently,â celebrity chef Joey Vargetto said.
Contestants on the show who spent considerable time with Mr Zonfrillo also expressed their sadness at the loss.
âIâm so shockedâ¦ rest in peace chef, my heart and condolences to loved ones,â MasterChef contestant Reynold Poernomo said on Instagram.
âSo sad to hear this. Rest in peace Jock. You will be missed,â fellow contestant Brendan Pang said.
The popular TV personality had flown back to Australia for the launch of the 15th season of the competition cooking show, where he was a judge.
Zonfrillo was scheduled to take part in a number of media interviews both ahead of and following the first episode, which was due to air on Monday night.
One of these interviews involved the father-of-four appearing as a guest on Channel 10âs The Project in the evening of his death.
He had battled with a crippling addiction to heroin which had taken hold of his life by the time he was 15.
âIâm not proud of it at all,â he said about his drug use. âItâs embarrassing and itâs embarrassing for my parents. But Iâm thankful to have been able to come through the other side of that and Iâm thankful for all the people who helped me at the right moments.â
After getting clean, he followed a successful career path and joined the Channel 10 program in 2019 for the 2020 season alongside Melissa Leong and Andy Allen.
The series has been pulled from broadcast for this week following the news of his death.
headline: Jock Zonfrillo was found by police at Lygon Streetâs Zagameâs House

Mr Zonfrillo had only posted on his own Instagram about the next season of MasterChef that was due to start on Monday, just hours before police would find him dead. 
Network 10 also shared a statement.
âNetwork 10 and Endemol Shine Australia are deeply shocked and saddened at the sudden loss of Jock Zonfrillo, a beloved member of the MasterChef Australia family. Jock passed away in Melbourne yesterday,â the network said.
âJock was known to Australians as a chef, best-selling author, philanthropist and MasterChef judge but he will be best remembered as a loving father, husband, brother and son.â
Mr Zonfrillo outlined his struggles with heroin addiction in his book âLast Shotâ which details his life story. 
âJockâs life spiralled out of control when he tried heroin for the first time as a teenager while growing up in 1980s Glasgow,â the bookâs blurb reads.
Jock Zonfrillo, a host on 10's MasterChef Australia passed away in Melbourne yesterday aged 46.The Scottish presenter and former chef joined the Channel 10 show in 2019, alongside Melissa Leong and Andy Allen.He is survived by his wife Lauren Fried and his four children.TheÃ¢â¬Â¦ pic.twitter.com/Vs6bbzFRoE
âFor years he balanced a career as a rising star amongst legendary chefs with a crippling drug addiction that took him down many dark paths.
âOn New Yearâs Eve 1999, Jock shot up his last shot of heroin before boarding a plane to Sydney, where he would find passion and new meaning in life in the most unexpected places. 
âThere would be more struggles ahead, including two failed marriages, the closure of his prized restaurant during COVID-19, his time on-country, and some very public battles.â
The book was praised for its candour and Mr Zonfrillo was praised for his resilience by the worldâs top chefs. 
âIâve known Jock for 25 years. He is not only a great mate but an incredibly talented chef - in Australia and around the world,â Matt Moran wrote about the book. 
âLast Shot really shows how resilient Jock is and how far he has come in his personal and professional life. Iâm inspired by how brave Jock has been for putting this biography out there.â
The renowned chef established himself in Australia as the head chef at Restaurant 41 in Sydney in 2000, before going on to open Restaurant Orana in 2013. 
Restaurant Orana was named as Restaurant of the Year by Gourmet Traveller in 2018 and by the Good Food Guide in 2019.
He initially worked under renowned Michelin-starred chef Marco Pierre White. 
âZonfrillo climbed his way to the top of the gastronomic ladder only to abdicate his position. He still inspires chefs worldwide,â Mr Pierre White said about Mr Zonfrillo in 2022. 
Mr Zonfrillo grew up in Glasgow to an Italian father and Scottish mother. 
He began working in kitchens as a dishwasher part-time at the age of 13 before going on to leave school to start an apprenticeship in the kitchens of the Turnberry Hotel on the west coast of Scotland. 
Jimmy Barnes was one of the first to pay tribute to his âdear friendâ, saying it was a âvery sad dayâ on social media. 
âJock was like a brother to me and we made each other laugh and cry. My heart goes out to his family. I am speechless,â he said. 
Celebrity chefs Jamie Oliver and Gordon Ramsay also paid tribute to Mr Zonfrillo. 
âIâm in total shock to wake up to the sudden death of chef Jock Zonfrillo. We had the best time working together for this years master chef, I canât tell how good it was to work with him!â Jamie Oliver said on Instagram.
âJock was very generous to me with his time and spirit in the show and for that I was really gratefulâ¦Mellisa, Andy & Jock work as the most inspiring judges and mentors and each have there very own unique view and styleâ¦Jock will be so very missedâ¦I canât believe Iâm writing this...â
âSaddened by the devastating news of Jock Zonfrilloâs passing,â Mr Ramsay said on Twitter.
âI truly enjoyed the time we spent together on MasterChef in Australia. Sending all my love to Lauren and the family in this difficult time.âMasterChef contestants were also quick to share their saddness. 
âShocked and heartbroken ï¸RIP Jock, you will be sorely missed. My condolences to your beautiful family,â Emelia Jackson commented on the familyâs statement. 
âIâm so shockedâ¦ rest in peace chef, my heart and condolences to loved ones,â Reynold Poernomo said. 
âI am literally in so much shock and hands are shaking. This is devastating news. I am so sad to hear this news,â Minoli Desilva commented.
headline: MasterChef judge Jock Zonfrillo dies as the show is pulled off air for a week

chat_gpt_summary: Conservative politician Penny Mordaunt has gained attention following her prominent role in the coronation of King Charles and Queen Camilla last Saturday. article:
King Charles and Queen Camilla were the central focus of Saturdayâs coronation, but viewers frequently found their eyes straying elsewhere: towards a potential future prime minister of the United Kingdom.
Conservative politician Penny Mordaunt featured prominently during the ceremony in her role as Lord President of the Privy Council, which required her to carry the Sword of State, and to hand Charles the Jewelled Sword of Offering. She was the first woman in history to do so.
The Sword of State, which dates back to the 1600s and is also used during the state opening of Britainâs parliament, is 121 centimetres long and weighs 3.5 kilograms. Ms Mordaunt, 50, had to hold it aloft at a right angle from her body for long stretches of the two-hour event.
RELATED: See all the best photos from the coronation
RELATED: âTruly unthinkableâ royal photo emerges
Her feat of upper body strength earned admiration from viewers, some of her political opponents among them. So did her stylish appearance, which contrasted strikingly with the parade of older, largely robed men around her.
Ms Mordaunt wore a bespoke teal dress and cape from London-based label Safiyaa, and a matching hat designed by Jane Taylor.
The outfit was embroidered with gold ferns, a âfeminisedâ reference to the traditional Privy Council uniform, and its colour was described as âPoseidonâ, a nod to her constituency in the seaside city Portsmouth.
âGot to say it, Penny Mordaunt looks damn fine! The sword bearer steals the show,â said Emily Thornberry, a Labour MP, prompting her amused followers to ask whether her Twitter account had been âhackedâ.
âThe Penny is mightier than the sword,â said another Labour MP, Chris Bryant.
Ms Mordaunt also impressed the American singer Courtney Love, who said she was âobsessedâ with the Tory politician.
âIâm now obsessed with Penny Mordaunt,â said Ms Love.
âObsessed! I couldnât take my eyes off her.â
Author Caitlin Moran joked that Ms Mordaunt and her sword were âthe âPippa Middletonâs Bumâ of the coronationâ, reminding viewers of Princess Catherineâs wedding and her sisterâs attention-grabbing dress.
The British press echoed that thought, with The Telegraph and The Guardian both labelling Ms Mordaunt âthe Pippa Middleton of the coronationâ, while The Daily Mailâs royal editor anointed her âthe âPippaâs bumââ of the event.

Penny Mordaunt has done extraordinarily well holding a sword for all that time. What a privilege for her and exceptionally well done. Surely a future PM? #Coronationpic.twitter.com/yW80xL6IGj
On a lighter note, Penny Mordaunt was absolutely magnificent. Aside from the music and Princess CharlotteÃ¢â¬â¢s gorgeous dress, a stand-out star. Definitely the Ã¢â¬ËPippaÃ¢â¬â¢s bottomÃ¢â¬â¢ of the #Coronation !https://t.co/m9jcf6MOri
British Twitter today pic.twitter.com/L6ieiNKOkI
Ms Mordaunt is currently Leader of the House of Commons in parliament, and previously served as Britainâs defence minister. She twice ran for the Conservative Partyâs leadership in 2022, losing to Liz Truss and then to the current Prime Minister, Rishi Sunak. However her showing was strong enough in both instances to make her a future contender.
Her role in the coronation required less politicking, though according to Ms Mordaunt, there was some training involved.
âItâs drawing on all of my military drill experience,â she joked to Politico before the event, alluding to her time as a reservist in the Royal Navy.
âI will be carrying the Sword of State, which is the heaviest sword, so Iâve been doing some press-ups to train for that,â she quipped to The Timesâ Red Box podcast.
âIt has to be carried at right angles to the body â hence the need to do press-ups â pointing upwards, out in front of you, for some time. We practised with some replicas that were weighted. And itâs a huge honour to do it.â
Ms Mordaunt further joked that her experience as a reservist had trained her in the art of âstanding for long periods of timeâ without fainting.
In a social media post after the ceremony, she struck a humble note.
âHonoured to be part of the coronation with thousands of others who played their part,â Ms Mordaunt wrote.
âIâm very aware that our armed forces, police officers and others have been marching or standing for hours as part of the ceremony to keep us all safe. In comparison, my job was rather easier.
âHuge and heartfelt thanks to all who made this so remarkable. Iâm so proud of you all and the King and Queen today.â
That sparked one final moment of appreciation for her fashion sense, courtesy of the broadcaster Rylan Clark, who is set to host the BBCâs Eurovision coverage in a few days and replied: âCan I have your cape for Eurovision please?â
headline: Penny Mordaunt labelled âPippa Middleton of the coronationâ

chat_gpt_summary: Japanese company Kirin Holdings is set to acquire Blackmores, Australia's largest vitamin business, for $1.88bn. Kirin will pay $95 in cash per share to Blackmores shareholders, with the deal expected to go through in August following a shareholder vote in July. Marcus Blackmore, a major shareholder and former chairman of Blackmores, is in favour of the deal, stating that Kirin will be a "brand custodian" for the company. Kirin's CEO, Yoshinori Isozaki, welcomed the acquisition, saying that it presents an opportunity to transform the company's health science domain.
article:
Much-loved Aussie vitamin brand Blackmores is set to be taken over by a major Japanese firm as part of a takeover deal worth a staggering $1.88 billion. 
On Thursday, Kirin Holdings â the parent company behind Lion, which owns Aussie beer brands including XXXX, Hahn and Tooheys â revealed it planned to take over 100 per cent of the countryâs biggest vitamin business. 
Under the plan, Kirin would pay shareholders a whopping $95 cash per share in order completely takeover the firm, with Blackmore shares jumping more than 20 per cent on the news.
If the deal goes through, Blackmores will be removed from the Australian Securities Exchange as soon as August.
Blackmoresâ shareholders will vote on the proposed deal in a July meeting.
However, it is expected to pass easily as the Blackmores board already unanimously advised shareholders to support the deal.
Major shareholder and former chairman Marcus Blackmore â whose father Maurice Blackmore founded the company in 1932 â is also on board, declaring Kirin would be a strong âbrand custodianâ for Blackmores.
âI believe this presents the next evolution of the business my father founded 90 years ago,â the 78-year-old said.
He also told Reuters he had wanted a way out for 18 months after developing an âantagonisticâ relationship with its board.
âWhen youâve spent 57 years at a business, you donât want to see the business suffer, and you want to see the business successful. I have no doubt in my mind that Kirin will deliver on that promise to me,â he said.
According to the Australian Financial Review, Mr Blackmoreâs 18 per cent stake in the company is worth $334 million. 
Kirin president and CEO Yoshinori Isozaki also welcomed the proposed sale in a statement.
âBlackmores presents an exciting opportunity to transform the scale and reach of our Health Science domain,â he said. 
âKirin Group is working to create social value and economic value by solving social issues through our business activities, and we have been transforming our business from a brewing business to a business model creating value across Food & Beverages and Pharmaceuticals domains, based on the concept of Creating Shared Value.â
The looming sale comes hot on the heels of a major recent controversy which saw social media users push for a company boycott after Mr Blackmore declared his opposition to the proposed Voice to Parliament and pledged his support for Northern Territory senator Jacinta Nampijinpa Priceâs âvote noâ campaign.
âIf Jacinta tells me I should vote no, I am voting no. She obviously knows a lot more about the Aboriginal issues than I do,â he told the Financial Review in February.
His comments saw the hashtag #Boycottblackmores shoot to the top end of Australiaâs Twitter trending list with outrage at Blackmoreâs stance flowing in thick and fast.
At the time, a Blackmores Group spokesperson said it was not able to comment on the views of Mr Blackmore who has not been an employee or director of the company since late 2020.
âHis views are completely independent of Blackmores Group,â they said.
âBlackmores is committed to supporting the health and wellbeing of all people and values and celebrates diversity, inclusivity and equality for employees, customers, partners, and those in the community.â
headline: Japanâs Kirin Holdings scores Blackmores vitamins in $1.85b takeover

chat_gpt_summary: Australian retail icon, David Jones, has come under fire after a customer service fail highlighted how some of the biggest brands are frustrating shoppers. Marketing expert and Queensland University of Technology professor Gary Mortimer shared a less-than-ideal shopping experience on Twitter after looking for help to pick the right $1,000 suit and to get the right size. David Jones apologised for not meeting customer expectations and blamed the service shortfall on the concessions being run by other brands, which are responsible for staffing, inventory, and service. Furthermore, department stores have been affected by online shopping and increasingly price-conscious shoppers.
article:
If youâre paying more than $1000 for some fancy new clothes you might expect store staff to fawn over you â or at the very least help ensure you get the right size. 
But a customer service fail at an Australian retail icon this week has highlighted how some of the biggest brands are frustrating shoppers. 
âIt was not what I expected,â said Queenslander Gary Mortimer of his shopping trip to David Jones in Brisbane. 
Professor Mortimer, who is a marketing expert at Queensland University of Technology, documented his less than ideal shopping experience on Twitter. 
âRespectfully, Iâve been wandering around David Jones Brisbane CBD for 10 minutes with a $1000 MJ Bale suit â just looking for a team member.â
In his uploaded video he wandered around the floor only to find the MJ Bale concession as well as concession after concession, and register after register, devoid of staff.
David Jones told news.com.au that âclearly in this instance we have not achieved customer expectations,â and said it had apologised to the customer. 
MJ Bale said it was âappalled to say the least,â at the customer service fail. 
The retail expert told news.com.au that he was at the Queens Plaza store about 2pm on Wednesday. Stopping by the stand of high end Australian brand MJ Bale he said there was no staff member there to help him pick the right suit. 
After 10 minutes at the concession, and after finding a suit, he then walked around the shop floor for another 10 minutes to try and locate someone â anyone â to help with sizing and direct him to the change room. 
âNot what I expected at David Jonesâ flagshipâ
âMaybe 15-20 minutes isnât too bad â but what was surprising was the lack of staff in many of the concessions in the menswear department,â Prof Mortimer said. 
âItâs definitely a âprice versus expectationâ situation. If youâre buying a higher-quality product, you expect higher levels of quality service.
âThis is not what I would have expected to experience at a David Jones CBD flagship store.â 
Prof Mortimer said the challenge for department stores was more of the floor space was being given over to concessions, not run by the store itself, meaning the customer experience could be wildly different depending on what brand you were purchasing. 
âItâs those brands that are responsible for staffing, inventory and service.â
But Prof Mortimer said it was more than that. Service in department stores could also vary depending on what branch of the same chain you were in. 
âI had quite the opposite experience at David Jonesâ Sydney Elizabeth Street store earlier in the week,â he said.
The Sydney CBD store is David Jonesâ undoubted Australian flagship.
A recent refit cost a whopping $400 million with the 12 storey retail behemoth featuring an entire floor dedicated to shoes, a top end food hall, multiple eateries and exclusive brands like Loewe and Balenciaga. 
âThere was plenty of staff there and great service too,â he said. 
The brand is the same but the challenge for David Jones â and other stores â is that there is often a very different shopping experience between their flagship branches and smaller, suburban outlets. 
âWe have been investing in service training nationally and have seen improvements in customer satisfaction levels,â a David Jones spokesman told news.com.au. 
âWe have met with Mr Mortimer and taken his feedback and apologised directly. David Jones remains committed to improving its instore and online experiences.â
A MJ Bale spokeswoman said the lack of staff wasnât up to scratch. 
âMJ Bale prides itself on our exceptional customer service, and weâre appalled, to say the least.
âWe will endeavour to make sure this never happens again.â
Certainly Australian department stores have gone through torrid times with the rise of online and increasingly price conscious shoppers. 
David Jones has been owned by the South African firm Woolworths Holdings â no connection to the supermarket of the same name â which bought the chain in 2014 for more than $2 billion.
But in December 2022, it agreed to sell DJs for what is thought to be just $100 million to private equity firm Anchorage Capital. The sale price was only a quarter of the cost of the Sydney CBD store refurbishment. 
However, the overall value of David Jones has been diminished by hundreds of millions of dollars after Woolworths Holdings either sold off â and rented back â many DJs stores or didnât include them in the sale to Anchorage.
Over the past two years David Jones has closed suburban stores in Brisbaneâs Toowong and Upper Mt Gravatt, while Myer recently announced it would exit its flagship store just up the Queen Street Mall from David Jones.
Yet both David Jones and Myer have done better of late. In March, DJs said sales were up 13.6 per cent in the first two months of 2023 while concessions, like MJ Bale, soared by 32 per cent. It said CBD stores were busy with customers as people shrugged off the last of the pandemic. 
Meanwhile, in January, Myer said it recorded its best result in nearly 20 years under CEO John King with profits for the half year up 104 per cent and sales rising by 37.9 per cent. 
The balance sheet is looking better but is that coming at the expense of in store customer service?
headline: David Jones blasted after customer fails to find staff member for 20 minutes

chat_gpt_summary: A Twitter user named Brad Turner has sparked debate by claiming that the values of Australia's Anzac Day are "no longer reflected" in the country's actions. He argued that the society that holds paramount ideals of egalitarianism, mateship, and sacrifice is forgotten on the other 364 days of the year. He also criticized Australia's confrontation with China on behalf of the United States and claimed that the country marches right past veteran suicides, war crimes, illegal wars, and widespread inequality and corruption. While some people agreed with Turner, others hit back and said Anzac Day was still important and separated the fluff of ordinary living to reflect on sacrifice.
article:
A Twitter user has sparked debate online with a controversial claim about Australiaâs relationship to Anzac Day.
Australians and New Zealanders gathered to commemorate the 108th anniversary of the landing of Anzac troops at Gallipoli in World War I on Tuesday. Services were held in cities and towns, big and small, to mark Anzac Day â the most solemn day on the Australian calendar.
But writing on Monday night, Brad Turner â who describes himself as a former Navy submariner and AFP officer â took to the social media platform to argue that the values of the annual celebration were âno longer reflectedâ in Australiaâs actions.
He took particular aim at Australiaâs confrontation with China on behalf of the United States.
Australia is a society that dutifully gets up early every April 25 to gather, Mach & remember our Dead.  Speeches are made, politicians speak of sacrifice & honour whilst possessing or embodying neither. That same society that holds paramount ideals of egalitarianism, mateship &Ã¢â¬Â¦ pic.twitter.com/sbHHbRiYAF
âAustralia is a society that dutifully gets up early every April 25 to gather, march and remember our dead,â he wrote in the post, which has been viewed more than 20,000 times.
âSpeeches are made, politicians speak of sacrifice and honour whilst possessing or embodying neither. That same society that holds paramount ideals of egalitarianism, mateship and sacrifice is forgotten on the other 364 days of the year. 
âOn those days Australia marches right past veteran suicides, war crimes, illegal wars and widespread inequality and corruption. Is it really a day of remembrance? Or is it theatrics so society can pretend they care about victims of war or our conduct as a country with an aim to feel better about apathy and inaction as a nation towards these things.
âWe donât notice any of these things because we are too busy marching. But this time itâs headlong into another pointless American war with China. The things we celebrate about our nation on Anzac Day are sadly no longer reflected in Australiaâs actions. They have not been in some time.â
A number of people agreed with Mr Turner.
âI donât like Anzac Day. It overlooks our follies in joining Britain and US wars. WWII was noble. The rest were con jobs to enrich the industrialists. Our people have all these solemn events only to assuage their âje ne câest quoiâ because they donât feel any guilt but should,â one wrote.
âOur politicians spend more on memorial monuments and museums that they can put their name on a plaque on the wall than they do for the actual veterans who are suffering from PTSD or other âsouvenirsâ they have brought back from their tours,â another agreed.
âFlag waving patriotism has taken over Anzac Day. We are one step away from parades of military hardware while the populace salute. What should be a reflection on the horrors of war has become itâs celebration. John Howard did this,â a third said.
âListening to the Labor government yesterday follow in the footsteps of the Coalition, justifying spending billions antagonising China at Americaâs request is not the âlest we forgetâ I think about,â a fourth wrote.
But others hit back and said Anzac Day was still important.
âMate â¦ itâs about remembering the sacrifice and loss of our mates â¦ lest we forget,â one wrote, adding, âI donât worry about [politicians] anymore grandstanding on the day. Itâs our day not theirs to remember our mates.â
Another said, âIt is tradition. It separates the fluff of ordinary living to reflect on sacrifice not only of the dead, of lives unlived, of the unfathomable grief but also of the living dealing with the trauma and moral injury of tooth and claw war. It is not a celebration which distracts.â
âI understand this perspective, but at the same time I ask myself â is there any harm in this form national reflection? I agree there have been some military follies following the absolute necessity of WWII, but would add that there is no guarantee that the next engagement is such,â a third wrote.
headline: Anzac Day: Twitter user says values âno longer reflectedâ, slams âillegalâ wars, US-China confrontation

chat_gpt_summary: SpaceX successfully launched its Starship rocket, the most powerful rocket ever built, at its Starbase facility in Texas. The rocket, designed to transport up to 100 people from Earth to the Moon and Mars, was not expected to survive, and SpaceX and the Federal Aviation Authority agreed on a splash down in the Gulf of Mexico with no recovery. However, the rocket exploded due to a technical hitch before landing in the Gulf of Mexico. The launch was streamed online, attracting over a million viewers. SpaceX founder Elon Musk congratulated the team on Twitter and said he had learned a lot for the next test launch in a few months.
article:
The most powerful rocket ever built was successfully launched today, before dramatically exploding due to a technical hitch.
Elon Musk, the founder of the company behind the rocket, SpaceX, had previously given the launch a 50/50 chance of success.
Mr Musk only wanted the rocket to get off the ground and not destroy the pad â two markers which SpaceX can successfully tick off, The Sun reports. 
But an âunscheduled disassemblyâ saw the rocket explode before landing in the Mexican Gulf, according to SpaceXâs current diagnosis.
âCongrats SpaceX team on an exciting test launch of Starship!,â Mr Musk wrote on Twitter soon after.
âLearned a lot for next test launch in a few months.â
Congrats @SpaceX team on an exciting test launch of Starship!Learned a lot for next test launch in a few months. pic.twitter.com/gswdFut1dK
The debut orbital launch of the $4.4 billion next-generation spacecraft took place at the SpaceXâs Starbase facility in Boca Chica, Texas.
Over one million people tuned into SpaceXâs lifestream of the test launch.
The 33-engine, nearly 123 metre tall, rocket is the eccentric billionaireâs biggest feat yet.
Starship has been designed to be the vehicle that makes humans interplanetary.
It is expected to take humans to the Moon through Nasaâs Artemis mission in 2025, and eventually to Mars sometime in the 2030s.
The mega-rocket is designed to transport up to 100 people from Earth to the Moon and Mars, so will eventually have its interior kitted out to support humans on months-long space voyages.
The team didnât bother decking out the interior as it would be on a Moon or Mars mission, as this edition of Starship was never intended to survive.
SpaceX and the USâ aerospace regulator the Federal Aviation Authority (FAA) agreed on a splash down in the Mexican Gulf ocean with no recovery.
All boaters were banned from the waters below prior to the launch, to make room for the rocketâs so-called âbelly flopâ into the sea.
Todayâs launch follows a failed attempt on Monday, which was due to a pressurisation issue, according to SpaceX at the time.
When Starship was scheduled to launch on Monday, the coastguard was forced to remove a boat from the water.
It is possible they would have received a hefty fine, or even had their boating licence revoked.
All rocket launches in the US are bound by environmental standards set by the FAA, which had previously stood in the way of the 33-engine rocketâs flight approval.
Instead of being recovered like it would be in future missions, whatâs left of Starship will join its predecessors at the bottom of the pacific, where old rocket parts now act as artificial coral reefs for marine life.
However, it is likely most of the rocket burned up in the atmosphere.
This story appeared in Teh Sun and is reproduced with permission.
headline: Elon Muskâs Starship rocket dramatically explodes seconds after launch

chat_gpt_summary: Perth, in Western Australia, has been named the city with the most stressed-out drivers in Australia, according to data collected by Budget Direct. Motorists in Fremantle accounted for 72.7% of stressed-out tweets, and seven out of the top ten roads that caused the most stress were in Western Australia. Queenslands coastal city of Mackay was also in equal pole position with Fremantle for having the most road rage, according to sentiment analysis tool TensiStrength. Dangerous driving, aggression, or rudeness from other motorists were the top reasons for road rage among surveyed Australians. Tasmanians were found to be the least irritable, while Queensland drivers were the most easily irritated.
article:
Drivers in one Australian city are getting hot under the collar more than anywhere else in the country despite there being a relatively low number of vehicles on the road. 
Perth, in Western Australia, might be renowned for its slow-moving charm, but it has recently been given the title of being home to the countryâs most stressed out drivers.
Motorists in Fremantle, about 20 kilometres southwest of the city, topped the charts for road raging drivers, with them accounting for 72.7 per cent of stressed out tweets, according to data collected by Budget Direct. 
Seven out of the top ten roads that caused the most stress were also in Western Australia, with Perthâs Reid Highway, Leach Highway and Welshpool Road scoring 100 per cent for stressful tweets. 
Behind them were WAâs Kwinana Freeway, Roe Highway, Tonkin Highway and the Mitchell Freeway, with the latter only over taken by Victoriaâs Nepean Highway. 
The roads that caused the fewest stressed tweets were Victoriaâs Tullamarine Freeway, the Dandenong Bypass, Warrigal Road, South Gippsland Highway and the West Gate Freeway. 
In equal pole position with Fremantle for having the most rage behind the wheel were drivers in Queenslandâs coastal city of Mackay. 
Sentiment analysis tool TensiStrength found drivers in Mackay were also behind 72.7 per cent of driving-related Twitter rage. 
Behind it was Parramatta in NSW, Darwin in the Northern Territory, Wagga Wagga in NSW, Brisbane in Queensland, Byron Bay in NSW, Bendigo and Ballarat in Victoria, and Townsville in Queensland. 
While NSW and Victoria have the biggest population density, they didnât even crack the top three in terms of states with the most angry driving tweets. 
Drivers in the Northern Territory were the worst offenders, with 63.2 per cent of driving-related tweets being stressed which according to Budget Direct, made it the state where drivers were âmost likely to spark road rageâ. 
Queensland was the next worse offender with 57.4 per cent, then the ACT, WA, NSW, South Australia, Victoria and Tasmania, respectively.
Drivers who were the least stressed on the road lived in NSWâs Newcastle, with their stress rate tweets just 44 per cent. 
Surveyed Australians indicated they were most peeved on the road by dangerous driving, aggression, or rudeness from other motorists. 
Tasmanians were found to be the least irritable, based on combining the situations that make people feel angry or annoyed. 
Meanwhile, Queensland drivers were the most easily ticked off.
More than 70 per cent of Australians surveyed said they had another driver shout, swear, or rudely gesture at them while on the road in the previous 12 months. 
Western Australians were the most likely to experience with road, with just 34 per cent saying they had not been a victim of road rage in the past year.
headline: Road rage: where the angriest drivers in Australia live

chat_gpt_summary: A photo of a fake "Chinese police car" with Chinese characters for "police" stencilled on the bonnet and "special police" along the side, and a Chinese police badge on the front door, has sparked outrage on social media. Reddit users quickly pointed out that the car was not actually affiliated with the Chinese government and that the markings were just decoration. While the cars may not be officially affiliated with the Chinese Communist Party, many online said they still served a purpose. The sightings sparked calls from the Greens at the time to tighten laws in the "grey area" around impersonating foreign police in Australia.
article:
A photo of a fake âChinese police carâ in Melbourneâs southeast has sparked outrage on social media.
The photo, uploaded to Reddit on Sunday, showed a dark Nissan sedan with Chinese characters for âpoliceâ stencilled on the bonnet and âspecial policeâ along the side, and a Chinese police badge on the front door.
âWhy is there a marked Chinese police car in the southeastern suburbs of Melbourne?â user MediocreStream wrote along with the photo.
Reddit users quickly pointed out that the car was not actually affiliated with the Chinese government and that the markings were just decoration.
âChinese students think itâs funny,â one wrote. âSource: Iâm from over there. Also: Itâs not funny. China is literally known to kidnap dissidents that arenât even Chinese citizens anymore from overseas.â
It comes after a bombshell investigation last year revealed China was secretly running illegal âpolice stationsâ overseas, including at least one in Sydney, in order to harass and spy on its citizens living on foreign soil.
While the cars may not be officially affiliated with the Chinese Communist Party, many online said they still served a purpose.
âItâs passed off as cosplay but is used to intimidate local Chinese communities as an extension of CCP power,â one Reddit user wrote.
But another said, âBelieve it or not, itâs just some young and stupid Chinese students showing off their stupidity. CCP intimidating programs usually involve threatening parents/children/relatives in China, not by showing some police cars. Source: I am Chinese Australian.â
A Victoria Police spokeswoman said she was unable to comment without more information about the time, date and location of the photo, and which station it was reported to.
Cars with similar markings were spotted in Adelaide and Perth in 2019, following rallies in Australia supporting Hong Kong pro-democracy demonstrators.
At the time, WA Police said officers spoke to the driver of one of the vehicles who âstated he purchased the decals onlineâ and âplaced them on his car as a jokeâ.
After violent clashes between pro-Hong Kong and pro-China protesters at Adelaideâs Rundle Mall, the organiser of the rally told the ABC people felt âintimidatedâ by the car spotted around the city.
Another car with Chinese police insignia spotted on the south coast of New South Wales Australia. A supporter took the photo and contacted my page pic.twitter.com/yRtcCIxeEg
âI think itâs highly inappropriate, especially when you pretend to represent a foreign law enforcement unit in a Western country,â she told the broadcaster.
âInitially we thought it was a bit of a joke. We did receive reports of it a few days before our protest â¦ Could this be an organised effort by the Chinese government or is it really just two completely separate instances of a prank?â
SA Police later tracked down the owner of the BMW. 
They would not reveal further details about the car or its owner but warned people to be careful if they were approached by anyone who arouses suspicion.
âWhile the markings on the BMW by themselves do not appear to constitute an offence, police are still making inquiries,â a police spokeswoman told The Advertiser.
The sightings sparked calls from the Greens at the time to tighten laws in the âgrey areaâ around impersonating foreign police in Australia.
Political activist Drew Pavlou shared the latest photo on Twitter, writing, âItâs illegal to impersonate Australian police officers but somehow itâs fine to impersonate foreign police in Australia. We need legislation making it illegal to impersonate foreign police otherwise it is too easy for the CCP to intimidate and terrorise dissidents in Australia.â
Later on Monday he posted another photo a Jeep 4WD with the same insignia, which he said had been spotted on the NSW south coast by a follower of his page.
âWhile we are not able to verify the authenticity of the images provided, police have previously looked into reports of vehicles with similar insignia and no offence was identified,â a NSW Police spokeswoman said.
frank.chung@news.com.au
headline: Fake âChinese police carâ spotted in Melbourne

chat_gpt_summary: Photos of a fake "Chinese police car" in Melbourne have gone viral on social media. The dark grey Nissan Altima sedan has Chinese characters for "police" stencilled on the bonnet and "special police" along the side, and a Chinese police badge on the front door. The car is an approved rideshare provider for platforms such as DiDi or Uber. Some social media users said the decals, which can be purchased online for around $10, were sometimes put on cars by Chinese students who "think it's funny". Others argued it was "passed off" as a joke but was "used to intimidate local Chinese communities as an extension of CCP power".
article:
More photos have emerged of a fake âChinese police carâ in Melbourne that sparked outrage on social media earlier this week.
The dark grey Nissan Altima sedan has Chinese characters for âpoliceâ stencilled on the bonnet and âspecial policeâ along the side, and a Chinese police badge on the front door.
A photo of the car in Melbourneâs southeast suburbs first went viral after being uploaded to Reddit on Sunday. 
âMore photos of same fake Chinese police car in Australia, this time spotted in West Melbourne,â political activist Drew Pavlou wrote on Twitter on Tuesday, sharing two pictures of the same car parked on Adderley St.
âIt is absolutely unacceptable to impersonate the Chinese police in Australia. Anonymous members of Chinese Australian community have sent this to me in fear.â
In another twist, a search of the Commercial Passenger Vehicles Victoria public register shows the car is an approved rideshare provider for platforms such as DiDi or Uber.
Some social media users said the decals, which can be purchased online for around $10, were sometimes put on cars by Chinese students who âthink itâs funnyâ.
But others argued even though the cars might not be officially affiliated with the Chinese Communist Party, it was âpassed offâ as a joke but was âused to intimidate local Chinese communities as an extension of CCP powerâ.
Victoria Police on Thursday confirmed it was âaware of images of a vehicle in Melbourne which appears to have been fitted out with various unofficial decals to give the appearance that it is a Chinese government vehicleâ.
âAt this time no specific offences have been detected and we have not received any reports in relation to the matter,â a spokesman said.
On Monday, Mr Pavlou shared another photo of a Jeep 4WD with the same insignia, which he said had been spotted on the NSW south coast by a follower of his page.
âWhile we are not able to verify the authenticity of the images provided, police have previously looked into reports of vehicles with similar insignia and no offence was identified,â a NSW Police spokeswoman said.
Cars with similar markings were spotted in Adelaide and Perth in 2019, following rallies in Australia supporting Hong Kong pro-democracy demonstrators.
At the time, WA Police said officers spoke to the driver of one of the vehicles who âstated he purchased the decals onlineâ and âplaced them on his car as a jokeâ.
In South Australia, after violent clashes between pro-Hong Kong and pro-China protesters at Adelaideâs Rundle Mall in 2019, the organiser of the rally told the ABC people felt âintimidatedâ by the car spotted around the city.
âI think itâs highly inappropriate, especially when you pretend to represent a foreign law enforcement unit in a Western country,â she told the broadcaster at the time.
âInitially we thought it was a bit of a joke. We did receive reports of it a few days before our protest â¦ Could this be an organised effort by the Chinese government or is it really just two completely separate instances of a prank?â
SA Police later tracked down the owner of the BMW. They would not reveal further details about the car or its owner but warned people to be careful if they were approached by anyone who arouses suspicion.
âWhile the markings on the BMW by themselves do not appear to constitute an offence, police are still making inquiries,â a police spokeswoman told The Advertiser.
The sightings sparked calls from the Greens at the time to tighten laws in the âgrey areaâ around impersonating foreign police in Australia.
It comes after a bombshell investigation last year revealed China was secretly running illegal âpolice stationsâ overseas, including at least one in Sydney, in order to harass and spy on its citizens living on foreign soil.
This week, authorities in the US arrested two men in connection with one such âsecret Chinese police stationâ, funded by Beijing, operating in the heart of New York City.
Two US citizens were arrested and charged with conspiring to act as agents of the Chinese government and obstructing justice in connection with the New York site.
Harry Lu Jianwang, 61, and Chen Jinping, 59, appeared in court in Brooklyn on Monday. The pair allegedly operated the police station in Manhattanâs Chinatown district which was shut down late last year.
China has said the âpolice stationsâ were actually âoverseas service centresâ where Chinese citizens in the US could renew documents such as driving licences.
But US officials have said they were set up at the behest of the Chinese Ministry of Public Security, claiming they undertook activities including identifying and harassing Chinese nationals in the US who were critical of the Communist Party regime.
Beijing hit back at the arrests and accused the US of âCold War thinkingâ â a common rebuke from Chinese officials.
âChina firmly opposes the US sideâs slandering, smearing, engaging in political manipulation, and maliciously concocting the so-called transnational repression narrative,â foreign ministry spokesman Wang Wenbin told reporters.
frank.chung@news.com.au
â with Benedict Brook
headline: Fake Chinese police car in Melbourne: More photos, Victoria Police issue statement

chat_gpt_summary: A conspiracy theorist has claimed that new U-turn bays installed on Narre Warren North Road, near Melbourne, are part of a sinister plan to restrict people to living in so-called 15-minute cities. These communities are designed to provide all essential services within walking or cycling distance, reducing dependence on cars and promoting healthy and sustainable living. However, some believe they are part of a plot to keep people under government control, and the new U-turn bays, along with pillars with weird blue lights, are intended as checkpoints. The theory has been criticised, with some pointing out the bays were added for safety reasons.
article:
A 15-minute city conspiracy theorist has made a bold claim about the construction of multiple U-turn bays on a Victorian road, as debate over the urban-planning concept continues globally. 
In a video shared to Twitter, an Australian podcaster filmed herself driving along Narre Warren North Road which is situated 38km southeast of Melbourne and is currently undergoing upgrades.
The roadworks commenced in 2020 and are part of the state governmentâs Big Build project which entailed the addition of extra lanes, installation of traffic lights and road safety improvements. 
Final asphalting works, guardrail and signage installations, line markings and vegetation works are currently underway with the project expected to be completed by mid this year.
In line with the project, extra U-turn bays were created for safer and easier access to streets adjacent to the main road. 
However, the conspiracy theorist believes these turnaround lanes have been installed to serve a more dire purpose, believing more 15-minute or 20-minute cities are set to pop up in the future. 
Also known as smart cities, the notion is an urban development idea where everything you need access to is located within a short distance.
This may include schools, shops, GP clinics and even the office or your place of work, all within the same zone. 
The concept is the brainchild of Franco-Colombian urbanist Carlos Moreno who came up with the idea to prompt more sustainable, convenient and healthier living.
Key elements of the theory include keeping essential services close, creating a sense of community solidarity and inspiring green urban living.
However, not all are convinced, with some conspiracists comparing the theory to a Stalin-style plot to keep people in lockdown or under the governmentâs control.
In the case of the woman who filmed herself driving along Narre Warren North Road, she believes the road upgrade project will become a âCheckpoint Charlieâ for smart cities.
âThis used to be a country road. Not only are they building wires and towers but theyâre also putting in interestingly three or four U-turn opportunities,â she explained in the video.
âI guess thatâs because youâll get a warning â youâre about to leave your 20-minute city, your district, your zone (and itâs your) last chance to turn back obviously before the fines start.â
As she drives further down the road, the woman highlights three âpillars with weird blue lightsâ positioned in the middle of the road next to several parked tradie cars. 
âUp here to the right youâll see three bollards â¦ I think this right here is the checkpoint,â she claims in the video. 
âThereâs now all of these opportunities to pull a U-turn and go back the way you came.
âIn the future, going out to the countryside is not something theyâre going to allow you to do without you handing over your money.â
The tweet, which has received over 1.3 million views and 692 likes, has amassed debate over the urban planning concept online with many arguing the woman has taken her thoughts âtoo farâ.
âThis is ridiculous. U-turns, or access for emergency vehicles? Or both? Forget something and need to go back home? A U-turn is handy. This is not a nefarious thing,â one person tweeted.
â15 minute (cities) have been around for ages and have nothing to do with climate change lockdowns. Itâs literally about ease of access and reducing dependency on cars,â a second person said.
âNo one is preventing you from going further away in your car.â
A third comment read: âThe wires reduce accidents. The breaks in the wire provide access points for emergency vehicles to turn. 
âThese safety measures can be found on roads around Australia.â
Meanwhile, one man suggested the push for electric vehicles (EV) over petrol cars could be another excuse to restrict people to their âzoneâ.
âIâm thinking this is one of the major reasons they want EV versus gas vehicles, fewer and less range!â he said. 
The debate online follows huge rallies around the world as conspiracy theorists criticise the concept, which has already come into effect in 16 cities globally including Paris and Shanghai. 
Edmonton Canada was also another city which tried to implement the idea, however received backlash from its residents.
âYou will spend 90 per cent of your life in this 15-minute area as they are monitoring your carbon footprint,â a flyer circulating warned.
Meanwhile, those who agree with the theory have slammed its critics, including registered nurse Christopher Patterson and national radio broadcaster Triple J Hack. 
âThere are a lot of noted intellectuals on TikTok telling me I should be suspicious of convenience,â Triple J Hack reporter Shalailah Medhora said in a radio package last month. 
Dr Patterson, who is also a University of Wollongong lecturer, explained there are numerous health benefits to the theory that many sceptics are overlooking.
âThe main (benefit) is giving people back their freedom (and) time,â Dr Patterson said.
âThe time you get back you could put into (your) health or sitting in green spaces to connect back with your community and family.â
headline: 15-minute cities: Womanâs bizarre claim about Victorian road project

chat_gpt_summary: Former Fox News host Tucker Carlson announced that he is reviving his show on Twitter, describing it as "the last remaining platform in the world" to allow free speech. Carlson offered few details but promised a "new version of the show weve been doing for the last six and a half years". His pivot to Twitter comes after the site has become more welcoming to mostly conservative accounts previously banned for spreading hate speech and disinformation under Elon Musks new direction. It's unclear what Carlson's plans mean for his remaining contract with Fox, which runs until 2025.
article: Tucker Carlson will be reviving his show on Twitter, after being abruptly dismissed from Fox News last month. In a tweet captioned âWeâre back,â Carlson on Tuesday shared a video discussing his next moves. The former host said he would be taking his show to Twitter, which he described as âthe last remaining platform in the worldâ to allow free speech. Carlson offered few details but promised a ânew version of the show weâve been doing for the last six and a half yearsâ. He did not mention when the show may air. But he did echo many of the same points he has often asserted: that the so-called mainstream media is full of propaganda and lies. âTwitter is not a partisan site, everybodyâs allowed here and we think thatâs a good thing,â he said. âAnd yet, for the most part, the news that you see analyzed on Twitter comes from media organizations that are themselves thinly disguised propaganda outlets.â Carlsonâs pivot to Twitter comes after the site has become more welcoming to mostly conservative accounts previously banned for spreading hate speech and disinformation under Elon Muskâs new direction. The billionaire took over the site in October 2022 and promptly allowed previously banished accounts to return, including that of Donald Trump. Carlson did not make any mention of Musk in his video. Twitter responded to a request for comment with a poop emoji. Musk, who has referred to himself as a âfree speech absolutistâ, tweeted on Tuesday: âWe have not signed a deal of any kind whatsoever. Tucker is subject to the same rules & rewards of all content creators.â Itâs unclear what Carlsonâs plans mean for his remaining contract with Fox, which runs until 2025. Typically, television companies include a no-compete clause when someone leaves the air. Axios reported on Tuesday that Carlsonâs lawyers sent a letter to Fox accusing the network of fraud and breach of contract. The letter reportedly argued that the noncompete provision in Carlsonâs contract with the network is no longer valid. Fox and and a representative for Carlson did not immediately respond to a request for comment. During the Trump presidency, Carlson had become one of the most successful hosts on the network, garnering a dedicated following while spouting xenophobic and racist rhetoric on his show. His show was terminated last month, in the aftermath of the $787.5m settlement of a $1.6bn defamation lawsuit brought by Dominion Voting Systems, over the broadcast of Donald Trumpâs lies about voter fraud in his 2020 presidential race defeat by Joe Biden. Fox News has not commented on the reason for Carlson going off air. But multiple outlets have reported that abusive comments about executives contributed to the decision. Sources close to Carlson have disputed that. Since his departure, leaked videos and text message have shown Carlson making misogynistic and insinuating remarks; saying the Fox Nation streaming channel âsucksâ; and calling a Dominion lawyer a âslimy motherfuckerâ. Following Carlsonâs departure from Fox News, his former employers have replaced his popular show with an interim program called Fox News Tonight, which features rotating pundits from the network until a replacement can be found. The Associated Press contributed reporting
headline: Tucker Carlson to revive show on Twitter after Fox News dismissal

chat_gpt_summary: Twitter has admitted to a privacy breach that allowed tweets meant only for users' Circles to be seen by the wider site. The feature enables users to share private thoughts with a selected list of friends, but a security incident earlier this year allowed tweets to be viewed by those outside of the Circle. For weeks, users had been reporting Circles tweets receiving likes and views from accounts that should not have been able to see them. The issue was eventually identified and fixed by the Twitter security team. However, Twitter did not address reports that similar privacy breaches were occurring to "private" accounts.
article: A privacy breach at Twitter published tweets that were never supposed to be seen by anyone but the posterâs closest friends to the site at large, the company has admitted after weeks of stonewalling reports. The siteâs Circles feature allows users to set an exclusive list of friends and post tweets that only they can read. Similar to Instagramâs Close Friends setting, it allows users to share private thoughts, explicit images or unprofessional statements without risking sharing them with their wider network. But, in an email to affected users seen by the Guardian, Twitter admitted tweets had escaped this containment. âA security incident that occurred earlier this year,â the email says, âmay have allowed users outside of your Twitter Circle to see tweets that should have otherwise been limited to the Circle to which you were posting.â For weeks, users had been reporting Circles tweets receiving likes and views from accounts that should not have been able to see them. Twitter, whose press office has been largely destaffed and set to autoreply to requests for comment with a poo emoji, did not acknowledge the reports. Now, the company says the issue âwas identified by our security team and immediately fixed so that these tweets were no longer visible outside of your Circleâ. âTwitter is committed to protecting the privacy of the people who use our service, and we understand the risks that an incident like this can introduce and we deeply regret this happened,â the company said. The email did not address separate reports that similar privacy breaches were occurring to âprivateâ accounts, whose tweets should not be displayed to anyone save for their approved followers. Since Elon Musk acquired the company in late 2022, Twitter has shed at least 60% of its headcount, with wave after wave of layoffs stripping teams to the bone. Over the same period, the site has experienced numerous outages, leading Musk to declare that it would not be stable until a âcomplete rewriteâ of the siteâs underlying code was completed. Similar cost-cutting measures have led the service to stop paying bills for office space, janitorial supplies and web hosting, with mixed success. Even as Musk attempted to institute a full return-to-the-office mandate, Twitter employees in countries including Singapore and London faced eviction from their workplaces over unpaid rent bills. More pressingly, layoffs in site-wide moderation teams have opened the company up to massive fines in countries including Germany, where effective content moderation is a legal requirement. The âsystematic failureâ of the social network to moderate well allows for fines of up to â¬50m (Â£44m) a case, the German lawyer Chan-jo Jun told TechCrunch last month.
headline: Twitter admits to âsecurity incidentâ involving Circles tweets

chat_gpt_summary: The Guardian's Rachel Aroesti recommends five podcasts about planet Earth, starting with Naturebang, which looks at natural phenomena and asks how we can apply them to human society. Your Place or Mine sees guests trying to convince presenter Shaun Keaveny that their chosen location is worth a visit. The Deep-Sea Podcast aims to overhaul the stereotype of the deep-sea as a terrifying, unknowable place, while Trees A Crowd explores 56 types of British trees and the people whose work is deeply entrenched in the natural world. Armchair Explorer allows listeners to traverse the wildest corners of the earth from their sofa.
article: Picks of the week Pod Save the UK Widely available, episodes weekly Given its hosts, this take on the popular US leftwing look at politics Pod Save America is inevitably great. Nish Kumar is one of our foremost political satirists and Guardian journalist Coco Khan is unfailingly witty about current affairs. Itâs less a play for laughs than genuine analysis thatâs full of withering putdowns on topics such as the immigration bill. Or as Khan puts it: âI love being oppressed by someone who looks like me!â Alexi Duggins Flipping the Bird: Elon vs Twitter Widely available, episodes weekly If youâve been wondering whatâs going on at Twitter, this new podcast from the makers of WeCrashed aims to investigate. From sackings to slowdowns, David Brown asks what Elon Muskâs motivation is and what will be left once heâs done with the social media platform. âIt felt like everything was descending into chaos,â offers one ex-employee in a juicy interview. Hannah Verdier Proper Class Widely available, episodes weekly The podcast that celebrates all things working-class returns, with Laura Checkley and Hannah Chissick back at the helm. The first guest is comedian Susan Wokoma, who gets nostalgic about Elephant and Castle shopping centre. Future guests include Vicky McClure. Hollie Richardson Who Robs a Banksy? Widely available, episodes weekly Who would âkidnapâ a Banksy sculpture and hold it to ransom, given how well-loved its creator is? âThatâs such a fucking wanky, middle-class question!â exclaims artist (and former porn actor/rave organiser) Andy Link in this showâs intro. Its tale of the resulting 20-year battle is incredibly colourful, due in no small part to what an utterly compelling voice Link is. AD Past, Present, Future Widely available, episodes weekly David Runcimanâs new podcast about the history of ideas gets off to a flying start with author Ian McEwan picking what he calls the best political novel: Italo Calvinoâs The Watcher. Itâs fascinating to hear him talk about the book that will âget you through a two-hour train rideâ. Guests coming up include Zadie Smith, John Lanchester and Lea Ypi. HV Thereâs a podcast for that This week, Rachel Aroesti chooses five of the best podcasts about planet Earth, from a deep dive into our oceans to an experiential travel adventure Naturebang Presented by Becky Ripley and Emily Knight, two BBC Radio 4 documentary producers, Naturebang is â unsurprisingly â a show about nature and wildlife. Yet itâs one that is particularly well-suited to those who donât normally gravitate towards straightforward science documentaries: each episode focuses on a natural phenomena and then asks how we might apply it to human society. Looking at bull elephants provides an opportunity to think about fatherhood; an investigation into the busyness of ants leads to a discussion of leisure time; and the traditions of the Great Tit allow for a meditation on cultural orthodoxy and immigration. Utterly fascinating, even if biology isnât really your thing. Your Place or Mine Part fact-packed travel guide, part gentle parlour game, this pod sees guests attempt to convince presenter Shaun Keaveny that their chosen location is well worth a visit. Some of the places pitched are classic holiday destinations, but others are locales you may never have considered: comedian Daliso Chaponda suggests Lilongwe in Malawi; chef Ching He Huang chooses Taipei; actor Aatif Nawaz goes for Lahore. Despite the chat being divided into rather dry-sounding sections â weather, hazards, landmarks and travel â our wisecracking host and his knowledgeable sidekick, historian and geographer Iszi Lawrence, ensure that it is always shot through with silliness and fun. The Deep-Sea Podcast Considering that 71% of our planetâs surface is covered in water, this show may just be the most on-topic of all when it comes to podcasts about the earth. Hosted by long-time pals Dr Alan Jamieson, a world authority on the deepest levels of our oceans, and Dr Thomas Linley â an expert in deep-sea fish â this accessible and often exhilarating series covers topics from bioluminescence to seamounts in an attempt to overhaul the stereotype of the deep-sea as a terrifying, unknowable place. The pair have also attracted some surprisingly starry guests, including Titanic director and avid sea explorer James Cameron. Trees A Crowd The passion project of actor David Oakes (who can be seen playing Earl Godwin in Netflixâs Vikings: Valhalla), this show is indeed a detailed exploration of Britainâs trees â 56 different types of them, to be exact, from the much-worshipped Rowan to the anti-inflammatory Dogwood, the gloriously pink Spindle to the giant Aspen â but itâs also much more than that. The affable Oakes is frequently joined by those whose work is deeply entrenched in the natural world, including artists, zoologists, wildlife photographers, adventurers and activists, leading to conversations that feel like a brain-cleansing break from technology-riddled modern life. Armchair Explorer Traverse the wildest corners of the earth from your sofa with the help of this podcast from travel writer Aaron Millar, who encourages listeners to live vicariously through some of our most fearless explorers. Each episode is dedicated to an extraordinary adventure or adventurer: hear about Levison Woodâs perilous journey through the heart of the Middle East, Rebecca Stephensâ conquering of the Seven Summits, and comedian Andy Smartâs 72,000 miles of pan-European hitchhiking. Not all of the locations are far-flung, however â Nick Huntâs recollections of a spooky hike in Scotlandâs Cairngorms proves you can push the boundaries of travel relatively close to home. Why not try â¦ A tale of âsubterfuge and secrecyâ â and a man who may have inspired 007 â in Cover Up: Ministry of Secrets. Stories from the intersection of race and climate justice in a new series of Temperature Check. Comic Omid Djalili has more fun with misheard tales in the second run of Please Tell Me a Story. If you want to read the complete version of the newsletter please subscribe to receive Hear Here in your inbox every Thursday
headline: Best podcasts of the week: What really happened when Elon Musk took over Twitter

chat_gpt_summary: Twitter will soon enable media publishers to charge users on a per-article basis with one click, according to CEO Elon Musk. The feature will allow users who do not subscribe monthly to pay a higher per-article price for occasional articles. Musk also announced that Twitter will take a 10% cut on content subscriptions after the first year, which include long-form text and hours-long video. These changes come as Musk tries to boost revenue at Twitter, which saw a drop in advertising income last year. However, there are concerns about Twitter's ability to comply with upcoming European standards, which could lead to fines and temporary suspension of service for breaches.
article: Twitter CEO Elon Musk said on Saturday that the social media platform will allow media publishers to charge users on a per-article basis with one click, calling it a win for both the public and media organisations. The feature, to be rolled out in May, will enable users who do not âsign up for a monthly subscription to pay a higher per article price for when they want to read an occasional articleâ, billionaire owner Musk tweeted. On Friday, Musk had said that Twitter will take a 10% cut on content subscriptions after the first year, noting that the company will not take a cut for the first 12 months. These subscriptions include long-form text and hours-long video. Since taking over the social media firm in October, Musk has been bringing in changes to try to boost revenue at Twitter after the social media platform saw advertising income drop last year in the run-up to his on-again-off-again acquisition that closed. Under Muskâs ownership Twitter has reduced its workforce from 7,500 people to about 1,500, leading to fears that moderation standards and its ability to comply with upcoming European standards would suffer as a consequence. Twitter has been repeatedly warned that it is not ready for a new European Union regulatory regime for monitoring digital platforms, with breaches risking a fine of 6% of global turnover and, in the most extreme cases, a temporary suspension of the service. Under the rules for large platforms, they must carry out annual risk assessments outlining the risks of harmful content such as disinformation, misogyny, harms to children and election manipulation. The moderation systems and measures put in place to mitigate those risks will also be checked by the EU. Platforms will also be banned from building profiles of child users for companies to target them with ads. Those platforms that can be reached by minors must also put in place measures to protect their privacy and keep them safe. Users must also be able to report illegal content easily. With Reuters
headline: Twitter to let publishers charge users per article read, says Elon Musk

chat_gpt_summary: "The Flash" movie, which was previously rumored to be scrapped due to star Ezra Miller's legal and reputational issues, has now been called one of the greatest superhero movies of all time by press and cinema owners at Las Vegas' CinemaCon. The movie, which is loosely based on the Flashpoint comic book run, will reset the DC multiverse and feature two versions of The Flash played by Miller, along with the return of Michael Keaton and Ben Affleck as Batman and Sasha Calle as Supergirl. The film is expected to "break the universe" and change the past, with potential ramifications for DC that go beyond what has been seen in advance publicity.
article: What a difference a few months makes. Talk as recently as September was that Andy Muschiettiâs The Flash might be scrapped due to the legal and reputational difficulties faced by star Ezra Miller. Flash forward to the present day, and it is being called one of the greatest superhero movies of all time following a screening for press and cinema owners at Las Vegasâ CinemaCon this week. Letâs just put that into perspective. According to the assembled geekerati (who have only been given permission to tweet at this time), this is a movie that might just be up there with The Dark Knight, the original Superman, Black Panther, Avengers: Endgame and Spider-Man: Into the Spider-Verse. And itâs made not by all-conquering Marvel but Warner Bros-owned DC. This is the studio that gave us the original Suicide Squad movie, Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice and Justice League, all films that made even comic book fans wonder if they actually liked superhero films. It arrives with a new regime at DC Studios, led by former Marvel man James Gunn, with the promise that it will reset the DC multiverse in a way that allows us to forget everything weâve seen before. Or at least, all the stuff Gunn doesnât fancy moving forward with. The Flash is loosely based on the seminal Flashpoint comic book run, which saw Barry Allen waking up in an alternate reality where Superman is a frightened weakling, Batman is Thomas Wayne (Bruceâs dad) and the Amazons and Atlanteans are destructive forces who seem to be engaged in perpetual war. While Muschiettiâs film is likely to cherry-pick from its source material, we do know that Miller will play two versions of The Flash (in the comics, the second Flash was the Reverse-Flash: in the film it will be a Flash from an alternate timeline). Michael Keaton will return to the role of the caped crusader, and so will Ben Affleck, while Sasha Calle is reportedly a revelation as Kara Zor-El/Supergirl. A new trailer, released this week with impeccable timing, shows us that the new film will see Allen âbreaking the universeâ and changing the past. Itâs likely there will be ramifications for DC that go way beyond what weâve yet seen in advance publicity. Frankly, this looks epic! The wonderful thing about multiverse movies is that they are primed and ready to explain away all kinds of superhero universe bad planning (of which there has been a lot at DC since 2013âs Man of Steel ushered in the Zack Snyder era) as simply the result of clashing alternate timelines. Moreover, if the new Supergirl does end up wowing audiences, or Michael Shannonâs General Zod gets the opportunity to shake the DC foundations that he should have received a decade ago, there is ample opportunity to bring them back in future episodes. Rumour is this will be Batfleckâs final turn in the cape and cowl, but if heâs well received â well thereâs no reason that has to be set in stone. Perhaps that skulking, meat-headed guy with the guns from Dawn of Justice was just a bad Bruce Wayne from another universe where everythingâs back to front and audiences love to turn up in their gazillions to watch really terrible movies. There are other reasons to be cheerful here. If the hype turns out to be true, The Flash may just present a much-needed blueprint for how to represent Batman (Batmen?) in ensemble comic book movies, a feat that nobody has ever really successfully achieved before (with the possible exception of Snyderâs directorâs cut of Justice League). Now all we need is for Robert Pattinsonâs dark knight to turn up, and it could be time to really get this superhero party started.
headline: âOne of the best superhero movies everâ: can The Flash live up to the Twitter hype?

chat_gpt_summary: Twitter, along with 16 other major digital platforms including YouTube, Facebook, and TikTok, will face the toughest level of scrutiny under a new European Union regulatory regime. The Elon Musk-owned platform has been designated a "very large online platform" under the bloc's Digital Services Act, and it has been warned that it is unprepared for the new rules. The DSA requires compliance measures such as publishing an independent audit of its compliance with the legislation. Failure to comply with the act could result in fines of up to 6% of global turnover and, in extreme cases, a temporary suspension of service. The designated companies now have four months to comply with the act's obligations.
article: Twitter is among the tech firms that will face the toughest level of scrutiny under a new European Union regulatory regime for monitoring digital platforms, after warnings from Brussels that the Elon Musk-owned platform is unprepared for the new rules. The company, which Musk bought in October 2022, has been designated a âvery large online platformâ under the blocâs Digital Services Act, which means complying with measures such as publishing an independent audit of its compliance with the legislation. It will be joined by 16 other major names including YouTube, Facebook, Instagram, Wikipedia, Snapchat and TikTok. Twitter has been repeatedly warned that it is not ready for the new rules, with breaches risking a fine of 6% of global turnover and, in the most extreme cases, a temporary suspension of the service. Under Muskâs ownership Twitter has reduced its workforce from 7,500 people to about 1,500, leading to fears that moderation standards and its ability to comply with the act would suffer as a consequence. In November last year, the EUâs commissioner for the internal market, Thierry Breton, implied that Twitter was in danger of non-compliance with the act, telling Musk that the company will have to raise its efforts to âpass the gradeâ. Breton added that Musk had âhuge work aheadâ to comply with the DSA. However, a readout of the November meeting with Musk added that the Tesla CEO had âcommitted to complyâ with the DSA. In January, Breton again urged Musk to âprogress towards full compliance with the DSAâ, with Musk replying that the DSAâs goals of transparency, accountability and accurate information were aligned with Twitterâs. Under the rules for large platforms, they must carry out annual risk assessments outlining the risks of harmful content such as disinformation, misogyny, harms to children and election manipulation. The moderation systems and measures put in place to mitigate those risks will also be checked by the EU. The big platforms will also have to publish an independent audit of their compliance with the DSA, as well as how many people they employ in content moderation. They must also provide details of their algorithms and allow independent researchers to monitor compliance with the act. Platforms will also be banned from building profiles of child users for companies to target them with ads. Those platforms that can be reached by minors must also put in place measures to protect their privacy and keep them safe. Users must also be able to report illegal content easily. The European Commission, the EUâs executive arm, confirmed Twitterâs designation as a VLOP on Tuesday, while Google and Microsoftâs Bing will also have to comply with similarly strict regulations after being designated âvery large search enginesâ. Tech platforms must reach at least 45 million monthly active users in the EU in order to be designated VLOPs or VLSEs. There are also regulations for smaller platforms such as publishing transparent terms and conditions. Breton said on Tuesday the âcountdown is startingâ for the companies designated with special status under the act. âToday is the D(SA)-Day for digital regulation,â he said. Guillaume Couneson, a partner at law firm Linklaters, said complying with the VLOP and VLSE provisions was a âchallenge for everyoneâ and not just Twitter. The designated companies now have four months to comply with the actâs obligations including the first annual risk assessment. âIt is not a long period of time to implement strict and in some cases burdensome obligations,â said Couneson.
headline: âUnpreparedâ Twitter among tech firms to face tough new EU digital rules

chat_gpt_summary: Twitter has given a verified gold tick to far-right political organisation Britain First and its leader Paul Golding, who was jailed in 2018 for religiously aggravated harassment. The move came after a shake-up of Twitter's verification system under new owner Elon Musk.
