Twitter is charging UK entities £1,140 a month for official gold tick status, while personal accounts are being charged £9.60 for a blue tick. Twitter's new paid-for verification system encountered more difficulties on Monday as the platform gave a gold tick to a fake Disney account, in the latest example of rogue actors launching "approved" parodies.
article: Twitter has given a gold tick to Britain First, the far right political organisation, after a shake-up of its verification system under new owner Elon Musk. The partyâs leader, Paul Golding, has also received a blue tick for his account, which means that his posts will be boosted in conversations and will be ranked higher in user searches. Golding was jailed in 2018 for religiously aggravated harassment. Twitterâs gold tick designates a verified organisation that is a business or non-profit entity, according to the platformâs website. Twitter is charging UK entities Â£1,140 a month for official gold tick status, while personal accounts are being charged Â£9.60 for a blue tick. Britain First, whose policies include prison terms for âany attempt to alter the demographic makeup of the British Islesâ, had its account suspended in 2017, but it was allowed back on to the platform after Muskâs takeover last year. The Center for Countering Digital Hate (CCDH), a campaign group, accused Twitter of promoting extreme content to drive controversy and user engagement with the aim of generating more revenue. âTwitter is now a topsy-turvy world where users have been told to ignore information supplied by good, reliable actors and pay undue attention to the bottom-feeders who want to spread hate, misinformation and sow division,â said Imran Ahmed, CEO of CCDH. âItâs harder and harder to know what to trust on the platform, while bad actors are put on a pedestal.â The Britain First account has 12,700 followers and Goldingâs has 45,300. Twitterâs new paid-for verification system encountered more difficulties on Monday as the platform gave a gold tick to a fake Disney account, in the latest example of rogue actors launching âapprovedâ parodies. An account with the handle @DisneyJuniorUK secured a gold tick on Monday morning. The account was suspended at 11.30am BST, but not before announcing that the cult animation series South Park was âofficially heading to Disney Juniorâ. It was not clear whether the holder of the account â which had 2,087 followers â paid the $1,000-a-month cost for the tick or was given it for free. This has been happening with blue ticks for large personal accounts following the launch of a cull last week for legacy accounts that had not paid for verification. However, the account holder indicated surprise at receiving a tick on Monday, tweeting âNo fucking wayâ and âThis isnât actually real rightâ. The user that claimed to be running the fake Disney account, @7virtues_, had tweeted a poll on Monday asking whether to deactivate the account âso I donât get murked by the Disney hitmenâ. Twitterâs previous attempt at charging for verification under new owner Elon Musk was pulled in November last year after the opportunity to pay for a verified account was hijacked by pranksters. A fake account representing pharmaceutical firm Eli Lilly â which had paid for verification â announced free insulin, while the gaming firm Nintendo and the pope were among the other victims of impersonators. The impersonation issue was one of the drivers behind a fall in advertising revenue on Twitter since Muskâs October 2022 takeover. Advertising accounted for 90% of Twitterâs $5bn in annual revenue before the deal, and Musk revealed in February that he expects turnover at the company to be less than $3bn this year, suggesting a slump in its ad business. Disney declined to comment. It is understood that Disney, which stopped broadcasting the Disney Junior UK channel in 2020 and pulled the related Twitter handle at the same time, had contacted Twitter on Monday morning as soon at it was made aware of the account. A request for comment from Twitterâs press office on the Britain First and Disney Junior UK accounts was met with an automatically generated poo emoji, as is now standard for all journalistic queries directed at the company.
headline: Far-right Britain First party given Twitter gold tick

chat_gpt_summary: Twitter has reinstated the "blue tick" verification status for celebrity users of its social network, including those who did not pay for it. The decision to do so without distinguishing between paid-for and free users has led to criticism of false advertising, as the boilerplate disclaimer for those users inaccurately describes their status as being granted "because they are subscribed to Twitter Blue". The move to strip all "legacy" users of the blue checkmark that indicated their account was genuine had unforeseen consequences, with fewer than 500 of the 400,000 legacy users signing up to the subscription fee.
article: Twitter has again U-turned over its verification policy, restoring the âblue tickâ free of charge to celebrity users of the social network. But the siteâs decision to reinstate the âverifiedâ status without distinguishing between paid-for and free users has led to criticism for false advertising, since the boilerplate disclaimer for those users inaccurately describes their status as being granted âbecause they are subscribed to Twitter Blueâ. The social network ended its old verification system on Friday 20 April, a date apparently chosen because of its significance in cannabis culture, and in the process stripped all âlegacyâ users of the blue checkmark that indicated their account was genuine. But the move, which left only those users who had paid for Twitterâs subscription service with a checkmark, had unforeseen consequences for Elon Musk, the social networkâs owner and chief executive. Rather than encouraging pre-existing verified users to splash out the subscription fee, which starts at $8 a month, the overwhelming majority simply continued using the site. Public data shows that fewer than 500 of the 400,000 legacy users signed up, and almost as many users cancelled their subscription at the same time, for a net revenue increase of less than $300 a month. As a result, a blue tick on the social network rapidly came to mark out a user as paying for the privilege, leading to a grassroots campaign to âblock the blueâ, with users committing to blocking subscribers on sight. Not every user with a blue tick had paid for it themselves, however. On Friday, Musk revealed that three had received one for free: Stephen King, LeBron James and William Shatner. Over the weekend, that number drastically increased, with almost every celebrity user with more than 1 million followers receiving a new blue tick (with one notable exception: Jack Dorsey, the co-founder of Twitter and of the decentralised Twitter competitor Bluesky, who did not get a new verification mark). The rapid loss of social credibility for having such a mark, however, led many users to disclaim their new status. Re-verified users including the Guardian columnist Owen Jones, the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and Twitter comic dril all revealed that their new status had come without them paying for or requesting it. Other users have been unable to issue such statements. The actor Paul Walker, who died in 2013, the celebrity chef Anthony Bourdain, who died in 2018, and the Saudi journalist Jamal Khashoggi, who was murdered by the Saudi state that same year, were all given âpaid-forâ verification. Some, including Jones and dril, wondered whether doing so, and marking their accounts as having âpaid forâ a service they did not, was plausibly illegal. âIsnât it some form of defamation to falsely make it look like people have purchased a product associated with being a total loser,â asked Jones. (Dril joked that Musk had âfired the people in charge of telling him itâs illegalâ.) English law protects celebrities against the tort of âpassing offâ, when individualsâ goodwill is harmed through misrepresentation. According to the solicitors Lewis Silkin, âin 2002, a landmark case established beyond doubt that celebrities can use passing off to protect the goodwill in their celebrity. Racing driver Eddie Irvine successfully sued TalkSport over a direct mailing piece which featured a photograph of him holding a portable radio which had the TalkSport name and logo on it. In fact, Irvine had been holding a mobile phone at the time the photo had been taken, but it had been digitally manipulated to replace the phone with the radio. âThe judge decided that the advertisement clearly gave rise to a false impression of endorsement of the radio station by Irvine, and that the law of passing off should protect him from this infringement of his goodwill.â A request for comment to Twitter went unanswered save for the companyâs standard automatic response, an emoji of a smiling poo.
headline: Twitter restores âblue tickâ free of charge to celebrities in U-turn

chat_gpt_summary: Twitter's new policy for verified accounts has caused chaos on the website, with impersonation and false information running rampant and few people signing up for the service the changes were meant to promote. Under the new Twitter Blue program, individual users can pay $8 per month for a blue checkmark while organizations pay upwards of $1,000 monthly. The change has shifted the meaning of the check from an account that has been independently verified to one that paid a premium to help their tweets be seen by more people. Despite Twitter's aggressive promotion of the program, few additional sign-ups under the new rules have been seen.
article: Friday marked the first full day Twitterâs new policies for verified accounts were applied â and the results were not pretty. Twenty-four hours after blue checkmarks began to disappear from formerly verified Twitter accounts, chaos reigned on the website, with impersonation and false information running rampant and few people signing up for the service the changes were meant to promote. The move came under new owner Elon Musk, who has pledged to make the struggling social media firm profitable by any means necessary â in this case, attempting to force users to pay for verification services that were previously free. Under the original blue-check system, Twitter had roughly 400,000 verified usersand checks meant that Twitter had verified that users were who they said they were. Under the new Twitter Blue program, individual users can pay $8 per month for a blue checkmark while organizations pay upwards of $1,000 monthly. The change has shifted the meaning of the check from an account that has been independently verified to one that paid a premium to help their tweets be seen by more people. The rollout â and its results â have been chaotic. Hereâs where things stood on Friday: Elon taketh and he giveth away Several high profile Twitter users and celebrities lost their verification status on Thursday, including BeyoncÃ©, Pope Francis, and Oprah Winfrey. President Donald Trump â who has not tweeted since he was allowed to return to the platform after being banned â has also been unverified. Some celebrity users â including basketball star LeBron James, author Stephen King and Star Trekâs William Shatner â pledged not to join Twitter Blue. All three still had blue checks on Friday after Musk said he paid for them himself. âMy Twitter account says Iâve subscribed to Twitter Blue. I havenât. My Twitter account says Iâve given a phone number. I havenât,â wrote Stephen King on Twitter. âYouâre welcome namaste,â replied Musk, who apparently gave it to the author for free. âVerifiedâ loses meaning Blue checks for users on Friday included a popup message noting the account âis verified because they are subscribed to Twitter Blue and verified their phone numberâ. But verifying a phone number simply means that the user has a phone number and they verified that they have access to it â it does not confirm the personâs identity, raising concern about the veracity of such accounts. Many took advantage of the new verification-free world on Twitter by changing their profile pictures and names to impersonate prominent figures, from Amazon CEO Jeff Bezos to the late Arizona Senator, John McCain. Others made prank tweets posing as legitimate news accounts to spread misinformation making fun of Musk. The ability to pose as legitimate organizations and figures raised concerns that Twitter could lose its status as a platform for getting accurate, up-to-date information from authentic sources, including in emergencies. Fake accounts claiming to represent the Chicago mayor Lori Lightfoot, Chicagoâs department of transportation and the Illinois department of transportation all began sharing messages early Friday falsely claiming that the cityâs Lake Shore Drive â a major thoroughfare â would close to private traffic starting next month. The genuine accounts for Lightfoot and the transportation agencies did not have a blue or gray check mark as of Friday. Lightfootâs office said the city is aware of the fake accounts and âworking with Twitter to resolve this matterâ. At least one was suspended Friday. And while is Twitter now offering gold checks for âverified organizationsâ and gray checks for government organizations and their affiliates, it was not always clear why some accounts had them Friday and others did not. Accounts from major transit systems in cities such as Paris and San Francisco as well as official weather trackers had lost their verification status as of Friday afternoon. Many impacted agencies said they were awaiting more clarity from Twitter, which has sharply curtailed its staff since Musk bought the San Francisco company for $44bn last year. Sloppy execution, few sign-ups The roll out of Twitter Blue â from user response to its execution â has been a flop. Some pointed out that it appears the blue checkmarks were not fully removed from Twitterâs system, flickering on and off for days before removal. Meanwhile, Twitter is continuing to push the program aggressively, telling advertisers that they are required to subscribe to Twitter Blue in order to continue running ads â at a time when cash flow from Twitterâs top advertisers has shrunk 65%. Twitter has seemingly yet to greatly benefit from the massive change in policy, with various calculations of its Twitter Blue subscribers showing any additional sign-ups under the new rules have been inconsequential. Independent researchers noted that according to publicly available information from Twitterâs API â which is now available by subscription only â there was only a net increase of 28 accounts on Twitter Blue in its first day when accounting for the number of people that unsubscribed. Another report put the number closer to 400 new accounts. An independent analysis from Travis Brown, a Berlin-based developer of software for tracking social media, found fewer than 5% of legacy verified accounts appear to have paid to join Twitter Blue. This story was amended on 24 April 2023 to reflect that there was a net increase of only 28 accounts the day of the Twitter Blue relaunch, when accounting for the number of cancelled subscriptions. The Associated Press contributed reporting
headline: Fake accounts, chaos and few sign-ups: the first day of Twitter Blue was messy

chat_gpt_summary: Twitter has removed the blue verification tick from a number of high-profile accounts including Cristiano Ronaldo, Beyonce, Kim Kardashian, JK Rowling and Sir Paul McCartney, as part of a move towards a subscription-based verification system known as Twitter Blue. The social media site's new owner, Elon Musk, had previously criticised the old system as "bullshit" and insisted that verified accounts should have to pay for the status. Twitter Blue subscribers will benefit from boosted rankings in search and conversations, while their replies will receive greater prominence, but critics have warned that the move could damage the site's reputation for trustworthiness.
article: Twitterâs aristocracy is no more. Last year, Elon Musk described the verification process as a âlords & peasants systemâ and on Thursday he deployed the guillotine. Feudalism has now given way to capitalism: money gets you status. In a long-threatened cull, famous names including Cristiano Ronaldo, BeyonceÌ, Kim Kardashian, JK Rowling and Sir Paul McCartney lost the blue ticks that confer verified status on accounts. On 1 November, shortly after buying the social media platform, Musk decried the system for verification, tweeting: âTwitterâs current lords & peasants system for who has or doesnât have a blue checkmark is bullshit.â Soon, he wrote, users would have to pay for accreditation, adding: âPower to the people!â Accounts affected by Thursdayâs move had not signed up to the Twitter Blue subscription service, which costs from $8 a month in the US, Â£9.60 in the UK and A$13 in Australia, and is now the only way of securing that coveted blue tick â unless Musk chooses to cover the cost himself. The change has stripped the blue tick from about 400,000 legacy verified accounts. The blue tick is not just an honorific, however. Subscribers to the new service will get boosted rankings in conversations and search, while their replies will also receive greater prominence. Tweets that they interact with will also benefit. It means that maintaining influence or presence on the platform will cost money from now on, whereas it was free under the previous system whereby blue ticks reassured users that the accounts were who they said they were. However, Musk has said that users will still be able to see unverified accounts that they follow on the platformâs default For You feed. Some safeguards against imposter accounts â which bedevilled a previous Twitter Blue push â have been introduced, such as blocking new accounts from signing up to the service for 30 days. The Twitter Blue website page adds that the platform is âworking on an updated process for new Twitter accounts in order to help minimise impersonation risks and may impose and change waiting periods for new accounts without noticeâ. Muskâs move is largely rooted in financial motivations, despite the anti-feudal rhetoric. When he tried to pull out of the deal to buy Twitter he argued he was doing so because he believed the platform was plagued by vexatious automated accounts. Twitter acknowledged the platform had a bot problem â largely related to pornography and cryptocurrency content â but Musk alleged it was much bigger than the company was letting on, meaning advertisers could not gauge whether they were receiving value for money. Under legal pressure from Twitter, Musk was forced to push ahead with the takeover but he remained adamant that bots were a problem and paid verification was the best solution. He said in his 1 November Twitter thread that giving paid-for verified accounts priority in replies, mentions and search was âessential to defeat spam/scamâ, presumably under the logic that a bot account would not pay for a tick and would thus be less prominent. Musk is also determined to reduce Twitterâs dependence on advertising, something he has already achieved with a botched Blue relaunch in November that led to a slew of impersonation accounts that in turn contributed to an advertiser exodus (some advertisers had also expressed concerns about moderation standards post-takeover). In its last published set of accounts, advertising represented 90% of Twitterâs $5bn (Â£4bn) in annual revenue. According to Musk recently, revenue is due to drop to less than $3bn this year. Costs have also been slashed sharply, with staff numbers cut by about 75% to 1,500 people, which Musk says has seen off the threat of bankruptcy. But if advertisers do not return in force he will need more than the 600,000-635,000 Blue subscribers the platform is estimated to have, which equates to about $5m+ a month in revenue. Loss of verified status may persuade some users to pay up. According to the software developer Travis Brown, who tracks Twitter Blue subscriptions, the number of signups has risen from 550,000-585,000 at the start of the month to his latest estimate of up to 635,000. In the meantime, however, Twitter has to hope that this move does not damage a priceless but intangible commodity: trust. If Musk is replacing a feudal system, he needs to do it with a structure that will last. Journalists and commentators are among the thousands of accounts that lost their ticks on Thursday. âTwitterâs approach may help its business, but wonât help people identify who or what is worth listening to and the danger is that it will ultimately degrade trust that is critical for long-term sustainability,â says Nic Newman, a senior research associate at the Reuters Institute for the Study Journalism.
headline: Why Elon Muskâs cull of Twitter âverifiedâ blue ticks could prove costly

chat_gpt_summary: Elon Musk has admitted to paying for prominent Twitter accounts to retain their blue ticks as Twitter launched a cull that stripped verified status from many famous names including Beyoncé, Ronaldo, and Paul McCartney. Musk pushed ahead with a long-threatened promise to strip the blue tick from about 400,000 legacy verified accounts unless they signed up to Blue, which costs upwards of $8 a month in the US, £9.60 in the UK, and A$13 in Australia. The switch to paid-for verification is necessary to eradicate automated bot accounts and generate an alternative source of income to advertising, which accounts for most of Twitter's income.
article: Elon Musk has admitted he is paying for some prominent Twitter accounts to retain their blue ticks, as the social media platform launched a cull that stripped verified status from many famous names including BeyoncÃ©, Ronaldo and Paul McCartney. Twitterâs owner confirmed the gesture after it emerged that the writer Stephen King, the actor William Shatner and the basketball star LeBron James had retained their ticks â which confer verified status on accounts â despite not signing up to Twitter Blue, the siteâs subscription service. On Thursday Musk pushed ahead with a long-threatened promise to strip the blue tick from about 400,000 legacy verified accounts unless they signed up to Blue, which costs upwards of $8 a month in the US, Â£9.60 in the UK and A$13 in Australia. The overnight cull meant that many famous names, with millions of followers, lost their blue-check status. The names now without verified status include BeyoncÃ©, Ronaldo, Kim Kardashian, Sir Paul McCartney, JK Rowling and Donald Trump. Twitter now has zero legacy verified accounts according to Travis Brown, a software developer who has been tracking Twitterâs subscription service, down from about 400,000 at the beginning of the month, with Blue sign-ups now at an estimated 630,000. Under Muskâs plans for Twitter Blue, subscribersâ replies will gain greater prominence in usersâ default For You feed, while tweets you interact with will also be boosted. However, Twitter will continue to display accounts that people follow in their For You feed, whether or not they are Twitter Blue subscribers. Musk has said the switch to paid-for verification is necessary to eradicate automated bot accounts and generate an alternative source of income to advertising, which accounts for most of Twitterâs income. Gary Lineker, the Match of the Day presenter and prominent tweeter, confirmed to his 8.9 million followers on Friday that he had paid for a blue tick. Responding to a tweet by Jemima Khan, in which the screenwriter said she had paid for a Twitter Blue subscription and was now a member of the âuncool gangâ, Lineker tweeted: âsame hereâ. The tech news site the Verge reported on Thursday that a Twitter employee had emailed LeBron James recently to âextend a complimentary subscription to Twitter Blue for your account, @kingjames, on behalf of Elon Muskâ. James, who has more than 52 million followers, had been a prominent opponent of paying for verification, stating last month that he âainât payingâ for a blue check. King, the multimillion-selling writer of The Shining and It, expressed bafflement he now had a verified account that told followers clicking on his blue check that he was a Twitter Blue subscriber. He wrote: âMy Twitter account says Iâve subscribed to Twitter Blue. I havenât.â Musk, indicating he had stepped in on Kingâs behalf to help him retain his verified status, replied: âYouâre welcome namaste.â Official organisations have had their blue checks replaced with a grey âofficialâ tick, including the account for Pope Francis. Bellingcat, the investigative news outlet, said it had been offered a grey tick as its founder, Eliot Higgins, said he had not paid for his own blue check. He added: âI fully expect to be asked to pay for it in the near future.â However, some official sites such as the United States Citizenship and Immigration Services account did not have a grey tick as of Friday morning. Perks for Twitter Blue subscribers include the ability to edit tweets, write longer posts and see fewer adverts. There was also confusion over fake accounts, an issue that has dogged Muskâs attempts to introduce a verification system, with a false New York City government account tweeting at the authentic NYC government account that âTHIS account is the only authentic Twitter account representing and run by the New York City Governmentâ. The fake account was later suspended.
headline: Elon Musk pays for Stephen King and LeBron James to keep Twitter blue ticks

chat_gpt_summary: Twitter has removed blue checkmarks from formerly verified accounts, as policies under new owner Elon Musk take hold. Musk, who bought the company for $44bn in 2022, has threatened to remove "legacy blue checks" for months and now users seeking verification will have to pay $8 a month for Twitter Blue. The removal of free verification processes has raised concerns about misinformation and impersonation of legitimate organizations and people. Numerous high-profile users have asserted they will not pay for blue checkmarks under the new policy, while others have announced they will leave the platform entirely. Nonprofit organizations Human Rights Watch and the NAACP have tweeted they will not be paying for Twitter Blue.
article: Blue checkmarks began to disappear from formerly verified Twitter accounts on Thursday, as policies implemented under new owner Elon Musk began to take hold. Musk, who purchased the company for $44bn in 2022 and has thus far struggled to make it profitable, has been threatening to remove what he called âlegacy blue checksâ for months now. The checkmark previously denoted accounts that had been verified for authenticity and was given to accounts of celebrities, journalists and media outlets. Now users seeking verification will have to pay for Twitter Blue, a controversial $8 a month subscription program under which any account can obtain a blue checkmark. The rollout of the changes on Thursday was chaotic. Numerous high-profile users took to the platform to assert they would not pay for blue checkmarks under the new policy, while others announced they would leave the platform entirely. Nonprofit organizations Human Rights Watch and the NAACP have tweeted they will not be paying for Twitter Blue. SCOTUSblog, a news website that follows the workings of the US supreme court, said it would cease posting on Twitter entirely. The publication follows a similar move from NPR, the US radio network, which left Twitter last week after being labeled as a âstate-affiliated media outletâ under new platform policies. The removal of free verification processes has also raised concerns about the risk of misinformation and impersonation of legitimate organizations and people. A plethora of false government accounts â including some posing as the US Internal Revenue Service amid tax-filing season â emerged on Thursday. Others changed their account photos and bios to impersonate prominent figures, with a fake Jeff Bezos tweeting he was dissolving Amazon and a fake John McCain tweeting that his plane had crashed (the Arizona senator died in 2018). Twitter has previously said that government entities could apply for a free blue check through a special program, but some have reported they had thus far been unable to do so. On Thursday, the Bay Area Rapid Transit system, the metro system in the San Francisco Bay Area, where Twitterâs headquarters are located, tweeted it had applied for such a checkmark but had not heard back from the company. Experts have stated that the failure to verify such entities increases the risks of scams and even threatens to collapse disaster response online, with agencies like the National Weather System now check-less. Impersonations have been a recurring problem since Musk took over the company. In November, the platform had to pause changes to the subscription program due to an influx of âverifiedâ accounts posing as legitimate users and organizations.
headline: âLegacy blue checksâ disappear from Twitter as Muskâs changes take effect

chat_gpt_summary: Mastodon, a decentralized social media network created in 2016, has been presented as an alternative to Twitter for users who fear that social media giant may allow extreme content to remain on its platform. It operates as a network of independent servers, each with their own moderators and users, who can interact with each other using an open protocol called ActivityPub. Mastodon initially saw a surge in monthly active users to 2.6 million, eight times its number prior to Elon Musk's purchase of Twitter. However, the user base has since decreased to 1.2 million, indicating that Mastodon is still far from being a threat to Twitter's market dominance.
article: When Elon Musk bought Twitter nearly six months ago, bringing back white supremacists and booting journalists who had criticized him, many users felt it was the right time to leave the platform. Thousands of tweeters â myself included â fled to Mastodon: a scrappy social media project designed from its start in 2016 to be resistant against takeovers by billionaires. Mastodon is decentralized: instead of a single website, itâs a network of thousands of independently run servers â each with their own moderators and users â who can interact with each otherâs posts, called âtootsâ, using an open protocol called ActivityPub. Other social media services can connect to ActivityPub as well, so no one app can monopolize the broader network that Mastodon is part of, called the âfediverseâ. All that posed a bit of a learning curve. In addition to learning the new terms, I had to carefully choose a server, which would determine who would be in charge of my data, and what toots I would see most often. Mastodonâs creator, a German programmer named Eugen Rochko, told me at the time that his creation could be âslightly more difficult to graspâ than Twitter. âBut weâre not trying to be an exact copy,â he said. âWeâre trying to make something better.â Musk has appeared threatened at times. In December, he banned links to Mastodon on Twitter and suspended users who posted their Mastodon handles, including Mastodonâs official account. Days later, he suddenly reversed course, calling the ban a âmistakeâ during a Twitter Spaces livestream. âFucking post Mastodon all goddamn day long, I donât care,â he said. Nearly half a year later, has Mastodon seized the momentum? Data shows that it saw a huge surge of interest late last year: its monthly active users increased more than eightfold to a high of 2.6 million about a month after Muskâs Twitter purchase. But that number has since dropped to just 1.2 million â a sign that Mastodon remains far from the levels of hype that would threaten a behemoth like Twitter. âItâs definitely the case that itâs slowed down,â says Nathan Schneider, a University of Colorado Boulder professor who researches collective ownership models and runs a small Mastodon server called social.coop. âI think a lot of people came and found it a little hard. Using Mastodon can feel like eating your vegetables.â Is bigger actually better? Some of Mastodonâs most passionate users â who tend to be more tech-savvy than average â say itâs no problem if the community stays small. Here, things arenât designed to go viral quickly. Thereâs no global search or global hashtags. Servers can easily be made private, and admins can block other servers to combat trolls. Thereâs also a feature to put posts behind content warnings, which users are encouraged to do for sensitive topics. J Logan Carey, an illustrator, has a much smaller following on Mastodon than he did on Twitter, âbut people seem to actually see the things I post on there whereas on Twitter I feel like everything gets algorithmically squashed unless youâre a brand or a celebrityâ, he says. Brett Elliff, a systems engineer, says he has been âreally lovingâ Mastodon after using it for a few months: âI only see what I want to follow, and there are actual conversations happening instead of people shouting into the ether.â And Tiffany Li, a technology attorney and law professor, says Mastodonâs small user base âmeans that there are fewer trolls and generally unpleasant peopleâ. Another enthusiastic Mastodon adopter is Jeff Jarvis, a professor at the City University of New Yorkâs Newmark Journalism School. Jarvis arranged for the school to fund a yearâs worth of operating costs for journa.host, a Mastodon server home to a few thousand journalists who have been verified by volunteers. âI find the discourse in general to be richer and nicer,â Jarvis says about Mastodon. âI think mass media corrupted the internet with its definitions of scale, that you had to be huge because you had to get a big audience to go to advertisers.â Mastodonâs diminutive size has turned off digital marketers, who have mostly shunned it and other Twitter alternatives as niche âdistractionsâ that would be a waste of ad dollars. But itâs also disappointing some activists searching for a way to get their message out without feeding Elon Muskâs machine. In January, Hannah Roditi, the executive director of Social Movement Technologies, a non-profit that provides digital tools training for progressive activists, hosted a Mastodon training session. It was the most popular session the group had ever hosted, with more than 600 attendees from over 100 countries. Attendees were tired of Twitterâs hate speech problem and opaque policies: some human rights campaigners had lost their accounts when their governments asked Twitter to take them down. But while Mastodon feels safer, Roditi finds it less useful. âWe want to be able to hijack hashtags and get material in front of people instantly,â she says. âBut a big portion of the world is on Twitter. Theyâre not on Mastodon. Itâs more limiting.â Andrea Learned, the host of a climate podcast, has also found Mastodon too challenging. âI have been frustrated by how non-intuitive it is to make a list and follow other climate media,â she tells me over email. âWe are all waiting for our various communities (in my case #BikeTwitter , urbanists, #PlantBased) to âlandâ some one place. So â we all dabble on several platforms and no big momentum is seen.â âThe homeownersâ association of social mediaâ Mastodon may be more of a village than a global arena â but that doesnât mean itâs always welcoming. Johnathan Flowers, an assistant professor of philosophy at California State University Northridge, started a Mastodon account last November after Musk bought Twitter. But after he posted some observations about the racial politics of the platform, users demanded that Flowers, who is Black, hide those posts behind content warnings. âTheir problem was that I wasnât following the cultural codes that they felt should prevail in the digital space â¦ [they felt there should be] a social entitlement to comfort around issues of race and racism,â he says. When he declined to use content warnings, he received a torrent of racist abuse in his inbox. âOn Twitter, it took me a little over two years to say something that got me a bunch of racist trolls in my DMs and mentions,â he says. âOn Mastodon, it took 48 hours.â The scholar was also hassled by users who were unhappy that he was using a tool to cross-post his posts from Twitter to Mastodon. âIâm just like, âWhat are you guys doing? Why are you being cops?â Thereâs no wonder that we started calling Mastodon the homeownersâ association of social media,â he says. In February, Flowers brought up some of his observations to Rochko, Mastodonâs creator. âI am hopeful that it gave him a more nuanced perspective on the platform that heâs running,â Flowers says. âBut as for whether itâll spark real change, your guess is as good as mine. This isnât a technical problem that one could fix with new features. This is a cultural problem.â (Rochko did not respond to a request to comment for this story.) These days, Flowers has mostly stopped using Mastodon, not necessarily over the race issue, but because its weak discovery and search features made it too hard to find the people he wanted to follow. âIt took me weeks to find some of my best friends and academic colleagues,â he says. Now he logs in for two main reasons: to check on âthe kind of interestingly diverse Star Trek community there,â and to look at cat pictures. Mastodon versus the monopolists Until recently, the Mastodon non-profit had just one full-time employee maintaining the software: Rochko. The organization is funded primarily through donations on Patreon, which add up to around $32,000 a month â a drop in the bucket compared with the trillions thrown around by tech giants. Itâs also facing new competition from established names: Meta has said itâs working on its own decentralized social network, code-named P92, which will reportedly connect to ActivityPub. And Twitterâs co-founder and former CEO Jack Dorsey is getting ready to unveil Bluesky, a decentralized social media app that will come with a new protocol of its own. Despite this, Rochko has swatted away Silicon Valley investment offers worth âhundreds of thousands of dollarsâ, arguing that it would compromise his project. âMastodon will not turn into everything you hate about Twitter,â he said. âThe fact that it can be sold to a controversial billionaire, the fact that it can be shut down, go bankrupt and so on. Itâs the difference in paradigms [between the platforms].â Schneider, the collective ownership researcher, says itâs heartening that Rochko refused the money. âIf he took that investment, if it adopted that kind of monopolistic business model that venture capital tends to require, this would cease to be the thing that itâs meant to be.â But it doesnât change the fact that there arenât great alternative models. âIt continues to reflect what remains my major anxiety of this whole moment, which is that we as a society are chronically incapable of investing in something better,â he says.
headline: Thousands fled to Mastodon after Musk bought Twitter. Are they still âtootingâ?

chat_gpt_summary: Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau has intervened in a dispute over Twitter's decision to label the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation (CBC) as "government-funded" after Conservative leader Pierre Poilievre called on Twitter owner Elon Musk to do so. The CBC paused its activities on Twitter after some of its feeds carried the label "government-funded media". Poilievre praised the move, calling the CBC "Trudeau propaganda", but Twitter changed the label to "69% Government-funded Media" from "70% Government-funded Media" after the CBC disputed the claim. The CBC is funded through parliamentary appropriations, but under Canada's Broadcast Act, it is guaranteed editorial independence.
article: Prime minister Justin Trudeau has waded into a feud over Twitterâs decision to label Canadaâs public broadcaster as âgovernment-fundedâ, accusing his main political rival Pierre Poilievre of enlisting the help of tech executives in an attempt to defund the network. Last week, the Conservative leader called on Twitter owner Elon Musk to label the English-language feed of the Canadian Broadcasting Corporationâs âgovernment-fundedâ â but stopped short of asking for the French arm of the network to also be given the same label. On Monday, the broadcaster said it would âpause our activities on Twitterâ after some of the networkâs feeds started carrying the label âgovernment-funded mediaâ. Soon after, the accountâs label was changed to â69% Government-funded Mediaâ by Twitter. The label had previously read â70% Government-funded Mediaâ, but Musk said the âCanadian Broadcasting Corp said theyâre âless than 70% government-fundedâ, so we corrected the labelâ. âOur journalism is impartial and independent. To suggest otherwise is untrue. That is why we are pausing our activities on Twitter,â the CBC tweeted. Poilievre previously praised the decision, tweeting that ânow people know that it is Trudeau propaganda, not newsâ and directing users to a Conservative party petition to defund the network, a long-running goal of the party. CBC has disputed the âgovernment-fundedâ label, saying the broadcaster was âpublicly funded through a parliamentary appropriation that is voted upon by all Members of Parliamentâ. Under the countryâs Broadcast Act, the CBC is also guaranteed editorial independence. Radio-Canada, the immensely popular French language broadcaster, is funded through the same appropriations. Poilievre has not suggested he would defund the French language services, which he says provide a valuable resource for the linguistic minority. But political analysts also suggest the Conservative leader was hoping to avoid angering voters in Quebec, where he will need to perform well if he hopes to topple Trudeau in the next election. âAttacking this Canadian institution, attacking the culture and local content that is so important to so many Canadians, really indicates the values and the approach that Mr Poilievre is putting forward,â Trudeau told reporters on Monday. âIn order to attack this institution that is important for many, many Canadians, he runs to American billionaires, the tech giants that they continue to defend.â Twitter owner Musk has made a number of controversial changes to the popular social networking site, including asking users to pay for âverifiedâ blue accounts, revoking the verification of the New York Times and labeling broadcaster National Public Radio as âstate-affiliatedâ media. The broadcaster announced last week it would leave Twitter in protest. Public TV broadcaster PBS also suspended tweets, citing the same reason. The British Broadcasting Corporation (BBC) also objected to Twitter labeling it as âgovernment-funded mediaâ on the companyâs main account and Musk said the social media platform will now change the BBCâs label. When asked for comment on its decision to label CBCâs English language wing as âgovernment-fundedâ, Twitterâs communications department responded to the Guardian with an auto-generated poop emoji.
headline: Canadaâs CBC âpausesâ Twitter use after government-funded media label

chat_gpt_summary: Twitter has labelled the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) and Special Broadcasting Service (SBS) as "government-funded media," a move that suggests the media outlets lack independence. The labelling system has previously been used on China's Xinhua news agency and Russia's RT outlet, as well as on the US's Public Broadcasting Service and National Public Radio. The latter two stopped using Twitter after being labelled "state-affiliated media," which Twitter later changed to "government-funded media." Both ABC and SBS said they would not quit Twitter, but the SBS spokesperson called the "publicly funded media" label more accurate.
article: Twitter has slapped a âgovernment-funded mediaâ label on the ABC and SBS. The social media platform led by Elon Musk has been labelling media organisations in a way that could imply they lack independence. The USâs Public Broadcasting Service and National Public Radio (NPR) stopped using Twitter after being labelled âstate-affiliated mediaâ, a tag that was later changed to ââgovernment-funded mediaâ. NPR said it would âno longer be active on Twitter because the platform is taking actions that undermine our credibility by falsely implying that we are not editorially independentâ. Sign up for Guardian Australiaâs free morning and afternoon email newsletters for your daily news roundup The âstate-affiliated mediaâ tag had otherwise been applied to Chinaâs Xinhua news agency and Russiaâs RT outlet. Twitter said it was for accounts that are involved in geopolitics and diplomacy. Earlier this week, the BBC had its âgovernment-fundedâ label changed to âpublicly fundedâ. Twitter defines state-affiliated media as an âoutlet where the state exercises control over editorial contentâ. Government-funded media refers to outlets âwhere the government provides some or all of the outletâs funding and may have varying degrees of government involvement over editorial contentâ. Then there is publicly funded media, which refers to organisations that âreceive funding from licence fees, individual contributions, public financing, and commercial financingâ. A spokesperson said the ABC was not planning to follow NPR and PBS by quitting Twitter. âThe ABC doesnât currently have any plans to shut down all its Twitter accounts. Weâre liaising with Twitter regarding changes to account verification and labels,â they said. An SBS spokesperson said labelling the company âpublicly fundedâ would be more accurate. âWhile we appreciate Twitterâs motivations with regard to transparency on its platform, we believe a âpublicly funded mediaâ label better reflects the hybrid public-commercial nature of our funding model and the fact that SBS retains full independence from government in our news editorial and content decision-making,â they said. Both media companies maintain full editorial independence from government, as set out in their charters. Since Musk acquired Twitter, the platformâs value appears to have halved and he axed half the companyâs workforce. He has also come under fire for his plans to remove the blue ticks awarded to âauthenticâ accounts. There has also been some legal trouble, and a range of changes to how the site operates. Guardian Australia contacted Twitter for a comment and received what has been described as its âstandardâ response â a poop emoji.
headline: Twitter labels Australiaâs ABC news and SBS âgovernment-funded mediaâ

chat_gpt_summary: Since Elon Musk acquired Twitter for $44bn in October 2022, he has made erratic decisions and reduced the workforce by half. After an advertiser boycott, Twitter has lost more than $20bn in value and now has to pay off a $13bn debt burden. Last month, Twitter's worth was calculated to be less than half of what Musk paid for it. The site's infrastructure and staff have also caused problems, leading to NPR leaving the platform. However, Musk believes that Twitter has a chance to become cash flow positive this quarter and has folded the site into X Corp to develop an "everything app" akin to WeChat in China.
article: On 28 October 2022 Elon Musk tweeted âthe bird is freedâ as he marked his $44bn acquisition of Twitter. Nearly six months later, it became a dog. The distinctive avian logo the Tesla CEO had referenced in October had been replaced by a picture of a Shiba Inu canine â the face of the Dogecoin cryptocurrency. There was speculation over what was behind the change. Was it linked to a recent attempt to dismiss a $258bn lawsuit filed against Musk by Dogecoin investors over an alleged pyramid scheme? Was it a delayed April Foolâs gag? Whatever the reason, the dog has now gone. But the episode was exemplary of Muskâs decision-making style at the social media company: erratic, and sometimes, inscrutable in motivation. As we approach six months of Muskâs acquisition of Twitter, it remains far from business as usual at the company. In the past week alone, there has been a spat with Substack, further problems with the siteâs infrastructure and NPR, the US radio network, has quit the platform. Musk himself admitted in an interview with the BBC that running Twitter had been âpainfulâ and that buying it had come with âemotional strainâ. Hereâs a look at how key areas of Twitterâs business have performed. Debt and company value The end of the month does not just mark six months since Muskâs purchase, it is also the due date for the second quarterly instalment on paying down Twitterâs $13bn debt burden (a payment of about $300m). When the first payment approached in January, it was against a backdrop of doom-laden warnings from Musk, who had cautioned shortly after the takeover that âbankruptcy isnât out of the questionâ. True, Musk had paid $44bn for a business that had been largely loss-making since its launch in 2006. But his own decisions at the platform had led to an advertiser boycott that had caused significant damage to the platformâs main source of revenue (more than $5bn in 2021). Last month it emerged that Twitter is now worth less than half of what Musk paid for it, having lost more than $20bn (Â£16.4bn) in value, according to calculations based on a leaked memo. Financial performance Once at the helm, Musk slashed costs and, last month, the CEO said he thought Twitter had a chance of turning cashflow positive â broadly, spending less cash to run the business than it takes in â in the current quarter. He repeated the claim in the BBC interview. In March he told a Morgan Stanley conference in San Francisco that Twitterâs revenue was due to drop to less than $3bn this year but expenditure had dropped from $4.5bn to $1.5bn. Aswath Damodaran, a professor of finance at the Stern School of Business at New York University, says Muskâs high-risk approach could pay off for a platform that was struggling for financial stability even before the chaotic takeover. âTwitter has always been a basket case as a business, unable to monetize its users into advertising revenues and the status quo was getting them nowhere,â he says. âMusk, as is his wont, has been a chaos agent, unfocused and unpredictable, but I would think that Twitter stands a chance of making it out of the forest, precisely because of this chaos.â Indeed, Musk recently folded Twitter into an entity called X Corp. Musk has referred to Twitter as being an âaccelerantâ for creating X, his âeverything appâ akin to WeChat in China. User base A self-declaredâfree speech absolutistâ, Musk early on chose to reinstate accounts that had been banned under the platformâs previous owners. Those included the accounts for Donald Trump, misogynist influencer Andrew Tate and the personal account of the far-right US congresswoman Marjorie Taylor Greene. According to Musk, users have not fled the platform in response. Musk said in November that Twitterâs user numbers had crossed 250 million, up from 238 million before the takeover. The controversy around account reinstatement, the threat of losing blue-check status and Muskâs dislike of mainstream media, including banning some prominent reporters, also do not seem to have deterred the journalists and influential pundits who use the platform regularly (see the Gary Lineker tweet that drove a whole news cycle recently). âDespite all the talk that journalists would be leaving Twitter, in practice very few have done so because it remains an important part of workflows, with networks that have been built up and carefully curated over the years â as well as being a compelling and amusing distraction,â says Nic Newman, a senior research associate at the Reuters Institute for the Study Journalism. âOur data suggests that there has been no substantial drop-off in the number of people that use it weekly â though that may well come.â Staff In an effort to dramatically cut costs, Musk axed half of the companyâs 7,500-strong workforce within days of sealing the takeover and reduced it further through a series of cuts including a bizarre redundancy program where staff were asked to commit to being âhardcoreâ or leave. Such was the chaotic reaction to that ultimatum, Twitter was forced to shut offices temporarily. According to one former employee who was made redundant following the takeover, the platform has gone backwards. âFor many of us former tweeps, seeing what Musk is doing to Twitter is heartbreaking,â said the former staff member, speaking on condition of anonymity. âThe platform has regressed in terms of toxicity, safety and nuance. The hard work of dedicated teams and colleagues over the years has been erased, including efforts to combat misinformation and create trustworthy safety policies and curation standards.â Advertisers Concerns over Muskâs erratic decision making, approach to content moderation and a botched relaunch of Twitterâs Blue subscription service underlined Muskâs revenue projections last month. At one point in January, the companyâs daily revenue was down 40% year-over-year, according to the tech newsletter the Platformer and some boycotts remain in place. Pharmaceutical firms Eli Lilly and Pfizer, retailer Macyâs and Cadbury owner MondÄlez spent no money on Twitter in the first two months of the year, according to the advertising data firm MediaRadar. However, MediaRadar said there were 3,700 companies advertising on Twitter in February â 8% more than the same period last year (although some, like Volkswagen, General Motors and Chipotle, have reduced their spending significantly). Nonetheless, there are signs of life. âJust this past couple of weeks weâve seen the first signs of recovery, as a few advertisers are now talking about Twitter ads again,â says Farhad Divecha, the managing director of the UK digital marketing agency AccuraCast. âTheyâre now coming to us asking about it, rather than us asking them if theyâre ready to reconsider Twitter â and them declining. Twitter Blue relaunch Determined to reduce Twitterâs reliance on advertising, Musk has invested big in the relaunch of Twitterâs subscription services. The first relaunch of Twitter Blue, in November, was paused after it led to a slew of fake âverifiedâ accounts. The company tried again in December, offering subscribers perks such as a blue tick â giving your account more prominence on the For You feed â and fewer adverts for $8 a month on the web or $11 on iOS or Android. According to Travis Brown, a software developer who has been tracking Twitterâs subscription service, the new-look Blue has about 550-585,000 subscribers which equates to $4m+ a month in revenue. Twitter will need many more sign-ups to offset the advertising loss. Meanwhile, the 400,000 legacy blue checks face a loss of status. Musk told the BBC that these checks will be phased out by next week, although a deadline has been missed before. Site performance and regulators Twitter has been hit by a series of outages since it was bought. In the latest breach, users reported that Twitterâs privacy-friendly Circles feature was leaking private user data. The US Federal Trade Commission is investigating the company amid concerns that Twitterâs ability to protect users, and comply with a 2022 deal with the FTC to maintain high data security standards, might have been affected by redundancies and cost cuts. âThe FTCâs investigation is quite serious,â says David Vladeck, a professor at Georgetown University Law Center. âThere is deep concern within the FTC as to whether Twitter is, in fact, making a concerted effort to bring it into compliance with the May 2022 consent decree.â Vladeck says that unless Twitter âups its gameâ another enforcement action, including âsubstantial civil penaltiesâ, looms. An emailed request for comment sent to Twitterâs press office was met, as is now standard practice at the company, with a poop emoji.
headline: Is the bird really freed? A look back at six months of Muskâs Twitter reign

chat_gpt_summary: In an op-ed for The Guardian, John Naughton notes that despite Elon Musk's chaotic attempts to mould Twitter to his liking, mainstream media continues to be glued to the social media platform. Naughton argues that Twitter has become a significant part of the public sphere because it is an obsession for politicians, advertisers, PR and communications people, and journalists. He highlights that Twitter is the go-to platform to reach the widest possible audience, even though many users have moved to Mastodon, a decentralised federation of independently run servers. Naughton suggests that the world would miss Twitter if it disappeared, but "we are stuck with it."
article: Last October, the richest manchild in human history fell into the trap he had dug for himself. Elon Musk was forced to purchase Twitter at an absurd price. He had no clear idea of what to do with his new acquisition, other than realising a fatuous idea about âfree speechâ. It was like watching a monkey acquire a delicate clock: the new owner started thrashing wildly about, slashing the headcount (from 8,000 to about 1,500) â in the process losing many of the people who knew how the machine worked â and generally having tantrums while tweeting incontinently from the smallest room in the companyâs San Francisco headquarters. All of this frenetic activity was watched â and avidly reported for weeks â by the worldâs mainstream media, for reasons that would have puzzled a visiting Martian anthropologist. After all, in relation to the other social-media companies, Twitter looked like a minnow. Most people have never used it. So why all the fuss about its acquisition by a flake of Cadbury proportions? The answer is that there is a select category of humans who are obsessive users of Twitter: politicians; people who work in advertising, PR and âcommunicationsâ; and journalists. These are people who spend every waking moment on the platform, and use it to disseminate information, argue, troll, boast and engage in relentless virtue-signalling. Given that some (many?) of these people work in media, their obsession with Twitter meant that it had become, de facto, a significant part of the public sphere. If you wanted to be anyone in that networked world, you had to be on Twitter. The person who understood this best was Donald Trump, who was an inspired maestro of the medium. He campaigned on Twitter, and eventually even governed by tweet â to the extent that some genius created a bot that automatically reformatted every tweet Trump issued as president as an official-looking White House press statement. When Musk embarked on his chaotic attempts to mould the platform to his liking, there was a stampede of advertisers and disaffected users from it. The former sat on their corporate hands, worried about brands being tainted by the racist and xenophobic hordes that Musk allowed on to the platform; the latter went to Mastodon which, though superficially similar to Twitter, is actually very different â itâs a decentralised federation of independently run servers. Mastodon is fine for some purposes. For one thing, itâs somehow quieter and more conversational. For another, itâs not algorithmically curated, so you only see posts from people you have chosen to follow. And though it does have some journalists on it, most of them seem to have hedged their bets â in that they have also remained on Twitter. And I can see why: if you are interested in reaching the widest possible audience for your humblebragging or even news of your latest scoop, then â because of its decentralised architecture â Mastodon doesnât have the âreachâ that you crave. Which means that, no matter how depraved Twitter becomes under its reigning proprietor, you have to be there, even if he despises you. Which he does. After he fired all the companyâs press team, for example, replies to media inquiries consist of an automated poo emoji. So, as tech journalist Casey Newton observes in âWhy journalists canât quit Twitterâ: âThe company was symbolically shitting all over them, and journalists couldnât get enough of it.â Which brings us, oddly enough, to the UK and Keir Starmerâs Labour party, which is suddenly displaying a perceptive understanding of how to use Twitter for political purposes. Exhibit A is a Labour advertisement that everybody in politics has been talking about for at least a week: a photograph of Rishi Sunak accompanying the text: âDo you think adults convicted of sexually assaulting children should go to prison? Rishi Sunak doesnât.â Under the Tories, the ad continued, â4,500 adults convicted of sexually assaulting children under 16 served no prison time.â The interesting thing is that the advert was posted only on the partyâs Twitter feed â and not on Facebook or other social media sites that account for the majority of party-political online advertising in the run-up to elections. The ad was seen by more than 22 million people â in itself a formidable achievement in a world where most people pay no attention to politics. But more importantly, it was seen by every journalist in the country, which is why so many people have been talking about it ever since. All of which suggests that unless Musk succeeds in actually demolishing his new toy, mainstream media will continue to be glued to it. None of the available alternatives look like a convincing replacement for it. And yet itâs clear that the world would miss Twitter if it disappeared. So maybe, as with death and taxes, we are stuck with it. What Iâve been reading Kids: still alright âWhatâs missing from the cultural narrative about gen Zâ is a sensible, unpatronising essay by Alfie Robinson on the Persuasion Substack. Backchat Jill Lepore has written a thoughtful New Yorker review essay about chatbots and knowledge called âThe data delusionâ. Tepid tech âThe dawn of mediocre computingâ is an intriguing essay by Venkatesh Rao on the Ribbonfarm Substack.
headline: Elon Musk hates journalists but journalists love Twitter. Where does that leave us? | John Naughton

chat_gpt_summary: US public broadcaster PBS has announced its departure from Twitter after the social media platform labeled the organization as "government-funded media." This move came after National Public Radio also left the platform amid comments by Twitter owner Elon Musk that NPR was "state-affiliated media" that should be defunded. Twitter has since relabeled NPR as "government-funded media," but the labels were criticized by the two organizations as undermining their credibility as independent news outlets. PBS spokesperson Jason Phelps said that the platform's simplistic label leaves the inaccurate impression that PBS is wholly funded by the federal government.
article: The USâs Public Broadcasting Service, better known as PBS, has quit its use of Twitter after the platform labeled the organization as âgovernment-funded mediaâ. PBSâs announced its Twitter exit on Thursday, one day after National Public Radio also left the platform amid comments by the Twitter owner, Elon Musk, that NPR was âstate-affiliated mediaâ which should be defunded. Twitter has since relabeled NPR as âgovernment-funded mediaâ, but that did not stop the radio broadcaster saying that the labels for it and the television broadcaster PBS were aimed at undermining their credibility as independent news outlets. The labels are shared by Russia Today and Chinaâs Xinhua, whose editorial decisions are heavily influenced by their respective state regimes, as USA Today noted. Meanwhile, both NPR and PBS fall in the middle â or neutral â part of the Ad Fontes media bias chart. A PBS spokesperson said the broadcaster does receive some government subsidies but gets far more from members of the public and from philanthropic organizations. While it does receive government subsidies, NPR says most of its funding comes from corporate as well as individual supporters and grants. United Press International noted Twitter has not labeled the accounts for the Musk-owned SpaceX and Tesla companies as government-affiliated organizations despite receiving billions in government subsidies. In a statement to USA Today, Jason Phelps of PBS said the broadcasterâs staffers stopped using the organizationâs Twitter account after learning that the platform had relabeled them. Phelps said PBS had âno plans to resume at this timeâ but added that the organization was âcontinuing to monitor the ever-changing situation closelyâ. âTwitterâs simplistic label leaves the inaccurate impression that PBS is wholly funded by the federal government,â Phelps added to USA Today. In a separate statement, PBS said that âeditorial independence is central to our work, and will never changeâ. âWe will continue to produce trustworthy content that features unbiased reporting and holds governments and institutions to account,â the PBS spokespersonâs statement added. The BBC was also recently labeled government-funded media by Twitter, but the platform relabeled it âpublicly fundedâ after the BBC complained. The BBC remains on Twitter. UK households fund the BBC through a TV license fee, and commercial operations also provide income to the broadcaster, which operates through a royal charter with the British government that requires the broadcaster to be independent.
headline: PBS quits Twitter after being labeled âgovernment-funded mediaâ

chat_gpt_summary: National Public Radio (NPR) and public TV broadcaster PBS have stopped posting fresh content on Twitter after the social media platform labeled them as "state-affiliated media." Twitter has since changed the label to "government-funded media." The move prompted responses from journalists and the Committee to Protect Journalists, which called on Twitter to reconsider its decision, highlighting the potential risks of negative connotations for journalists reporting from areas where government affiliation could be suggested. The British Broadcasting Corporation (BBC) also objected to Twitter's labeling of it as "government-funded media" and Musk said Twitter would change the label to "publicly funded."
article: National Public Radio (NPR) said on Wednesday it will no longer post fresh content to its 52 official Twitter feeds after the US organization was labeled as âstate-affiliated mediaâ by the social media platform. âWe are officially de-emphasizing Twitter across the organization,â NPR said in a statement, adding that it had made the decision after Twitter refused repeated requests to remove the âinaccurate labelâ. Public TV broadcaster PBS also suspended tweets, citing the same reason. A PBS spokesman, Jeremy Gaines, told the Washington Post: âWe donât have any plans to return.â The broadcaster did not immediately respond to the Guardianâs request for a comment. Twitter labeled both public media organizations as âstate-affiliated mediaâ before changing the wording to âgovernment-funded mediaâ. The BBC and Voice of America were also tagged. Twitter was not immediately available for comment. Before a takeover of Twitter by Elon Musk, the label was reserved for propaganda networks like Russiaâs RT and Chinaâs Xinhua News Agency. NPR is a non-profit media organization, based in Washington, that syndicates more than 1,000 local public radio stations across the US. Some public radio stations â including KCRW in Santa Monica, California, and WESA in Pittsburgh â also announced they would stop using the platform, though affiliated member stations were not tagged as âgovernment fundedâ. The majority of NPRâs funding comes from corporate and individual supporters and grants. The organization also receives programming fees from various member stations. The member stations receive about 13% of their funds from the federally funded Corporation for Public Broadcasting and other state and federal government sources, NPR said. âThe whole point isnât whether or not weâre government funded,â said the organizationâs CEO, John Lansing. âEven if we were government funded, which weâre not, the point is the independence, because all journalism has revenue of some sort.â Lansing echoed his message in a staff-wide email, saying: âIt would be a disservice to the serious work you all do here to continue to share it on a platform that is associating the federal charter for public media with an abandoning of editorial independence or standards.â The organization is setting up a two-week grace period so social media managers that run its accounts can revise their social media strategies. According to Lansing, NPR staff can decide for themselves whether they will continue remaining active on the platform. The organizationâs decision has prompted a slew of responses online, including from its own journalists. Scott Detrow, NPRâs White House correspondent, wrote: âNPR is stepping away from Twitter. Itâs the right move and Iâm proud of us for taking it.â Geoff Brumfiel, an editor and correspondent on NPRâs science desk, tweeted: âTwitter doesnât make or break anything we do as an organization, and so thereâs not much benefit for staying.â Meanwhile, the Committee to Protect Journalists has called on Twitter to reconsider its decision, with its program director, Carlos MartÃ­nez de la Serna, saying âit is imperativeâ. âNPR receives public funding, but is not state-controlled, meaning Twitterâs listing could pose risks for journalists reporting from areas where suggestions of government affiliation have negative connotations,â he said. Barry Malone, the deputy editor in chief of the Thomson Reuters Foundation, tweeted: âNPR leaves Twitter â the first major media org to do so. An influential newsroom with almost 9 million followers. Hard not to interpret this as a big blow to the platform.â The British Broadcasting Corporation (BBC) had also objected to Twitter labeling it as âgovernment-funded mediaâ on the companyâs main account. Elon Musk, Twitterâs billionaire owner, said the social media platform will now change the BBCâs label after the broadcaster objected. In an interview with the BBC, Musk said he had the âutmost respectâ for the outlet. âWe want [the tag] as truthful and accurate as possible. Weâre adjusting the label to [the BBC being] publicly funded. Weâll try to be accurate,â he added. The Tesla, Twitter and SpaceX chief made the announcement during a wide-ranging interview with the BBC in which he said that his pain level from running the site had been âextremely highâ but that the business was now âroughly breaking evenâ.
headline: NPR to quit Twitter after being labelled âstate-affiliated mediaâ

chat_gpt_summary: Australia's eSafety commissioner used its new cyber abuse powers for the first time to compel Twitter to remove severely harmful content targeting Brittany Higgins and her partner, David Sharaz. The commissioner issued a formal notice to Twitter to remove the content, which exemplified the widespread abuse and harassment the pair have suffered online. The laws allow the commissioner to compel major social media platforms to remove material deemed to be severe "cyber-abuse material targeted at an Australian adult". The commissioner has used these powers six times since they were enacted, resulting in the removal of material or geo-blocking the content.
article: Australiaâs eSafety commissioner deployed tough new cyber abuse powers for the first time to force Twitter to remove severely harmful content targeting Brittany Higgins and her partner, David Sharaz, last year. Sharaz lodged a formal complaint to the office of eSafety commissioner, Julie Inman Grant, in April last year, asking for an investigation of vitriolic content that Twitter was refusing to act upon, according to correspondence seen by Guardian Australia. His complaint singled out a highly offensive tweet â which the Guardian has chosen not to republish â that exemplified the widespread abuse and harassment the pair have suffered online. The commissioner acted quickly in response and intervened using new adult cyber abuse powers to issue a formal notice to Twitter to remove the content. It was the first time the eSafety commissioner had issued such a notice since the Online Safety Act was enacted in January 2022. The laws allow the commissioner to compel major social media platforms to remove material her office deems to be severe âcyberâabuse material targeted at an Australian adultâ. The powers can only be used where a platform has refused to act on content that an ordinary person would believe was âintended to have an effect of causing serious harm to a particular Australian adultâ and would âregard the material as being, in all the circumstances, menacing, harassing or offensiveâ. Upon receipt of the notice, Twitter took down the abusive tweet within 24 hours. Sign up for Guardian Australiaâs free morning and afternoon email newsletters for your daily news roundup The eSafety commissioner said it could not comment on individual complaints, but its intervention, until then unprecedented, shows the seriousness of the abuse directed at Higgins and Sharaz. A spokesperson for the commissioner said more generally that it had only used the powers six times since they were enacted roughly one year ago. In each of the six cases, the commissionerâs intervention had resulted in either the removal of material or geo-blocking the content. âThe adult cyber abuse scheme gives Australian adults somewhere to turn if an online service provider has failed to act on a report of seriously harmful online abuse,â a spokesperson said. âAdult cyber abuse can have a long-lasting impact on the targeted personâs sense of safety, self-esteem, mental health and physical wellbeing, especially when part of a broader pattern of abuse and harassment.â The reforms enacted last year also gave the eSafety commissioner broader powers to act on cyberbullying. Inman Grant, the eSafety commissioner, has previously told the Guardian that her agency had probed more than 1,680 cyberbullying complaints and made more than 500 removal requests to online platforms in the first 12 months since the Online Safety Act changes. Bruce Lehrmannâs defamation proceedings against News Corp and Network Ten are set to be brought back to the federal court on 28 April for a key ruling that will determine whether his case can proceed. Lehrmann is seeking to extend the usual 12-month time limit that applies to defamation proceedings so that he can sue News Corp and Network Ten for their initial reporting of Higginsâ allegations of rape â allegations he has always denied. At a hearing last month, Lehrmann argued that he was delayed in bringing proceedings due to prior legal advice, the prospect of a criminal trial and his mental health. But lawyers for News Corp, Network Ten, Samantha Maiden and Lisa Wilkinson argued it was not reasonable for Lehrmann to have delayed the proceedings, saying he did nothing, despite being âacutely awareâ that he was in a position to sue for defamation. Justice Michael Lee will hand down his decision at midday on 28 April. Lehrmann pleaded not guilty to one charge of sexual intercourse without consent. His first trial in the ACT supreme court was aborted due to juror misconduct, and prosecutors did not proceed with a retrial due to fears over Higginsâs mental health.
headline: Twitter forced to remove harmful content aimed at Brittany Higgins and partner

chat_gpt_summary: Twitter and Substack have ended a six-day row after Twitter stopped censoring links and searches for the newsletter platform. The row began when Substack announced a new feature called Substack Notes, which offers a Twitter-like experience for the companys user base of newsletter authors and their readers, some of whom are paying subscribers. Many Substack authors rely on Twitter for both reader acquisition and content to write about. The spat also appeared to have put an end to Elon Musks Twitter Files project, after he tweeted then deleted screenshots of a conversation between himself and one of its writers, Matt Taibbi, in which the pair sparred over the censorship.
article: A six-day row between Twitter and Substack has come to an uneasy truce after the social media site stopped censoring links and searches for the newsletter platform following the latterâs decision to launch a rival microblogging service. However, the spat appears to have put an end to Elon Muskâs âTwitter Filesâ project, after he tweeted then deleted screenshots of a conversation between himself and one of its writers, Matt Taibbi, in which the pair sparred over the censorship. The conflict started last Wednesday, when Substack announced a new feature, âSubstack Notesâ, which offers a Twitter-like experience for the companyâs user base of newsletter authors and their readers, some of whom are paying subscribers. âWhile Notes may look like familiar social media feeds, the key difference is in what you donât see,â said the Substack cofounder Hamish McKenzie in a post announcing the feature. âThe Substack network runs on paid subscriptions, not ads. This changes everything. âHere, people get rewarded for respecting the trust and attention of their audiences. The ultimate goal on this platform is to convert casual readers into paying subscribers. âIn this system, the vast majority of the financial rewards go to the creators of the content.â Many Substack authors rely on Twitter for both reader acquisition and content to write about, leaving the newsletter platform in a painful position if Muskâs chaotic administration of Twitter since his $44bn (Â£38bn) takeover last October were to lead to the social networkâs collapse. Even before the Twitter sale, Substack had been struggling: the companyâs 2021 revenues were negative, according to its financial statements, and it lost $25m in cash overall that year. Last year, it fired one in six staff members and last month it turned to retail investors for a fundraising round, despite having been valued at $650m in March 2021. In a statement, the company denied it was in difficulty, telling the Guardian: âThe financials shared are nearly 18 months old, and the company has transformed materially since then. âIn the period 2020 to 2022, Substack focused on growth. In particular, during this period we made aggressive investments to acquire writers who had large readerships so we could kickstart the growth of the Substack network.
