This effort brought tens of millions of readers into the system. Now, Substack has more than 35 million active subscriptions, including 2 million paid subscriptions. More than 17,000 people are earning money on Substack, and the top 10 writers earn more than $25 million.â But the companyâs efforts to compete with Twitter brought an immediate response from Musk himself. Over the Easter weekend, any tweet containing a Substack link was algorithmically deprioritised, blocked from being liked or retweeted, and hidden in search. Searches for the term âsubstackâ itself were automatically replaced with searches for the word ânewsletterâ. And many users who did manage to find and click on a link to a Substack site reported being warned by Twitter that the service was âunsafe or maliciousâ. âWeâre disappointed that Twitter has chosen to restrict writersâ ability to share their work,â the Substack founders said in a joint statement. âTheir livelihoods should not be tied to platforms where they donât own their relationship with their audience, and where the rules can change on a whim.â Taibbi, one of the most prominent writers on Substack, found himself in the middle of that conflict. Despite working closely with Musk on the Twitter Files â a selective publication of internal Twitter documents authorised by Musk with the apparent goal of demonstrating liberal bias under its former management â he said he would be leaving the platform over the restrictions. That departure prompted a response from Musk, the companyâs first public statement on the matter, days after the first reprisals against Substack had been noticed: Musk falsely accused Taibbi of being a Substack employee (he is not), claimed Substack links âwere never blockedâ (he later admitted they were temporarily marked as âunsafeâ), and accused Substack of âtrying to download a massive portion of the Twitter database to bootstrap their Twitter cloneâ, which Substackâs chief executive has denied in a post on Substack Notes. The spat appears to be distracting Musk from more pressing concerns at the social network. Over the weekend, users reported that the companyâs privacy-focused Circles feature was leaking private user data. Similar to Instagramâs Close Friends feature, posts shared to a Twitter Circle are supposed to be shown only to other users who have been explicitly added to that Circle. But multiple users, including security researcher Ian Coldwater, found that other users were able to see their supposedly secret posts. âI made a Twitter Circle with one person in it,â Coldwater said. âTwo people I donât follow saw the tweet & liked it. One of those people doesnât follow me either. Twitter Circles arenât private. Donât post anything you want private in them.â A request for comment to Twitter was unanswered, save for the companyâs automatic reply to all press inquiries: a poo emoji. â¢ This article was amended on 12 April 2023 to add a statement from Substack that was provided after publication.
headline: Row between Twitter and Substack ends with uneasy truce

chat_gpt_summary: Elon Musk praised the BBC as one of the least biased media organizations after the broadcaster objected to being labeled as "government-funded media" on Twitter. The BBC asserted its independence, stating it is funded by the British public through the license fee. Musk called for transparency and acknowledged that all organizations have bias to some extent. Twitter also labeled America's NPR as "state-affiliated media," but later changed it to "government-funded media" following objections.
article: Elon Musk has described the BBC as âamong the least biasedâ media organisations after the broadcaster objected to being labelled as âgovernment-funded mediaâ on Twitter. The BBC contacted Twitter after the designation was attached to the main @BBC account. The label links through to a page on Twitterâs help centre that says âstate-affiliated mediaâ are outlets where the government âexercises control over editorial contentâ in various ways. The BBC added in its statement: âThe BBC is, and always has been, independent. We are funded by the British public through the licence fee.â Since 1927, the BBC has operated through a Royal Charter agreed with the government that states the corporation âmust be independentâ, particularly over âeditorial and creative decisions, the times and manner in which its output and services are supplied, and in the management of its affairsâ. Britons pay a Â£159 licence fee each year to fund the corporationâs output. The fee is set by government but paid by individual households. Responding to the complaint, Musk asked: âIs the Twitter label accurate?â In an email to the BBC, he wrote: âWe are aiming for maximum transparency and accuracy. Linking to ownership and source of funds probably makes sense. âI do think media organisations should be self-aware and not falsely claim the complete absence of bias. All organisations have bias, some obviously much more than others. âI should note that I follow BBC news on Twitter, because I think it is among the least biased.â While the @BBC account concerned, which has 2.2 million followers, has been given the label, more popular accounts affiliated to the broadcasterâs news and sport output, including BBC News (World) and BBC Breaking News, are not being described in the same way. Twitter also designated Americaâs National Public Radio (NPR) as âstate-affiliated mediaâ, a label given to outlets including Russiaâs RT and Chinaâs Xinhua News. The description was later changed to the same âgovernment funded mediaâ tag now applied to the @BBC account. NPR â which receives some money from public institutions but whose funding mainly comes from sources such as corporate sponsorships and membership fees â had said it would stop tweeting from the account unless it was amended. With PA Media
headline: Musk admits BBC âamong least biasedâ in row over Twitter âgovernment-funded mediaâ tag

chat_gpt_summary: Twitter is facing accusations of yielding to government pressure in India by blocking numerous journalists, politicians, and activists from its platform. The Indian government demanded the removal of accounts following an internet shutdown in Punjab. Twitter complied and blocked over 120 accounts, including those of prominent figures. Critics argue that this demonstrates a crackdown on dissent and a threat to civil liberties. Elon Musk, Twitter's owner, acknowledged the issue but stated he cannot fix it immediately. India poses significant challenges for Twitter, with concerns about censorship and authoritarianism growing.
article: Twitter has been accused of bowing to government pressure in India by blocking scores of prominent journalists, politicians and activists from its platform in recent weeks. The Indian government issued notices to Twitter to remove people in the aftermath of an internet shutdown in Punjab during the search for a fugitive Sikh separatist leader. Twitter agreed to block more than 120 accounts, including the Canadian politician Jagmeet Singh, the Canadian poet Rupi Kaur, several journalists and an Indian MP. Twitter also blocked the handle of the BBCâs Punjabi bureau. Jaskaran Sandhu, the Toronto-based co-founder of Baaz News, an outlet focused on the Sikh diaspora, received an email from Twitter on 21 March that said his account had been withheld in India. In the email, seen by the Guardian, no specific tweet or activity by Sandhu was cited by Twitter for its action. âThe Indian government has made it a norm to take draconian measures and crack down on dissent coming from Sikh or other minority communities,â Sandhu said. âTwitterâs actions are just another example [that imply] civil liberties and democratic rights are under attack.â âMy entire account, not any tweet, has been banned in India. It is blanket censorship. And there is absolute silence from Twitter on this.â Freedom House, a US-based nonprofit organisation, has accused the prime minister Narendra Modiâs government of âdriving India toward authoritarianismâ and in 2021 downgraded Indiaâs status from âfreeâ to âpartly freeâ. India, the third-largest market for Twitter after the US and Japan, is proving to be one of its biggest challenges. Responding to a tweet about censorship in India, Elon Musk, who completed a takeover of Twitter in October and calls himself a âfree speech absolutistâ, tweeted: âIt is not possible for me to fix every aspect of Twitter worldwide overnight, while still running Tesla and SpaceX, among other things.â Social media platforms including Twitter had been seen as one of the remaining avenues for Indian people to express dissent, after traditional media houses largely caved in to pressure from the government to toe its line. Twitter sued the government in July over takedown orders, after the government introduced legislation in 2021 aimed at regulating every form of digital content, including online news, social media, and streaming platforms and empowering itself to remove content it deemed âobjectionableâ. Prateek Waghre, the policy director of the Internet Freedom Foundation, said much of the content being withheld was reportage that did not portray the government in a positive light. âThere is no contention. It is just absurd,â he added. Since his takeover, Musk has reportedly slashed Twitterâs workforce by 90% in India. âThere is a question if Twitter still has people to vet these requests,â Waghre said. âThe question is also on the willingness of a pushback, which has certainly reduced [since Musk takeover].â Raqib Hameed Naik, the founder of Hindutva Watch, a US-based site that tracks hate crimes in India, described the situation as âvery grimâ. âBig tech has completely surrendered to the authoritarian regime of PM Narendra Modi,â he said. âTwitterâs conduct in India sets a worrying trend of silencing media, critics and dissenters worldwide.â Sandhu said he was not optimistic about Indiaâs ability to âuphold minimal requirements for a healthy democracyâ, describing the system as ârotten to the coreâ.
headline: Twitter accused of censorship in India as it blocks Modi critics

chat_gpt_summary: Twitter changed its blue bird logo to a dog meme associated with Dogecoin, but Elon Musk, the owner, provided no explanation. Speculations arose about it being an April Fool's prank or a distraction from a lawsuit against Musk by Dogecoin investors. The lawsuit claims Musk manipulated the cryptocurrency's value for profit. Dogecoin's value surged after Musk's announcement about Tesla merchandise. Twitter's worth has reportedly decreased, and it has yet to remove blue ticks for verified users as promised.
article: Almost 24 hours after Twitter changed its blue bird logo to a badly cut-out image of a dog meme made famous by cryptocurrencies, the companyâs billionaire owner, Elon Musk, has still offered no explanation or justification for the change. On Monday, US time, users noted that the blue bird logo on Twitterâs homepage and loading screen had been replaced with the shiba inu image associated with the Dogecoin memecoin cryptocurrency. For hours, neither Twitter nor Musk even acknowledged the change. Adding to the confusion was an apparently unrelated bug that surfaced at the same time, one of an increasing number in Twitterâs user interface, which removed the ability to tell which tweets had been retweeted on to your timeline. In typical Musk fashion, he eventually tweeted a meme noting the change, and followed up with the closest to an explanation he has proffered: a callback to a joke a follower made in March 2022 suggesting that he should buy Twitter and replace the logo with Doge. The official Dogecoin account tweeted in response: âVery currency. Wow. Much Coin. How Money. So Crypto.â An email requesting comment from Twitterâs press office received only the automatic response, a single poo emoji, that has sufficed for Twitterâs public relations operation since late March. Some users speculated it was meant to be an April foolâs day gag that the company was unable to bring in on time on 1 April. Others wondered if it was an effort to flood out news of a court case against Musk. The change came just days after Musk petitioned a court in the US to dismiss a lawsuit filed against him by Dogecoin investors for $258bn over an alleged pyramid scheme. Reuters reported in June last year that according to the complaint, the plaintiffs claim Musk knew that since 2019 the cryptocurrency had no value, but promoted Dogecoin to profit from its trading. âMusk used his pedestal as worldâs richest man to operate and manipulate the Dogecoin Pyramid Scheme for profit, exposure and amusement,â the complaint reportedly stated. The plaintiffs reportedly complained the sell-off of Dogecoin began when Musk appeared on Saturday Night Live and referred to Dogecoin as a âhustleâ in a segment. Lawyers for Musk and Tesla have called the lawsuitâs allegations a âfanciful work of fictionâ over Muskâs âinnocuous and often silly tweetsâ about Dogecoin. The value of Dogecoin jumped last year after Musk announced Tesla merchandise could be bought using it. On Twitterâs logo changing, Dogecoinâs value jumped from US$0.079 to US$0.094, the highest value the currency has been since November last year. Twitter is now worth less than $20bn, according to a leaked internal memo, under half what Musk paid for it six months ago. Despite promising to remove legacy blue ticks for verified users from 1 April, the site has only so far removed the tick for the New York Timesâs main Twitter account.
headline: Twitter makes unexplained logo change to Dogecoin cryptocurrency image

chat_gpt_summary: Twitter has not removed blue ticks from legacy verified users as announced by Elon Musk. The New York Times' blue tick was removed after they declined to pay for the service, leading to speculation of retaliation. Twitter removed the information distinguishing legacy verified accounts from Twitter Blue subscribers. Musk mentioned adding a verified date only for subscribers. Twitter's worth has reportedly decreased to less than $20bn, and the platform no longer has a communications department.
article: Twitter has so far not followed through on an announcement that it would remove blue ticks from legacy verified users, meaning those users continue to display them alongside paying subscribers. Last month, Twitterâs billionaire owner, Elon Musk, announced that from 1 April, legacy verified users would have their blue ticks removed from the service unless they paid the US$8 a month subscription fee for Twitter Blue. For organisations, the fee is US$1,000 a month. As April foolâs day came and passed, the blue ticks remained, despite much anticipation. As of Sunday, Musk appears to have only removed one blue tick: that for the account of the New York Times. This appears to have been done in retaliation for the news outlet announcing it would not pay for the service, according to a reply from Musk. The New York Times also reportedly told reporters that it would not reimburse their costs for subscribing to Twitter Blue, except where it may be needed for their reporting. The Times had reported that Twitter would keep the verification badge for the 10,000 most followed organisations, which would include the Times with nearly 55m followers. The Washington Post reported on Friday that the removal of legacy verification badges may take a long time because the process may require a lot of manual elements. On Sunday, Twitter also removed the information that differentiated between legacy verified accounts and Twitter Blue subscribers, with users told when clicking the tick that the account is âverified because itâs subscribed to Twitter Blue or is a legacy verified account.â Users that had subscribed to the service had sometimes found themselves ridiculed on the platform for paying for the account, and Twitter was reportedly also mulling an option for subscribers to hide their verified badges. Musk on Sunday said Twitter would also add a verified date to a userâs account, but this would only apply to subscribers. Last week Musk backed down on a plan to only promote verified users through the companyâs âFor Youâ timeline that is algorithmically curated, stating other users would be visible as well in that feed. A leaked memo from Musk last week also revealed Twitter is worth less than half what the billionaire paid for it six months ago, down to less than US$20bn. Twitter no longer has a communications department.
headline: Twitter legacy blue ticks remain despite Elon Muskâs subscription threat

chat_gpt_summary: Catherine Lacey, author of novels like "The Answers" and "Pew," discusses her new book "Biography of X." The novel follows a widow uncovering the life story of her avant-garde artist wife in a parallel America. Lacey explains how she developed the idea of a fake biography and an alternate history. She also shares her connection to the American South and her fascination with characters struggling to exist. Lacey recommends Joshua Rivkin's biography of Cy Twombly and praises Lyn Hejinian's memoir "My Life."
article: Catherine Lacey, 37, is the author of three previous novels, including The Answers, currently being adapted for television by Darren Aronofsky, and Pew (2020), about a nameless amnesiac of ambiguous race and gender. Her new novel, Biography of X, set in a parallel America, follows a widow untangling the life story of her wife, an avant-garde artist known as X. The New York Times has called it âsprawling and ambitiousâ¦ strange and dystopianâ. Lacey, one of Grantaâs best young American novelists in 2017, was speaking from her home in Brooklyn. Which part of the book came first: the alternate history or the fake biography? I liked the idea of writing a fake biography and the biographies I like best are usually written by someone with some kind of compromised perspective. I thought the worst person to write a biography would be a surviving spouse with a bit of a grudge, but I didnât want to get into the heterosexual dynamics of a man writing about a woman or a woman writing about a man; it had to be two women. At the same time, I wanted the novel to be set in the mid-20th century but I wasnât interested in writing about the actual struggles a prominent lesbian couple would have gone through in that time. So my alternate history grew out of that problem. I thought, if I have an America where this female artist could exist and this couple could exist without having to justify themselves, I just need a totally different America. As a workaround, it hardly cut corners. I liked that! I started the novel in 2016 at the same time that I was writing Pew, which takes place in a week and was so spare. Iâd decided to make myself write Pew quickly to see what would happen; I found that I can do it, I just prefer not to. Biography of X was more a kind of collecting project that I knew would take longer. Where do the various photographs of X come from? A lot of them I found in junk shops; for the images of her books, I commissioned jackets from a book designer. Why did you include real names from the art and book world? I saw it as another tool to make the novel as much like a biography as possible. Thereâs a quote [used in the book] from the New Yorker critic Merve Emre that is actually something she wrote about a Susan Sontag biography. There are a lot of names in there. A lot of them I made up. Like the critic âRichard Cuskâ. His quote is from Rachel Cuskâs essay on Celia Paul, about being female and making art. It was full of insights related to what I was writing, but by the time I set up the novelâs world I knew the essay would have to be flipped into a man arguing for his right to make art. Why does the story stop short of the 21st century? My fiction has never actively involved cellphones or the internet. Itâs too big; I canât get near it. The internet Iâm still on mentally is the more isolated, late 90s internet that was about weird web design and play. It wasnât that constant nervous Twitter energy, which repels me. I do use cellphones and the internet â Iâm not off in a cabin â but theyâre a plot killer. Did you have qualms about portraying the American south as a separatist theocracy? Itâs an exaggerated nightmare of what could have happened to that part of the country. I didnât want a cheap shot. Iâm southern. I grew up in Mississippi and then in Tennessee and my whole family still lives in Mississippi. I donât want to be one of those people who dismisses Mississippi as full of ignorant racists, because itâs not. The culture I grew up in is the reason I write. I think for a lot of writers coming out of the south itâs a very complicated place. Itâs America magnified: everything problematic about America just made really big. What draws you to characters who find it so hard simply to exist? I think itâs reacting to my very biblical childhood. Itâs not a conscious thing: âOh, Iâll insert a character that refuses identity or has difficulty with a fundamental aspect of their existence.â I think itâs just what happens when you leave a religion. Part of you is always going to ask: âWhy? Why any of this?â Not many of the people I grew up with have left the south and most of the ones who go to church take a soft view of their own belief: âMaybe thereâs a god, maybe there isnât; it doesnât really matter, I just like going to church.â I could never be that way; the minute I didnât believe, I couldnât go. Name a (real) biography you admire. Joshua Rivkinâs Chalk: The Art and Erasure of Cy Twombly. While he was writing it the estate decided they didnât want him to do it and started making his life very difficult. So halfway through the biography his attempt to write the book becomes part of the story. He gets at something of Twomblyâs life and work and the way people respond to it. I broke down looking at his last painting at the Twombly museum in Houston. Most Twombly fans â and Iâd put myself in this category â have some very extreme response to his work that feels mysterious. What else have you enjoyed reading recently? My Life by Lyn Hejinian: a strange, amazing memoir. Last summer, I was staying with a friend who had it in her house. I picked it up one morning and read it all that day. I used to be very rigid about what I read and when; I used to have a schedule, almost. But I find Iâm much happier when I just let books sort of stumble into my life. â¢ Biography of X is published on 6 April by Granta (Â£18.99). To support the Guardian and Observer order your copy at guardianbookshop.com. Delivery charges may apply
headline: Catherine Lacey: âThat constant nervous Twitter energy repels meâ

chat_gpt_summary: The article highlights the coincidental timing of legal verdicts involving former President Donald Trump's indictment over hush money payments and Gwyneth Paltrow's courtroom win in a ski accident case. Twitter users reacted with mixed emotions, with some finding humor and others noting the scripted-like nature of the events. Speculation arose about the celebrities' reactions to sharing the spotlight.
article: An ex-president indicted for alleged hush money payments to a porn star. A wealthy actor and wellness guru vindicated in a nail-biting fight for justice against a retired optometrist. And all in the space of a few hours. The reaction on Twitter was clear: God bless America. Social media was quick to flood with users highlighting the remarkable timing of the verdicts. First came the supposedly untouchable Donald Trump, who was indicted by a New York grand jury over an alleged hush money payment made to the adult film actress Stormy Daniels during the 2016 election. Less than two hours later, in a Utah courtroom, a jury sided with Gwyneth Paltrow, finding her not at fault for a ski accident with Terry Sanderson at a posh mountain resort, and awarding her $1 in compensation. Trump, whose other accomplishments include trying to overturn a legitimate election and seeking political counsel from a pillow salesman, will soon be fingerprinted and processed for a felony arrest â marking a first for a US president. Paltrow, a Hollywood nepo baby turned orgasm-candle salesperson, captivated onlookers during a weighty civil suit, which offered a rare glimpse into what itâs like to be absurdly rich. Some Twitter users reacted with pure, unfiltered joy. Others remarked that a better afternoon of legal drama couldnât have been scripted for television. The timing also led to speculation about how the two celebrities might feel about sharing the spotlight.
headline: Trump loses, Paltrow wins: Twitter marks a historic afternoon for America

chat_gpt_summary: Twitter has reversed its decision to limit the "for you" timeline to paying subscribers only, following backlash. Elon Musk, the owner, stated that he had "forgotten" to mention that other users would still be visible. The move was initially aimed at addressing AI bot swarms. Musk has been concerned about spam accounts, even before acquiring Twitter. Plans to introduce paid-only voting in polls are still underway, but there is no confirmation of Musk stepping down as head of the company.
article: Twitter has reversed course on plans to limit presence on its âfor youâ timeline to paying users only, with Elon Musk claiming he âforgot to mentionâ that other users would be visible as well. When the companyâs owner first announced the plan on Tuesday he said it would limit the tab that algorithmically curates tweets for users to only display accounts who had paid Â£8 a month for âTwitter Blueâ and linked their account to a working phone number. Musk said restricting it to those subscribers, who will be the only âverifiedâ users on the site after Twitter closes its âlegacyâ verification program on Saturday, was âthe only realistic way to address advanced AI bot swarms taking overâ. The announcement was met with a backlash from many users, however, and later that day Musk said in a second tweet: âForgot to mention that accounts you follow directly will also be in For You, since you have explicitly asked for them.â Since its launch under Musk, as a rebranded version of the pre-existing ârecommendedâ feed, the for you tab has proved controversial. It is more aggressively curated than its predecessor, regularly inserting tweets from accounts the user does not follow, and has a noted predilection for pushing tweets from a small number of prominent accounts into as many feeds as possible: such as Menswear commentator @dieworkwear, conservative commentator Ben Shapiro and almost every public post from Musk himself. The stated rationale for limiting the for you tab to paid accounts only was to prevent âbot swarmsâ from dominating it. Musk has been focused on the prominence of automated spam accounts since before he even bought the site, citing spam as one of the key reasons why he wanted to acquire it, and later citing the same spam as one of the reasons he should be allowed to renege on the deal. However, his focus stepped into a higher gear in late December, after he posted a âbindingâ poll to ask whether he should step down as the head of the company. Within 24 hours, more than 10 million users had voted in favour of him resigning, 57.5% of the overall votes. The following day, Musk broke his silence only to tweet the word âinterestingâ to several suggestions that the results of the poll were skewed by fake accounts, and to agree with a suggestion that only paid-for accounts should be able to vote in polls. That policy is on track to be introduced on 15 April, Musk said in a tweet on Tuesday. Musk has yet to confirm any plans to step down as head of the company.
headline: Twitter to no longer only promote paid-for accounts after backlash

chat_gpt_summary: Twitter's owner and CEO, Elon Musk, announced that the platform's "For you" feed will exclusively promote tweets from verified accounts who pay the Â£8 monthly subscription fee, starting from April 15. Musk claims it's necessary to combat AI bot swarms. Poll voting will also require verification. Existing "legacy verified" users will lose their badges unless they subscribe. Special privileges remain for a selected list of 35 VIP users, including Musk, to reassure him of algorithmic changes not affecting his reach.
article: Twitterâs feed will promote only the tweets of users paying its Â£8 monthly subscription service, Elon Musk, the siteâs owner and chief executive, has tweeted. From 15 April, the âFor youâ tab on the site, which attempts to algorithmically curate popular posts for users, will feature only âverified accountsâ, Musk tweeted, describing the decision as âthe only realistic way to address advanced AI bot swarms taking overâ. Voting in polls on the site will also require verification âfor same reasonâ, Musk added. From 1 April, existing users with verification badges on the site, now known as âlegacy verifiedâ, will lose them unless they pay the monthly fee. A âverified accountâ will need to pay the Â£8 fee and provide a working phone number. In 2022, Musk proposed requiring users to pay a fee to vote in polls, after a public proposal that he step down as chief executive of the site came to a surprise close with a large majority in favour of him quitting. Although he had initially promised the vote would be binding, in the hours after he began flirting with the idea that a large number of âbotâ accounts had skewed the vote. As well as the Â£8 monthly service for Twitter Blue, organisations have been offered a distinctive form of verification, which gives a yellow tick, with a price tag of $1,000 a month. That allows them to bestow further verification for their employees, for another $10 a month, while linking them back to the company. Not everything is bad for the former Twitter elite, though. According to a report from the Platformer newsletter, Twitter still offers special service to a hand-picked list of 35 VIPs, including Musk himself, who are artificially promoted on the platformâs algorithmic feeds. The list includes a bizarre selection of power users from across American society, including the politicians Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez and Joe Biden, journalists Ben Shapiro, Matthew Yglesias and Glenn Greenwald, and the poster Dril, who once tweeted (in capitals): âIf the zoo bans me for hollering at the animals I will face god and walk backwards into hell.â But the list was not created to boost the accounts, according to the report. Instead, it was assembled to help reassure Musk that algorithmic changes were not affecting his own reach. A cross-section of the platformâs biggest accounts, it helped demonstrate which changes to the ranking system were meaningful, in the process increasing their engagement.
headline: Twitter to promote only paying usersâ tweets, Elon Musk announces

chat_gpt_summary: Twitter is taking legal action to identify the leaker who posted parts of its source code on GitHub. The code was released by a user named "FreeSpeechEnthusiast." Leaked source code can pose security vulnerabilities. Twitter's cybersecurity setup was criticized by a former head of security, Peiter "Mudge" Zatko. Elon Musk revealed in a memo that Twitter's value has decreased by half since his acquisition. The platform has faced challenges like an advertiser boycott and concerns over moderation standards.
article: Twitter has revealed some of its source code has been released online and the social media platform owned by Elon Musk is taking legal action to identify the leaker. According to a court filing made on Friday, Twitter is demanding that GitHub, a code-sharing service, identifies who released on the platform parts of its source code â the underlying software on which the service operates. GitHub has taken down the leaked code but Twitter has asked a US court to order the Microsoft-owned business to âidentify the alleged infringer or infringers who posted Twitterâs source code on systems operated by GitHub without Twitterâs authorisationâ. The code was posted online by a GitHub user who used the name FreeSpeechEnthusiast, in an apparent nod to Musk, referring to himself as a âfree speech absolutist.â Musk is obsessed with the threat of Twitter being sabotaged by current and former staff, according to the tech newsletter Platformer, after a takeover that led to the immediate firing of half of Twitterâs 7,500 staff and the reinstatement of formerly suspended rightwing accounts including that of Donald Trump. Twitterâs workforce now numbers fewer than 2,000 people. In the court filing, Twitterâs assistant general counsel, Julian Moore, said the request to identify the leaker was being made under the Digital Millennium Copyright Act, which came into force in 1998. Leaking source code could allow security vulnerabilities, according to one expert. âLeaks of source code like this can allow security vulnerabilities to be identified and may disclose sensitive commercial information,â Steven Murdoch, a professor of security engineering at University College London, said. âHowever, Twitterâs most valuable resources are its brand, customer base, and the skills of its employees. I would be surprised if this leak has any significant long-term effect on the company.â Twitterâs cybersecurity setup was strongly criticised by a whistleblower before Musk completed his takeover. Twitterâs former head of security, Peiter âMudgeâ Zatko, who was fired in January 2022, claimed he had uncovered âextreme, egregious deficiencies by Twitter in every area of his mandateâ, including weak controls of employee access to user data and interference by foreign governments. The filing on Friday was made as Musk revealed to employees that the business he bought for $44bn (Â£36bn) in October is now worth less than half that, according to a memo seen by the New York Times. The memo said Twitter, which has debts of $13bn related to the financing of the takeover, had been four months away from running out of money. The platform, which makes most its revenue from advertising, has been hit by an advertiser boycott after Muskâs acquisition, amid concerns over issues including moderation standards and the impact of job cuts. GitHub has been contacted for comment. A request for comment from Twitterâs press office was met with an automated reply containing a poo emoji, a new policy announced by Musk this month.
headline: Twitter takes legal action after source code leaked online

chat_gpt_summary: Twitter's value has reportedly dropped to less than half of what Elon Musk paid for it six months ago, losing over $20 billion. Musk's leaked memo suggested the company is now valued at less than $20 billion, compared to the $44 billion he paid in October 2022. Advertiser departures and a devaluation of Fidelity's stake have contributed to the decline. Musk mentioned a path to a $250 billion valuation and proposed a stock grants model similar to SpaceX's.
article: Twitter is worth less than half of what Elon Musk paid for it six months ago having lost more than $20bn (Â£16.4bn) in value, according to calculations based on a leaked memo from the billionaire. Musk suggested in memo to the social media companyâs staff that it is now valued at less than $20bn. This compares with the $44bn he paid for it in October 2022. The companyâs steep devaluation follows Muskâs turbulent takeover. Several large advertisers have left the platform and a major source of funds for Muskâs purchase of the company, the investment firm Fidelity, has written down the value of its stake by 56%. The measure of Twitterâs worth was based on Muskâs offer of stock grants, according to Platformer and the Information, which first reported on the memo. Generally used as way to incentivise employees, stock grants are an opportunity to buy shares that cannot be sold until a set point in time, as opposed to stock options, which - depending on the conditions applied - can be more flexible. The aim is to encourage staff to reach a set valuation by a point in time so that they can sell their shares for cash. The stock grants could be âsold every six months, based on a third party valuationâ, another separate internal email to Twitter staff said. Muskâs email also said that, before a spate of high-profile, acrimonious layoffs the company had been about four months from running out of money. Twitterâs headcount has been cut from about 7,500 to about 2,000 employees, according to figures Musk put forward in December. In his latest memo, he also told staff: âI see a clear, but difficult, path to a >$250B valuation,â which would imply a tenfold increase in share value. The memo suggests the model would be similar to that which Musk, who also runs Tesla, has adopted at SpaceX, another of his companies, which allows staff to sell shares back to it. This can be a lucrative incentive if the companyâs value rises significantly, but it is not as flexible as selling a listed stock.
headline: Elon Musk memo suggests Twitter worth less than half of what he paid for it

chat_gpt_summary: Twitter has failed to have a complaint by the Australian Muslim Advocacy Network (Aman) dismissed, accusing the platform of not taking action against accounts promoting hatred. Aman lodged a complaint with the Queensland Human Rights Commission, alleging that Twitter Australia and Twitter Inc were responsible for hateful content. Twitter argued that the complaint lacked substance and that the legislation did not apply to them. The commission, however, disagreed and referred the matter to the Queensland Civil and Administrative Tribunal for a jurisdictional decision.
article: Twitter has lost a bid to have a complaint by an advocacy group for Australian Muslims thrown out after they accused the platform of failing to take action against accounts that incite hatred. The Australian Muslim Advocacy Network (Aman) lodged a complaint to the Queensland Human Rights Commission (QHRC) last June. They argued that, as a publisher, Twitter Australia and Twitter Inc are responsible for content posted by a far-right account that has been referred to in the manifesto of a white supremacist and mass murderer. Aman says the platform has repeatedly refused to delete the account or take down replies to its posts which refer to the Qurâan as âthe terrorist handbookâ and to Islam as âthe most violent and sexually perverse cultâ. The complaint to the commission contained 419 items, including 29 tweets it claims incited hatred and 390 comments and quotes on those tweets. Aman made the complaint under Queenslandâs Anti-Discrimination Act, alleging Twitter incited hatred as a publisher of third-party accounts, as well as discrimination for refusing to take action against hateful content. Twitter hit back at the complaint, arguing it should be dismissed as it was âmisconceivedâ and âlacking in substanceâ, according to a letter detailing the QHRCâs decision. Sign up for Guardian Australiaâs free morning and afternoon email newsletters for your daily news roundup The letter, seen by Guardian Australia, argued Twitter Australia was the wrong entity for the complaint as it does not host, operate, or control the Twitter service â which is controlled by Twitter Inc. Twitter Inc argued Queenslandâs Anti-Discrimination Act does not apply to it, as the platform is âincorporated under the laws of the state of Delaware in the United Statesâ. The company also refuted the idea that âany courts or tribunals in Queensland are or can be a âcourt of competent jurisdictionâ in relation to the complaintâ. In a decision by the QHRC, a commission officer said they could not agree that the complaint was âmisconceived or lacking in substanceâ. The officer also questioned Twitterâs claims that the stateâs legislation does not apply to them, before referring the matter to the Queensland Civil and Administrative Tribunal for a decision on jurisdiction. âA foreign person is not immune from [the] application of Queensland legislation in respect of things that occur in Queensland,â the officer said. âThe service is available and operates within Queensland and as such, it is likely to be required [to] comply with Queensland legislation.â The QHRC officer wrote that the matter âremains unresolvedâ despite the parties participating in a conciliation conference on 11 October. Aman said Twitterâs approach âcontradictsâ the position put forward by Twitter Incâs chief executive, Elon Musk, at Februaryâs world government summit in Dubai. âSocial media companies should adhere to the laws of countries, and not try to put a thumb on the scale beyond the laws of countries,â Musk said at the summit. âI think that the general idea is to reflect the values of the people as opposed to imposing the values of, essentially San Francisco and Berkley, which are somewhat of a niche ideology as compared to the rest of the world.â Aman says community groups have been forced âto bring one legal action after another to assert their right to live free from discriminationâ. âThe case will deal with issues of public importance, such as the degree to which social media companies are liable for content published on their platform and whether it is discriminatory for platforms not to uphold local standards,â they said. A QHRC spokesperson said complaints lodged with the commission are âconfidentialâ and they âdo not provide any details about any complaint at any stage of proceedingsâ. They said the commission was âimpartial and will not take sidesâ. Twitter has been contacted for comment.
headline: Twitter loses bid to throw out complaint by Australian Muslim group over âhatefulâ content

chat_gpt_summary: Shares in banks worldwide have tumbled amid fears of a broader crisis triggered by the collapse of Silicon Valley Bank (SVB). The rapid spread of market concerns has been fueled by social media chatter, accelerating the panic. SVB's failure, coupled with online banking accessibility and viral social media behavior, has amplified the psychological factors behind a bank run. Regulators and bank executives are scrambling to respond to the unique challenges posed by social media-driven financial crises.
article: Shares in banks all over the world have plummeted in recent days as fears that the collapse of Silicon Valley Bank (SVB) could precipitate a wider crisis in the sector. The speed at which market jitters have spread across the world have forced bank executives and regulators to move with unprecedented swiftness: US authorities guaranteed all deposits in SVB â and smaller bank Signature â 48 hours after it collapsed. Just hours after Credit Suisseâs share price plunged on Wednesday, the Swiss central bank stepped in with a $54bn loan. While thereâs nothing new about a financial emergency, these crises â and their resulting responses â are unique in having been accelerated by a frenzy of social media chatter that has fuelled the panic. âIt was a bank sprint, not a bank runâ A bank run occurs when customers lose faith in an institutionâs ability to look after their money, and large numbers withdraw their deposits all at once. As more people withdraw their funds, the likelihood of the bank being able to cover the withdrawals falls, leading more customers to pile in and demand the return of their money. âIf you see a bomb disposal expert running down the street, donât ask them whatâs happened, just try to keep up,â writes Daniel Davies, the managing director of Frontline Analysts, in the Financial Times. Rumours around a bankâs solvency can build up for months or years before it leads to a run. Or it can happen in a matter of hours. The collapse of SVB was the second-largest bank failure in the history of the United States. The largest, Washington Mutual in 2008, took place over the course of eight months. SVBâs collapse played out in barely two days. Anxious Twitter posts and WhatsApp exchanges, coupled with the ease of access that online banking provides, are seen by analysts as a serious catalyst for the current crisis. Experts suggest that in the social media age, the psychological behaviour behind a bank run â mass fear from depositors of losing their savings â may be amplified and go viral quicker than bank officers and regulators can successfully respond. Michael Imerman, a professor at the Paul Merage School of Business at the University of California-Irvine, says that what happened to SVB was, âa bank sprint, not a bank run, and social media played a central role in that.â âYou should be absolutely terrified right nowâ What few SVB customers realised a week ago was how vulnerable their bank was. Like all banks, it had invested its customers deposits, with much of the money going into long-dated US government bonds. The problem was that bonds have an inverse relationship with interest rates, so when the Federal Reserve started to hike rates rapidly to combat inflation, the bonds SVB owned started to lose significant value. Many of SVBâs customers were also hurt by interest rate rises and needed to access their deposits to meet day-to-day business expenses. But with the value of their investments squeezed, the bank struggled to meet their customers demands. A decision to raise funds through a sale of shares proved to be the bankâs death knell. Venture Capital firm, Founders Fund, is reported to have told companies in its portfolio to move their money out of SVB. In the gossip-fuelled world of Silicon Valley, this news spread like wildfire. Customers withdrew $40bn â one-fifth of SVBâs deposits â in just a few hours. Mark Tluszcz, CEO of Mangrove Capital, tweeted: âIf you are not advising your companies to get the cash out, then you are not doing your job as a board member or as a shareholder.â Investor Bill Ackman tweeted that if federal regulators didnât quickly step in and guarantee all deposits, runs on other banks would start on Monday. âYou should be absolutely terrified right now,â investor Jason Calacanis tweeted, using all capital letters for emphasis. âThat is the proper reaction to a bank run and contagion.â Other high-profile entrepreneurs sounded the alarm which spread on social media, resonating loudly with the bankâs customers who tended to be tech-savvy entrepreneurs keenly tuned in to online chatter. Congressman Patrick McHenry, chairman of the US House Financial Services Committee, referred to the turmoil as, âthe first Twitter fuelled bank run.â Some messages that caused cold sweats among financial customers proved to be misleading, prompting calls to focus on facts not speculation. âThe last several days represent a unique incident fuelled by misinformation on social media and are not indicative of the health of our industry,â said Lindsey Johnson, president of the Consumer Bankers Association, in a statement. The fear spreads SVB might be the first bank run of the social media era, but it wasnât the first bank to see its fundamental business rocked by feverish Twitter speculation. Early on Thursday, Switzerlandâs Credit Suisse announced that it would take a $53.7bn loan from the Swiss central bank to shore up its finances after its share price fell by as much as 30%. The selloff occurred when the bankâs largest shareholder, Saudi National Bank (SNB), ruled out providing it with fresh funding because of restrictions limiting its holding. However, SNBâs chairman said Credit Suisse was âa very strong bankâ and was unlikely to need more cash after a major restructuring plan in autumn last year. A cap on how large its stake could be was the reason for not investing further. Credit Suisseâs problems are not new, the bankâs customers have weathered a series of scandals and stock fluctuations over the past decade which have led to an exodus of clients, pulling their cash from the bank, contributing to losses that grew to 7.3bn Swiss francs in 2022. But last October, its shares fell 12% in one day after a journalists tweeted that a âmajor international investment bankâ was on the brink. The tweet was then wrongly paraphrased by investing.com, which tweeted it out to their thousands of followers. The rumour spread like wildfire across online forums and social media accounts, but was, at least then, unfounded. Credit Suisseâs issues were well established by then and its share price had been declining for months, but experts have pointed to the tweet, and its subsequent dissemination, as highly damaging to the bank. Regulators, policymakers and bankers are all now being forced to look at the role that social media may have played in the current upheaval â and work out what they can possibly do to stay ahead of the rumours. Associated Press and Agence France-Presse contributed to this report
headline: âThe first Twitter-fuelled bank runâ: how social media compounded SVBâs collapse

chat_gpt_summary: Former Queensland supreme court chief justice, Catherine Holmes, praised reporters from Guardian Australia, the Saturday Paper, and citizen Twitter journalists for their comprehensive coverage of the robodebt royal commission, calling it a valuable public service. Holmes criticized other media outlets for their inconsistent coverage. The royal commission has been investigating the Centrelink income compliance program and the suffering experienced by robodebt victims. Holmes recognized the important role of social media, particularly Twitter, in providing access to the evidence and engaging the public in the inquiry.
article: The former Queensland supreme court chief justice overseeing the robodebt royal commission has singled out reporters from Guardian Australia and the Saturday Paper and citizen Twitter journalists for their âcommittedâ coverage of the evidence, calling it a âremarkably useful and important public serviceâ, while criticising many other media outlets for their âpatchyâ coverage. On the final day of hearings into the former Coalition governmentâs Centrelink income compliance program, just before closing statements, the commissioner, Catherine Holmes SC, took a few minutes to make observations about media coverage of the proceedings. âThis commission has to inquire and report, and an important part of the inquiry component is these public hearings because itâs the opportunity to explore evidence in a public forum,â Holmes said. âBut not many people have the practical ability, or the time or perhaps the will to sit through day after day of hearings. The interest of what Iâll call the traditional media to distinguish it from social media in these hearings has, with some honourable exceptions, been patchy.â Sign up for Guardian Australiaâs free morning and afternoon email newsletters for your daily news roundup In the five months the royal commission has been holding public hearings, victims of robodebt have described financial and emotional suffering in the face of an opaque and punitive government program that was designed for budget savings rather than social welfare. Media coverage across âtraditionalâ outlets tended âto flare when a minister is on the standâ, Holmes said. The royal commission heard from multiple former Coalition ministers, including former prime ministers Scott Morrison and Malcolm Turnbull, former human services minister Alan Tudge, former government services minister Stuart Robert and former social services minister and attorney general Christian Porter. âAs a result, Iâve come to appreciate the importance of social media in this context,â Holmes said. âIâve been struck by how committed and serious some of the people tweeting are. They provide an almost full-time running summary of evidence with occasional comment. Some of them are people whoâve long been engaged in the robodebt issue. And they both tweet and cross over into mainstream commentary. âIâm thinking of people like [law lecturer] Dr [Darren] OâDonovan, [Saturday Paper journalist] Mr [Rick] Morton and [Guardian Australia social affairs and inequality editor] Mr [Luke] Henriques-Gomes,â Holmes said. âI hasten to say I donât agree with every privacy or characterisation of the evidence that Iâve seen but I want to acknowledge that the Twitter coverage of these hearings has performed a remarkably useful and important public service in giving people access to the evidence.â The welfare advocate Tom Studans, who posts as @maximumwelfare, tweeted minute-by-minute updates of the commission on every day of inquiry hearings, while another account, @strangerous10, regularly posted video clips of the evidence. The royal commission held its final public hearing on Friday after 46 days of evidence.
headline: Robodebt inquiry commissioner criticises mainstream media, praising âcommittedâ coverage on Twitter

chat_gpt_summary: Labor has agreed to the Greens' demands to exclude financing for new gas, coal projects, and native logging from the proposed national reconstruction fund, bringing a major bill closer to realization. The Greens leader, Adam Bandt, hailed this as a victory for the climate and the economy. If passed, the bill would establish a $15 billion investment fund, described as one of the largest peacetime investments in manufacturing in Australia. The support of the Greens increases the chances of the bill passing the Senate.
article: Good afternoon. A major bill is closer to being realised after Labor agreed to Greensâ demands not to use the proposed national reconstruction fund to finance new gas and coal projects or native logging. âCoal and gas are the biggest cause of the climate crisis, so this is a big win for the climate and a big win for jobs and the economy,â the Greens leader, Adam Bandt, said. Greens support means the bill is now closer to passing the Senate later this month. If passed, it will establish an off-budget $15bn investment fund that the industry minister, Ed Husic, says is âone of the largest peacetime investments in manufacturing this country has ever seenâ. Bandt thanked the government for its âconstructive approachâ in negotiating the deal, and setting a positive tone between the two parties still trying to break an impasse over Laborâs safeguard mechanism policy. If you want to read more on how those talks could advance, read todayâs column from our climate and environment editor, Adam Morton. Top news PM promises âabsolute sovereigntyâ over submarines | Albanese made the remarks amid revelations that the UK had succeeded in its bid to sell Australia British-designed nuclear submarines. Australia will become the seventh country to have a nuclear-powered submarine fleet. That has drawn the ire of China, which has argued Australiaâs possession of the nuclear reactors is a breach of the Nuclear Non Proliferation Treaty. Oscar goodie bags contain Queensland âscrubâ | Oscar nominees are set to receive one square metre of land in outback Australia in their gift bags this year, but environmental organisations have questioned the environmental mission of the company. âPieces of Australiaâ is one of a number of brands to pay $4,000 to secure a spot in the hamper which is unaffiliated with the Academy, but sent by the company Distinctive Assets to the acting and directing nominees. But those gifted the land wonât be able to use the âsymbolic souvenirâ. Home values down 7.9% nationally | â¦ which is the largest slide over a 12-month period on record. Leading the way was Sydney â down 13.4%, then Hobart 11.8% Melbourne 9.6%, Brisbane 6.8% and Canberra 6.7%. Bucking the trend were Adelaide (up 5.1%), Darwin (up 2.9%) and Perth (up 2.4%). Labor, Greens back four-day work week | Senators from the two parties joined forces in recommending a four-day work week trial at full pay and more than double paid parental leave to 52 weeks. Free transport day for Sydney | To make up for yesterdayâs peak-hour meltdown of the Sydney train network, the New South Wales premier, Dominic Perrottet, has ordered a fare-free day be instituted. Perilous migrant path from China to the US | Thereâs a growing number of would-be Chinese migrants trying to reach the US via a dangerous jungle between Colombia and Panama. Numbers surged last year amid tough Covid lockdowns. âI donât know much about the US, but at least itâd be better than living in China â¦ Weâre like animals. We migrate to a warmer place, instead of staying in a cold place. We donât want to be frozen to death,â one asylum seeker said. Tucker Carlson âpassionately hatesâ Trump | Or so a text message on 4 January 2021, two days before the Capitol Hill insurrection, said. âI hate him passionately â¦ What heâs good at is destroying things. Heâs the undisputed world champion of that. He could easily destroy us if we play it wrong,â the Fox News host wrote. Georgia protests | Thousands are continuing to protest against a proposed law that would create a âforeign agentsâ register for organisations receiving more than 20% of their funding overseas. The law is similar to a 2012 law in Russia, and has raised concerns it could jeopardise Georgiaâs chances of joining the EU. Greece protests | Tens of thousands have staged protest rallies and workers staged a 24-hour general strike as anger over last weekâs train disaster intensified. âThis is more than a train collision and a tragic railway accident. You get the sense that the country has derailed,â said Nasos Iliopoulos, a spokesperson for Greeceâs main leftwing opposition party, Syriza. Full Story The battle over Laborâs key climate policy Negotiations over Laborâs major climate policy are in deadlock. With the governmentâs tight deadline to pass its bill to cut greenhouse gas emissions looming, whatâs holding up this deal? And whatâs at stake if the parties fail to reach a compromise? Listen to this 20-min episode. What they said â¦ *** âSome of the Closing the Gap targets are going backwards â¦ The one that really concerns me that has, where the statistics have gone backwards slightly, is the healthy birth weight of babies â¦ It is not good enough and I know everyone in this House agrees with that.â - Linda Burney Healthy birth weight is one of several Closing the Gap targets going backwards, the Indigenous affairs minister told parliament today. In numbers An NT government report also found levels of property break-ins were down by nearly 46% and youth offences were down by 36% since the restrictions were brought. Before bed read Twitter has broken down six times this year - most recently on Monday. Experts point to the sacking of thousands of workers, leaving too few engineers to catch and fix problems when they arise. Since Musk completed his US$44bn takeover of Twitter in October last year, the workforce has been reduced from 7,500 employees to about 2,000. âThe result is that eventually problems occur which are sufficiently serious to be noticed by large portions of Twitterâs user base,â said Steven Murdoch, a professor of security engineering at University College London. chat_gpt_summary: Twitter experienced its sixth outage this year, causing error messages and disruption for users. Speculation arose that demands made by Elon Musk, who recently took over Twitter, had contributed to the failure. The error message pointed to a mistaken change in the Twitter API, with Musk later acknowledging the need for a complete rewrite of the code. The regularity of the outages has raised concerns about a systemic problem, exacerbated by reductions in Twitter's engineering team. Financial pressures and cost-cutting measures further compound the situation.
article: On Monday Twitter broke for the sixth time this year. Clicking any link on the social network resulted in an error message, while attempting to post a new image resulted in nothing but a big blank box where the picture should have been. Unlike the last four outages â three in February, and another already in March â the site wasnât completely unavailable, giving Twitter users the opportunity to engage in their favourite activity: discussing the continued destruction of Twitter live on the site. (The sixth outage this year, in January, only affected Android users.) The trending topics on the site were promptly filled with various phrases relating to the outage, as users speculated that Elon Muskâs own demands had ultimately caused the failure. The error message referred to the Twitter API, a service that allows other programmes to interact with the site. In January, the company had, with no notice, banned third-party apps from using the API, rendering them non-functional overnight. The error message suggested that Twitter had continued tinkering with the feature and accidentally banned its own apps in the process. âA small API change had massive ramifications,â Musk confirmed later that day, calling the code of the site âextremely brittle for no good reasonâ. Fixing the problems, he added, would âultimately need a complete rewriteâ. Just a single reliability engineer had been allocated to a project to create a paid version of the API, according to a report in the Platformer newsletter, and that engineer pushed a mistaken change to the live version of the site without realising the ramifications. Mistakes happen, and Twitter isnât alone in being knocked offline by a single engineer: in 2021, Facebookâs services were offline for almost six hours after the company accidentally deleted itself from the âphone bookâ of the internet. But the regularity of the outages at Twitter, which seems to be getting worse over time, has left some wondering if the occasional errors are adding up to a more systemic problem. Steven Murdoch, a professor of security engineering at University College London, said substantial reductions in Twitterâs engineering team meant fewer people to monitor systems and catch minor problems before they become bigger. âThe result is that eventually problems occur which are sufficiently serious to be noticed by large portions of Twitterâs user base,â he said. âIt has been suggested that rewriting the Twitter code could help avoid such problems but this is a high-risk strategy. It would result in splitting the already-reduced engineering team between maintaining the old code and making the new version.â Pushing for such a rewrite has already been the cause of Muskâs downfall once before. In the early 00s, after his company, X.com, had merged with the creators of PayPal, Musk as chief executive led a project to merge the back-ends of the two companies, which had been built on incompatible systems. The rewrite spiralled into âa holy warâ, according to a 2007 profile of his time at PayPal, and just six months after the merger, Musk was fired as chief executive while on honeymoon. At Twitter, a rewrite will also have to compete with other demands on the companyâs time. On Tuesday, the Financial Times reported that the EU had demanded Musk hire more moderation experts in order to comply with the blocâs new regime for regulating social media platforms, while the US Federal Trade Commission is investigating the company amid concerns that Twitterâs ability to protect users might have been affected by redundancies. Since Musk completed the $44bn (Â£37bn) takeover of Twitter in October last year, the workforce has been reduced from 7,500 employees to about 2,000. On Tuesday, Musk apologised to a Twitter worker after becoming engaged in a spat with him over whether he still worked at the company or not. The exchange included Musk referring to Haraldur Thorleifssonâs disability as an âexcuseâ for his performance at work. Musk, who later apologised to Thorleifsson over a âmisunderstandingâ that led to his tweets, said Thorleifsson was now considering staying at the company. Cost-cutting measures under which Twitter has stopped paying bills for office space, janitorial supplies and even web hosting are starting to meet pushback. The company stepped back from a bruising confrontation with Amazon Web Services as it tried to negotiate a discount on its cloud computing, according to the news site The Information, while a similar standoff with Salesforce saw its Slack communications platform disabled entirely over one weekend in February, leaving staffers unable to collaborate. Twitterâs engineering problems are taking place against a backdrop of financial pressure against the company, which took on $13bn of debt as part of Muskâs funding package for the takeover. That debt requires quarterly interest payments of about $300m. Musk made the first payment in January but analysts have warned that the business, which was loss-making for the majority of its existence before the takeover, must stage a turnaround in order to make those payments consistently. The Tesla boss said this week that Twitter had a âshotâ at being cashflow positive in the next financial quarter, referring to one of the financial metrics that can be used to indicate whether a company can meet its debt payments. But at what cost? Twitter has a âshotâ at being financially sustainable due to cuts that appear to be affecting the reliability of the site as well as alarming regulators. According to Twitterâs last set of quarterly results as a listed company, published in 2022, Twitter generated negative free cashflow (spending more cash to run the business than it takes in) of nearly $124m. Musk also reiterated his plans to introduce payments on Twitter, and said he envisions users could eventually send money to each other with one click. âI think itâs possible to become the biggest financial institution in the world,â he said. However, advertising is Twitterâs largest source of revenue, accounting for the majority of its $5.1bn turnover in 2021, and Musk admitted soon after the $44bn takeover in October last year that there had been a âmassiveâ drop in advertising revenue. In January it was reported that Twitterâs daily revenue was down 40% compared with the previous year. Farhad Divecha, the managing director of UK digital marketing agency Accuracast, said: âTrust is a big factor right now, and these outages do not instil a lot of confidence in Twitterâs ability to service our clients to the level where we or the brands we represent feel comfortable putting money in the service.â Site breakages add another complication to Muskâs drive to put Twitter on a sustainable footing.
headline: Rise in Twitter outages since Musk takeover hints at more systemic problems

chat_gpt_summary: The ABC has accused News Corp and the Daily Mail of amplifying misogynistic social media abuse by publishing articles that showcased abusive tweets targeting News Breakfast host Lisa Millar over her outfit. The ABC criticized the outlets for giving publicity to anonymous bullies and perpetuating online abuse of women. The ABC's director of news, Justin Stevens, called the republishing of sexist abuse unacceptable, and Millar expressed her disappointment at the coverage on the eve of International Women's Day. Offensive tweets were later removed from the stories.
article: The ABC has accused News Corp and the Daily Mail of amplifying misogynist social media abuse by publishing articles that included âvileâ Twitter criticism of an outfit worn by News Breakfast host Lisa Millar. Millar was subjected to trolling for the skirt she wore on Mondayâs show, leading to two news stories that included screenshots and abusive tweets, first in the Daily Mail and then in news.com.au on Tuesday. The former foreign correspondent turned breakfast host abandoned Twitter in 2021 after a torrent of abuse about everything from her interview style to whether she smiles, but it has not stopped the critics. âGiving anonymous social media bullies publicity on a national platform is participating in perpetuating antisocial behaviour and the very serious issue of online abuse of women,â an ABC statement said. âEspecially on the eve of International Womenâs Day, we ask for a more responsible approach to reporting on these issues.â The ABCâs director of news, Justin Stevens, said republishing sexist abuse of a high-profile woman is unacceptable. âMedia outlets that amplify this disgusting anonymous trolling need to take a good hard look at themselves and their standards,â Stevens said. âThe relentless and vile bullying Lisa Millar is subjected to on social media, particularly Twitter, is unacceptable. She is an outstanding broadcaster and journalist and does an incredible job.â Guardian Australia understands Stevens also appealed directly to News Corpâs corporate affairs chief, Campbell Reid, to reconsider publishing stories like that. Some of the more offensive tweets have been removed from the story since the ABC complained. Millar has responded in an Instagram post that the coverage on the eve of International Womenâs Day âperpetuates abuse and proves to all of us how far we still have to goâ. âI would prefer to be thinking about the amazing contribution women around the world make, whether it be in their private or professional lives,â she said. The ABC was approached for comment by a news.com.au journalist at 6.42am, but the broadcaster said it was not going to dignify any âvile commentsâ being made about a presenterâs clothes by responding to them. âIf news.com.au was genuine in its concern about such behaviour, it wouldnât amplify it by republishing the comments it describes as âsickeningâ, accompanied by a screenshot,â the spokesperson said. The news.com.au story was positioned as critical of the trolls and headlined ââJust plain gutlessâ: Aussie Twitter users slam online trolls for sickening Lisa Millar commentsâ. The story ended with: âMillar returned to the set on Tuesday morning alongside co-host Michael Rowland wearing a green long-sleeve blouse and black slacks.â The ABC said it regularly receives queries concerning abusive comments âunder the guise of concernâ but that these stories âare republishing abuseâ. The news.com.au journalist asked the ABC: âI just wanted to check in to see how Lisa was doing and to see if she or the ABC wanted to comment on the behaviour of the trolls online for a story? âIf so, can you please provide a statement regarding how Lisa is doing, what ABCâs reaction is towards people making these inappropriate comments online, how the ABC plans to take action, if any, against those making inappropriate comments and what the ABC will do to ensure comments like this are regulated or prevented in the future.â News Corp and the Daily Mail have been approached for comment.
headline: ABC accuses News Corp and Daily Mail of amplifying misogynist Twitter abuse of Lisa Millar

chat_gpt_summary: Twitter experienced another outage, leaving the site nonfunctional for over an hour on Wednesday. Despite the fix, users still had difficulty accessing their home feed while notifications and direct messages worked. Elon Musk's ownership of Twitter has been marked by numerous layoffs, reduced communication, and cost-cutting measures. This outage marks the fifth this year, surpassing last year's total, raising concerns about the platform's stability.
article: Twitter was unavailable for users around the world for over an hour on Wednesday morning, the latest in a spate of technical difficulties suffered by the site since its takeover by Elon Musk. Beginning at about 10:20am UK time, visitors to Twitter.com were greeted with error messages. Although the total outage was rapidly fixed, the site remained in effect nonfunctional until well into the afternoon, with users unable to access their âhomeâ feed, despite notifications, profile visits and direct messages still working. Unusually, users could still post to the site throughout the outage, and the âtrending topicsâ continued to refresh, leading to trends including â#TwitterDownâ, âMy Twitterâ and âWelcome to Twitterâ. The âFor Youâ feed, which presents an algorithmic collection of the top tweets across the site, was restored before the home feed. Since taking over the business in November, new owner and chief executive Elon Musk has launched at least eight waves of punishing layoffs, reducing the headcount from 7,500 before he started to fewer than 2,000 people. Reports from inside the business have described âcriticalâ teams being laid off in their entirety, with hurriedly promoted replacements struggling to pick up where their departed colleagues left off. For the remaining staff, communication has also been hampered by other cost-cutting decisions. Twitter has stopped paying rent in locations around the world, reversing Muskâs initial push to force all staff to return to the office, while an unannounced reorganisation of its internal communication platform, Slack, saw employees cut off entirely for more than a day, until access was restored with more than 80,000 pre-existing channels archived. In November, after the second wave of layoffs â prompted by Muskâs demand that workers sign a pledge to an âextremely hardcoreâ mode of working â the chief executive reassured onlookers that Twitter would not shut down because of the lack of staff, saying âthe best people are staying, so Iâm not super worriedâ. Despite that, outages at the site have become an increasingly common occurrence. According to NetBlocks, Wednesdayâs outage is Twitterâs fifth this year, already putting the platform over halfway towards topping its 2022 total.
headline: Twitter down for more than an hour around world

chat_gpt_summary: Elon Musk has reportedly fired 200 staff at Twitter, including the executive responsible for the revamp of its paid premium service. The job cuts account for about 10% of Twitter's workforce, with positions such as product managers and engineers being affected. Esther Crawford, the director of product management, was among those reportedly let go. Musk's cost-cutting measures come as Twitter faces financial uncertainty and seeks to generate subscription revenue. The platform's premium subscription service, Twitter Blue, has approximately 180,000 subscribers in the US.
article: Elon Musk has fired another 200 staff at Twitter including the executive behind the revamp of its paid-for premium service, according to a report. The latest round of job cuts equates to about 10% of Twitterâs vastly reduced workforce, which stood at 7,500 people before Musk bought the company in October. According to the New York Times, Twitter sacked at least 200 employees from its 2,000-strong workforce on Saturday. The redundancies affected jobs including product managers, data scientists and engineers who ensure the site runs efficiently, the NYT reported. Esther Crawford, the director of product management at Twitter who oversaw the introduction of charging for account verification, was reportedly among the employees affected. Muskâs hard-driving approach to management was exemplified in November by a picture of Crawford sleeping on the floor of Twitterâs offices, which she retweeted with the hashtag #SleepWhereYouWork. Crawford, tweeted on Sunday that she was âdeeply proudâ of her team, as she criticised people who had jeered or mocked her achievements, although she did not confirm her departure directly. Twitterâs premium subscription service had a troubled relaunch in November after some users took advantage of paying for a verified account by launching a slew of impersonator accounts. Nintendo, the pharmaceutical firm Eli Lilly and the US politician Ted Cruz were among the firms and public figures who found themselves being impersonated by accounts with blue ticks. Twitter Blue was relaunched again in December and, according to news site the Information, has 180,000 subscribers in the US compared with a global monthly user base of more than 250 million people. Musk has identified growth in subscription revenue as a key target for Twitter, which relied on advertising for the majority of its income prior to his takeover but has suffered a plunge in ad revenue because of issues including the impersonation problem. The job losses have taken place against a backdrop of financial uncertainty at Twitter, a company that has been loss-making historically and has struggled to generate the cash flow required to pay off the significant debts it inherited after Muskâs $44bn (Â£36.7bn) takeover. The dealâs financing included $13bn worth of debt that now sits on Twitterâs balance sheet and costs more than $1bn a year to service. Twitter made the first quarterly payment on that debt in January, but analysts have warned that Musk needs to turn round the business in order to make the debt sustainable in the long term. Musk sacked half of Twitterâs workforce, about 3,750 people, within days of taking over the business and hundreds more left weeks later after the Tesla CEO demanded that staff commit to being âhardcoreâ or leave. Musk said in December that his cost-cutting drive meant Twitter was is ânot on the fast lane to bankruptcy any moreâ but he has continued to take action on costs in 2023. Twitter has been contacted for comment.
headline: Elon Musk fires additional 200 people at Twitter, report says

chat_gpt_summary: The BBC has retracted a story about Will Ferrell apologizing to Sunderland football fans after falling for a parody Twitter account with a paid-for blue tick. The account impersonated Ferrell and tweeted an apology, fooling readers. Twitter's shift to paid verification has led to an increase in impersonation incidents. Meta, the parent company of Facebook and Instagram, has announced plans to offer paid verification with higher costs and identity verification requirements.
article: The BBC has removed a story about Will Ferrell apologising to Sunderland football fans, after being fooled by a parody Twitter account with a paid-for blue tick. Ferrell, who has been touring Britain attending football matches over the past month, recorded a video before Sunderland played his team, Queens Park Rangers, in which he mocked âthe tears of sorrowâ his opponents were going to experience. After the match â which Sunderland won 3-0 â a Twitter account named âWill Ferrellâ tweeted a screenshot of a headline about Sunderland fans hitting back, and said âHaway man, sorryâ. Readers who tapped on the account (@OfficialWilllF, with three âlâs) would see it had a blue âverifiedâ tick. But only if they tapped on the tick itself would they be told that the account âis verified because itâs subscribed to Twitter Blueâ, Twitterâs paid-for subscription. The accountâs bio reads âComedian, actor, impressionist (parody)â and has fewer than 40,000 followers. âIn a BBC News Online article, we incorrectly stated QPR fan and actor Will Ferrell apologised for mocking Sunderland fans,â the broadcaster said in a statement. âA quote was taken from a verified Twitter account, but it was not made by the actor.
