First, Warren Buffett at the Buffalo News, my hometown paper where I started as a summer intern and became the first woman top editor; and more recently, Jeff Bezos at the Washington Post, where I was the paperâs media columnist for six years, mostly during the legendary Marty Baronâs stint as executive editor. Both Buffett and Bezos made it easier for those running their media operations â they trusted their appointed people and didnât interfere editorially. So, one key to running Twitter is the tricky matter of âmanaging upâ. Anyone whoâs ever worked in a corporation or big agency, especially as a manager, knows that you have to handle the boss. You have to keep them informed, hold off their worst instincts, tactfully set boundaries and, most of all, somehow convince them that every move you make is really their brilliant idea â or at least a fulfillment of their underlying vision. And thereâs the rub. Twitterâs problems are solvable. But the volatile and narcissistic Musk may be the boss that canât be managed. Margaret Sullivan is a Guardian US columnist writing on media, politics and culture.
headline: How I would fix Twitter if I were CEO | Margaret Sullivan

chat_gpt_summary: Twitter is facing lawsuits from landlords in San Francisco and London for allegedly failing to pay rent on its offices. The Crown Estate in London and the owner of Twitter's San Francisco headquarters have filed claims against the company. This comes after reports of unpaid rent on other Twitter offices, including one in San Francisco and another in Singapore. The legal actions follow Elon Musk's takeover of Twitter, which has been marred by job cuts, a relaunch controversy, and a drop in revenue.
article: Twitter is being sued by landlords in San Francisco and London after failing to pay rent on its offices, as new owner Elon Musk takes on extreme cost-cutting strategies that reportedly include simply not paying the bills. The crown estate in London, which manages property belonging to King Charles III, filed a claim against Twitter in the high court in the UK capital last week. The alleged rental arrears relate to office space near Piccadilly Circus in central London, according to the BBC. The owner of Twitterâs San Francisco headquarters has also sued Twitter after it failed to make its latest monthly rent payment for January, amounting to $3.4m, according to documents filed on Friday with the superior court of California. This comes after a report earlier this month stated that Twitter owed $136,260 in overdue rent on a separate office in San Francisco and was facing a lawsuit. Also in January, workers at a Twitter office in Singapore were evicted due to unpaid rent on the building. Twitter did not immediately respond to a request for comment. The actions came only a few months after Twitter was taken over by Elon Musk, the co-owner of Tesla and SpaceX, in October last year. Musk paid $44bn (Â£36bn) for the platform and quickly initiated sweeping job cuts to the firmâs 7,000-strong workforce â cutting it by 50%. Muskâs takeover has not been without issues, including a chaotic relaunch of the blue tick scheme for verified users that led to a number of impersonator accounts and advertisers withdrawing from the platform over concerns about a rise in hate speech. The social media company was reportedly hit by a 40% drop in revenue after more than 500 clients paused their spending, with high-profile brands such as Audi and Pfizer halting advertising. The BBC reported that the crown estate took legal action after previously contacting the social media company about the alleged rental arrears at its office space. John Wallace, a solicitor and director at the London-based law firm Ridgemont, said the hearing between the crown estate and Twitter was likely to take place in the next six months and warned that the UKâs struggling economy could lead to an increase in rent arrears claims. He said: âThe receding of the UKâs economy will inevitably lead to commercial landlords having to take action against non-paying tenants. âI would expect to see a sharp rise in commercial rent arrears claims in second and third quarters of 2023, given the Office for Budget Responsibilityâs prediction that a recession will last until at least autumn 2023.â The estate is one of the largest landowners in the UK, and although the portfolio belongs to the monarch, it is not private property. The revenue from the estate goes to the Treasury for public spending and in return the monarch receives the sovereign grant. Muskâs property woes are just the latest legal headache for the billionaire, who has been testifying in recent days in a separate class-action lawsuit from Tesla investors alleging his 2017 tweet misled them about funding to take the electric carmaker private. The Associated Press contributed reporting
headline: Twitter sued in London and San Francisco over alleged unpaid rent

chat_gpt_summary: Chanel's latest haute couture show, led by designer Virginie Viard, took inspiration from the animals of Coco Chanel's Paris apartment. The collection featured demure glitter tweed suits and abstract plywood sculptures by artist Xavier Veilhan. Chanel will be in the spotlight with a major exhibition honoring Karl Lagerfeld at the Metropolitan Museum of Art and a retrospective of Coco Chanel at the V&A. Chanel's relationship with Hollywood and its support of actors on the red carpet were also highlighted.
article: It was Coco herself who said fashion reflects the world we live in. But while much of fashion week holds up a mirror to the current era of roiling controversy and outrage â at Schiaparelli, a foam lionâs head worn by Kylie Jenner provoked social media fury from distressed animal lovers, until the president of Peta rode unexpectedly to coutureâs rescue by saying the look âcelebrates lionâs beautyâ â Chanel is the quiet eye of the storm. Virginie Viard, who replaced the great showman Karl Lagerfeld at Chanel four years ago, has introduced an understated mood here. The animals of Cocoâs elegant Paris apartment â where marble lions stood guard alongside pairs of carved wooden deer, and a lucky gold frog took pride of place on a coffee table â were the theme for her latest haute couture show. In contrast to Schiaparelliâs Instagram-bait of Kardashians and faux-taxidermy, the Trojan camels, stags and birds at Chanel were abstract plywood sculptures by artist Xavier Veilhan, and the models who emerged from them wore demure glitter tweed suits. Drama came with a light touch, in circus-master top hats and bow ties worn as chokers. Nonetheless, Chanel will have the lionâs share of the spotlight this year. A major exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum in New York honouring the career of Lagerfeld, who spent four decades at Chanel, will be followed by a major retrospective of Coco herself at the V&A in London later this year. Backstage before the show, Chanelâs president of fashion, Bruno Pavlovsky, said he had âseen the layout of the Met exhibition â it is fantastic. I worked with Karl for many years, and he was forever talking about the latest Met show. He really loved the museum.â Pavlovsky was also waiting to discover which of Chanelâs red carpet ambassadors would receive Oscar nominations. Last year was a successful award season for Chanel, who dressed best actress nominees Kristen Stewart and PenÃ©lope Cruz. âWe have fantastic actors who can help talk about our brand, so anytime when we can help them to be at their best is very important for us,â Pavlovsky said. âWe try to position ourselves as a supportive partner â it is a case of whatever they want, when they want it.â Chanelâs relationship with Hollywood began in 1931, when Gabrielle Chanel was invited by movie mogul Sam Goldwyn, who sent a welcoming party that included Greta Garbo to meet her from her train. Chanel will stage a major Cruise catwalk show in Los Angeles in May, one week after the Met Gala launches the Lagerfeld exhibition. âIn New York, we celebrate 40 years of Karl â and then we head straight to LA to show a new collection and talk about the future. It will be a busy week for everyone, especially with [the coronation of] Charles III in between. But you cannot be Chanel just by staying in an apartment on the first floor of the 1st arrondissement of Paris.â In September, the V&A will showcase âthe modern style of an era when star designers, of who Mademoiselle Chanel was one, defined so much of modern fashionâ, said Pavlovsky. âFor me, there is no contradiction between the past and future of Chanel.â
headline: Chanelâs elegant show is the quiet eye of a Twitter storm at Paris fashion week

chat_gpt_summary: Twitter is planning to introduce an advertising-free version of its subscription product to boost revenue and demand. Elon Musk, the owner of Twitter, aims to increase subscription income and reduce dependency on advertising. Advertisers have paused spending on the platform due to concerns about hate speech. Musk also highlighted the frequency and size of ads on Twitter and plans to address these issues. The company is facing a $300 million quarterly payment as part of the debt loaded during the takeover.
article: Twitter is planning an advertising-free version of its subscription product, as the company attempts to raise revenue and increase demand for its premium offering. Elon Musk has targeted an increase in subscription revenue as a key part of the social media platformâs business plan under his ownership. The Tesla chief executive tweeted: âThere will be a higher priced subscription that allows zero ads.â Twitter relaunched its premium offering for the second time under Musk in December, offering users perks including verified account status for $8 (Â£6.50) a month on the web or $11 a month for iPhone and Android phone users. Advertising accounted for 90% of Twitterâs revenue in 2021 but has fallen away since Musk bought the business last October, with daily revenue reportedly dropping 40% compared with last year. Advertisers including the carmaker Audi and the drugs firm Pfizer have paused spending on Twitter amid fears of a rise in hate speech on the platform, compounded by a botched revamp of Twitter Blue in November that led to pranksters paying for verified status in order to launch fake corporate accounts. Tweeting on Saturday, Musk added that despite the advertising downturn, ads were too frequent on the platform and âtoo bigâ. He added: âTaking steps to address both in coming weeks.â Musk aims to reduce Twitterâs dependency on advertising as payment looms for an interest payment on the $13bn of debt he loaded on the company as part of the takeover. According to reports, Twitter is due to make a quarterly payment of $300m this month, potentially as soon as this week. Musk told staff in November that Twitter might not survive a forthcoming downturn without a substantial increase in subscription income. âWithout significant subscription revenue, there is a good chance Twitter will not survive the upcoming economic downturn. We need roughly half of our revenue to be subscription,â he wrote in a company-wide email. Twitter Blue is available in the US, the UK, Canada, Australia, New Zealand and Japan. Musk has likened Twitter to a âplane that is headed towards the ground at high speed with the engines on fire and the controls donât workâ and has flagged the prospect of bankruptcy for a business that he bought for $44bn. However, last month Musk played down the prospect of the company going bust, saying it was ânot on the fast lane to bankruptcy any moreâ.
headline: Twitter to launch ad-free subscription tier, Elon Musk says

chat_gpt_summary:
Twitter, owned by Elon Musk, faces a $300 million interest payment on its debt this week. The social media platform's advertising revenue has plummeted since Musk's takeover, leading to concerns about its financial stability. While Twitter has a net cash position of $1 billion, it needs to improve its advertising revenue to service its debt. Musk could potentially fund Twitter from his personal fortune, but bankruptcy or debt restructuring remain possible outcomes if the situation worsens.


Twitter, owned by Elon Musk, faces a $300 million interest payment on its debt this week. The social media platform's advertising revenue has plummeted since Musk's takeover, leading to concerns about its financial stability. While Twitter has a net cash position of $1 billion, it needs to improve its advertising revenue to service its debt. Musk could potentially fund Twitter from his personal fortune, but bankruptcy or debt restructuring remain possible outcomes if the situation worsens.
article: Elon Musk sold a statue of Twitterâs bird logo last week for $100,000 â and he needs the money. The social media platform that he owns reportedly faces an interest payment of about $300m (Â£242m) on its debt as soon as this week, amid difficult financial conditions for the company. Twitter has been a loss-making business, even in the good times, but its problems have worsened since it was bought by the Tesla chief executive less than three months ago. Musk himself has raised the spectre of Twitter entering chapter 11 bankruptcy, although he has since played that prospect down. How much trouble is Twitter in, months after it was bought by the worldâs second richest man? How much money must Twitter pay banks next week? According to reports, the first quarterly payment on the $13bn worth of debt used by Musk to buy Twitter must be paid by the end of the month. Analysts put the amount at approximately $300m, or a quarter of the estimated $1.2bn in annual interest payments due. The debt, which sits on Twitterâs balance sheet and is loaned by a consortium of banks led by Morgan Stanley, comprises: a $6.5bn senior secured term loan facility (a bank loan); a $3bn senior secured bridge loan facility (a loan to tide over the company post-acquisition that, conventionally, is paid off with the proceeds of a bond issue); and a $3bn senior unsecured bridge loan facility. Twitter also has a $500m senior secured revolving facility, which is effectively a corporate overdraft. Can Twitter afford the $300m payment? Musk warned soon after taking over Twitter that the company could go bankrupt. He also revealed a sharp drop in advertising revenue, which accounts for 90% of Twitterâs turnover, caused by clientsâ concern over moderation standards post-takeover and a botched relaunch of Twitterâs subscription service, which led to a rash of fake âverifiedâ corporate accounts. The advertising situation has not improved. It was reported last week that Twitterâs daily revenue has slumped by 40%. Its cashflow â a proxy of its ability to meet debt payments â is poor and in 2021 it generated negative free cashflow (spending more cash to run the business than it takes in) of $370.4m. Musk had warned that loss was heading towards $3bn this year but now expects it to break even. Musk told a podcast last month that Twitter is ânot on the fast lane to bankruptcy any moreâ. He has also said Twitter has a net cash position of $1bn, which would at least cover next weekâs payment along with the $500m overdraft. âTwitter should have no problem making its interest payment in late January, which could be funded with cash on hand or its revolving credit facility,â says Jordan Chalfin, a senior analyst at the credit research firm CreditSights. âLonger term, the company needs to turn around the business, particularly its advertising revenue, in order to service its debt.â Can Musk fund Twitter from his personal fortune? To buy Twitter, Musk put in more than $20bn of his own money, alongside $7.1bn from associates and about $4bn from his existing stake in the company. Last year, he sold $23bn worth of shares in Tesla, presumably to fund his part of the deal. More than 60% of Muskâs remaining stake in Tesla has been pledged âto secure certain personal indebtednessâ, which leaves him with about $67bn worth of shares he can sell immediately, says Ben Silverman, director of research at VerityData. Musk therefore has the means to support Twitter financially, if he wishes. However, he said in December, not for the first time, that he was not planning to sell more Tesla shares. âI wonât sell stock until, I donât know, probably two years from now. Definitely not next year under any circumstances and probably not the year thereafter,â Musk said. Is bankruptcy or restructuring the debt an option? If Musk defaults on an interest payment, Twitter could enter chapter 11 bankruptcy proceedings, where a company is sheltered from creditors temporarily while it attempts to restructure its finances. This would put Muskâs entire equity investment, and the billions put in by his associates, at risk. Another option would be to renegotiate the debt. âWhen the banks look at Musk, they are looking beyond just Twitter,â says Brian Quinn, a professor at Boston College law school. âThey are also looking at potential future business with Tesla, SpaceX. They may decide that itâs worth it to them to take 50 cents on the dollar in order to keep open the possibility of future business with Twitter and the rest of the Musk universe.â However, banks could seek a stake in Twitter as part of any restructuring, which would dilute Muskâs control. In the long term, Musk has to get advertisers back, or rapidly increase subscriptions to Twittersâ premium product, Blue, in order to avoid humbling options.
headline: Is Elon Muskâs Twitter in too much trouble to cover its debts?

chat_gpt_summary: An auction of Twitter's office supplies, including a statue of its logo, fetched high prices, with the statue selling for $100,000. The auction, organized by Heritage Global Partners, is part of the aftermath of Elon Musk's chaotic $44 billion takeover of the company. The sale includes items such as a neon Twitter sign, a planter in the shape of the @ symbol, and furniture. The auction is not related to Twitter's financial position, according to Heritage. Advertisers' pause in spending and a reported 40% revenue drop are separate concerns for the company.
article: What do you get the tech fan who has everything? Perhaps a statue of Twitterâs bright-blue logo, for a mere $100,000. Thatâs what the priciest item went for at an auction of the companyâs office supplies, according to the BBC. The sale marks the latest episode in the continuing saga of Elon Muskâs $44bn takeover of the company, which has generated seemingly endless chaos â from sudden policy changes to the elimination of thousands of jobs. Heritage Global Partners, which ran the auction, has not released sales figures, but the BBC and SFGate caught a few highlights: A 10ft tall neon Twitter sign, perhaps a nice companion piece to the statue, sold for a mere $40,000. A 6ft tall planter in the shape of the @ symbol â which is, of course, an icon of the platform â closed at $15,500, according to SFGate. A conference table made from reclaimed wood closed at nearly $10,500. A fancy espresso machine from La Marzocco went for about $13,500 â less than half its retail value â while an Eames chair apparently saw added value thanks to its Twitter associations. Normally, it would go for $1,195, but Twitterâs chair went for at least $1,400, as a company engineer pointed out. Other items on sale included kegerators (AKA beer fridges), a rotisserie oven and a âhigh-performance task chairâ â in short, everything you need for a productive day in Silicon Valley. The sale comes after Musk himself warned of a âmassive drop in revenueâ in November. Reports on Wednesday pointed to a 40% plunge year-over-year as advertisers pause spending. But thatâs not why the items are being auctioned, according to Heritage. A representative told Fortune in December that the auction âhas nothing to do with their financial positionâ, adding: âIf anyone genuinely thinks that the revenue from selling a couple computers and chairs will pay for the mountain there, then theyâre a moron.â Then again, he didnât mention the statue.
headline: $100,000 for a bird statue: the results of the Twitter office auction are in

chat_gpt_summary: Twitter's revenue has dropped 40% YoY, with over 500 top advertisers pausing their spending since Elon Musk's takeover in October. Advertising is Twitter's main source of income, accounting for over 90% of its revenue in 2021. Concerns about an increase in hate speech on the platform and the proliferation of impersonator accounts have prompted advertisers to withdraw. Musk is reportedly considering options such as selling more of his Tesla shares or putting Twitter into bankruptcy protection. Twitter has not commented on the reports.
article: Twitter remains in the grip of an advertising squeeze, with the social media platform hit by a 40% drop in revenue after more than 500 clients paused their spending, according to reports. The companyâs daily revenue was down 40% year-over-year, the tech newsletter the Platformer reported, while the news site the Information said staff were told more than 500 of Twitterâs top advertisers had halted spending since Elon Musk bought it in October. Advertising is the main source of income for Twitter, accounting for more than 90% of its $5.1bn in revenue in 2021, but clients including Audi and Pfizer are among the firms that have paused after the Tesla CEOâs $44bn (Â£35bn) takeover. Concerns about an increase in hate speech on the platform after its acquisition by a self-described âfree speech absolutistâ have prompted advertisers to withdraw in droves. They have also been alarmed by a spate of impersonator accounts that flourished on the site after a botched relaunch of its blue tick scheme for verified users. Giving more detail on the 40% figure, the Information reported that a senior Twitter manager had told staff on Tuesday that the revenue for that day was 40% lower than the same day a year ago. And in a further report on Wednesday, the Information said that Twitterâs revenue for the fourth quarter alone fell about 35%, according to details shared at an internal staff meeting. The reports came as the Financial Times reported that Twitter was due to make payments on its near-$13bn debt burden as soon as the end of this month, with Musk considering options including selling more of his shares in Tesla or even putting Twitter into bankruptcy protection. Musk sold more than $20bn worth of shares in Tesla last year to help finance the Twitter deal. He said in December that Twitter was facing a ânegative cashflow situation of $3bn a yearâ but claimed the company should âroughlyâ reach cashflow break-even after cost-cutting efforts, including the departure of more than 5,000 staff. He also said last month that the company was ânot on the fast lane to bankruptcy any moreâ, having warned in the immediate aftermath of his takeover that Twitter was in danger of going bust. Twitter has been contacted for comment.
headline: Twitter hit by 40% revenue drop amid ad squeeze, say reports

chat_gpt_summary: Former employees of Twitter's UK operation are accusing the company of "unlawful, unfair, and completely unacceptable" treatment during a redundancy process. A law firm representing 43 ex-staff members is raising the prospect of an employment tribunal to resolve the issue, claiming that Twitter's actions during the redundancy process violated the 1992 Trade Union and Labour Relations Act. The letter also accused Twitter of failing to respond to formal grievances lodged by individual workers. In the US, Twitter faces four class action lawsuits and 200 legal complaints from affected workers
article: A group of former workers at Twitterâs UK operation have accused the company of subjecting them to âunlawful, unfair and completely unacceptableâ treatment during a âshamâ redundancy process. A law firm representing 43 Twitter staffers who were made redundant has raised the prospect of an employment tribunal to resolve the situation, which it says has been marred by a flawed consultation period under the companyâs new owner, Elon Musk. âWe consider that an employment tribunal will take an extremely dim view of the companyâs failings to date, not least having regard to its size, resources and access to legal advice,â said lawyers at the British firm Winckworth Sherwood in a letter emailed to Twitter executives and seen by the Guardian. The firm said the redundancy process began for the affected employees on 18 November by treating them as if they had already been dismissed, despite a legal obligation to consult with people earmarked for losing their jobs for a minimum of 45 days. It said immediately cutting off employees from internal company systems effectively suspended them from their jobs when Twitter had no contractual right to do so. The letter added that blocking staff from accessing Twitter systems and premises made it âimpossibleâ for employee representatives to help affected colleagues effectively. Winckworth claimed this was a breach of the 1992 Trade Union and Labour Relations Act and that an employment tribunal âwould not hesitate to reach the same conclusionâ. The letter also claims there was a failure to establish fair selection criteria for redundancy, which it alleges is a further breach of the act. Winckworth said the companyâs cost-cutting justification for redundancies, which affected more than 180 people in the UK, was undermined by Twitter flagging âfuture opportunitiesâ in London on the career section of its corporate website. The law firm said in a âsignificant number of instancesâ its clientsâ jobs are not genuinely redundant. The letter says that the company claimed the postings might not be âactual advertsâ. Twitter made redundant around 50% of its 7,500-strong global workforce soon after it was acquired by Musk in a $44bn (Â£36bn) deal. Despite this, a substantial number of employees were contacted on 23 December requiring them to respond to invitations about individual consultations on redundancy. Some had been given deadlines to accept settlement terms before their consultations, the letter alleged. âInevitably, and perhaps intentionally, it caused much stress, anxiety and distress to those affected,â said the letter, which adds that Twitter has used the Acas arbitration service to secure settlements. Elsewhere in the letter, Twitter is accused of failing to respond to formal grievances lodged by individual workers. In the US, the company faces four class action lawsuits, and 200 legal complaints, from affected workers. Twitter has been contacted for comment.
headline: Sacked Twitter UK staff claim unlawful treatment in âshamâ redundancy

chat_gpt_summary: Twitter has reportedly cut a dozen people from its trust and safety team, including those in charge of international content moderation and hate speech and harassment. The move has raised concerns that owner Elon Musk is dismantling the company's regulation of hateful content and misinformation. Musk has claimed that harmful content on the platform has declined since his acquisition, but researchers and rights advocates have found otherwise. NBC News recently uncovered dozens of Twitter accounts offering to sell or trade child sexual exploitation materials, despite Musk's pledge to prioritize addressing the issue.
article: Twitter has made more cuts to its trust and safety team in charge of international content moderation, as well as a unit overseeing hate speech and harassment, Bloomberg reported on Friday. The move adds to longstanding concerns that new owner Elon Musk is dismantling the companyâs regulation of hateful content and misinformation. With Musk at the helm, Twitter has suffered a public relations crisis featuring sackings, resignations, tumbling revenues, reluctant advertisers and lawsuits over unpaid bills. The latest round of cuts affected a dozen people at Twitterâs Dublin and Singapore offices, sources who requested anonymity told Bloomberg. Among them were Analuisa Dominguez, Twitterâs senior director of revenue policy, and Nur Azhar Bin Ayob, the recently hired head of site integrity for the Asia-Pacific region. Employees in charge of Twitterâs misinformation policy, global appeals and state media were also sacked. Twitterâs head of trust and safety, Ella Irwin, confirmed to Bloomberg that several members of the teams were removed, while denying the cuts targeted other areas. âIt made more sense to consolidate teams under one leader (instead of two) for example,â Irwin told Bloomberg by email, adding Twitter removed roles in areas in the company that did not have enough âvolumeâ to warrant support. Irwin said Twitter would continue having a head of revenue policy and a head for its Asia-Pacific region for trust and safety. She also said the company increased staffing in its appeals department. Musk had been on a quest to overhaul Twitter since his $44bn (Â£36bn) takeover in October. The billionaire entrepreneur has outlined his vision for a âdigital town squareâ that enshrines free speech and healthy debate. He has also claimed harmful content has declined on the platform since his acquisition. But researchers and rights advocates found slurs, hateful rhetoric and malicious content to have thrived on Twitter since Musk arrived. While banned accounts belonging to far-right reactionaries were reinstated, several prominent tech journalists found themselves briefly suspended from Twitter last month. On Friday, NBC News uncovered the existence of at least dozens of Twitter accounts offering to sell or trade child sexual exploitation materials, an issue Musk previously said he would make a priority. Last month, Reuters â citing people familiar with the matter â reported that Musk had personally ordered the removal of a feature that promoted suicide prevention resources to users who look up certain content.
headline: Twitter reportedly makes more cuts to online safety teams

chat_gpt_summary: The Northern Ireland secretary Chris Heaton-Harris has apologised after his Twitter account was hacked and posted offensive tweets about race, sexuality and gender identity. His team said they were in contact with Twitter to resolve the issue. This follows the hacking of education secretary Gillian Keegan's Twitter account over Christmas. The Commons speaker wrote to MPs in November to advise them on boosting security on their mobile phones with multi-factor verification, updating software and deleting old messages. The British army's Twitter and YouTube accounts were also hacked in July.
article: A second cabinet minister has said they fell victim to hackers and was forced to apologise after their Twitter account posted a series of offensive tweets about race, sexuality and gender identity. Chris Heaton-Harris, the Northern Ireland secretary, said others temporarily gained access to his account and posted some âdeeply unpleasant stuffâ. The tweets were deleted swiftly, and his team said they were in contact with Twitter to resolve the issue. One of the posts on Heaton-Harrisâs account read: âWhy are black people so poor?â Another, captured by social media users, appeared to say: âWe are passing a new law soon, all transgenders and homosexuals will now serve 10 years behind bars.â Heaton-Harris sent a message to his 33,000 followers shortly afterwards. He said: âIâm afraid my Twitter account was hacked overnight and someone posted some deeply unpleasant stuff on my account for which I can only apologise.â The hack of his account will cause concern among government security officials. It follows another cabinet minister, the education secretary Gillian Keegan, also having her Twitter account hacked over Christmas. Her account was compromised for several days, and spewed out a series of tweets promoting cryptocurrencies. Keeganâs account responded to several other usersâ tweets with links to a website advertising bitcoin and dogecoin. Several days later, all references to Keegan in her Twitter name, biography, photograph and banner had been removed. Issues with tech security among MPs has become a salient issue over the past few months. In November, the Commons speaker, Lindsay Hoyle, wrote to MPs advising them to boost security on their mobile phones with multi-factor verification, update software and delete old messages. The warning came after Liz Trussâs phone was reportedly hacked by Russians in the summer when she was foreign secretary and frontrunner in the Conservative party leadership race. Hoyleâs letter to MPs, which included 10 security tips, said: âYou may not feel able to do everything on this list, but the more you do the less likely your personal information and mobile phone will be compromised, or the less damaging the consequences if you are hacked.â In July, the British armyâs Twitter and YouTube accounts also were reportedly hacked, with posts promoting NFTs â non-fungible tokens or digital artworks â and a purported interview with Musk about cryptocurrency. Elon Musk, the under-fire owner of Twitter, has been vocal previously about his commitment to stamping out false and spam users on the social media platform.
headline: Second cabinet minister says Twitter account hacked

chat_gpt_summary: The author ponders where people will go if Twitter dies and suggests Mastodon or Hive as alternatives. However, they admit that Twitter's addictive nature may mean that people will switch to a more addictive platform. The author, who is hopelessly addicted to Twitter, suggests that Elon Musk may be their only hope for salvation from the toxic public discourse on the platform. They hope that Musk will use his platform to unite people for the collective good and use their "cognitive surplus" for something useful.
article: Where are we all going when Twitter dies? Mastodon? Hive? Back to sitting in saggy armchairs reading chunky books? Personally, Iâm hoping itâs the latter, but Iâm not optimistic. Twitter, of course, has been designed by a lot of very clever people to be extremely addictive, and if everyone switches to something else, it will probably be because itâs more addictive again, prodding all our dopamine-spiking buttons in some as-yet-undiscovered sequence with which battered airport paperbacks will be even less able to compete. Which, come to think of it, means it definitely wonât be Mastodon. Obviously, Iâm hopelessly addicted to Twitter, like so many journalists who pretend we are using it for our jobs. Iâve tried to tie myself to the mast like Odysseus, installing apps that block it at certain hours or force me to take a cooling off period before I refresh the page, but I always find a way around them. Even if you delete your account entirely, thereâs a 30-day cooling-off period, during which I inevitably re-up, like Odysseus with a pocketknife inside his tunic. Elon Musk, then, may be my only hope. Soon after his acquisition of the platform, a few waggish types suggested he might be deliberately trying to tank it â to make the public discourse less toxic, maybe, or just for the lols. Recently, that opinion has become less fashionable, but Iâm clinging to it like Odysseus to a fig tree â hoping that there is some galaxy-brain plan in motion in which Musk is prepared to sacrifice his fortune and reputation to let us get back to doing something useful. Author Clay Shirky talks about âcognitive surplusâ, the free mental energy we have to collaborate on projects that can be useful to humanity â and now Twitter is just a great big machine for turning all that energy into hot takes and Thanos memes. If Musk kills it, maybe his next step will be to unite us all in using that leftover thinking-space for the collective good, such as designing Mars rockets just to spite him, or something. Which would make him â¦ Poseidon? I donât know â I havenât actually read the Odyssey. Joel Snape is a writer and fitness expert Do you have an opinion on the issues raised in this article? If you would like to submit a response of up to 300 words by email to be considered for publication in our letters section, please click here.
headline: Iâm horribly addicted to Twitter. Will Elon Musk save me from myself this year? | Joel Snape

chat_gpt_summary: Twitter plans to relax its ban on political advertising in an effort to increase revenue after Elon Musk's $44bn takeover. The social media platform banned political advertising in 2019, but has since announced plans to expand its political advertising policy to align with that of TV broadcasters and other media outlets. Advertising accounts for 90% of Twitter's revenue, but after Musk's takeover, advertisers have paused spending amid fears of divisive content. However, Twitter has announced that there will be an immediate change for restrictions on "cause-based" advertising.
article: Twitter has said it will relax restrictions on political advertising as it seeks to generate more revenue after Elon Muskâs $44bn (Â£36.4bn) takeover of the platform. The social media platform banned political advertising in 2019 after its then chief executive, Jack Dorsey, declared that reaching people with political messages should be âearned, not boughtâ. Twitter has signalled a reversal of that policy, announcing it plans to âexpand the political advertising we permit in the coming weeksâ. In a post on Twitterâs safety account, the company said it would align its advertising policy with that of TV broadcasters and other media outlets. The post added that Twitter would ensure, as with any policy change, âour approach to reviewing and approving content protects people on Twitterâ. However, Musk has recently reinstated controversial accounts, such as those belonging to Donald Trump and Andrew Tate, despite pledging initially that such moves would be adjudicated by a âcontent moderation councilâ that has since fallen by the wayside. There will be an immediate change for restrictions on âcause-basedâ advertising, which it defines as ads that encourage people to take action on issues such as social inequality and economic growth. According to a Twitter advertising policy page, cause-based ads that target users in the US will no longer face restrictions such as a ban on using political terms like âconservativeâ or âliberalâ. Advertising is Twitterâs main source of revenue, accounting for 90% of its $5.1bn turnover in 2021. However, advertisers have paused spending on Twitter after Muskâs takeover, amid fears that divisive content would mushroom on the platform, while a botched relaunch of Twitterâs subscription service also alarmed advertisers by triggering a wave of fake corporate accounts. About 70% of Twitterâs top 100 advertising clients were not spending on the platform as of mid-December, according to research firm Pathmatics.
headline: Twitter to relax curbs on political ads as revenues drop

chat_gpt_summary: Twitter experienced its second outage in a few weeks, with users in Australia and New Zealand reporting issues accessing the site, including slow loading times, error messages, or complete inability to access it. Some users blamed Twitter's new owner, Elon Musk, for the issues. Twitter had not acknowledged the issue at the time of publication, and since Musk took over, the company no longer has a communications team. After purchasing the platform for $44bn, Musk sacked approximately 50% of staff and contractors, leading to fears of future outages.
article: Twitter users in Australia and New Zealand reported difficulty accessing the social media site for several hours on Wednesday â its second outage in the past few weeks. The website Downdetector received thousands of reports from about 7am AEST on Wednesday saying that load times for the site were slow, they were given error messages, or they were unable to access it entirely. âFeed has a 50-50 chance of not loading and timing out,â one user posted. Several users blamed Twitterâs new owner. âHope Elon regrets firing everyone,â one said, referring to Elon Muskâs huge round of job cuts at the company after he took over. âProfile and feed not loading. Thanks Elon!â another said. Sign up for a weekly email featuring our best reads Twitter users in Australia who were able to send tweets reported the site had slowed down significantly. The issue appeared to be limited to users based in Australia and New Zealand, with some users reporting being able to use a virtual private network (VPN) to access the website as normal via the US. At the time of publication, Twitter had not acknowledged the issue. Guardian Australia attempted to seek comment from Twitter, however since Musk took over the company it no longer has a communications team. It follows a significant global outage on the desktop version of the website at the end of December. At the time, Musk tweeted that the site was working for him, that âsignificant backend server architecture changesâ had been made and âTwitter should feel fasterâ. After Musk initially purchased the platform for US$44bn, and sacked approximately 50% of staff and the majority of its contractors, there had been fears that the departure of expert staff would over time lead to outages for the website. Musk has been attempting to slash costs for the business as the company will need to pay US$1bn a year in interest payments for the purchase. Late last month Musk defended the cost cuts as necessary, as the company had âa negative cash flow situation of $3 billion a year. Not good. Since Twitter has 1 billion in cash. So thatâs why I spent the last five weeks cutting costs like crazy. âThis company is like, basically, youâre in a plane that is headed towards the ground at high speed with the engines on fire and the controls donât work,â Musk explained.
headline: Australian Twitter users aim ire at Elon Musk after apparent local outage

chat_gpt_summary: The letters section of The Guardian features a variety of topics, including Andrew Tate's arrest for insulting Greta Thunberg, the reinstatement of his Twitter account, and one reader's struggle with identity. Other letters include a request for Brian May's investiture to be held at Windsor Castle, and a father's love for the funny brief letters section, which he read to his blind elderly father every morning. Finally, a reader points out that Rishi Sunak would never use the term "the hoi polloi," and wonders if he will soon be gone.
article: Having read of Andrew Tateâs attempt to belittle Greta Thunberg, it cheered me up to hear of his arrest. What did surprise me was to read that his vile Twitter account had been reinstated after a ban (Andrew Tate put in 30-day pre-trial detention in Romania after arrest, 30 December). Iâm still waiting to get my account back after being mildly rude about Nadine Dorries. Sue Boulding Baschurch, Shropshire â¢ On reading Brian Mayâs name in the new year honours (New year honours 2023: Mary Quant and Lionesses among those recognised, 30 December), I thought: I do hope the investiture is held at Windsor, so you can headline it âQueenâs knight to kingâs castleâ. Martin Stallion Braintree, Essex â¢ As a former philosophy student who does his own ironing and bakes sourdough bread but doesnât clean the house, Iâm having a serious identity crisis reading the brief letters at the moment (Letters, 27 December). Just who am I, and where do I belong? Dr Mark Wilcox Holmfirth, West Yorkshire â¢ When my father was in his 90s and had lost most of his sight, I became a live-in carer and his Guardian-reader. The first thing he wanted read to him each morning were the funny brief letters. Like Ian Grieve (Letters, 27 December), he said they raised his spirits and set him up for the day. Elizabeth Bailey Edinburgh â¢ Iâm sure that an old Wykehamist such as Rishi Sunak would never use the term âthe hoi polloiâ (Cartoon, 29 December). The âtheâ is redundant. As may he be soon? Terence Jowett Beckenham, London
headline: Why hasnât Twitter reinstated my account? | Brief letters

chat_gpt_summary: Since Elon Musk's acquisition of Twitter, the platform has experienced controversial and unpredictable changes. Musk fired senior executives and half of Twitter's workforce, resulting in a negative impact on revenue. The platform suffered a drop in advertising revenue and faced setbacks with its premium service, Blue, due to fake verified accounts. Musk lifted suspensions on banned accounts and announced a new content policy of "freedom of speech but not freedom of reach". Musk's reign at Twitter has been inconsistent, with him suspending journalists and causing outrage amongst employees and advertisers.
article: When Elon Musk walked into Twitterâs offices on 26 October carrying a sink, one day before he bought the platform for $44bn (Â£38bn), it was the first sign that the tale of his ownership would not be a conventional one. âLet that sink in!â he tweeted. For everyone swept up in what followed â from thousands of Twitter employees to advertisers and critical journalists â it certainly has now. Muskâs reign since has proved unpredictable and controversial, with the Tesla CEO losing the title of the worldâs richest man in the process. Here are some of the standout moments from those eventful past 10 weeks: Firing half the workforce As soon as Musk took over Twitter he fired senior executives including: the CEO, Parag Agrawal; Ned Segal, the chief financial officer; and Vijaya Gadde, the head of legal policy, trust and safety. Days later he axed 50% of the companyâs 7,500-strong workforce with affected areas including the communications team, the curation unit that helped counter disinformation and the human rights team. More departures followed a bizarre episode in which Musk set employees a mid-November deadline to commit to working âlong hours at high intensityâ and being âextremely hardcoreâ or leave with three monthsâ severance pay. This led to the departure of a further 1,200 staff, according to one estimate. Musk now says Twitter has about 2,000 employees. About the same time, it was reported that Twitter had let go 4,000 contractors in fields including content moderation and engineering. Responding to predictions of Twitterâs demise in late November, Musk tweeted: âWasnât Twitter supposed to die by now or something â¦ ?â However, the platform, which has faced warnings of technical problems after letting go so many expert staff, did suffer an outage on 28 December that affected some users. Musk said the firings were necessary because Twitter was losing $4m a day. That is an intimidating number for a business that must make payments of more than $1bn on the near-$13bn of debt that now sits on its balance sheet, as part of the takeoverâs financing. Musk said in December that Twitter was facing a ânegative cashflow situation of $3bn a yearâ but claimed the company should âroughlyâ reach cashflow break-even after his cost-cutting efforts. Alienated advertisers and subscription setbacks Musk admitted that Twitter had suffered a âmassive drop in revenueâ after the takeover, which he blamed on campaign groups lobbying advertisers about the future of safety and content guidelines under Muskâs leadership. The carmaker Audi, the drugs firm Pfizer and General Motors were among the brands that paused spending on the platform in the immediate wake of the takeover. This is a material issue for a company that made 90% of its more than $5bn in revenue in 2021 from advertising. The ad freeze deepened in the wake of a botched relaunch of Twitterâs premium service, Blue, which resulted in a host of impersonators taking advantage of the chances to launch âfakeâ verified company accounts for just $8 a month. Companies affected included the pharmaceutical firm Eli Lilly & Co and Muskâs own Tesla, leading to the service being temporarily suspended. Work is underway to repair the damage. Twitter is working with the World Federation of Advertisers, which says its membership represents 90% of global ad spending, on addressing advertisersâ concerns, plus Blue has been relaunched again without a resurgence of the fake account problem. The new service offers verified status â via a blue tick or checkmark â for $8 a month or $11 a month on their iPhone. Musk believes mass verification is the best way to defeat vexatious spam accounts, one of his Twitter bÃªte noires. Other perks promised by the subscription service include an edit button, a 50% reduction in the number of adverts in a userâs feed and the ability to post longer tweets. Reinstating banned accounts Musk has lifted suspensions on the accounts operated by Donald Trump, the British-American former kickboxer Andrew Tate â who had been banned for extreme misogynist posts, and was on Friday arrested in Romania on charges of human trafficking, rape and forming an organised crime group â and the Canadian psychologist Jordan Peterson, among others. The account of US rapper Ye â formerly Kanye West â was also reinstated but then suspended again after he tweeted an image of a swastika blended with a star of David. At the same time Musk announced a new content policy of âfreedom of speech, but not freedom of reachâ, stating that ânegative/hateâ tweets would be âdeboostedâ and no adverts would appear near them. The reinstatements were another sign of the inconsistent behaviour that would mark Muskâs reign, coming weeks after he said no decisions would be taken on reinstatement until a newly announced âcontent moderation councilâ had met. He blamed the apparent backtrack on unnamed âpolitical/social activist groupsâ, accusing them of persuading advertisers to stay away. Suspending journalists In mid-December Musk contradicted his stance on freedom of speech by freezing the accounts of prominent tech journalists at CNN, the Washington Post, Mashable and the New York Times. He accused them of breaching a newly created Twitter guideline that barred users from publishing âlive location informationâ that would âreveal a personâs location, regardless if this information is publicly availableâ. This guideline had been created as an apparent justification for suspending, @ElonJet, a Twitter account that had long vexed Musk by displaying the location of his private jet via publicly available information. The journalists were reinstated days later, after Musk launched a poll on his own Twitter account that delivered a majority in favour of lifting the suspensions. But Muskâs targeting of journalists drew condemnation from the UN, the EU and campaign groups. Also in December, Musk released internal Twitter documents to select journalists in a project dubbed the âTwitter Filesâ. The documents showed the internal process behind decisions to suspend Donald Trumpâs account in 2021 and the platformâs response to the Hunter Biden laptop story. Another excerpt from the files raised questions about Twitterâs dealings with the Pentagon. Dragging Tesla into it Muskâs status as Tesla CEO is key to his fortune and had made him the richest person on the planet, before he lost the title to the luxury tycoon Bernard Arnault in December. The performance of the electric carmaker, in which Musk holds a substantial stake, has got worse as his interest in Twitter has grown. Muskâs involvement in the platform first emerged in early April with the revelation that he held a large shareholding in the business, followed weeks later by the deal to buy the company, which he initially walked away from â leading to legal action â before he returned to complete it two months ago. In 2022, Teslaâs shares declined in value by 70% to $123. Some of this is Tesla-specific, such as slowing demand and fears over Covid shutdowns at its Chinese factories, but Muskâs repeated sales of Tesla stock to fund his Twitter purchase â despite saying in April he had no more planned â plus concerns that he is focusing too much on the social media platform have also rattled investors. âMusk has lost credibility with the broader investment community as broken promises (selling stock again and again and again â¦.), the Twitter fiasco, opening up the political firestorm on Twitter, and brand deterioration for Musk and Tesla has led to a complete debacle for the stock,â said Dan Ives, the managing director at the financial services firm Wedbush Securities. âResigningâ as boss Musk said on 20 December he would resign as the CEO of Twitter âas soon as I find someone foolish enough to take the job!â His announcement followed a poll on his Twitter account in which users voted decisively in favour of him standing down. The pledge also followed court testimony in November in which he said he expected to âreduce my time at Twitterâ after an âinitial burst of activityâ. Whoever takes the job will be running a globally influential social media platform with more than 250 million daily users. But with a very demanding, and impulsive, owner. âOne of the first things I said after the acquisition closed was like, âweâre gonna make a bunch of mistakes but then weâll try to recover from them quickly,â and thatâs what weâve done,â Musk said on the All-In Podcast, released days after his announcement he was stepping down. But for the Tesla CEO, the biggest mistake â with a lower chance of full recovery â might have been buying Twitter in the first place.
headline: Slumping revenue, Tesla woes and a âresignationâ: Muskâs wild reign at Twitter so far

chat_gpt_summary: Social media platforms are facing criticism for allowing the spread of misinformation and conspiracy theories related to Andrew Tate, a British-American internet personality arrested in Romania in connection with human trafficking and organised crime. His followers have falsely claimed he was freed and suggested he was set up. Concerns have been raised about the impact on legal proceedings and the responsibility of social media platforms that helped Tate reach a wider audience. TikTok has said it will remove any content that violates its guidelines, while Twitter has not commented.
article: Social media firms are under fire this weekend for allowing the spread of misinformation by followers of âking of toxic masculinityâ Andrew Tate after his arrest in connection with a human trafficking investigation. In the hours after his detention, TikTok and Twitter were flooded with posts falsely claiming he had been freed and conspiracy theories saying he had been set up, Observer analysis shows. Imran Ahmed, chief executive of the Center for Countering Digital Hate, said: âHaving conspiracy theories proliferating which might put at risk the integrity of an investigation or the safety of those involved is unconscionable.â Tate, 36, a British-American internet personality best known for his misogynistic views, was arrested with his brother Tristan in Romania on 29 December as part of an investigation into human trafficking, rape and organised crime. An investigation by the Observer in August into the former kickboxer and Big Brother contestant revealed that TikTok was aggressively promoting his content to users including boys and young men. Members of Tateâs online academy had been instructed to post deliberately controversial clips in an effort to boost engagement and manipulate the algorithm. After his arrest last week, a statement from prosecutors said four people, including two Britons, were suspected of being part of a criminal group that sexually exploited women after luring them with promises of a relationship. The women were allegedly subjected to âphysical violence and mental coercion through intimidation, constant surveillance, control and invoking alleged debtsâ and forced to make pornographic videos. Six potential victims had been identified. Further details of the specific allegations against Tate have not been made public. On Friday, it was confirmed that he would spend the next 30 days in detention as Romaniaâs Directorate for Investigating Organised Crime and Terrorism continues its inquiries. On social media, thousands of supporters have already reached their verdict. On TikTok and Twitter, Tateâs fans claimed without evidence that he had been framed, using hashtags such as #freetopG and #tateinnocent. âPeople lie because they hate Tate,â one wrote on Twitter. âIâm 100% sure Tate is innocent. FREE TATE,â said another. Others blamed âthe Matrixâ for setting him up. This was fuelled by Tate himself in a tweet posted after news of his arrest: âThe Matrix sent their agents,â he wrote on Friday. Since the release of the 1999 sci-fi film about people living in a simulation, where a man is given the choice to take a red pill and âwake upâ, the metaphor has been repeatedly repurposed in a range of conspiracy theories, as well by fringe online groups who use âredpillâ to mean men waking up to the ârealityâ that feminism subjugates them. On TikTok on Friday, the most-liked recent video about Tate was one that appeared at first to be a factual report but ended by asking viewers: âWhat do you guys think is the real reason Tate was arrested? Was it the Matrix, or did Tate actually commit a serious crime?â On Twitter, where Tate has more than 4m followers after his account was reinstated in November, many posts referenced #Pizzagate â a debunked theory that predated QAnon and claimed senior Democrats were behind a child sexual abuse ring â and suggested he was being used as a scapegoat by real paedophile rings. In a video made shortly before his arrest, after a Twitter spat with the climate activist Greta Thunberg, Tate had appeared on camera with a pizza box in front of him in what some speculated was a reference to the conspiracy. âThey want to cover up Pizzagate with Andrew Tate,â one Twitter user wrote, tagging Elon Musk. Other accounts posted old videos suggesting Tate had been cleared, despite him remaining in detention. One clip viewed 780,000 times on Twitter by Saturday claimed to show him being freed from custody. âAndrew Tate got Released Matrix attack Failed,â the caption read. The fierce defence of Tate and spread of misinformation since his arrest will add to concerns about the impact on any future legal proceedings and raise questions for the social media platforms that helped propel him to the mainstream. In the weeks after the Observerâs August investigation, TikTok banned Tateâs official account and said it took a tough stance on hateful content including misogyny. On Saturday night, TikTok said it had begun a systematic review of content flagged with it and would remove any that violated its guidelines, which ban âmisinformation that causes significant harm to individuals, our community, or the larger publicâ. Twitter did not respond to a request for comment.
headline: Andrew Tate arrest: TikTok and Twitter under fire over false posts from fans

chat_gpt_summary: Elon Musk has given internal documents and conversations to selected journalists, causing controversy over Twitter's moderation practices. Some see it as evidence of collusion to silence conservatives, while others view it as a publicity exercise. The use of algorithms to "deamplify" tweets and the criteria for banning users are questioned. Twitter's censorship and political bias have increased concerns, and more transparency is needed. However, Musk dismissed a request for academic researchers to inspect the data.
article: Half the room is jumping up and down, screaming âGotcha!â. The other half shrugs its shoulders, muttering âSo whatâs new?â. Welcome to the war over the so-called Twitter Files. Over the past month, Twitterâs new owner, Elon Musk, has made available to a handpicked group of journalists internal documents and conversations that took place before his takeover. They are mainly discussions about who and what should be moderated or banned, ranging from the Hunter Biden laptop story to the question of whether to remove Donald Trump from the platform. The journalists have made public selected slices of the data through a drip feed of Twitter threads. For some, the Twitter Files provide evidence of collusion between tech companies, liberal politicians and the âdeep stateâ to silence conservatives. For others, they constitute little more than a publicity exercise that told us nothing that we did not know. As someone who has long made a case for the importance of free speech, I think we should take the Twitter Files seriously, but also look at the discussion with a sceptical eye, given that much of it is framed by the culture wars. Consider the controversy over âshadow banningâ. Itâs a phrase much bandied about in debates about social media, but its meaning is contested. For the curators of the Twitter Files, âshadow banningâ means using algorithms to âdeamplifyâ tweets â that is, stop them reaching a wider audience. For the old pre-Musk Twitter, however, it meant something different â âdeliberately making someoneâs content undiscoverable to everyone except the person who posted itâ, as a 2018 blog post put it. The conflicting definitions have allowed the critics to accuse former Twitter executives of lying, although they seem as interested in putting the old Twitter regime in the dock as in uncovering the truth. The journalists curating the Twitter Files have presented deamplification as a secret process. Certainly, the internal mechanisms of moderation have been veiled in secrecy. As a practice, however, Twitter has long been open about deamplification â or âvisibility filteringâ as it also calls it â noting even in its terms of service that âwe mayâ¦ limit distribution or visibility of any Contentâ. Itâs a practice championed not just by old Twitter but new Twitter, too. Shortly after buying the platform, Musk tweeted that his policy would be one of âfreedom of speech, but not freedom of reachâ, adding that ânegative/hate tweets will be max deboostedâ â in other words, deamplified. But is it a good policy? Who decides who or what should be âdeamplifiedâ? By what criteria? And how different is this from straightforward censorship? Unfortunately, the polarisation of the debate seems to have overridden a nuanced debate around such questions. The Twitter Files also reveal some of the processes by which users are banned. Twitter insists that it does not suspend accounts for âpolitical reasonsâ. Thatâs hard to square with the evidence. Take the controversy over Trump. Twitter executives held anguished discussions about how to deal with the president, recognising the dangers of banning a democratically elected leader. Nevertheless, as one executive put it, âthe narrative that trump [sic] and his friends have pursued over the course of this election and frankly last 4+ years must be taken into accountâ. In other words, Trumpâs politics mattered. After the 6 January riot at the Capitol, the pressure that Twitter faced led to the second argument taking precedence over the first. All this has strengthened the view on the right of tech companies as fomenting a liberal conspiracy against conservatives. Within Twitter, Musk tweeted, ârules were enforced against the right, but not against the leftâ. Yet a 2021 study suggested the opposite. Looking at millions of tweets in seven countries â Britain, America, Canada, France, Germany, Spain and Japan â researchers found that, with the exception of Germany, Twitter algorithms amplified rightwing politicians more than the left. They also found that in America, conservative news sources were boosted more than liberal ones. These results cut against the grain of conventional wisdom. It may be that thereâs a sharp divide between algorithmic decisions and those made by human moderators. It may also be that the high-profile censoring of rightwing voices is not representative of the mass of decisions. In the last six months of 2021 alone, Twitter censored an extraordinary 4m tweets â a figure that itself should give us pause. The political bias in those 4m decisions is unknown. There is little discussion, for instance, about the suppression of Palestinian voices, a practice that has continued under Musk. At the very least, we need more transparency about moderation. Yet, when Alex Stamos, of Stanford Universityâs Internet Observatory, asked Musk to allow not just handpicked journalists but academic researchers to inspect the data, Musk dismissed him on the bizarre grounds that âyou operate a propaganda platformâ. Musk seems more interested in being seen to âown the libsâ than in opening up Twitterâs inner workings. The most worrying issue the Twitter Files have exposed is the level of contact between the social media company and state security organisations. The FBI regularly holds meetings with Twitter executives, pressuring them to take action against âmisinformationâ, even when this amounted to little more than a satirical tweet, and demanding the personal data of users. Twitter, to its credit, often pushed back. Nevertheless, the Twitter Files do show an unhealthy relationship between social media and state security. Equally unhealthy is the response of many liberals who have become sanguine about the work of the security apparatus. There has been a remarkable partisan shift in American attitudes towards the FBI, with a huge swing in Democratic support for the organisation. Many now view the FBI as an essential weapon against populism. Many seem to have forgotten the sordid history of the FBI in undermining radical movements from unions to civil rights organisations. The insouciance of liberals and many on the left to such state interference in public life is disquieting. Twitter, we are constantly told, is not real life. Thatâs true. But, like all social media, it plays an inordinately large role in real life, a private company that has become an intimate part of the global public square. We need to keep that public square as open as possible. That is why the revelations of the Twitter Files matter. And that is why we need to understand their significance beyond the clamour of the culture wars. Kenan Malik is an Observer columnist Do you have an opinion on the issues raised in this article? If you would like to submit a letter of up to 250 words to be considered for publication, email it to us at observer.letters@observer.co.uk
headline: The Twitter Files should disturb liberal critics of Elon Musk â and hereâs why | Kenan Malik

chat_gpt_summary: Australian actor Christie Whelan Browne talks to The Guardian about her recent work and life, including her experiences of publicly accusing Craig McLachlan of indecent assault and the subsequent media coverage and defamation suit. Whelan Browne talks about continuing to work and becoming a vocal ally for women who have experienced sexual assault. Despite still being trolled on social media, she is inspired by younger female performers who "will not take the sh*t other generations have taken".
article: Christie Whelan Browne cheerfully admits sheâll hit her âageing diva phaseâ any minute now. The Melbourne-based actor recently turned 40 and is at near-exhaustion point when we meet, juggling a new sketch comedy TV series, a solo stage show for Sydney festival and grabbing a few moments on FaceTime with her almost two-year-old son Duke. âHe doesnât understand that Iâm away, heâs too little,â Whelan Browne says. âFor me itâs a new level of heartbreak. I was an absolute wreck the first week away from him.â Whelan Browne is sitting on the edge of a bed in her temporary digs in Newtown, Sydney, at the end of what has already been a long day. Immaculately groomed after a photoshoot, she veers from confident to cautious in the media spotlight, after the âugliest, most horrible four yearsâ of her life. Best known for her work on the stage, Whelan Browne has delighted audiences with her whip-sharp timing in Murielâs Wedding the Musical, Shakespeareâs As You Like It and Oscar Wildeâs An Ideal Husband and The Importance of Being Earnest. On the small screen, sheâs starred in Shaun Micallefâs Mad as Hell and has just wrapped We Interrupt This Broadcast, a new Channel 7 comedy for 2023. She describes herself as a comic actor. âI feel confident in my ability to make people laugh,â she says, adding that her solo Sydney festival piece Show People â which premiered at Adelaide cabaret festival (under a different name, Pure Blonde) in 2015 â is âtragic and hilariousâ. Performing it comes as a welcome change of gear after four years of intense media coverage that overshadowed her talent. In 2018, Whelan Browne, along with two other female cast members, brought forward allegations of indecent assault against Craig McLachlan, the star of their 2014 production of the Rocky Horror Picture Show. McLachlan denied the allegations. In 2020, a criminal trial found him not guilty, and in 2021 he brought a defamation case against Whelan Browne, the ABC and Nine, before dropping the suit in May of 2022. Those were dark times, Whelan Browne recalls. She received death threats and rape threats. âThat really shocked me,â she says. âI copped anger and hatred from the media and the public and I just wasnât prepared for that.â The end of the court case left her feeling âa bit like a zombieâ. âThe next day, my son woke up at six, and life just carried on. I was back at work the next day or the day after,â she says. âIt wasnât until just a few weeks ago that I finally realised there is this big heavy monkey on my back and that Iâm going to need to address it at some point.â Whelan Browne says she lost work during this time and was fired from one job after she was sued for defamation. âThat was very painful,â she says. âBut I made it my mission to continue working, to make it clear I wasnât broken or beaten.â Twice during our interview she wipes away a tear, but she doesnât want it misinterpreted: âIâm only crying because Iâm so very tired. Please donât make it a sad story â because Iâm not.â Whelan Browne is now a powerful vocal ally on Twitter for women who have experienced sexual assault. âI know what it meant to me when people were willing to put their face and voice to a supportive comment, when others shied away because they knew it would provoke the trolls,â she says. âBut Iâm not afraid any more. I would prefer to be someone who uses their voice. I am never going to be quiet any more.â She is still being trolled on Twitter too, she says. When it happens, she writes âFuckhead alertâ to warn other women. âI donât want women to feel theyâve got no hope or that theyâre alone. I get people reaching out in my DMs asking how best to navigate the shitty situations women find themselves in. I donât really know what I can do other than calling out injustice when you see it.â Thereâs a long way to go, but Whelan Browne says sheâs inspired by the younger generation of female performers who âwill not take the shit other generations have taken â they just wonât,â she says. âThe young women I worked with on Murielâs Wedding were amazing at calling out anything they didnât like. They are far better at pointing it out and saying, âThat needs to stopâ, and that gives me so much hope for the future. They just donât have that same fear that I definitely grew up with, and that makes me so happy.â Show People predates her experiences on Rocky Horror. It began in 2015 when Barry Humphries invited Whelan Browne to create a show for the Adelaide cabaret festival, after her hit Britney Spears cabaret written by her collaborator and friend Dean Bryant. Bryant also wrote and directed Show People, in which Whelan Browne plays six roles: a new drama school graduate; a mum juggling performing and childcare; an ageing diva; an understudy; an older actor ready to retire, and the misogynistic leading man. âI was nervous to perform the show at first, knowing people would be wondering who the characters could be based on,â she says. âBut the truth is, they are all of us. I have been at least three of the characters myself and I will probably be more. Theyâve all faced obstacles along the way.â The careworn actor-mum has special resonance these days, she says. Whelan Browne was performing nightly in a play when Duke was only eight months old. She missed bath and bedtime terribly. âI thought, âThatâs it, I canât do theatre any more.â I think my time in that world might be done for a while. âIn my 20s and 30s I was striving for a career but now happiness is my goal. Happiness and less stress. A toddler helps with that a lot. When you are stopping to look at flowers at every single house along the way to the park and a 10-minute walk takes 40 minutes, thatâs when you realise how much beauty we miss in our busy lives.â Show People plays at Sydney festival on 12 January
headline: âIâm not afraid any moreâ: Christie Whelan Browne on Show People, Twitter trolls and her âhorribleâ four years

chat_gpt_summary: Twitter experienced a global outage, affecting website users primarily, with over 10,000 user reports of problems. Elon Musk responded to users reporting problems by tweeting "works for me" and later announced significant backend server architecture changes. Concerns about regular outages increased after Twitter reduced its workforce, and Musk confirmed he would step down as CEO.
article: Twitter users have reported a massive global outage with many unable to access the website and its features for hours. According to downdetector.com, which tracks site traffic, the website became unavailable shortly before midnight GMT (11am Thursday AEDT, 7pm Wednesday EST), with outages most commonly reported on website rather than the app. Within an hour, the website had recorded more than 10,000 user reports of problems accessing Twitter. The London-based internet monitor NetBlocks said âTwitter is experiencing international outages affecting the mobile app and features including notificationsâ. âThe incident is not related to country-level internet disruptions or filtering.â Many users were still able to use the platform, while others were met with an error message that read âsomething went wrong, but donât fret â itâs not your faultâ. One user in Ireland reported âdifficulties logging into Twitter tonight â¦ Iâm supposed to be asleep but now Iâm watching news stories on the global twitter crashâ. Elon Musk, who bought Twitter for $44bn in October, responded to users reporting problems by tweeting âworks for meâ. Hours later, Musk tweeted that âsignificant backend server architecture changesâ had been made and that âTwitter should feel fasterâ. Concerns about longer and more regular outages increased when Twitter slashed, by some estimates, up to half of its workforce with little notice under Muskâs tenure. About 50 percent of Twitterâs 7,500 staff were sacked in Muskâs first week. In his second week, about four in five of the firmâs 5,500 contractors were released. The mass layoffs reportedly gutted teams that cover human rights, machine learning ethics, curation, communications and accessibility. In July, before the job losses, Twitter experienced one of its longest outages for years, with the social network unavailable to users on web and mobile for almost an hour. Earlier this month, Musk confirmed he would step down as chief executive once a suitable replacement was found, citing the companyâs finances as a reason to delay his promised departure.
headline: Twitter outage: Elon Musk says âworks for meâ as users report problems with website

chat_gpt_summary: Mastodon founder Eugen Rochko has rejected offers from several US-based investors to invest in his open-source social network. The platform has grown in popularity since Elon Musk's $44bn acquisition of Twitter last year. Rochko said Mastodon's status as a non-profit organisation was "untouchable" and its independence was part of its appeal to users. The platform, which has surged from 300,000 to 2.5 million monthly active users after the Twitter deal, was dragged into controversy this month when Musk suspended its Twitter account for sharing a link to his own suspended account.
article: The founder of Mastodon has said he has rejected approaches from more than five US-based investors, as the Twitter rival grows in popularity after Elon Muskâs chaotic debut as a social media owner. Eugen Rochko, who launched the open-source social network in 2016, told the Financial Times he had received the offers from Silicon Valley private equity firms to put âhundreds of thousands of dollarsâ into the product. The popularity of Mastodon has surged since the $44bn acquisition of Twitter by Musk in October. Rochko said last week that Mastodon had jumped from 300,000 monthly active users to 2.5 million after the Twitter deal, which has seen Musk reinstate banned accounts such as Donald Trumpâs and temporarily suspend journalists at publications including the New York Times and Washington Post. Rochko, a German software developer, told the FT his platformâs status as a non-profit organisation was âuntouchableâ and its independence was part of its appeal to users. Mastodon has more than 9,200 patrons on Patreon, the online membership service, who are contributing more than Â£28,000 a month to the platform between them. âMastodon will not turn into everything you hate about Twitter,â he said. âThe fact that it can be sold to a controversial billionaire, the fact that it can be shut down, go bankrupt and so on. Itâs the difference in paradigms [between the platforms].â Mastodon was dragged into Muskâs controversial approach to moderation on Twitter this month, after its own Twitter account was suspended for sharing a link to the Mastodon account of @elonjet, an account that Musk had suspended for showing the location of his private jet. Musk also briefly banned all links to Mastodon and suspended users who tweeted their Mastodon usernames. In a blog post, Rochko wrote: âThis is a stark reminder that centralised platforms can impose arbitrary and unfair limits on what you can and canât say â¦ At Mastodon, we believe that there doesnât have to be a middleman between you and your audience and that journalists and government institutions especially should not have to rely on a private platform to reach the public.â Mastodon is made up of âinstancesâ, or decentralised servers. Two of the most popular instances are run by Rochko, with many smaller ones operated by hobbyists. Once a user has joined an instance, they can communicate with users on others.
headline: Mastodon founder says investors lining up since Elon Muskâs Twitter takeover

chat_gpt_summary: Former Australian Prime Minister Scott Morrison, along with several celebrities, was included in a leaked sample of data on 400 million Twitter users released by an alleged cybercriminal.
