Telsa investors seem to pleased with the way that Muskâs Twitter poll is leaning towards his potential resignation, with shares up 4% in pre-market trading: Economic data interlude: The German Ifo business climate data for December shows confidence among the countryâs firms rose more than expected, despite the energy crisis and high inflation. The index rose from 86.4 in November to 88.6 this month. A Reuters poll of analysts had suggested the reading would be closer to 87.4. A quick update on Muskâs Twitter resignation poll, which has now attracted 15.8 million votes with just two hours left to go: Yes: 57.4% No: 42.6% Victoria Scholar, head of investment at interactive investor, says Muskâs Twitter controversies are compounding other issues for Tesla, which is already grappling with supply shortages and increased competition. Scholar explains: The electric carmaker has been one of the worst performers in US tech this year, down by more than 60% following a meteoric surge for the stock of more than 1600% from the 2020 trough to the peak in 2021. Tesla has had the added pressure this year from Elon Muskâs Twitter acquisition which has distracted the billionaire, taking his attention away from the EV giant. Even prior to the Twitter deal, Musk was already spreading himself very thinly with SpaceX, Neuralink, the Boring Company as well as Tesla. Itâs also worth remembering that Musk used his Tesla shares to help fund his $44bn takeover of Twitter, which has also caused concern among investors. Musk has been using Tesla stock to fund his Twitter deal by selling a total of $22.9bn worth of Tesla stock this year in another sign he is taking his eye off the ball and weighing on investor confidence. Tesla has had a series of headwinds to grapple with from growing competition in the EV space, the global chip shortage, problems with the global supply chain and the shift in investor preferences away from technology. Investors remain cautious towards technology in 2023 and Muskâs Twitter distraction certainly doesnât help. Shares in Tesla, the electric car company that is responsible for making Elon Musk one of the richest men in the world, continue to suffer in after-hours trading. The stock price is down a further 0.77%, adding to further pain for shareholders. Tesla shares having plunged more than 62% so far this year â a fall that is partly linked to the continued controversies related to Muskâs forays into social media ownership. A quick check in on European equity markets, where major indices are trading higher at the start of trading: FTSE 100 is up 0.36% FTSE 250 is up 0.2% Germanyâs Xetra Dax is up 0.68% Franceâs Cac 40 is up 0.7% Italyâs FTSE MIB is up 0.6% Dan Ives, a managing director of equity research at US investment firm Wedbush Securities, says Muskâs willingness to step back may be linked to the fact that controversies linked to Twitter have started to damage his âgolden childâ: Tesla. Ives told BBC Radio 4âs Today programme this morning that while Musk has not necessarily followed through with the decisive calls of Twitter polls in the past, this time is different: The last few weeks, few months, [have] been a black eye for Musk and a black eye for Tesla, and I think ultimately thatâs the golden child: that 90% plus of his wealth. And thatâs why I think the writings on the wall, and I think ultimately in the next 24 hours, Musk will probably name a temporary CEO of Twitter. Ives said itâs clear that Musk needs to stick to his strengths: He can build rockets and create electric cars. Thatâs why he is who he is. But when it comes to social media and to Twitter, I think this is a diff type of animal, and heâs realised he canât balance this as well as Tesla and Space X. And I think the writingâs on the wall that he cannot be CEO of Twitter. And as for how quickly we could see changes enacted, Ives reckons the executive overhaul could be triggered within hours. I think the pressure was building, I think ultimately, probably in the next 5-6 hours, itâs going to be the end of Musk reigning as CEO of Twitter. Full story: Musk sets up Twitter poll asking if he should step down as head Elon Musk has asked Twitter users whether he should step down as the head of the company, promising to abide by the results of his poll. Musk assumed the role of CEO at the end of October after firing a host of senior executives and dissolving its board of directors. Within minutes of posting the poll, more than 1 million people had voted. After 20 minutes of polling, when the yes vote gained a double-digit lead, Musk responded to a suggestion that he had already picked a new CEO, saying: âNo one wants the job who can actually keep Twitter alive. There is no successor.â Good morning, and welcome to our rolling coverage of the economy, business and the financial markets. Less than two months after Elon Musk controversially bought Twitter for $44m and installed himself as CEO of the company, he is putting his fate in the hands of its users. Following a string of controversies over layoffs, new posting policies and temporary journalist bans, the billionaire issued a Twitter poll in the early hours of Monday morning, asking users âShould I step down as head of Twitter? I will abide by the results of this pollâ As of the time of writing, the poll had already attracted more than 14 million votes, with around 57% voting for his resignation. The poll is set to close around 11am GMT, though it is not clear how quickly Musk would step down if the majority of voters call for his ousting. It is also unclear who would replace Musk as chief executive. He said in a separate tweet, Musk said: âNo one wants the job who can actually keep Twitter alive. There is no successor.â Meanwhile, itâs relatively quiet on the economics front in the lead up to the Christmas weekend, with the CBI industrial trends survey for December due later this morning. Stay tuned! The agenda 9am GMT: German IfO business climate index for December 11am GMT: UK CBI industrial trends survey for December
headline: Elon Muskâs Twitter poll says he should step down as chief executive â as it happened

chat_gpt_summary: A Twitter poll posted by Elon Musk on whether he should step down as CEO received over 10 million votes, with 57.5% in favour of his resignation. Musk has stated there is no successor in the wings and nobody wants the job. His recent controversial decisions have caused some of his closest backers to break ties with him. Musk has a history of using Twitter polls to make major decisions, but has also been criticised for giving the impression of already having decided the outcome.
article: More than 10 million people have voted in favour of Elon Musk stepping down as the chief executive of Twitter in a poll he posted on the site late on Sunday. However, the billionaire, who bought the company and installed himself as its head only 50 days ago, has insisted there is no successor in the wings. âNo one wants the job who can actually keep Twitter alive,â he said on the social network. âThere is no successor.â Replying to another user who said they could do the job, Musk added: âYou must like pain a lot. One catch: you have to invest your life savings in Twitter and it has been in the fast lane to bankruptcy since May. Still want the job?â On Sunday, Musk asked Twitter users whether he should step down as the head of the company, promising to abide by the results of his poll. When the poll closed on Monday, 57.5% said he should step down. As the majority owner of the privately held company, no one can force Musk out, but a series of baffling decisions over the past few days has caused even some of his closest backers to break ties with him. A decision to ban an account that tracked the location of his private jet last week was followed by a mass suspension of critical journalists who reported on the ban. That led in turn to an exodus of some engaged users to other social networks, chiefly its decentralised competitor Mastodon, whose own account was banned for posting a link to the jet trackerâs account on the rival platform. On Sunday, Musk reacted by banning all links to other social networks, including Mastodon, Instagram, Facebook, and even minor platforms such as Nostr, used by the Twitter founder Jack Dorsey, and Linktree, a homepage creation tool favoured by influencers. That ban was rescinded by the end of the day, after a Twitter poll from the Twitter Safety account, with Musk saying: âGoing forward, there will be a vote for major policy changes. My apologies. Wonât happen again.â However, the move was the final straw for some. Paul Graham, an Anglo-American venture capitalist who had only a month earlier backed Musk, saying: âItâs remarkable how many people whoâve never run any kind of company think they know how to run a tech company better than someone whoâs run Tesla and SpaceX.â Graham also declared the move âthe last strawâ and told users they could find a link to his Mastodon profile on his personal website. His account was suspended for the post. Musk has a history of using Twitter polls to rubber-stamp major decisions, selling a tenth of his Tesla holdings after one poll in 2021, restoring Donald Trumpâs account after a second last month and reinstating a number of suspended accounts after a third. âVox Populi, Vox Dei,â Musk tweeted after the Trump poll. However, in many cases, he has given the impression of already having decided on the outcome before posting: he had already announced a sale of his Tesla holdings, for instance, long before he put it to a vote, and his plan to reinstate Trump had been discussed since before he even bought Twitter. The decision to step down as chief executive had also been hinted at long before the Twitter poll was published. On 16 November, he told a Delaware judge that he planned to reduce his time at Twitter and âfind somebody else to run Twitter over timeâ. â¢ This article was amended on 19 December 2022. The headline and introduction to an early version suggested Elon Musk had said he was stepping down as head of Twitter after the result of the poll; while he stated when initiating the poll that he would abide by its result, he has not made any announcement since. The articleâs subheading was also amended to correctly refer to Musk as Teslaâs chief executive, not its founder.
headline: Elon Muskâs Twitter poll: 10 million say he should step down

chat_gpt_summary: Elon Musk posted a poll on Twitter asking whether he should step down as CEO of Tesla, promising to follow the results. Within minutes, over a million people voted, with the majority saying he should stay. Musk also commented on Twitter's policy to remove accounts promoting social media competitors, saying it would only apply to accounts whose primary purpose is promotion. He attended a football game in Qatar with Jared Kushner, where Trump's Truth Social, included in the ban, was discussed. The poll ended with 58.7% saying he should U-turn on the ban immediately.
article: Elon Musk has asked Twitter users whether he should step down as the head of the company, promising to abide by the results of his poll. Musk assumed the role of CEO at the end of October after firing a host of senior executives and dissolving its board of directors. Within minutes of posting the poll, more than one million people had voted. After 20 minutes of polling, when the yes vote gained a double-digit lead, Musk responded to a suggestion that he had already picked a new CEO, saying: âNo one wants the job who can actually keep Twitter alive. There is no successor.â He also walked back the siteâs latest policy controversy, after Twitter announced that it would remove accounts that offered âfree promotion of certain social media platformsâ. Musk said the policy would be adjusted to affect only accounts whose âprimary purpose is promotion of competitors, which essentially falls under the no spam ruleâ. The platform earlier said the move would affect content from numerous social media websites, including Meta Platformsâ Facebook and Instagram, Mastodon, Truth Social, Tribel, Nostr and Post, but would allow cross-content posting. However, video platform TikTok, owned by Chinaâs ByteDance, was not included in the list. The announcement came on Sunday â the same day that Musk tweeted photos from the Lusail Stadium in Qatar, where he watched Argentina beat France on penalties to win the menâs football World Cup. Musk attended the game alongside Jared Kushner, a former US presidential adviser and Donald Trumpâs son-in-law. Trumpâs Truth Social was among the platforms named in the Twitter linking ban. On the initial policy change, the Twitter Support account said: âWe recognise that many of our users are active on other social media platforms. However, we will no longer allow free promotion of certain social media platforms on Twitter.â It gave examples of content that would be removed including âfollow me @username on Instagramâ and âcheck out my profile on Facebook â facebook.com/usernameâ. It added: âWe still allow cross-posting content from any social media platform. Posting links or usernames to social media platforms not listed above are also not in violation of this policy.â Former Twitter CEO Jack Dorsey, who recently invested in Nostr, replied to the Twitter support post with one word: âWhy?â In a reply to another user posting about the Nostr promotion ban, Dorsey said it âdoesnât make senseâ. Noam Bardin, the founder of Post, tweeted: âJust wanted to assure everyone that you can post any link you want on http://post.news. âWe make it easy to add all your social media links to your profile since none of us only use one platform. Freedom = Choice.â He added: âIn case I get kicked off this platform â¦ So long and thanks for all the fish â¦â Last week, Twitter disbanded its Trust and Safety Council, a volunteer group formed in 2016 to advise the social media platform on site decisions. The policy change follows other contentious decisions at Twitter since Musk bought the social network in October, including sacking senior management and laying off about half of its workforce. A number of major advertisers left the platform over concerns about its direction. Musk, 51, also suspended the accounts of several journalists after a controversy over publishing public data about the movement of his private jet. He later reinstated the accounts after criticism from government officials, advocacy groups and journalism organisations. The billionaire, who was warned that he could face EU sanctions over his initial decision, asked Twitter users what he should do. Nearly 3.7 million people voted, 58.7% of whom said he should U-turn on the ban immediately, rather than in a weekâs time. âThe people have spoken. Accounts who doxxed my location will have their suspension lifted now,â he tweeted.
headline: Musk sets up Twitter poll asking if he should step down as head

chat_gpt_summary: Veteran musicians discussed the dangers of aging in the music industry following a Twitter rant by Mick Harris, a former member of Napalm Death. Harris attacked "dole scroungers" and "benefit cheats" in a video, leading to a debate among 90s rockers about the best way for aging musicians to tackle their senior years. Geoff Barrow, founder member of Portishead, and Sleaford Mods frontman Jason Williamson warned of the industry's destructive nature. The biggest killer is not facing your own personal issues, Williamson said. Harris has been criticised before for his political views, and many fans have struggled to reconcile their love of music with the star behind the sound.
article: The world of rock is a dangerous place to stay, with veteran musicians either damaged by the lifestyle or growing more out of touch with every passing year. This is the view of some of Britainâs well-known performers, responding to a rightwing Twitter rant from a one-time rock radical. The drummer Mick Harris, an original member of Napalm Death, launched an angry attack last week on âdole scroungersâ and âbenefit cheatsâ in a short video, full of crude language. This led to a lively online debate among 90s rockers about the best way for ageing musicians to tackle their senior years. Geoff Barrow, founder member of Portishead, and Sleaford Mods frontman Jason Williamson warned that the industry can be a destructive environment to work in for any length of time. Barrow said: âI think youâve [got to] realise when youâve had a good run and slide out the fire exit.â While rock rarely has direct links with party politics, many independent artists see a strong connection between their music and a liberal, if not socialist, outlook. Williamson, who has collaborated with Harris in the past, expressed shock at Harrisâ views, saying: âThe biggest killer in the music industry is not the corporates or Spotify, or conformity, or whatever. The biggest killer is not facing your own personal issues. It destroys all you initially gave, until all thatâs left is you in a room on your own with nothing.â Harris, 55, was in at the birth of the âgrindcoreâ sound in the 1980s with Napalm Death, originally famous for its ringtone-length songs and its left-leaning politics. The drummer left the band in 1991 and went on to work with Bill Laswell and release electronic and experimental music as Scorn, and then Lull. This is not the first time Williamson, 52, has had a run-in with Harris on the social media site. In May, Williamson claimed the problems between them began when he refused to work with Harris a second time â and then poked fun at his political transformation by comparing the bald and bearded man to Alf Garnett. Barrow, 51, was drawn into the row when he saw Williamsonâs Twitter posts and the opinionated conversation thread that developed below them, involving several established talents. âI think anyone still doing any music related work in their 50s â¦ are genuinely insane. And I know tons of them,â he wrote. âI donât mean insane in a good or bad way, I mean itâs a tough ride to stay independent and survive as a musician for so many years without taking on a normal nine to five.â Artists âwhoâve been in the business that long can kind of create their own universes and they become twisted when not challenged,â he added. âEspecially successful artist[s]. I know a few who properly have some strange ideas but go unchallenged by the people around them because they are famous.â The cliche of the ageing rock star with reactionary views is older even than the surviving members of the Rolling Stones, but it is still unclear what direction formerly energetic and engaged musicians should take in their later years, whether they are rich or poor. Should they follow Neil Youngâs view that it is âbetter to burn outâ, or John Lennonâs advice to âfade away like an old soldierâ? Lennon once railed against Youngâs lyric from Rust Never Sleeps during an interview a few months before his death in which he imagined âanother 40 years of productivityâ. The problem is that for those who live on, there are so many more opportunities to disappoint. From Morrisseyâs support of a far-right political party and Kanye Westâs antisemitism, to Ian Brownâs Covid vaccination scepticism, plenty of fans have struggled to reconcile their love of music with a distaste for a star behind the sound. Todayâs rock stars also find it harder to âfade awayâ. A 60s songwriter might have retired comfortably on the royalties from a few hits. But now even established performers need to keep up extra jobs. Harris himself works as a music technician, while Barrow writes scores for movies and TV series.
headline: Go out in flames or fade away? Rightwing Twitter rant rekindles dilemma for ageing rockers

chat_gpt_summary: The article describes Elon Musk's struggles with Twitter since he purchased it and became its reluctant owner. His contradictory decisions, maniacal tweeting, and lack of understanding of the social media platform have caused a decline in its value. The article suggests that Musk's dual personality, one of a restless genius and the other of a narcissistic man-child, is responsible for his mismanagement of Twitter. It concludes that for Twitter to succeed, Musk needs to be replaced by someone who knows how to run it properly.
article: Watching whatâs going on at Twitter is like watching a guy losing his mind in slow motion. The guy in question is Elon Musk, who once upon a time was the worldâs richest man and now isnât. (That slot is apparently occupied by Bernard Arnault, the luxury goods mogul.) Musk is in a hole but apparently doesnât know Denis Healeyâs First Law of Holes: when youâre in one, stop digging. The funny thing is that he dug the hole himself. First, he paid way over the odds for Twitter. Then, when Tesla shares (the main source of his wealth) tanked, and Twitterâs share price dropped, he tried to get out of the deal. That failed, so he was forced to borrow a lot of money â incurring interest payments of around a billion dollars a year â thereby becoming the reluctant owner of a loss-making company. And he hasnât the faintest idea of how to make it work. So heâs thrashing around, doing one contradictory thing after another. He started by firing half of the staff, including quite a few key people who knew how hard it is to run a social media platform. He demanded that highly skilled software engineers print out their code on paper so that he could give it the once-over. He rescinded the bans that the company had imposed on legions of rightwing nutters and then discovered that many advertisers, who are the companyâs main source of revenue, pulled out, anxious lest their corporate brands get tainted by proximity to lunacy, hate speech and white supremacist cant. He even rescinded the ban on Donald Trump, only to find that Trump was no longer interested in being on the platform. He took to sleeping on a sofa in Twitterâs San Francisco HQ, babbling about a âcode redâ crisis, the need to âclear the decks of any prior wrongdoing and move forward with a clean slateâ and describing the company as a âcrime sceneâ. To find some evidence for this, he commissioned two journalists to go through stacks of internal records of moderation decisions made long before he owned the company. Reports suggest that the documents merely show staff panicking about the radicalisation of the US right before and after the election and trying to react to events such as the storming of the Capitol building in Washington on 6 January 2021 â in other words, no smoking gun. And all the while, Musk has continued his maniacal tweeting. He tweeted a white rabbit, for example, which the QAnon crowd interpreted as a sign of support. He misread a blog post by the former head of trust and safety at Twitter and insinuated he was a paedophile, prompting others to label the man a âgroomerâ. (This chimed with his 2018 accusation that one of the team that rescued a group of children from a cave in Thailand was a âpedo guyâ.) The other day, he tweeted that âMy pronouns are Prosecute/Fauciâ â a multipurpose and daft insult revealing, among other things, that Musk doesnât actually know how this âpronounsâ business works. One could go on, but you get the point. The guy is flailing around and Twitter has become âThe Musk Experienceâ, as the blogger Helen Lewis puts it. Meanwhile, the worldâs media watch in morbid fascination. How can the worldâs second richest man â the guy who transformed the automobile industry and built rockets that can deliver payloads into orbit and return to land accurately and safely on ocean-going rafts â be making such a mess of reforming a mere social media platform. After all, that doesnât require rocket science, right? For the answer, we need look no further than Robert Louis Stevensonâs The Strange Case of Dr Jekyll and Mr Hyde. Elon Musk is our contemporary gothic horror story. On the one hand, we have Dr Elon, a restless genius who transformed PayPal and used the proceeds to build two world-changing companies. Nobody who has seen him at work in these outfits doubts that he is fully on top of the technology and the business. Watch him on a tour of a SpaceX installation, for example, talking to the engineers who are building the kit and you see a CEO who really knows what he â and they â are doing. Likewise, ask him whatâs special about the electric motors in the Tesla Model 3 or the Model S Plaid and youâre in for an interesting hourâs tutorial. In that sense, Dr Elon is the spiritual heir of Henry Ford, the genius who invented a new way of manufacturing complicated products at scale and, in doing so, changed the world. And then, on the other hand, we have Mr Musk, a narcissistic man-child with a pathetic craving for attention, the attention span of a newt and a maximalist interpretation of what is meant by âfree speechâ. This creature now controls a platform that plays a small but significant role in the global public sphere. Run properly and with a viable business model, Twitter could continue to play a useful role in our lives. But for that to happen, Dr Elon would have to be in charge. And at the moment heâs missing in action. â¢ John Naughton chairs the advisory board of the Minderoo Centre for Technology and Democracy at Cambridge University Do you have an opinion on the issues raised in this article? If you would like to submit a letter of up to 250 words to be considered for publication, email it to us at observer.letters@observer.co.uk
headline: Elon Musk is a Jekyll and Hyde character. And as head of Twitter, Hyde is winning | John Naughton

chat_gpt_summary: Elon Musk lifted the suspension of several journalists' Twitter accounts after a second poll went against his preferred outcome. Musk initially suspended the journalists for allegedly breaching a new rule about revealing people's locations, claiming they had "doxxed" him. However, the articles written by the journalists did not include information about Musk's real-time location or that of his family members. The suspension was widely condemned by media organizations, the EU, and the United Nations. After the poll results, Musk lifted the ban and some users returned to the platform
article: Elon Musk has lifted the suspensions of the Twitter accounts of several journalists he had banned a day earlier, after the second poll he conducted on the topic went against his preferred outcome. On Thursday, Musk suspended a group of tech journalists from the website, including Ryan Mac from the New York Times, Drew Harwell of the Washington Post and CNNâs Donie OâSullivan, for what he said were breaches of the companyâs new rule about revealing peopleâs locations. After an initial poll supported an immediate reversal of the bans on Thursday, Musk said there were too many options, and ran another poll for 24 hours with just two options: to keep the ban in place for seven days, or lift the ban immediately. After close to 3.7m votes, users voted to lift the ban 58.7% to 41.3%. In a tweet shortly after, Musk said he would lift the bans, and several of those users returned to the platform. âThe people have spoken,â Musk tweeted. The new rule bars users from publishing âlive location informationâ that would âreveal a personâs location, regardless if this information is publicly availableâ. Musk claimed the journalists had âdoxxedâ him, but in fact they had recently published articles about Muskâs suspension of a Twitter account that had shared publicly available data about the movements of his private jet. The articles written by several of the reporters before their accounts were suspended did not include information about Muskâs real-time location, or the location of any of his family members. The ElonJet account that was dedicated to tweeting the location of his private jet remained suspended at the time of reporting. The suspension of the accounts of reporters who cover Musk was widely condemned by their employers, other media organisations, the EU and the United Nations. It was a chaotic 24 hours on Twitter even by the standard set by Musk since he took over the platform. In a Twitter Spaces event after the suspensions were announced, Musk briefly entered and was questioned by some of the journalists who had their accounts suspended, but were nevertheless able to participate in the Spaces event. He said journalists were not being treated differently to other citizens. âIf you doxx, you get suspended. Thatâs it. End of story.â After further questioning from the host, BuzzFeed News tech reporter Katie Notopoulos, Musk left the event, and not long after the Space abruptly ended and was then deleted entirely by Twitter. Then Twitter took the entire Spaces product offline for almost a day, with Musk saying a âlegacy bugâ needed to be fixed. After it returned, Notopoulos found she had been banned from Spaces. Twitter also targeted its nearest rival, Mastodon, banning linking to several Mastodon servers and blocking users from adding their Mastodon username to their profile.
headline: Elon Musk reinstates Twitter accounts of suspended journalists

article: Moments after killing two police officers on their property at Wieambilla in Queensland, Gareth and Stacey Train huddled together in the dark and recorded a video. âThey came to kill us and we killed them,â Gareth said. The video was uploaded on Monday night on a now-deleted YouTube account as well as another online conspiracy site. The prime minister is urging media outlets not to publish the video. âThis is a shocking and devastating crime and I would encourage media outlets and others do not publish in any way such material that I have not seen and are not aware of the nature of,â Anthony Albanese said. The video is the latest disturbing revelation as details continue to surface surrounding the ambush, and the lives of the three shooters. Top news Labor lifts ban on citizenship ceremonies | Local councils will be permitted to hold citizenship ceremonies outside of Australia Day. The move lifts a Coalition-era ban prohibiting councils from moving the date of ceremonies. âThe days of citizenship being used as a culture war are over under this government,â Labor minister Chris Bowen said. Covid wave still with us | â¦ but at varying trajectories. Victoria saw its numbers fall from the previous week, with 84 deaths, 675 in hospital and 27,790 new cases reported. New South Wales steadied at 74 deaths, 1,606 in hospital and 40,194 new cases. But numbers are rising in Queensland, with deaths more than doubling in the past week and cases increasing by more than 3,000. The state recorded 33 deaths, 515 in hospital and 16,600 new cases this past week. Michael McCormack falls ill after Pacific drink | The Nationals MP was in Micronesia when he drank kava â a ceremonial drink also known as Sakau. âIn a bid to show my respect to local traditions I drank the whole bowl of Sakau,â he said. That decision landed McCormack in hospital for treatment. He fortunately rode through the hazy phase, later tweeting he was âfeeling much better nowâ. Administrative Appeals Tribunal abolished | The federal government has been applauded for its decision to abolish the tribunal, which attorney general Mark Dreyfus dubbed âa disgraceful exhibition of cronyism by the Liberal partyâ. The body, which was originally designed to provide an independent review of government decisions, was stacked with Liberal MPs and associates â at least 85 over the last nine years. The Greens and the Australia Institute welcomed the decision. Chips shortage | Coles has imposed a limit on sales of frozen chips because of a potato shortage. Farmers are blaming a cold and wet winter for the shortfall, which is likely to persist until January. Coles customers will be temporarily limited to two items. Malaysia landslide kills at least eight | The landslide engulfed a campsite about 50km north of Kuala Lumpur, falling in the early hours of this morning. A child and a woman were found among the dead, with 53 people so far rescued. The campsite is located on an organic farm not far from the Genting Highlands hill resort, a popular tourist destination with theme parks and Malaysiaâs only casino. Deadly Peru protests | The death toll in Peru has climbed to 12 amid ongoing protests sparked by the removal of president Pedro Castillo from power last week. A judge has ordered Castillo to remain in preventive detention for 18 months pending trial on charges of rebellion for his attempt to shutter congress and rule by decree. The countryâs new government declared a 30-day nationwide state of emergency on Wednesday, deploying the army on the streets and suspending the right to gather and move freely. Twitter suspends journalists | Twitter has suspended accounts of several journalists from CNN, Mashable, the Washington Post and the New York Times, all of whom had reported on Elon Musk. It comes a day after the platform banned an account tracking the billionaireâs private jet. Itâs the latest move seemingly contradicting Muskâs claims of being a champion of free speech. Full Story The most pivotal stories of the year â with Lenore Taylor and Mike Ticher A new government, floods, Covid and a cost-of-living crisis â we take a look at the pivotal stories that shaped 2022 in this 23-minute episode. What they said â¦ *** âThat sort of shrill response is just laughable. I understand chief executivesâ desire to maximise their profits. We have a different job. Our job is to act in the national interest â¦ to protect Australian industries, to protect Australians.â â Chris Bowen Bowen was hitting back at complaints from the Santos chief executive that the price caps on coal and gas were âSoviet-style policyâ. In numbers Bernie Sanders was one of 11 senators who voted against the defence bill, tweeting: âAt a time when we spend more than the next 11 nations combined on defence, we should invest in health care, jobs, housing and education â not more weapons of destruction.â Before bed read Didi Conn, the actor who played Frenchy in Grease alongside Olivia Newton-John all those years ago, has remembered her co-star and friend in this touching tribute. âShe would always send me beautiful orchids on my birthday. This year I got very sick and was in the hospital for two months. When I got home I called her and she said: âI heard from so-and-so you were sick. Why didnât you tell me?â The next day, I got beautiful orchids from her. Well, the day before she died, one of those orchid buds fell down, and I just had a feeling that that meant something. Then sure enough I got the call that she had gone.â Sign up If you would like to receive this Afternoon Update to your email inbox every weekday, sign up here. And start your day with a curated breakdown of the key stories you need to know. Sign up for our Morning Mail newsletter here.
headline: Afternoon Update: Queensland shooters uploaded video after killing police; Twitter suspends journalists; and a touching Olivia Newton-John tribute

chat_gpt_summary: Several journalists reporting on Elon Musk and Twitter have been suspended or banned from the platform after Musk accused them of posting his real-time location and "assassination coordinates." Journalists from CNN, the Washington Post, Mashable, and the New York Times were affected, along with Mastodon and individual Mastodon accounts. Musk claimed that doxxing his location and endangering his family was not acceptable, while the suspended journalists argued that their articles did not include such information. Musk later stated that the suspensions would be for only seven days.
article: A number of prominent journalists who have reported on Twitter and its new chief executive, Elon Musk, appear to have been suspended or banned from the platform. In a series of evening tweets, Musk wrote that sharing his real-time location on Twitter was forbidden, and accused journalists who he alleged had been sharing information about his location of posting âassassination coordinatesâ. Accounts of tech journalists at CNN, the Washington Post, Mashable and the New York Times were suspended in quick succession on Thursday evening. All had recently published articles about Muskâs suspension of a Twitter account that had shared publicly available data about the movements of his private jet. Each of these articles had highlighted the tension between Muskâs stated commitment to âfree speechâ and his choice to ban an account that he personally disliked. The Twitter account for rival social media company, Mastodon â which some Twitter users have migrated to after Muskâs takeover of Twitter â also appeared to have been suspended. Links to individual Mastodon accounts also appeared to be banned. An error message notified some users that links to Mastodon had been âidentifiedâ as âpotentially harmfulâ by Twitter or its partners. Ryan Mac, a New York Times tech reporter, wrote on a new Twitter account that he was given âno warningâ before his account was suspended and that he had received no communication from the company about the reason his account was âpermanently suspendedâ. The Washington Post said in a statement that the suspension of their technology reporter, Drew Harwell, âundermines Elon Muskâs claim that he intends to run Twitter as a platform dedicated to free speechâ. CNN said in its statement: âTwitterâs increasing instability and volatility should be of incredible concern to everyone who uses the platform.â âMusk just seems to be stamping out accounts that he doesnât like,â Donie OâSullivan, one of the journalists whose account was abruptly suspended, told CNNâs Anderson Cooper. The Committee to Protect Journalists said that if individualâs bans were confirmed as retaliation for journalistsâ work, it would be a âserious violation of journalistsâ right to report the news without fear of reprisalâ. In a series of late-night tweets on Thursday, Musk said: âCriticizing me all day long is totally fine, but doxxing my real-time location and endangering my family is not.â He added that the âsame doxxing rules apply to âjournalistsâ as to everyone elseâ and wrote: âThey posted my exact real-time location, basically assassination coordinates, in (obvious) direct violation of Twitter terms of service.â Musk did not clarify in what way he believed the reporters who were suspended had shared his âexact real-time locationâ. The news articles about Musk that several reporters had published before their accounts were suspended did not include any information about his real-time location, or the location of any of his family members. The articles were focused on ElonJet, an account that had posted the location of the billionaireâs private jet as it travelled to different cities. In a Twitter spaces event, Musk was questioned about the bans by some of the journalists who had their accounts suspended. Musk said journalists were not being treated differently to other citizens, and âif you doxx, you get suspended. Thatâs it. End of story.â While the journalists had reported that the suspensions were permanent, in multiple tweets Musk said the suspensions would be for only seven days. âSome time away from Twitter is good for the soul â¦â Musk tweeted. He subsequently tweeted a poll asking people whether the ban should be lifted now, tomorrow, in seven days or longer. The poll went in favour of immediately unbanning the users, with 43% of the over half a million votes going with ânowâ. Musk then tweeted that he would redo the poll because there were too many options, narrowing it to now or in seven days. It is similar to the poll launched by Musk that resulted in former US president Donald Trump being unbanned from the platform. At least two of the reporters whose accounts were suspended had reportedly tweeted about a public statement from the Los Angeles police department, responding to an allegation Musk had made about an incident in LA in which he said a stalker had targeted a car, believing it was his. Donie OâSullivan, the CNN reporter whose account was suspended, is one of the countryâs leading reporters on conspiracy theories and disinformation, and had shared a comment from the LAPD about Musk shortly before he was suspended. Matt Binder, the Mashable reporter whose account was suspended, âwas tweeting about OâSullivanâs suspension when his account also went darkâ, the Washington Post reported. Twitter, which recently dissolved the majority of its press department, did not immediately respond to request for comment. But Twitterâs head of trust and safety told the Verge: âWithout commenting on any specific accounts, I can confirm that we will suspend any accounts that violate our privacy policies and put other users at risk.â
headline: Twitter suspends accounts of several journalists who had reported on Elon Musk

chat_gpt_summary: Twitter suspended the account @ElonJet, which tracks Elon Musk's private jet, for violating rules but later restored it. Musk suspended it again, along with other bot accounts run by Florida college student Jack Sweeney, who tracks the planes of various celebrities and Russian oligarchs. Sweeney claimed that Twitter had also shadowbanned his account. Musk had previously asked Sweeney to take down the account for security reasons. The incident highlights concerns about Musk's unilateral control over content decisions on Twitter.
article: Twitter on Wednesday suspended an account that monitors the flight paths of a private jet owned by the social media giantâs new boss, Elon Musk. Later that evening, the account, @ElonJet, confirmed via tweet it was back online after being suspended for âviolat[ing ] Twitter rulesâ. An hour later, Musk again suspended the jet-tracking account after imposing new conditions on all of Twitterâs users that the sharing of anyoneâs current location was not allowed. The account is run by Jack Sweeney, a Florida college student and aviation enthusiast who ran similar âbotâ accounts tracking other celebritiesâ airplanes. For hours after the suspension of the @elonjet account, other Sweeney-run accounts tracking private jets used by Bill Gates, Jeff Bezos, Mark Zuckerberg and various Russian oligarchs were still live on Twitter. But by later on Wednesday, Twitter suspended all of them, including Sweeneyâs personal account. He also operates accounts tracking Muskâs jet on rival social platforms such as Facebook and Instagram. After Russiaâs invasion of Ukraine in February, the account also began tracking the flight paths of various Russian oligarchs. The decision to suspend the account underscored concerns about the new Twitter CEOâs unilateral control over content decisions on the platform. On 7 November, shortly after acquiring Twitter for $44bn, Musk tweeted: âMy commitment to free speech extends even to not banning the account following my plane, even though that is a direct personal safety risk.â But on Wednesday morning, Sweeney tweeted: âWell, it appears @ElonJet is suspended.â He also tweeted a screenshot of a Twitter message that read: âAfter careful review, we determined your account broke the Twitter Rules. Your account is permanently in read-only mode, which means you canât Tweet, Retweet, or Like content. You wonât be able to create new accounts.â Twitter, which under Musk has dissolved much of its media department, did not respond to a request for comment. Over the weekend, Sweeney tweeted that his account had been shadowbanned, meaning that its visibility had been deliberately reduced. âInternal messages obtained by a[n] anonymous Twitter employee explained to me that on â2 Dec[ember] 2022 your account @elonjet was visibility limited/restricted to a severe degree internally,ââ Sweeney wrote. He then included a screenshot that allegedly showed Ella Irwin, vice-president of Twitterâs trust and safety council, asking her team to apply âheavy VF [visibility filtering] to @elonjet immediatelyâ. The trust and safety council was dissolved on Monday. The same day, Sweeney tweeted that it appeared @ElonJet was no longer banned or hidden. On Wednesday, Sweeney did not immediately respond to a request for comment. When Musk discovered the @ElonJet account, earlier this year, he asked Sweeney to delete it. âCan you take this down? It is a security risk,â he wrote to Sweeney, adding: âI donât love the idea of being shot by a nutcase.â In February, Sweeney told the Guardian: âAnd then he offers me $5,000 to make it harder for people to track him and to take down the account, and I make my counter-offer.â Sweeney replied: âAny chance to up that to $50K? It would be great support in college and would possibly allow me to get a car, maybe even a [Tesla] Model 3.â Musk, the owner of Tesla, which makes electric cars, declined to pay up. He eventually blocked Sweeney on Twitter.
headline: Twitter suspends account monitoring Elon Muskâs flight paths

chat_gpt_summary:
Twitter is auctioning off surplus office assets, including a 3ft-tall statue of its bird logo and a 6ft-tall planter in the shape of the @ symbol. The sale comes amid Elon Musk's takeover and job cuts, but the auctioneer says it is not related to Twitter's financial position. Other items include a high-performance task chair, kegerators, a rotisserie oven with 24 spits, and an old iMac with a Twitter sticker over the Apple logo. The sale symbolizes a shift in the tech industry from the lavish days of the early 2000s to a more uncertain era.


Twitter is auctioning off surplus office assets, including a 3ft-tall statue of its bird logo and a 6ft-tall planter in the shape of the @ symbol. The sale comes amid Elon Musk's takeover and job cuts, but the auctioneer says it is not related to Twitter's financial position. Other items include a high-performance task chair, kegerators, a rotisserie oven with 24 spits, and an old iMac with a Twitter sticker over the Apple logo. The sale symbolizes a shift in the tech industry from the lavish days of the early 2000s to a more uncertain era.
article: Great news, holiday shoppers: you can finally get your hands on a 100% authentic, 3ft-tall statue of the Twitter bird. An online auction next month will feature hundreds of the companyâs âsurplus corporate office assetsâ that could add a certain je ne sais quoi to any home or workplace, from bizarre decor to high-end cooking equipment. The sale comes amid Elon Muskâs chaotic $44bn takeover of the company, which has brought rapid-fire policy changes (and immediate U-turns), the reinstatement of banned accounts, and, according to Musk himself, a huge dip in advertising revenue. Itâs also involved shedding thousands of jobs â and now, apparently, shedding office furniture. A representative for the auctioneers, Heritage Global Partners, told Fortune that the auction âhas nothing to do with their financial positionâ, adding: âIf anyone genuinely thinks that the revenue from selling a couple computers and chairs will pay for the mountain there, then theyâre a moron.â Regardless of the reason, itâs hard not to see the auction as symbolic of a tech industry shift: from the heady days of the early 2000s, when endlessly wealthy platforms catered to workersâ every whim, to a more uncertain modern era. Somehow, that industrial cheese slicer just doesnât feel as necessary as it once did. Hereâs a guide to the saleâs most memorable items, in case youâre still looking for that perfect gift: A 6ft-tall planter in the shape of the @ symbol. Sure to be a hit with the tech-obsessed gardener in your life, this piece marries the ancient art of horticulture with a ubiquitous symbol of decaying public discourse. Expect heads to turn when you install this in front of your home, announcing to passersby that you have no soul. A âhigh-performance task chairâ. Nothing says high-performance like sitting down. Turn workaday programming into X-treme coding with this seat, which uses the latest in sedentary technology to shield your thighs and buttocks from direct contact with the floor. Itâs surprising Musk is willing to part with this at a time when his priorities are âextremely hardcoreâ. Kegerators. A house isnât a home without a fridge that dispenses beer. And a workplace isnât a workplace if you canât drink on the job. Imagine channeling your fluids through the same tubes that might once have lubricated the likes of the Twitter co-founders Jack Dorsey and Christopher Isaac âBizâ Stone. A rotisserie oven with 24 spits. Who could forget those late nights at the office, rustling up a snack of 24 whole chickens while sifting through hate speech? Pairs perfectly with a 20-gallon vegetable dryer. An old iMac. This computer might be out of date, but in a courageous act of corporate one-upmanship, someone stuck a Twitter sticker over the Apple logo. So thatâs pretty cool. And just think â this computer might have been the one used to ban Donald Trump! Thatâs the best of whatâs on offer for now, but stay tuned â the next Twitter-auction drop might feature everything you need for a âmodest bedroomâ.
headline: Twitter office oddities go up for auction â from bird statues to rotisserie ovens

chat_gpt_summary: Elon Musk has been promoting "The Twitter Files," a series of Twitter threads from friendly journalists using material provided by the company to re-litigate the company's role in the culture wars of years past. The leaked documents focus on two high-stakes individual moderation decisions, one widely regarded as an error in hindsight and the other as divisive as anyone would have guessed beforehand. The excerpts of internal emails and chat messages show staff tackling the enormous burden that has been placed on them with a rough mixture of panic and resolve.
article: The threat model of a social network is complex. Your security team has to deal with conventional hacking attacks, as hostile actors probe for technical errors in your apps and servers that they can use to extract valuable private data, inject malicious code, or simply wreak havoc for fun. They also have to deal with people using the siteâs own capabilities in destructive ways, from simple-minded spam bots through to nation states carrying out âcoordinated inauthentic behaviourâ. They have to protect users from account takeovers due to password theft, and they have to do it all while navigating the minefield that is content moderation. And then the site gets bought on a whim by a capricious billionaire and the threat comes from inside the house. What are the Twitter Files? Elon Musk has been pushing âthe Twitter Filesâ, a series of Twitter threads from friendly journalists using material provided by the company to re-litigate the companyâs role in the culture wars of years past. Typically, big news stories claiming to be the [something] âfilesâ are based on enormous leaks, providing a hitherto impossible look at the inner workings of the organisation under the microscope. It is less typical for an enormous leak to have been ordered by the chief executive of the company, and executed by their subordinates openly working with the journalists reporting on the story. But little about Elon Muskâs Twitter is typical. What of the files themselves? A week and a half in, there have been four releases, from three writers: Matt Taibbi, Bari Weiss and Michael Shellenberger, all broadly part of a wave of âpost-liberalâ Substack newsletter writers. Itâs unclear how they were selected to receive the documents. One requirement, however, was that everything they published be shared on Twitter itself, Taibbi has said, but beyond that âweâve been encouraged to look not just at historical Twitter, but the current iteration as well. I was told flat-out I could write anything I wanted, including anything about the current company and its new chief, Elon Musk.â At the same time, the reporting was done inside Twitterâs offices, with the assistance of Twitter staff. And all three have focused on the areas that one might guess, given their previous statements about the social network. Taibbiâs first thread covered Twitterâs efforts to respond to the New York Postâs story about Hunter Bidenâs laptop; his second thread, as well as Shellenbergerâs, looked at the events around the suspension of Donald Trump and the January 6 attack on the US Capitol. Weiss, meanwhile, reported on what she described as âTwitterâs secret blacklistsâ.â Freedom of speech v âfreedom of reachâ The bulk of the material so far, then, has been focused on what are effectively two extremely high-stakes individual moderation decisions, one widely regarded as an error in hindsight (hiding stories about Bidenâs laptop), and the other exactly as divisive as anyone would have guessed beforehand (Trumpâs ban). The documents shared by Taibbi and Shellenberger largely support that reading. Shorn of the conspiratorial framing of the two writers, the excerpts of internal emails and chat messages that they have posted appear to show staff tackling the enormous burden that has been placed on them with a rough mixture of panic and resolve. In the days following the publication of the Postâs story on Hunter Biden, that wasnât enough. The executives quoted by Taibbi are clearly aware of the prospect of a repeat of 2016âs WikiLeaks dump of hacked Democratic Party documents, and move quickly to discuss enforcing a policy against sharing hacked materials. But the materials werenât hacked, and while the chain of custody of Bidenâs laptop remains murky, it rapidly became clear that the policy was wrongly applied. Twitterâs most senior staff were too slow removing the ban as that became clear, and, in Taibbiâs words, âerred on the side of â¦ continuing to errâ. Just two months later, the same group was convened to discuss Donald Trump. The president had used social media to egg on a protest in Washington DC that turned violent as his supporters decided to storm the US Capitol building. In the days since the election, Twitter had been aggressively applying its ânewsworthinessâ policy, slapping a label on posts that would be deleted were it not for the prominence of their author, but by 7 January, it was clear that was unsatisfactory in the case of Trump. A series of Slack posts shared by Shellenberger show the team, led by former trust and safety head Yoel Roth, desperately trying to invent policy on the fly (all staff except Roth are anonymised in the posts Shellenberger shared). Trump had been given special treatment, left on the site for months after a typical user would have seen his account deleted: at what point does that approach cease to be viable? The answer was clearly January 6. But if you give someone special treatment without admitting as such, it just makes it all the more difficult to take it away. Weissâs part of the saga is different. Rather than focusing on the narrow world of US electoral politics, her thread takes a more systemic look at Twitterâs moderation practices. Working with Ella Irwin, a trust and safety staffer at Twitter, Weiss published screenshots of the moderation pages for some of the siteâs most notorious users. Jay Bhattacharya, a Covid sceptic, was placed on a âtrends blacklistâ; Dan Bongino, a rightwing media personality, on a âsearch blacklistâ; Charlie Kirk, whose decision to attend a protest wearing a diaper caused such secondhand embarrassment it effectively destroyed the Republican youth movement he founded, was set to âdo not amplifyâ. The tags are various examples of what Twitter calls âvisibility filteringâ, a form of moderation that is intended to impact âfreedom of reachâ without affecting âfreedom of speechâ. Users who are filtered can post what they like, but their involvement in the algorithmic amplification of the site is limited. Some wonât show up in search results or trends; others wonât be recommended to users to follow. The most aggressive form of visibility filtering, which didnât affect any of the prominent accounts Weiss highlighted, means that new posts wonât even show up for followers, and are only visible to people who navigate directly to the posterâs profile. Not every user Weiss examined was hurt by the moderation. One, LibsofTikTok, was given special treatment, warning moderators to do nothing to it without consulting the siteâs senior team. Despite that, it had still received two strikes for abuse, and been placed on the trends blacklist. What did we learn? I think itâs important to distinguish between the Twitter files, and the âTwitter Filesâ. The latter, a big, hyped, coordinated publication, has so far failed to achieve its apparent goals. The throughline of the whole exercise is that Twitter is a hotbed of leftwing bias, explicitly aligned with the US Democratic party, and taking unwarranted action to censor speech for politically motivated purposes. The posts themselves show little of the sort. Some, like Weissâs, donât even attempt to: individual examples of rightwing users being on the end of light-touch moderation says little about overall bias. Were leftwing users also given visibility filters? Weiss doesnât say. Were rightwing users given filters more? Weiss doesnât say. Others show almost the opposite. There were plenty of easy reasons to remove Donald Trump from the social network in January 2021, but the posts seem to reveal Twitter staff methodically working through their actual rulebook, trying to understand how to react to unprecedented events in a way that doesnât simply throw precedent out the window. Like so much to do with American politics, the Files fall flat if you view the American right as an outlier. If you have rules against election misinformation and only one party engages in a systematic campaign of election misinformation, itâs not an unreasonable outcome for one party to be the focus of moderation efforts. But the lowercase files, the documents themselves, are an interesting historical artefact nonetheless. They show that, at periods of global crisis, the people making the decisions inside Twitter were acutely aware of, and uncomfortable with, the power they held. Even as a set of cherrypicked examples, they show that efforts to create and apply a consistent rulebook were driven as much by a desire to avoid criticism as a belief that doing so was important for protecting users. They give us an insight into the sorts of discussions that were likely happening at Facebook and YouTube at the same time. And they show us never to trust Elon Musk. Insider threat Musk has been promoting the series as an exercise in âtransparencyâ, and, if youâre Weiss, Taibbi or Shellenberger, thatâs what it is. But itâs the sort of transparency that companies get when their database is hacked and sold on the darknet. In this case, the database cost $44bn, and came with control of the site to boot. Marcus Hutchins, the ethical hacker who stopped the WannaCry ransomware infection, posted on Mastodon about the docs. âAs a security professional, not much scares me,â he said. âIâve seen my personal data stolen numerous times, watched nationstate hackers spray zerodays across the internet, and Iâm a shameless user of TikTok. âBut now you have someone sitting on top of the personal data of several billion users, someone who has a long track record of vindictive harassment, someone who has the ear of the far right, and someone who has just shown us his willingness to weaponise internal company data to score political points. That scares me a lot.â The Shellenberger posts named only one person: Twitterâs former head of trust and safety Yael Roth. When Musk bought the company, Roth was initially welcoming: one of the few staffers who was prepared to advocate for his boss publicly, and a much-needed source of internal expertise after the immediate sacking of Vijaya Gadde, the longtime head of Twitterâs platform safety efforts. But the relationship clearly soured. On 10 November, Roth quit, resurfacing a week later to write a New York Times post arguing that âeven as he criticizes the capriciousness of platform policies, [Musk] perpetuates the same lack of legitimacy through his impulsive changes and tweet-length pronouncements about Twitterâs rules.â In doing so, he seems to have become a bete noire for his brief boss, and so for the wider rightwing media ecosystem that Musk now conducts. The day before Shellenberger shared his part of the Twitter Files, Musk posted an out-of-context excerpt of Rothâs decades-old PhD thesis, which looked at whether services like Grindr were causing harm by forcing teenagers to pretend to be adults in order to access dating sites. To an audience of hundreds of millions, Musk accused Roth of being âin favour of children being able to access adult internet servicesâ, and indirectly accused him of personally deciding to make Twitter a safe space for paedophiles. The accusation is nonsense, but the charge, in an atmosphere of rightwing panic over âgroomersâ in the media, is life-changing. On Monday, Roth and his partner were forced to flee their home after a sharp increase in credible threats against him. For insufficient loyalty, he will have to spend the rest of his life checking over his shoulder. What will happen to the next person who annoys Elon? If you want to read the complete version of the newsletter please subscribe to receive TechScape in your inbox every Tuesday
headline: TechScape: I read Elon Muskâs âTwitter Filesâ so you donât have to

chat_gpt_summary: Market research agency Insider Intelligence predicts that over 30 million users will leave Twitter in the next two years due to concerns over technical issues and offensive content, following Elon Musk's $44bn takeover. Insider Intelligence also cut its forecast for Twitter's ad revenue growth and anticipates the platform losing users in the US and UK, with the biggest concentration of departures from under-25s and over-45s. Musk's focus will be on kickstarting Twitter's revenue engine after losing advertisers. Twitter has dissolved its trust and safety council, an advisory group of nearly 100 independent organizations.
article: More than 30 million users are expected to leave Twitter over the next two years as concerns mount over technical issues and the proliferation of offensive content after Elon Muskâs $44bn takeover, according to a forecast. The number of global monthly users is predicted to fall by nearly 4% next year and 5% in 2024 â more than 32 million in total â in the first annual declines forecast by the market research agency Insider Intelligence since it began tracking the social media platform in 2008. âThere wonât be one catastrophic event that ends Twitter,â a principal analyst at Insider Intelligence, Jasmine Enberg, said. âInstead, users will start to leave the platform next year as they grow frustrated with technical issues and the proliferation of hateful or other unsavoury content. âTwitterâs skeleton staff, working around the clock, wonât be able to counteract the platformâs infrastructure and content moderation problems.â Its report anticipates that Twitter will lose more users in the US, its biggest market, than any other country, with numbers declining 8.2 million over the next two years. By the end of 2024, US user numbers are forecast to fall to 50.5 million, the lowest level since 2014, as the Twitter becomes âmore unstable, and less pleasantâ. In the UK, Twitter will lose about 1.6 million users over the next two years, to a base of 12.6 million, Insider Intelligence said. It predicts that while disillusioned users leaving the platform will occur across all age demographics, the biggest concentration of departers will come from the under-25 and over-45 age groups, which âarenât as loyal and are less willing to tolerate a degrading experienceâ. Insider Intelligence has also slashed its forecast for ad revenue growth for Twitter from 22% in 2023 and 16% in 2024 to âessentially flatâ, as advertisers pull back, pause or stop advertising over growing brand safety concerns on the platform. In November, the research company cut its outlook for Twitterâs ad revenue growth by 40% this year. âMuskâs primary focus in 2023 will be kickstarting Twitterâs revenue engine, after losing many of its biggest advertisers and a long tail of other advertisers who have been quietly quitting the platform,â it said. On Monday, Twitter abruptly dissolved its trust and safety council, an advisory group of nearly 100 independent civil, human rights and other organisations that the company formed in 2016 to address hate speech, child exploitation, suicide, self-harm and other problems on the platform, moments before a meeting scheduled with the company. The unpopularity of the takeover by Musk, who has fired thousands of employees and told those remaining they had to work long hours at high intensity, was summed up when the worldâs richest man received a 10-minute chorus of booing from a crowd of 18,000 when he joined the comedian Dave Chappelle on stage in San Francisco on Sunday night.
headline: Twitter âto lose 32m users in two years after Elon Musk takeoverâ

chat_gpt_summary: Twitter dissolved its Trust and Safety Council, an advisory group of nearly 100 independent civil, human rights, and other organizations formed in 2016 to address problems on the platform. This move comes amid escalating personal attacks, including from Elon Musk, on Twitter's former top safety official, Yoel Roth. Musk's recent condemnation of Anthony Fauci also drew rebuke. Jean-Pierre, the White House press secretary, called Musk's comment "dangerous" and "disgusting."
article: Elon Muskâs Twitter abruptly dissolved its Trust and Safety Council on Monday night, just moments before it was scheduled to meet with company representatives. The council was an advisory group of nearly 100 independent civil, human rights and other organizations that the company formed in 2016 to address hate speech, child exploitation, suicide, self-harm and other problems on the platform. But Twitter informed the group via email that it was disbanding shortly before the meeting was to take place on Monday, according to multiple members. The council members, who provided to the Associated Press and other outlets images of the email from Twitter, spoke on the condition of anonymity due to fears of retaliation. âOur work to make Twitter a safe, informative place will be moving faster and more aggressively than ever before and we will continue to welcome your ideas going forward about how to achieve this goal,â said the email, which was signed âTwitter.â The news appeared to deepen the turmoil that has beset the company following Muskâs takeover. Also on Monday, it was reported that Twitterâs former top safety official, Yoel Roth, was forced to flee his home amid escalating personal attacks, including from Musk himself. Outlets including the Washington Post and CNN reported on Monday that Roth and his family fled after Muskâs tweets misrepresented Rothâs academic writing about sexual activity and children. As head of trust and safety at Twitter, Roth was involved in many of the platformâs decisions about what posts to remove and what accounts to suspend. His communications with other Twitter officials have been posted in recent days as part of what Musk has dubbed âthe Twitter files,â a series of internal documents that Musk has shared and disseminated on the platform via journalists including Matt Taibbi and Bari Weiss. Muskâs tweets to his tens of millions of followers have for years prompted his supporters to deluge the targets of his ire with online threats â famously, a participant in the rescue of a boys soccer team trapped in a cave in Thailand who Musk branded âpedo guy.â But now that Musk owns one of the most powerful social networks in the world and has gutted the division that previously policed online harassment, the stakes are even higher. Muskâs recent condemnation of Anthony Fauci, the top US health official, has also drawn rebuke. Musk over the weekend tweeted: âMy pronouns are Prosecute/Fauci.â Karine Jean-Pierre, the White House press secretary, called Musksâ comment âdangerousâ and âdisgustingâ in a press briefing on Monday. âThey are disgusting, and they are divorced from reality, and we will continue to call that out and be very clear about that,â Jean-Pierre said on Monday. She praised Fauciâs handling of public heath crises, including the coronavirus pandemic. Fauci, who said he planned to retire in December as Joe Bidenâs top medical adviser, has dealt with the thorny questions around health crises from HIV/AIDS to avian flu and Ebola, and has served as an adviser to seven presidents. Fauci has said he has faced death threats. He has endured criticism from Trump and various conservatives who objected to safeguards such as vaccination, social distancing and masking that he advocated to try to limit the lethality of the Covid-19 pandemic.
headline: Twitter abruptly dissolves safety council moments before meeting

chat_gpt_summary: Twitter is relaunching its subscription service, @TwitterBlue, on Monday. Users can pay $8 or $11 a month to gain access to exclusive features, including the blue verification tick. Subscribers will have more prominence on the platform than non-payers, with a promised boost to their replies, mentions, and search ranking. Twitter says the feature will help combat spam and scams, and plans to introduce a color-coded verification scheme. Other features include the ability to edit tweets, shorter adverts, and longer tweets. Apple users will be charged more, and Elon Musk is critical of Apple's fees.
article: Twitter is relaunching its subscription service on Monday, offering users verified status for $8 (Â£6.50) a month or $11 a month on their iPhone. The move follows a botched revamp of the service last month that resulted in a host of impersonator accounts appearing on the platform as some users took advantage of the chance to launch bogus âverifiedâ accounts for major companies and public figures. Twitter said: âWeâre relaunching @TwitterBlue on Monday â subscribe on web for $8/month or on iOS for $11/month to get access to subscriber-only features, including the blue checkmark.â It added that users willing to pay $8 on the web or $11 a month via Appleâs app store would get more prominence on the platform than non-payers, promising that subscribers would ârocket to the top of replies, mentions and searchâ. Twitter said this feature would be coming soon. According to Twitterâs website, the blue tick service is âcurrently available on iOS only in the US, Canada, Australia, New Zealand, and the UK, with plans to expandâ. Twitter said giving priority to subscribers would help combat âscams and spamâ, referring to one of the bugbears of the platformâs owner, Elon Musk, who attempted to walk away from a deal to buy the business because of his concerns over vexatious automated accounts. Subscribers who attempt to change their handle, display name or photo will temporarily lose their tick until the account is reviewed again, Twitter said. Other features offered to subscribers include the ability to edit tweets. According to a trial launched by the company in September, shortly before Musk bought Twitter, users will be able to edit a tweet up to 30 minutes after it is published â with a symbol showing it has been modified. Other planned new features include offering half the number of adverts and the ability to post longer tweets. The company also confirmed that it would introduce a colour-coded verification scheme, with businesses receiving a gold tick or checkmark and government accounts receiving a grey symbol. Twitter did not explain why Apple users were being charged more than others on the web but Musk has been openly critical of the fees charged in its app store, which takes a cut of up to 30% on sales. In a series of tweets last month, he accused Apple of threatening to block Twitter from its app store for unspecified reasons and also said the iPhone maker had stopped advertising on the social media platform. However, after a subsequent meeting with Apple chief executive, Tim Cook, he tweeted that the misunderstanding about Twitter being removed from Appleâs app store had been resolved. Musk has made clear that he wants Twitter to be less dependent on advertising, which accounted for 90% of its $5.1bn in revenues last year. That need has become more urgent after the Tesla chief executive reported a âmassive drop in revenueâ when advertisers withdrew from the platform amid concerns about content moderation, with the outbreak of âverifiedâ impostor accounts exacerbating those concerns.
headline: Twitter relaunches blue tick service with higher price for iPhone users
